description: Those looking to complete the Lean Six Sigma Yellow Belt certification will find in this course an overview of the process in achieving the certification and details about the exam required to pass in order to receive the certification. The certification is not just for IT professionals, but can be used in any industry and is best suited for those who want to increase their critical thinking skills. Viewers will hear an overview of what Lean Six Sigma (LSS) is, why it is important, how it applies to IT professionals, how it interfaces with other process improvement methodologies, and etc. Learn more about Dr. Terra Stern and Lean Six Sigma by visiting her site www.SSDGlobal.net.
name: Lean Six Sigma - Yellow Belt
subtitle: Yellow Belt

episodes.description: The Lean Six Sigma Yellow Belt certification is a method of process improvement to make an already established environment or process better, faster and more cost effective. Viewers will hear an overview about the knowledge one needs to attain the Lean Six Sigma Yellow Belt certification, how it applies to IT professionals, and brief details about the exam.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.364
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.364 --> 00:00:10.178
In this video we're gonna take a look
at the Lean Six Sigma Yellow Belt

3
00:00:10.178 --> 00:00:14.911
certification, and more importantly,
we're gonna look at how it

4
00:00:14.911 --> 00:00:20.058
applies to IT professionals in the IT
world, because a lot of you guys have

5
00:00:20.058 --> 00:00:24.956
probably heard of six sigma or
heard of lean or heard of Lean Six sigma,

6
00:00:24.956 --> 00:00:29.640
but heard of it in production floor or
factory type environments.

7
00:00:29.640 --> 00:00:32.702
And applying it in IT is actually a very
beneficial thing that a lot of people just

8
00:00:32.702 --> 00:00:35.030
either haven't thought of or
haven't heard of.

9
00:00:35.030 --> 00:00:37.922
So we're gonna take a look at that and
kind of set you up for

10
00:00:37.922 --> 00:00:41.500
what our video series is about to be
that covers well, Lean Six Sigma.

11
00:00:41.500 --> 00:00:44.210
Dr. Stern, if you could help me,

12
00:00:44.210 --> 00:00:49.641
let's start off with kind of
an overview for people who don't know.

13
00:00:49.641 --> 00:00:50.560
What is Lean Six Sigma?

14
00:00:50.560 --> 00:00:54.287
>> Lean Six Sigma takes two methodologies,
lean thinking and Six Sigma, and

15
00:00:54.287 --> 00:00:57.850
it blends them together to help
enhance our critical thinking skills.

16
00:00:57.850 --> 00:01:02.505
And it is comprised of a methodology and
a tool set that can actually partner with

17
00:01:02.505 --> 00:01:05.020
just about anything you
can think of in IT.

18
00:01:05.020 --> 00:01:09.651
>> Now, one of the things I
like about Lean Six Sigma is

19
00:01:09.651 --> 00:01:14.720
it takes a lot of stuff that
really would be difficult.

20
00:01:14.720 --> 00:01:17.410
Six Sigma really focuses in
on statistics quite a bit.

21
00:01:17.410 --> 00:01:21.112
A lot of math and
Lean Six Sigma makes it a lot more simple,

22
00:01:21.112 --> 00:01:23.590
a lot more easy and approachable.

23
00:01:23.590 --> 00:01:29.449
So I think it's a great way to implement
process improvement in your environment,

24
00:01:29.449 --> 00:01:33.564
and kind of tears down a lot of
the barriers of entry for it.

25
00:01:33.564 --> 00:01:36.910
Now if somebody is going to be working
towards this, who would that somebody be.

26
00:01:36.910 --> 00:01:41.135
What kind of person, what kind of IT
worker would be interested in pursuing

27
00:01:41.135 --> 00:01:42.956
the Lean Six Sigma yellow belt?

28
00:01:42.956 --> 00:01:47.656
>> Well that's kind of an interesting
question because the yellow

29
00:01:47.656 --> 00:01:52.660
belt actually benefits everyone,
not just the IT professional.

30
00:01:52.660 --> 00:01:57.460
But the way it works with IT is that
no matter what level of IT you're at,

31
00:01:57.460 --> 00:02:02.580
the tools that help you reason through
problem solving just make it easier.

32
00:02:02.580 --> 00:02:08.000
And they partner, like I said, very well,
with already existing IT methodologies.

33
00:02:08.000 --> 00:02:08.960
For example, it works well with Agile.

34
00:02:08.960 --> 00:02:15.380
It works well with ITIL, or ITIL,
which is what we say a lot here.

35
00:02:15.380 --> 00:02:19.923
It works even with CMN,
the capability maturity and so

36
00:02:19.923 --> 00:02:25.851
even just getting familiar with
the basic terms and the terminology and

37
00:02:25.851 --> 00:02:30.320
the methodology is the benefit
to the IT profession.

38
00:02:30.320 --> 00:02:31.155
>> All right now,

39
00:02:31.155 --> 00:02:35.332
our series that we're about to film here
we're gonna cover a lot of different

40
00:02:35.332 --> 00:02:39.440
concepts that serves as an introduction
for people to get their feet wet.

41
00:02:39.440 --> 00:02:41.904
Do we need to have a lot of
experience before we jump into this?

42
00:02:41.904 --> 00:02:43.640
Or you said it, it helps everybody.

43
00:02:43.640 --> 00:02:44.360
>> It does help everyone and

44
00:02:44.360 --> 00:02:47.196
I think one of the things that
>> people are excited about is that once

45
00:02:47.196 --> 00:02:51.601
they get involved in the program there's
a lot about Lean Six Sigma that everyone

46
00:02:51.601 --> 00:02:52.530
already knows.

47
00:02:52.530 --> 00:02:56.100
They just didn't realize
there was a term for it.

48
00:02:56.100 --> 00:02:59.900
Or they didn't realize that wasn't
something you just did in your head.

49
00:02:59.900 --> 00:03:02.842
And when you're trying to explain
how you think through things,

50
00:03:02.842 --> 00:03:05.152
having these models are just
really very helpful.

51
00:03:05.152 --> 00:03:09.184
So to answer that question Don, you can
start from zero and in just a couple of

52
00:03:09.184 --> 00:03:12.780
days, you can go out and use
Lean Six Sigma tools to your advantage.

53
00:03:14.280 --> 00:03:19.081
>> You know we had a funny conversation
before filming this where, Dr.

54
00:03:19.081 --> 00:03:22.490
Sternon asked me how much
I knew about Six Sigma.

55
00:03:22.490 --> 00:03:25.620
And I said,
I've worked in a lot of environments.

56
00:03:25.620 --> 00:03:26.863
I'm a pmp certified project manager, so

57
00:03:26.863 --> 00:03:28.290
I worked in a project
management environment.

58
00:03:28.290 --> 00:03:32.254
I said I haven't really used
a lot of tools and production.

59
00:03:32.254 --> 00:03:35.120
I've read the books, but
I haven't actually implemented any.

60
00:03:35.120 --> 00:03:37.270
And she said actually you have.

61
00:03:37.270 --> 00:03:41.080
A lot of this stuff snaps right together
with the systems we already have in place.

62
00:03:41.080 --> 00:03:43.730
And it's pretty neat to see that.

63
00:03:43.730 --> 00:03:45.210
You'll see that as we watch this series.

64
00:03:45.210 --> 00:03:48.600
You'll notice this kind
of snapping together.

65
00:03:48.600 --> 00:03:52.264
And one of the things that Lean Six sigma
is built around is the idea of process

66
00:03:52.264 --> 00:03:55.587
improvement and the disconnect that I had,
the reason that I didn't

67
00:03:55.587 --> 00:03:59.387
see that connection was I was always
thinking of it in terms of manufacturing.

68
00:03:59.387 --> 00:04:03.546
If I make 100 vehicles, like a car,
how many defects do we have and

69
00:04:03.546 --> 00:04:05.570
how can we reduce those defects?

70
00:04:05.570 --> 00:04:10.771
But if you apply it to IT, it can be
something like help desk support tickets.

71
00:04:10.771 --> 00:04:14.170
What's your average close time for
a help desk support ticket?

72
00:04:14.170 --> 00:04:15.560
Six hours, all right.

73
00:04:15.560 --> 00:04:18.040
Well, what if we could get
that down to five hours.

74
00:04:18.040 --> 00:04:19.330
That's process improvement,
if we can make that better.

75
00:04:19.330 --> 00:04:23.450
How long does it take to deploy
a new server in the environment?

76
00:04:23.450 --> 00:04:24.330
Three days.

77
00:04:24.330 --> 00:04:25.900
Could we get that down to two days?

78
00:04:25.900 --> 00:04:27.210
That's process improvement.

79
00:04:27.210 --> 00:04:31.842
So its not necessarily manufacturing,
we can use these technologies in IT, and

80
00:04:31.842 --> 00:04:35.857
I know you're a proponent of this,
we can use it not just in our work but

81
00:04:35.857 --> 00:04:37.240
in our personal lives.

82
00:04:37.240 --> 00:04:38.371
It's really diverse.

83
00:04:38.371 --> 00:04:39.070
>> Oh, absolutely.

84
00:04:39.070 --> 00:04:44.180
Many of the Lean Six sigma tools can be
used as meeting management tools as well.

85
00:04:44.180 --> 00:04:48.546
I think the key thing for IT
professionals to remember is that process

86
00:04:48.546 --> 00:04:52.987
improvement is designed to look at
an activity you already in place and

87
00:04:52.987 --> 00:04:57.450
how can we make that activity better,

88
00:04:57.450 --> 00:05:01.064
Lean Six Sigma partners with all

89
00:05:01.064 --> 00:05:05.769

90
00:05:05.769 --> 00:05:09.992

91
00:05:09.992 --> 00:05:14.495
>> All right, now throughout our
series we're going to be talking about

92
00:05:14.495 --> 00:05:17.700
a number of different tools
that are available and

93
00:05:17.700 --> 00:05:21.300

94
00:05:21.300 --> 00:05:23.400
>> And improve them to make them better.

95
00:05:23.400 --> 00:05:27.500
Or even processes that don't quite

96
00:05:27.500 --> 00:05:30.630
I know, I hate to use that term, design,
because we do start to blend into some

97
00:05:30.630 --> 00:05:32.840

98
00:05:32.840 --> 00:05:35.840

99
00:05:35.840 --> 00:05:40.350
Now, if we've watch the series, we've

100
00:05:40.350 --> 00:05:43.090

101
00:05:43.090 --> 00:05:46.520

102
00:05:46.520 --> 00:05:50.648
You wanna show that you are Lean Six

103
00:05:50.648 --> 00:05:54.100

104
00:05:54.100 --> 00:05:58.040

105
00:05:58.040 --> 00:06:01.340
You can just go to my website,

106
00:06:01.340 --> 00:06:04.284
We own kind of the most of the endings, so

107
00:06:04.284 --> 00:06:09.840
if you just key in ssdglobal into

108
00:06:09.840 --> 00:06:10.740

00:06:10.740 --> 00:06:15.854

111
00:06:18.660 --> 00:06:21.210
This would constitute

112
00:06:21.210 --> 00:06:25.180
So that qualifies you to sit for the exam.

113

114

It's online, it is timed and
you do have to study but

115

if you listen to all the videos,

116
00:06:35.796 --> 00:06:40.560
the study guide just sort of reiterates

117
00:06:40.560 --> 00:06:42.338
>> Yeah.
You might be wondering about that out

118
00:06:42.338 --> 00:06:43.180
there in TV land.

119
00:06:43.180 --> 00:06:47.430
We said it's an open book exam,
but here you are watching a video.

120
00:06:47.430 --> 00:06:49.610
It's open video too, [LAUGH] but

121
00:06:49.610 --> 00:06:51.840

122

123
00:06:54.770 --> 00:06:57.849
You don't have to get certified,
the information is very valuable and

124
00:06:57.849 --> 00:06:59.040

125
00:06:59.040 --> 00:07:02.300
But if you want something to put on
your resume, it's a nice thing to do.

126
00:07:02.300 --> 00:07:05.108
You do get a certificate that
shows that you completed it and

127
00:07:05.108 --> 00:07:06.860
now you're yellow belt certified.

128
00:07:06.860 --> 00:07:07.975
And that's important,

129
00:07:07.975 --> 00:07:11.010

130
00:07:11.010 --> 00:07:13.400
This is that first stepping stone.

131
00:07:13.400 --> 00:07:15.760
It's really nice,
because it's a low barrier to entry.

132
00:07:15.760 --> 00:07:17.690
You can take the exam in

133
00:07:17.690 --> 00:07:20.801
It's an online exam, it's open book so
it's not a ton of pressure but

134
00:07:20.801 --> 00:07:22.450
you do need to study and be prepared.

135
00:07:22.450 --> 00:07:25.580
And then you can jump in and
knock that one out.

136
00:07:25.580 --> 00:07:26.420
It's a great one.

137
00:07:26.420 --> 00:07:30.270
I just like that you don't have to have
a lot of experience to go into this.

138
00:07:30.270 --> 00:07:31.400
It's very valuable.

139
00:07:31.400 --> 00:07:35.833
>> And I think one of the benefits
that my company gives is that you can

140
00:07:35.833 --> 00:07:39.230

paid that nominal fee.

141

142
00:07:43.220 --> 00:07:48.920

143
00:07:48.920 --> 00:07:52.787

144

145
00:07:55.300 --> 00:07:58.036
So I know a couple of people
think wow I'll just take it and

146
00:07:58.036 --> 00:08:01.865
I'll just take it again next week cuz
I will have memorized the question.

147
00:08:01.865 --> 00:08:05.250
There's definitely going to be different
questions over the same content.

148
00:08:05.250 --> 00:08:08.310
But we allow you to do that
until you pass the exam.

149
00:08:08.310 --> 00:08:13.106
Another thing that I think is interesting
about the yellow belt certification is

150
00:08:13.106 --> 00:08:16.560

companies that require you to be

151

152

153
00:08:23.490 --> 00:08:24.710

154
00:08:24.710 --> 00:08:29.960

the employer, hey I'm at least based.

155
00:08:29.960 --> 00:08:33.380
I'm at least aware of the basic
information in Lean Six Sigma.

156
00:08:33.380 --> 00:08:37.219
Because what this course does is
it covers of course training and

157
00:08:37.219 --> 00:08:39.290
certification in how that works.

158
00:08:39.290 --> 00:08:42.140
But it also covers
the Lean Six Sigma terminology.

159
00:08:42.140 --> 00:08:44.610
It covers all the tools.

160
00:08:44.610 --> 00:08:50.820
It covers the core Methodology,

161
00:08:50.820 --> 00:08:54.038
It talks about how it
impacts the IT professionals,

162

that we draw those connections between
that and say things like the CNN and

163

ITEL so that you can have intelligent

164
00:09:03.130 --> 00:09:06.110
Since we're all working
from the same models,

165
00:09:06.110 --> 00:09:10.432
what it also affords the yellow belt
professional is to be able to feel

166
00:09:10.432 --> 00:09:15.590
confident that they are talking to a green
belt, black belt or master white belt.

167
00:09:15.590 --> 00:09:20.263
>> Yeah, now I'm gonna steal one of your
phrases here and that, basically when we

168
00:09:20.263 --> 00:09:24.588
apply Lean Six Sigma methodology to
our environment, to our processes,

169
00:09:24.588 --> 00:09:28.940
it's a great way to make things better,
faster and more cost effective.

170
00:09:28.940 --> 00:09:32.400
And so it's definitely something
that benefits you and your company.

171
00:09:32.400 --> 00:09:33.850
It really is a great resource.

172
00:09:33.850 --> 00:09:37.242
So, if that sounds exciting to you and
it interesting and

173
00:09:37.242 --> 00:09:39.940
you want to jump in,
I encourage you to do it.

174
00:09:39.940 --> 00:09:42.960
Stay tuned, we've got episodes for
Lean Six sigma coming up next.

175
00:09:42.960 --> 00:09:46.355
If that doesn't sound like the right fit
for you, well, no hard feelings there

176
00:09:46.355 --> 00:09:49.091
we've got plenty of content
available in the content library so

177
00:09:49.091 --> 00:09:51.490
be sure to check out the other
shows that are available.

178
00:09:51.490 --> 00:09:54.401
Lots of stuff there in project management,
and

179
00:09:54.401 --> 00:09:59.090
other IT concepts that are just
as important for most workers.

180
00:09:59.090 --> 00:10:01.192
But Lean Six Sigma,
especially the Yellow Belt Level,

181
00:10:01.192 --> 00:10:02.450
really does apply to everybody.

182
00:10:02.450 --> 00:10:06.730
So I hope to see you guys in
our episodes coming up next.

183
00:10:06.730 --> 00:10:12.639
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Lean Six Sigma (LSS) is a combination of two methodologies: lean thinking and Six Sigma blended together to help critical thinking skills. LSS is about looking at an existing activity or process already set in place and looking at how it can be made better, faster, or more cost effective. Viewers will be introduced to the concept of LSS and hear extended information about the process and how it compares with other process improvement methodologies like, AGILE, ISO, CMMI, and ITIL.
episodes.title: Introduction to LSS
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.045 --> 00:00:10.045
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.269 --> 00:00:14.707
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:14.707 --> 00:00:17.330
And welcome back to another
episode of IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:17.330 --> 00:00:22.520
I'm your host Don Pezet back with
another episode of, well, ITproTV.

Stern, why don't you tell us a little bit

the difference between Lean and

So, I'm Dr. Terra Vanzant-Stern.

Probably the most important

And I've written a number

30
00:01:36.307 --> 00:01:40.493
After this, I'm gonna show you the cover

And on the manufacturing floor, and

481
00:27:44.769 --> 00:27:48.143
we're going to be talking about
that in our next segment.

482
00:27:48.143 --> 00:27:50.644
On the manufacturing floor,
mistakes are called defects.

483
00:27:50.644 --> 00:27:54.766
In the service industry they're typically
called just like I said, mistakes.

484
00:27:54.766 --> 00:27:58.973
Now, Lean Six Sigma says,
why not do all of the above?

485
00:27:58.973 --> 00:28:03.053
So, absolutely,
Lean Six Sigma blends Lean and Six Sigma.

486
00:28:03.053 --> 00:28:07.502
It's still mostly Six Sigma, and that's
because most Fortune 100 companies, and

487
00:28:07.502 --> 00:28:10.805
remember, those companies fall on and
off the list all the time,

488
00:28:10.805 --> 00:28:12.305
use some form of Six Sigma.

489
00:28:12.305 --> 00:28:17.728
So, we already know it works, so,
when you hear the term Lean Six Sigma,

490
00:28:17.728 --> 00:28:22.728
it's still rooted in Six Sigma,
but it has a heavy lean influence.

491
00:28:22.728 --> 00:28:27.373
But what's happened over the last 12
years that it's been in existence,

492
00:28:27.373 --> 00:28:29.925
is that it says why not
do all of the above?

493
00:28:29.925 --> 00:28:34.556
Why not take the best of the best and
just kind of roll it into one big ball and

494
00:28:34.556 --> 00:28:36.517
let's call it Lean Six Sigma.

495
00:28:36.517 --> 00:28:39.220
>> And at the end of the day we're left
with a framework that is great for

496
00:28:39.220 --> 00:28:40.226
a lot of organizations.

497
00:28:40.226 --> 00:28:41.728
>> Absolutely.

498
00:28:41.728 --> 00:28:44.943
>> All right, well Dr. Sue I think
that's a pretty good run down on what

499
00:28:44.943 --> 00:28:48.548
Lean Six Sigma is and some of the things
that we'll be covering in this show but

500
00:28:48.548 --> 00:28:50.719
we're a little short on
time in this segment.

501
00:28:50.719 --> 00:28:54.271
So, do you have any parting
thoughts before we wrap up?

502
00:28:54.271 --> 00:28:58.969
>> Well I would definitely like to say
that what you want to start doing is

503
00:28:58.969 --> 00:29:03.991
looking at activities in your everyday
life and start thinking about what

504
00:29:03.991 --> 00:29:09.435
are those activities that I could make
better, faster or more cost effective.

505
00:29:09.435 --> 00:29:13.728
Identifying the activity that you want
to do is probably key to everything.

506
00:29:13.728 --> 00:29:15.336
It's downhill after that,

507
00:29:15.336 --> 00:29:18.690
because I'm gonna show you how
to accomplish those goals.

508
00:29:18.690 --> 00:29:20.851
>> Awesome.
Well, I know I'm looking forward to it.

509
00:29:20.851 --> 00:29:24.083
I'm sure the viewers out there are looking
forward to it, too, but for now,

510
00:29:24.083 --> 00:29:26.143
this is a good spot for
us to wrap this episode up.

511
00:29:26.143 --> 00:29:26.767
Stay tuned.

512
00:29:26.767 --> 00:29:32.180
We've got more Lean Six Six Sigma coming
up down the line, but signing off for

513
00:29:32.180 --> 00:29:37.017
IT Pro I'm Don Prezel, with Dr.
Stern and we'll see you next time.

514
00:29:37.017 --> 00:29:44.010
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Within Lean Six Sigma (LSS) are different certification levels. Viewers will hear about the five different levels of the certification and how it is applied in the work field. A brief background of LSS is also discussed along with some of the other important factors.
episodes.title: LSS History
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.712 --> 00:00:14.790
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:14.790 --> 00:00:17.067
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:17.067 --> 00:00:21.706
I'm your host, Don Pezet, back again
wtih another episode of Lean Six Sigma.

5
00:00:21.706 --> 00:00:25.036
And in this episode, we're gonna be
taking a look at a bit of the history,

6
00:00:25.036 --> 00:00:28.315
a bit of the background that goes along
with Lean and Six Sigma combined,

7
00:00:28.315 --> 00:00:31.037
like peanut butter and
chocolate into some amazing thing.

8
00:00:31.037 --> 00:00:33.187
And to help me, as always, I've got Dr.

9
00:00:33.187 --> 00:00:36.075
Stern who's gonna help walk
us through this process and

10
00:00:36.075 --> 00:00:40.192
get a chance to see what all is involved
in the background of Lean Six Sigma before

11
00:00:40.192 --> 00:00:43.525
we go jumping head first into
deploying it in our organization.

12
00:00:43.525 --> 00:00:45.371
So, Dr. Stern, where do we start?

13
00:00:45.371 --> 00:00:49.880
>> Well, in the 1800s, I'm just kidding.

14
00:00:49.880 --> 00:00:54.730
I actually have a slide presentation
that should painlessly take you through

15
00:00:54.730 --> 00:00:55.869
the basics of the history.

16
00:00:56.910 --> 00:01:02.240
And so we're gonna start with the first
slide, which is just about the roles and

17
00:01:02.240 --> 00:01:05.290
responsibilities and
the different belt levels.

18
00:01:05.290 --> 00:01:08.520
I've been in this industry for
a long time and

19
00:01:08.520 --> 00:01:12.830
still I will go to a conference, and when
they see that I'm a master black belt,

20
00:01:12.830 --> 00:01:15.300
they'll say you must be
in really great shape.

21
00:01:15.300 --> 00:01:19.030
So even in the industry sometimes
these terms are a little confusing.

22
00:01:19.030 --> 00:01:22.210
One of the things that I wanna
point out before we we move too far

23
00:01:22.210 --> 00:01:26.990
in to the history is that these different
belt structures are really used for

24
00:01:26.990 --> 00:01:28.098
recruiting purposes.

25
00:01:28.098 --> 00:01:33.520
There are companies that just recruit for
Lean Six Sigma personnel and

26
00:01:33.520 --> 00:01:37.790
their agency, or
there's entities such as Deloit,

27
00:01:37.790 --> 00:01:43.340
Price Waterhouse Coopers, etc that
have whole Lean Sic Sigma departments.

28
00:01:43.340 --> 00:01:47.080
So more than anything else,
these belts, designations,

29
00:01:47.080 --> 00:01:51.300
are so that the recruiter knows what level
of Lean Six Sigma experience you have.

30
00:01:51.300 --> 00:01:55.460
And if you use them or not,
that's kind of all over the board.

31
00:01:55.460 --> 00:01:57.660
For example, I do some work
with DuPont in Puerto Rico and

32
00:01:57.660 --> 00:01:59.510
they actually put the belts on the door.

33
00:01:59.510 --> 00:02:04.810
Every time they achieve the belt,
a lot of the people at that plant do that.

34
00:02:04.810 --> 00:02:06.120
And yet here,

35
00:02:06.120 --> 00:02:10.340
DuPont here in the States, sometimes
it not even on their business card.

36
00:02:10.340 --> 00:02:14.500
Walmart Hires a number of Black Belts and
Master Black Belts.

37
00:02:14.500 --> 00:02:19.290
But when they go to work for Walmart
Corporate in Bentonville, Arkansas,

38
00:02:19.290 --> 00:02:21.700
they might have titles like
Process Improvement Engineer.

39
00:02:21.700 --> 00:02:24.560
So the titles are kind of more just so

40
00:02:24.560 --> 00:02:29.560
that you know where that person is at,
in the whole scheme of things.

41
00:02:30.640 --> 00:02:35.126
Another thing is that these structures
are sort of in a perfect world.

42
00:02:35.126 --> 00:02:38.320
Because if you're the the only
person there at the company,

43
00:02:38.320 --> 00:02:41.900
you're the Yellow Belt,
Green Belt, and Black Belt.

44
00:02:41.900 --> 00:02:42.970
You're doing everything.

45
00:02:42.970 --> 00:02:47.680
But in a perfect world, this is the way
that they would kind of flesh out.

46
00:02:47.680 --> 00:02:49.850
It uses a martial arts nomenclature.

47
00:02:49.850 --> 00:02:51.060
And the first one,

48
00:02:51.060 --> 00:02:55.630
White Belt, doesn't really have
a lot of industry standards around.

49
00:02:55.630 --> 00:02:57.720
It was created kind of late in the game.

50
00:02:57.720 --> 00:03:00.522
It's generally used as market leader or

51
00:03:00.522 --> 00:03:03.960
if a company's not really sure if they
wanna make the Lean Six Sigma decision, so

52
00:03:03.960 --> 00:03:05.850
sometimes it's in a lunch and
learn format.

53
00:03:05.850 --> 00:03:11.152
A lot of hospitals have
started calling white

54
00:03:11.152 --> 00:03:16.739
belt training part of
their hospital program.

55
00:03:16.739 --> 00:03:19.872
Because if you are working in
a hospital and you touch a patient,

56
00:03:19.872 --> 00:03:22.019
there's certain rules that you have to be,

57
00:03:22.019 --> 00:03:25.497
there's certain orientation practices
that you have to go through.

58
00:03:25.497 --> 00:03:28.200
And so they blended white belt in there.

59
00:03:28.200 --> 00:03:31.160
And so sometimes you might see
a hospital orientation for two or

60
00:03:31.160 --> 00:03:34.870
three days saying that it's a white belt,
but it's mostly about the hospital.

61
00:03:34.870 --> 00:03:37.220
And the white belt piece
is just a couple of hours.

62
00:03:37.220 --> 00:03:41.357
Now, yellow, green and black have

63
00:03:41.357 --> 00:03:45.500
the most industry standards and
what I mean by that is that

64
00:03:45.500 --> 00:03:49.130
everyone that's in the business sort
of agrees on the competency model.

65
00:03:49.130 --> 00:03:52.240
So if you say you're a yellow belt or
a green Belt or a black belt,

66
00:03:52.240 --> 00:03:54.590
there's certain expectations
that they have of you.

67
00:03:54.590 --> 00:03:57.650
And I'm gonna go over
those in just a moment.

68
00:03:57.650 --> 00:04:02.210
Master Black Belt is another one that,
it has a lot of industry standards.

69
00:04:02.210 --> 00:04:04.540
But not as much as the Yellow,
Green, and Black Belt.

70
00:04:04.540 --> 00:04:07.290
In the Master Black Belt category,

71
00:04:07.290 --> 00:04:10.360
a lot of times those
are university-type programs.

72
00:04:10.360 --> 00:04:15.970
So I already mentioned that
White Belt is an orientation.

73
00:04:15.970 --> 00:04:18.420
And not a lot of standards around it.

74
00:04:18.420 --> 00:04:22.050
Yellow belt, however,
has distinct standards and

75
00:04:22.050 --> 00:04:26.450
in a yellow belt program, what you're
learning is just what you're learning

76
00:04:26.450 --> 00:04:29.060
in the courses in the series of
courses that we're doing right now.

77
00:04:29.060 --> 00:04:31.600
You're learning the basic terminology,

78
00:04:31.600 --> 00:04:37.440
you're learning how to identify a Lean Six
Sigma project and those types of things.

79
00:04:37.440 --> 00:04:41.590
Now the best way to explain the difference
between a green and a A Black Belt.

80
00:04:41.590 --> 00:04:43.300
And it's a simplistic explanation.

81
00:04:43.300 --> 00:04:45.590
But it's the best way
that I can explain it.

82
00:04:45.590 --> 00:04:48.490
It's that if you take
the Green Belt program,

83
00:04:49.550 --> 00:04:52.630
you are directly marrying that
to whatever it is you do.

84
00:04:52.630 --> 00:04:54.490
So you're a Green Belt.

85
00:04:54.490 --> 00:04:55.700
But you're an HR professional.

86
00:04:55.700 --> 00:04:56.460
You're a Green Belt.

87
00:04:56.460 --> 00:04:57.590
But you're an IT professional.

88
00:04:57.590 --> 00:04:58.740
You're a Green Belt.

89
00:04:58.740 --> 00:04:59.480
But you work in ops.

90
00:04:59.480 --> 00:05:03.870
So you take the things that you
learn in the Lean Six Sigma program,

91
00:05:03.870 --> 00:05:09.230
to make your specific job Job better,
faster or more cost effective.

92
00:05:09.230 --> 00:05:12.030
So you're working with
an existing process.

93
00:05:12.030 --> 00:05:14.340
You need something that
you're doing right now,

94
00:05:14.340 --> 00:05:18.310
an activity you're doing right now,
in your job right now.

95
00:05:18.310 --> 00:05:21.680
And as a green belt,
you're pretty much saying,

96
00:05:21.680 --> 00:05:25.820
in my areas of subject matter expertise,
I am able to make those processes better,

97
00:05:25.820 --> 00:05:28.130
faster, more cost effective.

98
00:05:28.130 --> 00:05:30.900
A black belt is essentially saying,
I can do that in any.

99
00:05:30.900 --> 00:05:32.310
Department in the company.

100
00:05:32.310 --> 00:05:35.340
So I can identify process and
improvement opportunities.

101
00:05:36.430 --> 00:05:41.520
Doesn't matter if it's finance,
marketing, HR, the manufacturing floor.

102
00:05:41.520 --> 00:05:44.990
Now, in order to be a good successful
black belt, this requires that you have

103
00:05:44.990 --> 00:05:48.980
a little bit of understanding about
how all of those departments work.

104
00:05:48.980 --> 00:05:52.410
So typically, good candidates for

105
00:05:52.410 --> 00:05:57.930
the Lean Six Sigma black belt program
are Are people who have an MBA because,

106
00:05:57.930 --> 00:06:00.700
as you know,
in a Masters of Business Administration,

107
00:06:00.700 --> 00:06:05.790
you learn a little bit about
all those different areas.

108
00:06:05.790 --> 00:06:08.320
People who are IT professionals,
because these days

109
00:06:08.320 --> 00:06:10.940
you can't do an enterprise-wide process
improvement without involving IT.

110
00:06:10.940 --> 00:06:14.660
So by default, what's happened with IT is
they've had to learn a little bit about

111
00:06:14.660 --> 00:06:19.000
marketing, a little bit about human
resources, a little bit about finance.

112
00:06:19.000 --> 00:06:21.580
So those are good candidates.

113
00:06:21.580 --> 00:06:26.630
And finally the third good candidate is
if you've ever owned your own business.

114
00:06:26.630 --> 00:06:30.340
I know there's probably a lot of you out
there that have owned your own business.

115
00:06:30.340 --> 00:06:32.020
And when you do that, you're marketing.

116
00:06:32.020 --> 00:06:33.570
And you're customer service.

117
00:06:33.570 --> 00:06:34.260
And you're payroll.

118
00:06:34.260 --> 00:06:38.360
And so people that have kind
of a well-rounded idea,

119
00:06:38.360 --> 00:06:41.350
typically do well in
the Black Belt program.

120
00:06:41.350 --> 00:06:44.220
So again,
Green Belts pretty much apply their

121
00:06:44.220 --> 00:06:47.880
Green Belt expertise to the job
that they're already doing.

122
00:06:47.880 --> 00:06:50.800
Where as a Black Belt, that could
actually be their job at a company.

123
00:06:50.800 --> 00:06:52.710
Is just to go around the company and
do process improvement.

124
00:06:52.710 --> 00:06:55.920
>> So when we're talking about white belt
and yellow belt, just really general.

125
00:06:55.920 --> 00:06:58.310
>> Right.
>> And then when we get into green belt,

126
00:06:58.310 --> 00:07:00.340
we start getting into specializations.

127
00:07:00.340 --> 00:07:03.990
But once we get past that into black belt,
it starts becoming general again, right?

128
00:07:03.990 --> 00:07:06.220
Kind of covering all the different areas.

129
00:07:06.220 --> 00:07:06.900
>> Yes, absolutely.

130
00:07:06.900 --> 00:07:08.130
Good observation.

131
00:07:08.130 --> 00:07:12.720
I think another thing that's very
interesting about the Yellow belt program

132
00:07:12.720 --> 00:07:18.030
that we're participating in as I speak,
is that a lot of times this program is

133
00:07:18.030 --> 00:07:23.250
labeled Lean Six Sigma leadership,
Champion Training.

134
00:07:23.250 --> 00:07:25.720
It has a lot of different names.

135
00:07:25.720 --> 00:07:28.050
The course is the same, but

136
00:07:28.050 --> 00:07:32.190
sometimes what happens is a CEO who
inherits a Lean Six Sigma company, or

137
00:07:32.190 --> 00:07:35.370
department manager that inherits
a Lean Six Sigma department,

138
00:07:35.370 --> 00:07:39.410
has to quickly understand what the heck
is going on in their department.

139
00:07:39.410 --> 00:07:41.520
And so they'll take this course just
to get kind of the basic overview.

140
00:07:41.520 --> 00:07:45.417
They're not planning to really
do the work that green belts and

141
00:07:45.417 --> 00:07:49.401
black belts are doing, but
they need to certainly understand.

142
00:07:49.401 --> 00:07:53.047
>> Yeah, and skipping over white belt,
that's perfectly fine.

143
00:07:53.047 --> 00:07:54.875
>> Right, it's great.

144
00:07:54.875 --> 00:07:56.720
>> Not to take away from
the importance of it, right?

145
00:07:56.720 --> 00:07:57.580
But it is just kinda the introduction.

146
00:07:57.580 --> 00:07:58.550
>> Yeah.
>> And so if you go

147
00:07:58.550 --> 00:08:00.670
straight into yellow like we're doing,
that's fine.

148
00:08:00.670 --> 00:08:04.850
But then If you wanted to go into green or
black,

149
00:08:04.850 --> 00:08:07.810
you really don't wanna be skipping
belts at that point right?

150
00:08:07.810 --> 00:08:09.940
>> Most of the time I
would say that's true.

151
00:08:09.940 --> 00:08:13.040
Now people who have a PMP
sometimes will go straight

152
00:08:13.040 --> 00:08:16.280
the the black belt that and
that's, project.

153
00:08:16.280 --> 00:08:18.150
What does that acronym stand for?

154
00:08:18.150 --> 00:08:19.680
>> Project management professional.

155
00:08:19.680 --> 00:08:20.393
>> Right.
Because so

156
00:08:20.393 --> 00:08:24.228
much of Lean Six Sigma is rooted in basic
project management depending on what types

157
00:08:24.228 --> 00:08:25.705
of projects a PMP has worked on,

158
00:08:25.705 --> 00:08:29.240
a lot of times they'll make a good
candidate to go straight to black belt.

159
00:08:29.240 --> 00:08:33.890
>> And then master black belt, right now,

160
00:08:33.890 --> 00:08:38.940
is that really just trainers or is there
an actual business case for that one?

161
00:08:38.940 --> 00:08:42.445
>> Well, there's a lot of confusion
about a master black belt and

162
00:08:42.445 --> 00:08:43.820
at my company, at SSD Global,

163
00:08:43.820 --> 00:08:47.730
I often get requests for master black
belts that actually a green belt could do.

164
00:08:47.730 --> 00:08:49.755
So there's a lot of
confusion in the market.

165
00:08:49.755 --> 00:08:55.640
But Technically, the core program,
the most you're gonna

166
00:08:55.640 --> 00:08:59.760
learn about Lean Six Sigma is
contained in the black belt course.

167
00:08:59.760 --> 00:09:04.190
And the master black belt course,
to your point, is more for

168
00:09:04.190 --> 00:09:09.280
people that want to train or, in many
cases, large companies believe that

169
00:09:09.280 --> 00:09:11.570
it's advantageous to build
an internal Lean Six Sigma program.

170
00:09:11.570 --> 00:09:13.640
So a lot of the people that are in my

171
00:09:14.890 --> 00:09:19.680
master black belt program the company has
requested to build an internal program.

172
00:09:19.680 --> 00:09:22.120
And so they do that as well.

173
00:09:22.120 --> 00:09:27.090
And the other thing is that a Master
Black Belt, a lot of times you don't

174
00:09:27.090 --> 00:09:31.790
see those unless you're in a company
that's making a billion in revenue.

175
00:09:31.790 --> 00:09:36.600
A billion and under revenue, typically
a Black Belt can probably facilitate.

176
00:09:36.600 --> 00:09:38.086
>> That's a lot of money.

177
00:09:38.086 --> 00:09:40.780
>> [LAUGH] A lot of room for
error there, so.

178
00:09:40.780 --> 00:09:43.100
>> Yeah.
Definitely important.

179
00:09:43.100 --> 00:09:45.210
All right.
So we've got the belt structures and

180
00:09:45.210 --> 00:09:46.540
those have been around awhile.

181
00:09:46.540 --> 00:09:47.840
>> Right.
>> You said white belt was newer,

182
00:09:47.840 --> 00:09:50.720
both the other belts all kinda
came around about the same time.

183
00:09:50.720 --> 00:09:54.370
What else do we need to understand
about the history of Lean Six Sigma?

184
00:09:54.370 --> 00:09:56.650
>> Well, there's some additional
roles that are very, very important.

185
00:09:56.650 --> 00:09:58.390
And in these additional roles,

186
00:09:58.390 --> 00:10:00.960
it doesn't really matter what
belt structure that you're using.

187
00:10:00.960 --> 00:10:04.310
So the additional roles
would be process owner.

188
00:10:04.310 --> 00:10:05.930
And I think one of the challenging things.

189
00:10:05.930 --> 00:10:11.000
Things when you're starting in Lean Six
Sigma, is those hidden process owners.

190
00:10:11.000 --> 00:10:15.560
And what I mean by that is that
someone may have developed

191
00:10:15.560 --> 00:10:17.600
the activities in that department.

192
00:10:17.600 --> 00:10:20.050
And been promoted to another department.

193
00:10:20.050 --> 00:10:22.780
But they still kinda feel
ownership of that process.

194
00:10:22.780 --> 00:10:24.180
So it's not just the process owners.

00:10:24.180 --> 00:10:26.750

00:10:26.750 --> 00:10:28.313

00:10:28.313 --> 00:10:32.793
And as long as I've been in In this
industry, when I wear my consultant hat,

00:10:32.793 --> 00:10:34.124
I mostly do training.

199
00:10:34.124 --> 00:10:38.057
But when I wear my consultant hat, very
rarely do I go into a department where

200
00:10:38.057 --> 00:10:42.418

201
00:10:42.418 --> 00:10:45.575
yay, she's here to improve me,
because it's difficult.

202
00:10:45.575 --> 00:10:48.814
And sometimes that's one of the most

203
00:10:48.814 --> 00:10:49.325
to manage.

204
00:10:49.325 --> 00:10:53.306
The person who is actually responsible
we call the process owner.

205
00:10:53.306 --> 00:10:56.810
Now the champion role is Is kind of fun.

One of the defense firms that I work for

00:11:05.250 --> 00:11:09.280

rah, sis boom bah person

who's going to go out there and
spread the word about how great you are.

210
00:11:12.630 --> 00:11:15.820
Sometimes your champion might
just be like a well-loved person

00:11:15.820 --> 00:11:17.440

00:11:17.440 --> 00:11:21.030
But they're really
supposed to help you and

213
00:11:21.030 --> 00:11:24.980

kind of move your project forward.

00:11:24.980 --> 00:11:29.300
So sometimes when people, such as
the defense firm that I mentioned, make

00:11:29.300 --> 00:11:33.510

not be totally bought into the project.

00:11:33.510 --> 00:11:38.650
Right, so can you do a Lean Six Sigma

00:11:38.650 --> 00:11:39.620
Absolutely.

00:11:39.620 --> 00:11:40.555
It's just.

Just, it's one of those preferred roles.

00:11:42.955 --> 00:11:47.615
Now, on the other hand, you cannot do a

A sponsor, a lot of times that's

So your sponsor might be your boss.

00:11:58.212 --> 00:12:00.333
But your sponsor could be your bosses.

00:12:00.333 --> 00:12:01.275
Bosses, boss.

And it's important to keep in mind

00:12:05.271 --> 00:12:09.120

that's who you're gonna be answering to.

00:12:09.120 --> 00:12:10.660

Is it the same way in [CROSSTALK]
>> Absolutely, and

in today's society that I think
the hardest thing about this sponsors.

He might not even or

00:12:41.005 --> 00:12:44.949

00:12:44.949 --> 00:12:46.516
they're basically-

00:12:48.971 --> 00:12:53.726
>> Sure and when you're working

00:12:53.726 --> 00:12:58.305
we'll be talking about this

You're still doing a project charter and

permission to move forward and

So having a sponsor is key to that,

00:13:08.506 --> 00:13:14.821
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right so,

00:13:14.821 --> 00:13:16.545
couple of different roles

You've got your belt holders,

00:13:18.840 --> 00:13:22.055
You've got your other people

00:13:22.055 --> 00:13:24.685

What else do we need to

00:13:26.885 --> 00:13:31.690
>> Well, I think in a perfect world,

00:13:31.690 --> 00:13:34.730
you'd have a team.

00:13:34.730 --> 00:13:38.490
And we have those, they're about,
I don't know, I wanna say 10 or

255
00:13:38.490 --> 00:13:42.830
20 years ago was the first time I

00:13:42.830 --> 00:13:45.659
Lean Six Sigma has a tiny bit of a

00:13:47.690 --> 00:13:50.090
Let's talk about

00:13:50.090 --> 00:13:56.780
So, a cross-functional team is where

00:13:56.780 --> 00:14:00.095
And the idea is so that you can

00:14:00.095 --> 00:14:01.555

00:14:01.555 --> 00:14:02.890
>> Yeah, absolutely, and

no one person generally has that great big

00:14:07.350 --> 00:14:10.580
So you gotta get people together

00:14:17.280 --> 00:14:20.890

00:14:20.890 --> 00:14:26.250

00:14:36.370 --> 00:14:37.775

00:14:37.775 --> 00:14:40.190
cross-functional teams

00:15:01.000 --> 00:15:03.130

00:15:03.130 --> 00:15:05.370
Even though it's still

00:15:05.370 --> 00:15:07.740
I might have to handle that

285
00:15:07.740 --> 00:15:12.820
I'll do as much work as I can, but
I need you to look over my work and

00:15:12.820 --> 00:15:15.890

287
00:15:15.890 --> 00:15:19.910
So the whole, there's a couple of

00:15:19.910 --> 00:15:21.530
Lean takes a whole different view about.

00:15:21.530 --> 00:15:25.265
And one of them is that you don't

00:15:25.265 --> 00:15:28.600

piece in your project.

00:15:28.600 --> 00:15:33.820
And the other one is that, in a perfect

00:15:33.820 --> 00:15:35.250
sitting in your meeting.

00:15:35.250 --> 00:15:39.120
But in the real world, you're gonna

294
00:15:39.120 --> 00:15:43.630
And you might have to set up those

00:15:43.630 --> 00:15:45.210
minimal work on their part.

00:15:45.210 --> 00:15:48.190
And sometimes they even on some

00:15:48.190 --> 00:15:51.250
I've even gone out and said,

00:15:51.250 --> 00:15:52.700
I'm gonna give you total credit.

00:15:52.700 --> 00:15:56.070
And if it's a failure,
I'm not even gonna mention your name, so.

00:15:56.070 --> 00:15:58.130

with none of the risk?

301
00:15:58.130 --> 00:15:58.862
>> Exactly.
>> That's not fair.

302
00:15:58.862 --> 00:15:59.599
[LAUGH]
>> It's not fair,

303
00:15:59.599 --> 00:16:01.180
but it's the way it is sometimes.

304
00:16:01.180 --> 00:16:02.670
>> Absolutely.

305
00:16:02.670 --> 00:16:06.020
>> So I'd like to talk a little bit
about what process improvement is.

306
00:16:06.020 --> 00:16:13.200
First thing, I wanna say is that it
started with Total Quality Management.

307
00:16:13.200 --> 00:16:15.400
When you look at the history of TQM,

308
00:16:15.400 --> 00:16:19.790
there's a lot of different opinions
about when it actually started.

309
00:16:19.790 --> 00:16:26.420
But you've probably heard some
names such as Edwards Deming.

310
00:16:26.420 --> 00:16:30.170
And it really is Edwards with an S,
Edwards Deming, and Joseph Juran.

311
00:16:30.170 --> 00:16:33.310
They both had a different
spin on quality management,

312
00:16:33.310 --> 00:16:34.720
but they had a lot of synergies.

313
00:16:34.720 --> 00:16:37.460
And Edwards Deming kind of
took the lecture circuit.

314
00:16:38.790 --> 00:16:43.770
Whereas Joseph Juran, another
pioneer in total quality management,

315
00:16:43.770 --> 00:16:45.940
took more of the book route.

316
00:16:45.940 --> 00:16:52.510
And even today, if you're taking a quality
engineering class, he's footnoted.

317
00:16:52.510 --> 00:16:53.680
Deming died in the 1990's at 90 and

318
00:16:53.680 --> 00:16:56.950
Joseph Juran only died a few
years back at the age of 102.

319
00:16:56.950 --> 00:16:59.620
So we have a lot of information
about those two people.

320
00:16:59.620 --> 00:17:03.800
>> You remember,
a lot of the concepts we talked about here

321
00:17:03.800 --> 00:17:06.270
came out of the Industrial Revolution-
>> Absolutely.

322
00:17:06.270 --> 00:17:10.712
>> And so, it's interesting
cuz it's kindalike new and yet

323
00:17:10.712 --> 00:17:12.350
old at the same time.

324
00:17:12.350 --> 00:17:16.070
So it's all under 100 years old,
but that's when it started and

325
00:17:16.070 --> 00:17:19.062
things haven't changed all
that much in that time.

326
00:17:19.062 --> 00:17:24.350
>> Yeah, and in the industrial revolution,
decisions were made in an autocratic way.

327
00:17:24.350 --> 00:17:28.230
And so the person who was running the
plant, sometimes even ran the whole town.

328
00:17:28.230 --> 00:17:30.390
And everyone just did what
that person said, right?

329
00:17:30.390 --> 00:17:34.275
So when TQM, and then there was the short
period of time that a lot of you might

330
00:17:34.275 --> 00:17:38.600
remember from your university days,
where they kind of experimented on people.

331
00:17:38.600 --> 00:17:46.060
So they played with the whites, and
they have people walking around,

332
00:17:46.060 --> 00:17:50.090
and very famous sewing machine
factory kinds of experiments.

333
00:17:50.090 --> 00:17:53.160
And what they were trying to do is to see,
how will people be more productive?

334
00:17:53.160 --> 00:17:56.140
How will people be better,
faster and more cost effective?

335
00:17:56.140 --> 00:17:58.580
And then we moved into this
whole tiki lin era, and

336
00:17:58.580 --> 00:18:01.090
it's kind of funny because at

337
00:18:01.090 --> 00:18:03.940
That first people were like,

00:18:03.940 --> 00:18:07.610
they don't pay me the big bucks to come

00:18:07.610 --> 00:18:09.690
So it's kinda funny,

00:18:09.690 --> 00:18:15.255
Because when this concept first came out,

00:18:15.255 --> 00:18:19.597
Or they felt like,
this is too much of a burden for me.

342
00:18:19.597 --> 00:18:21.962
Just tell me what to do and I'll do it.

343
00:18:21.962 --> 00:18:22.508
>> Yeah, and

344
00:18:22.508 --> 00:18:26.587
really it's about having people take
ownership of the processes they work on.

345
00:18:26.587 --> 00:18:29.046
And it goes back to what you said

346
00:18:29.046 --> 00:18:32.539
We're trying to make these things better,

00:18:32.539 --> 00:18:37.330
So you gotta have people who

00:18:37.330 --> 00:18:39.163
That's part of what

00:18:39.163 --> 00:18:39.865
right-

00:18:39.865 --> 00:18:42.530
>> Is to rally people to that cause and

00:18:42.530 --> 00:18:43.560
>> Right, and it's so valuable.

00:18:43.560 --> 00:18:46.820
Like I said, you can do a Lean Six Sigma

00:18:46.820 --> 00:18:47.390
It's so much easier.

00:18:47.390 --> 00:18:49.470
I mean, just even for

00:18:49.470 --> 00:18:50.780
If you have someone that you can go to.

00:18:50.780 --> 00:18:54.060
And if you're still trying to put

00:18:54.060 --> 00:18:55.650
having that sounding board, it's huge.

358
00:18:55.650 --> 00:18:58.040
>> I look at it as,
it's not essential to have.

359
00:18:58.040 --> 00:19:00.070
But it improves your odds of success,

360
00:19:00.070 --> 00:19:01.270
>> Oh, absolutely.

361
00:19:01.270 --> 00:19:01.800
>> It's a boon.

362
00:19:01.800 --> 00:19:05.660
>> Yeah, absolutely, so
when we talk about process improvement.

363
00:19:05.660 --> 00:19:08.860
What we're trying to do is,
we're trying to make something better.

364
00:19:08.860 --> 00:19:11.930
And that's just an easy word for quality.

365
00:19:11.930 --> 00:19:14.440
So instead of using quality,
we use the word better.

366
00:19:14.440 --> 00:19:20.160
And we're trying to make things more

00:19:20.160 --> 00:19:23.900
Because I'm sure a lot of you would agree,

368
00:19:23.900 --> 00:19:25.990
that I could make
an existing process faster.

369
00:19:25.990 --> 00:19:28.180
And it would just be a disaster, right?

370
00:19:28.180 --> 00:19:29.990
So, we say faster because it's faster.

371
00:19:29.990 --> 00:19:32.550
But we're really talking about

372
00:19:32.550 --> 00:19:35.640
And then the third one,
more cost-effective.

373
00:19:35.640 --> 00:19:39.940
I wanna spend a little bit of
time explaining those terms, so

374
00:19:39.940 --> 00:19:42.500
that we're all on the same page.

375
00:19:42.500 --> 00:19:48.600
When we say better, we're gonna increase
the quality that always costs something.

376
00:19:48.600 --> 00:19:51.660
And that was the famous
saying of Joseph Juran.

377
00:19:51.660 --> 00:19:54.130
Quality always costs something, right.

378
00:19:54.130 --> 00:19:59.400
So when I go in to my boss to present
a process improvement argument,

379
00:19:59.400 --> 00:20:02.280
where I'm gonna make things better.

380
00:20:02.280 --> 00:20:05.940
I'm gonna have to have a little
bit more material with me

381
00:20:05.940 --> 00:20:09.845
because the other two options,
I'm probably gonna save or make money.

382
00:20:09.845 --> 00:20:13.565
But on this option,
I'm asking you to spend money.

383
00:20:13.565 --> 00:20:17.215
So, it's always a little trickier.

384
00:20:17.215 --> 00:20:20.065
Faster, which we're gonna say
is really more efficient, but

385
00:20:20.065 --> 00:20:23.251
the thing about faster is there's
only one way to make things faster.

386
00:20:23.251 --> 00:20:25.392
And that's to map the existing process.

387
00:20:25.392 --> 00:20:28.651
And that just means write down all
the steps in the existing process.

388
00:20:28.651 --> 00:20:31.475
And figure out which steps
you can eliminate or combine.

389
00:20:31.475 --> 00:20:35.968
Now, the theory is simple and what's
fun about that is that you can leave

390
00:20:35.968 --> 00:20:40.031
the office right away saying, oh,
I know what I need to be doing.

391
00:20:40.031 --> 00:20:42.945
I need to be looking at these
different activity steps and

392
00:20:42.945 --> 00:20:45.321
trying to figure out
which ones to eliminate.

393
00:20:45.321 --> 00:20:49.394
In reality, it gets a little dicey because
you still have to have conversations.

394
00:20:49.394 --> 00:20:53.556
You can't just be pulling things off
a process map without understanding.

395
00:20:53.556 --> 00:20:56.688
They could be like a compliance issue or
something like that.

396
00:20:56.688 --> 00:21:01.305
But the hard part of it is getting
used to listening for that word faster

397
00:21:01.305 --> 00:21:05.859
because a lot of times, people
aren't going to say the word faster.

398
00:21:05.859 --> 00:21:09.663
I need to make this process faster,
they might say,

399
00:21:09.663 --> 00:21:14.339
I need to improve cycle time,
or we're missing our deadlines.

400
00:21:14.339 --> 00:21:19.253
But the moment that you hear that
they're trying to speed up that process,

401
00:21:19.253 --> 00:21:23.153
that's when you know it's time to stop,
map the process,

402
00:21:23.153 --> 00:21:25.738
start looking at what you can combine.

403
00:21:25.738 --> 00:21:30.254
This is a great argument as well when
you're trying to convince your boss that

404
00:21:30.254 --> 00:21:31.788
this is a good thing to do.

405
00:21:31.788 --> 00:21:35.996
Because whatever boxes you are able
to take off that process map,

406
00:21:35.996 --> 00:21:37.765
you can cost those box out.

407
00:21:37.765 --> 00:21:40.411
Labor, facility, equipment.

408
00:21:40.411 --> 00:21:44.508
So you automatically have a way that
you can say you've saved some money.

409
00:21:44.508 --> 00:21:49.213
Now cost effectiveness is kind of an
interesting one because cost effectiveness

410
00:21:49.213 --> 00:21:50.951
actually has three buckets.

411
00:21:50.951 --> 00:21:53.982
The first bucket is profit and
profit is always king.

412
00:21:53.982 --> 00:21:57.385
If I walk into your office and I say,
I've got a process improvement and

413
00:21:57.385 --> 00:22:01.318
it's gonna make you money, you're gonna
at least stop and listen to me, right?

414
00:22:01.318 --> 00:22:02.530
>> Yeah, absolutely, and

415
00:22:02.530 --> 00:22:05.776
this might not be the first time
you've come to me either, right?

416
00:22:05.776 --> 00:22:07.541
So you might have made one
set of improvements and

417
00:22:07.541 --> 00:22:10.126
then you make a second set of
improvements, so it's getting better and

418
00:22:10.126 --> 00:22:11.677
better each time-
>> Exactly.

419
00:22:11.677 --> 00:22:14.393
>> Until sooner or later, we hit that
threshold, right, where the cost of

420
00:22:14.393 --> 00:22:17.169
the improvement exceeds the benefit
of the improvement you're making.

421
00:22:17.169 --> 00:22:19.981
But if you tell me you can save
me some money, I'm gonna listen.

422
00:22:19.981 --> 00:22:20.701
I'm all ears.

423
00:22:20.701 --> 00:22:22.514
>> Which brings us to the second point.

424
00:22:22.514 --> 00:22:27.493
So making money and then saving money,
while saving money in our world,

425
00:22:27.493 --> 00:22:32.570
if I go to the store and I buy apples,
and let's say they're $2 a pound.

426
00:22:32.570 --> 00:22:33.870
They're really good apples.

427
00:22:33.870 --> 00:22:34.869
And they're $2 a pound.

428
00:22:34.869 --> 00:22:39.155
And I go to another store and
they're $1.50 and I decide to make my

429
00:22:39.155 --> 00:22:44.041
purchasing decision there, I drive
home saying, I saved $0.50 a pound.

430
00:22:44.041 --> 00:22:46.058
In the process improvement role,

431
00:22:46.058 --> 00:22:49.835
we look at savings through
a slightly different lens.

432
00:22:49.835 --> 00:22:54.465
In order for it to constitute
a true process improvement savings,

433
00:22:54.465 --> 00:22:56.385
we have to already have the money.

434
00:22:56.385 --> 00:22:57.846
It can be in our budget,

435
00:22:57.846 --> 00:23:02.244
or my boss could have actually handed
me $20 and I give him 10 back.

436
00:23:02.244 --> 00:23:07.007
So unless I've already been allocated the
money or have the money in my hand, and

437
00:23:07.007 --> 00:23:11.255
I give you money back,
then it doesn't count as cost savings.

438
00:23:11.255 --> 00:23:14.853
Whereas, I think we look
at savings differently.

439
00:23:14.853 --> 00:23:18.215
>> Yeah, when I hear savings,
I immediately think of money.

440
00:23:18.215 --> 00:23:23.069
I don't necessarily think of
savings in terms of saving time or

441
00:23:23.069 --> 00:23:25.091
saving other resources.

442
00:23:25.091 --> 00:23:29.986
>> And then finally the cost avoidance,
or cost effectiveness.

443
00:23:29.986 --> 00:23:34.706
And when I'm looking at, okay, so
I could make money, I could save money, or

444
00:23:34.706 --> 00:23:36.790
I could avoid you spending money.

445
00:23:36.790 --> 00:23:41.122
And there's a couple different ways
I could look at that cost avoidance

446
00:23:41.122 --> 00:23:42.281
argument as well.

447
00:23:42.281 --> 00:23:45.348
One way is, if I'm looking at compliance.

448
00:23:45.348 --> 00:23:49.254
And people such as OSHA and
EPA actually have schedules that say,

449
00:23:49.254 --> 00:23:54.167
if you make this violation, we're gonna
charge you x amount of dollars, right?

450
00:23:54.167 --> 00:23:58.961
So if I make a process improvement
that keeps me from being fined,

451
00:23:58.961 --> 00:24:03.941
then I can go ahead and say,
I've avoided you spending that money.

452
00:24:03.941 --> 00:24:05.742
The other one's a little trickier.

453
00:24:05.742 --> 00:24:08.841
And that's when sometimes you
have to spend money upfront,

454
00:24:08.841 --> 00:24:11.221
because it's gonna save
money down the line.

455
00:24:11.221 --> 00:24:14.124
Now remember what we were saying,
that profit?

456
00:24:14.124 --> 00:24:17.130
I go tell you I'm gonna make you money,
you're at least gonna listen to me.

457
00:24:17.130 --> 00:24:17.885
And savings?

458
00:24:17.885 --> 00:24:20.260
That's pretty easy,
because I'm giving you money back.

459
00:24:20.260 --> 00:24:22.570
And you're going oh, wow,
I got money back, right?

460
00:24:22.570 --> 00:24:26.548
But then when we get down to cost
avoidance, you need to spend a little more

461
00:24:26.548 --> 00:24:30.860
this quarter than you thought, but
down the line, it's gonna save you money?

462
00:24:30.860 --> 00:24:33.099
Sometimes that gets to be kinda tricky.

463
00:24:33.099 --> 00:24:35.496
And you're gonna have to show
a spreadsheet that says,

464
00:24:35.496 --> 00:24:37.129
we're spending this money upfront.

465
00:24:37.129 --> 00:24:41.173
A lot of times I think we run into
that with software where we're doing

466
00:24:41.173 --> 00:24:44.380
an Enterprise rollout of like say,
Oracle or SAP, and

467
00:24:44.380 --> 00:24:48.496
there's some things that if we're
not a student doing that rollout,

468
00:24:48.496 --> 00:24:53.267
there's things that we don't know,
modules that we might not have purchased.

469
00:24:53.267 --> 00:24:57.294
But if we do it the next time and
we buy in a bundle, in the big picture,

470
00:24:57.294 --> 00:24:58.898
it's gonna save us money.

471
00:24:58.898 --> 00:25:00.373
>> And you see that like with a make or

472
00:25:00.373 --> 00:25:03.379
buy analysis, right, that there's
a lot of things where you say,

473
00:25:03.379 --> 00:25:07.123
well, I could outsource this, or I could
purchase it pre-made, or we could try and

474
00:25:07.123 --> 00:25:09.953
make it ourselves, and
it might seem like a good idea at first.

475
00:25:09.953 --> 00:25:13.110
I know I've started this kind of project
before where all of a sudden you realize,

476
00:25:13.110 --> 00:25:16.312
halfway through, boy, I should have just
paid somebody else to do this [LAUGH], but

477
00:25:16.312 --> 00:25:17.212
now you're in a hole.

478
00:25:17.212 --> 00:25:21.846
>> Right, and that brings a good point
about Lean Six Sigma cuz Lean Six Sigma

479
00:25:21.846 --> 00:25:26.181
promotes the idea that you need to
do the things that you're best at,

480
00:25:26.181 --> 00:25:30.923
do the things where you have your
competencies and outsource other stuff.

481
00:25:30.923 --> 00:25:32.478
Let somebody else do that.

482
00:25:32.478 --> 00:25:36.948
Now in order to do this, in order to
make an existing process better, faster,

483
00:25:36.948 --> 00:25:39.816
more cost effective,
you have to develop a plan.

484
00:25:39.816 --> 00:25:43.251
You have to know your competition and
your customers.

485
00:25:43.251 --> 00:25:45.191
You have to have the right tools.

486
00:25:45.191 --> 00:25:46.676
You have to manage the plan.

487
00:25:46.676 --> 00:25:50.952
And what I think is
interesting about this is that,

488
00:25:50.952 --> 00:25:54.234
even though TQM gets the credit for it,

489
00:25:54.234 --> 00:25:58.915
General Sun from Art of War
had this down centuries ago.

490
00:25:58.915 --> 00:26:02.205
>> It's funny you mention that because in
the project management episodes that I've

491
00:26:02.205 --> 00:26:03.521
done with one of our other hosts,

492
00:26:03.521 --> 00:26:05.544
we always end up mentioning
the Art of War somehow.

493
00:26:05.544 --> 00:26:06.298
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

494
00:26:06.298 --> 00:26:07.904
>> And it's almost like managing

495
00:26:07.904 --> 00:26:10.628
a project, process improvement,
it's warfare.

496
00:26:10.628 --> 00:26:11.568
[LAUGH]
>> Right?

497
00:26:11.568 --> 00:26:13.120
It is.
>> It's you versus them.

498
00:26:13.120 --> 00:26:16.639
>> Yeah, and I think it's interesting
because a lot of times when you're

499
00:26:16.639 --> 00:26:19.470
listening to politicians,
they come up with Art of War.

500
00:26:19.470 --> 00:26:23.511
And what is the other one, Rules for
Radicals, they're saying that we.

501
00:26:23.511 --> 00:26:26.788
But it kinda seeps over into everything.

502
00:26:26.788 --> 00:26:31.912
In TQM, Total Quality Management,
something that is really important

503
00:26:31.912 --> 00:26:36.365
is the philosophies and
values about people being important.

504
00:26:36.365 --> 00:26:39.452
And that we need to listen to
the voice of the customer and

505
00:26:39.452 --> 00:26:42.486
the voice of the process and
the voice of the employee.

506
00:26:42.486 --> 00:26:45.690
All of that's the same as
it was in the 40s and 50s.

507
00:26:45.690 --> 00:26:50.673
It's just that now with Lean Six Sigma,
we have tools that can help us do that,

508
00:26:50.673 --> 00:26:54.084
again, better, faster,
and more cost effective.

509
00:26:54.084 --> 00:26:56.256
After the Industrial Revolution and

510
00:26:56.256 --> 00:27:00.877
after that kind of weird period of time
where they were experimenting on this,

511
00:27:00.877 --> 00:27:04.938
when they came up with the original,
when Deming and Joseph Juran and

512
00:27:04.938 --> 00:27:09.595
several others came up with this idea,
the tools were very people centric.

513
00:27:09.595 --> 00:27:12.173
We're gonna do things like
total quality circles,

514
00:27:12.173 --> 00:27:14.993
where we get everyone in a room
together and talk to them.

515
00:27:14.993 --> 00:27:18.005
But what's happened over
the years is that man time

516
00:27:18.005 --> 00:27:21.575
has become more expensive
than machine time.

517
00:27:21.575 --> 00:27:26.183
Back in the day, machines were really
expensive, and men weren't that expensive,

518
00:27:26.183 --> 00:27:29.712
or man labor or women labor just
wasn't that expensive, right?

519
00:27:29.712 --> 00:27:33.565
And so they could afford to do
a lot of people based things.

520
00:27:33.565 --> 00:27:38.470
So if you're a student of TQM,
it's important that you remember

521
00:27:38.470 --> 00:27:43.106
that the philosophies,
the values, people are important,

522
00:27:43.106 --> 00:27:47.051
the people who work with
the process are important.

523
00:27:47.051 --> 00:27:51.667
Our collective intelligence is
better than our single ideas,

524
00:27:51.667 --> 00:27:54.287
then I think you're in good shape.

525
00:27:54.287 --> 00:27:58.879
>> All right, so we got a chance to
see some of the belt levels we have,

526
00:27:58.879 --> 00:28:04.706
the different history that's kinda like
a back story of total quality management,

527
00:28:04.706 --> 00:28:08.419
TQM, and so
I've kind of done a good picture of that.

528
00:28:08.419 --> 00:28:12.255
Now, going forward, we still need to
learn a lot more about Lean Six Sigma and

529
00:28:12.255 --> 00:28:13.450
how we implement that.

530
00:28:13.450 --> 00:28:16.392
But from a historical perspective,
that's a pretty good rundown.

531
00:28:16.392 --> 00:28:18.947
Do you have anything else you wanted to
throw in before we wrap up the episode?

532
00:28:18.947 --> 00:28:23.485
>> No, I just wanna say that in our next
episode, we'll be talking about waste and

533
00:28:23.485 --> 00:28:26.620
defects and how that impacts
IT as well as other areas.

534
00:28:26.620 --> 00:28:27.343
>> Excellent.

535
00:28:27.343 --> 00:28:31.013
And definitely a topic we need to
understand because Lean Six Sigma does

536
00:28:31.013 --> 00:28:33.776
draw such a defined line
between those two concepts.

537
00:28:33.776 --> 00:28:35.512
So, all right, well, at that point,

538
00:28:35.512 --> 00:28:37.905
this is a pretty good spot
to wrap this episode up.

539
00:28:37.905 --> 00:28:39.761
So I hope you guys have enjoyed it so far.

540
00:28:39.761 --> 00:28:42.240
Stay tuned.
We've got more Lean Six Sigma coming down

541
00:28:42.240 --> 00:28:42.777
the line.

542
00:28:42.777 --> 00:28:46.480
But for now, signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

543
00:28:46.480 --> 00:28:47.595
>> And I'm Dr. Stern.

544
00:28:47.595 --> 00:28:49.673
>> And we'll see you next time.

545
00:28:49.673 --> 00:28:56.950
[SOUND]

episodes.description: One of the key goals of Lean Six Sigma is to identify defects and waste and then reduce/ eliminate them. It is important to understand the main functionalities of both sides where, Six Sigma concentrates on defects/ mistakes, while Lean concentrates on waste. Viewers will hear discussions about terms used in both Six Sigma and Lean as well as details of the processes involved in each and how they identify and reduce waste and defects.
episodes.title: Waste and Defects
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.674 --> 00:00:15.656
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

3
00:00:15.656 --> 00:00:17.658
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:17.658 --> 00:00:19.891
I'm your host, Don Pezet, back again
with another episode of Lean Six Sigma.

5
00:00:19.891 --> 00:00:26.775
And in this episode, we're gonna be
taking a look at waste and defects.

6
00:00:26.775 --> 00:00:28.915
We're gonna be talking
about what those are and

7
00:00:28.915 --> 00:00:32.609
really what the difference is between
the two because in a non-LSS environment,

8
00:00:32.609 --> 00:00:34.712
then we might think of
those as the same thing.

9
00:00:34.712 --> 00:00:38.473
So, we're gonna take a deep dive into
that, and get a chance to look at it, and

10
00:00:38.473 --> 00:00:40.367
here to help me with that is Dr. Stern.

11
00:00:40.367 --> 00:00:41.505
Great to have you back on the show.

12
00:00:41.505 --> 00:00:43.037
>> Thank you.
It's great to be back.

13
00:00:43.037 --> 00:00:46.451
>> And so, where do we get
started with waste and defects?

14
00:00:46.451 --> 00:00:51.014
>> Well, I think it's important,
when you're looking at Lean Six Sigma,

15
00:00:51.014 --> 00:00:55.813
to understand the key differences between
the science of Six Sigma and Lean.

16
00:00:55.813 --> 00:00:58.816
Because Six Sigma concentrates on defects,
and

17
00:00:58.816 --> 00:01:03.886
in the service world those are called
mistakes, and Lean concentrates on waste.

18
00:01:03.886 --> 00:01:09.220
And both want to eliminate, that would
be the top thing they'd wanna do,

19
00:01:09.220 --> 00:01:15.360
but if they can't eliminate it then they
definitely wanna work at reducing it.

20
00:01:15.360 --> 00:01:20.285
So when Lean and Six Sigma are combined,
when both of them are together,

21
00:01:20.285 --> 00:01:25.129
they take on sort of a whole different
profile, and they basically take

22
00:01:25.129 --> 00:01:30.000
the best of both sciences, but
it does end up being a little different.

23
00:01:30.000 --> 00:01:34.155
But I think if we take a look at
Six Sigma and then take a look at Lean,

24
00:01:34.155 --> 00:01:37.137
it makes more sense how
they combine together.

25
00:01:37.137 --> 00:01:39.691
>> All right, so
which one do we wanna start with?

26
00:01:39.691 --> 00:01:41.710
>> Let's start with Six Sigma.

27
00:01:41.710 --> 00:01:45.263
And I have a slideshow just to
kinda keep myself on track.

28
00:01:45.263 --> 00:01:50.147
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay, so the core thing about

29
00:01:50.147 --> 00:01:54.562
Six Sigma that you wanna remember
is that it identifies mistakes and

30
00:01:54.562 --> 00:01:58.124
mistakes are defects in
the manufacturing world, and

31
00:01:58.124 --> 00:02:01.842
then the reason why we're
identifying those mistakes or

32
00:02:01.842 --> 00:02:05.811
defects is that we want to reduce or
eliminate them, right?

33
00:02:05.811 --> 00:02:10.570
And that sounds pretty simple, except
that one of the big differences between

34
00:02:10.570 --> 00:02:14.042
waste and mistakes is that
mistakes are pretty obvious.

35
00:02:14.042 --> 00:02:17.854
If you go somewhere, and there's a big
hole in the wall, you're gonna say, hey,

36
00:02:17.854 --> 00:02:18.790
that's a mistake.

37
00:02:18.790 --> 00:02:23.700
Or you go somewhere and your order is
late, your fast-food order isn't on time,

38
00:02:23.700 --> 00:02:24.919
that's a mistake.

39
00:02:24.919 --> 00:02:28.727
In the waste arena,
sometimes it gets subjective.

40
00:02:28.727 --> 00:02:33.332
That's why there's not as many
tools to identify mistakes as there

41
00:02:33.332 --> 00:02:35.570
are to identify waste.

42
00:02:35.570 --> 00:02:40.050
One of the main major methods,
that was kind of repetitive.

43
00:02:40.050 --> 00:02:43.306
>> [LAUGH]
>> One of the big things in Six Sigma is

44
00:02:43.306 --> 00:02:45.010
to reduce variation.

45
00:02:45.010 --> 00:02:48.284
Another way to say that is to standardize.

46
00:02:48.284 --> 00:02:52.815
So there is a thought in the Six Sigma
world that if I take a process and

47
00:02:52.815 --> 00:02:56.086
I standardize it,
it's not all over the place.

48
00:02:56.086 --> 00:02:59.057
I could have an automatic
process improvement.

49
00:02:59.057 --> 00:03:02.934
But even if I don't have
an automatic process improvement,

50
00:03:02.934 --> 00:03:07.038
I've leveled the playing field,
so the next attempt to roll out

51
00:03:07.038 --> 00:03:11.538
the improvement isn't going to be
like up and down all over the board.

52
00:03:11.538 --> 00:03:14.137
I'm at least gonna get
everyone at a level place.

53
00:03:14.137 --> 00:03:15.067
Does that make sense?

54
00:03:15.067 --> 00:03:18.871
>> Absolutely, and just to put this
into a kind of a timely reference,

55
00:03:18.871 --> 00:03:22.610
we went to lunch today at a Mexican
restaurant that's nearby that I

56
00:03:22.610 --> 00:03:25.972
like them not because it's
the greatest food in the world.

57
00:03:25.972 --> 00:03:29.154
There's been a reference out there,
but they're very consistent.

58
00:03:29.154 --> 00:03:32.334
That every time I go, the food is at
the same level of quality and I really

59
00:03:32.334 --> 00:03:36.044
appreciate that because sometimes you go
to a restaurant and they have great food,

60
00:03:36.044 --> 00:03:39.012
and you go back a week later and
have a very different experience and

61
00:03:39.012 --> 00:03:41.344
very poor food, and
it kinda ruins the whole thing.

62
00:03:41.344 --> 00:03:46.050
So having that standardized experience
each time helps to, like in this case,

63
00:03:46.050 --> 00:03:48.452
build up an established customer base.

64
00:03:48.452 --> 00:03:53.373
>> And to echo what Don is saying, I do
a lot of traveling all over United States,

65
00:03:53.373 --> 00:03:55.116
Europe and Australia, and

66
00:03:55.116 --> 00:03:59.461
I can tell when the housekeepers
have a checklist to clean the room.

67
00:03:59.461 --> 00:04:00.529
You can tell.

68
00:04:00.529 --> 00:04:04.968
I mean that, sometimes I go to hotels and
the cleanliness of the room is all over

69
00:04:04.968 --> 00:04:08.012
the board, but
you can tell the ones that have a list.

70
00:04:08.012 --> 00:04:11.239
So, sometimes you have this
automatic process improvement.

71
00:04:11.239 --> 00:04:13.362
So, in order to do that,

72
00:04:13.362 --> 00:04:18.945
what happens is that Six Sigma
depends on a number of statistics.

73
00:04:18.945 --> 00:04:23.810
And most of the statistics that are used
in Six Sigma, have to do with variation.

74
00:04:23.810 --> 00:04:27.315
I have to identify the variation
to do a variation study.

75
00:04:27.315 --> 00:04:29.917
And then I have to analyze the variation.

76
00:04:29.917 --> 00:04:34.616
Because if I´m gonna reduce it, I have
to at least understand where it´s at.

77
00:04:34.616 --> 00:04:38.840
There´s lots of different ways when
you´re thinking about Six Sigma,

78
00:04:38.840 --> 00:04:41.483
some of the terms, variation, obviously.

79
00:04:41.483 --> 00:04:45.681
But there's a lot of ways that I can look
at variation, and one of them is Sigma.

80
00:04:45.681 --> 00:04:50.224
And Sigma has six levels, and we're gonna
talk a little bit about Sigma later.

81
00:04:50.224 --> 00:04:54.196
But if there's six levels and
you're at a three Sigma and

82
00:04:54.196 --> 00:04:57.192
go to four Sigma, then you've improved.

83
00:04:57.192 --> 00:05:02.904
Now the reason why I mention that is,
if you're familiar with RPNs,

84
00:05:02.904 --> 00:05:07.534
Risk, wow, Risk,
[INAUDIBLE] Risk Priority Numbers,

85
00:05:07.534 --> 00:05:12.668
what happens is,
that number you're trying to make go down.

86
00:05:12.668 --> 00:05:17.531
So, like an RPN would look at things
like severity, detection, occurrence,

87
00:05:17.531 --> 00:05:19.209
and you would get a number.

88
00:05:19.209 --> 00:05:23.512
And the idea behind the RPN is,
I'm trying to make that number go down or

89
00:05:23.512 --> 00:05:25.976
I'm trying to make Sigma go up, right?

90
00:05:25.976 --> 00:05:30.865
So, another term that you hear
in Six Sigma a lot is DMAIC, and

91
00:05:30.865 --> 00:05:36.615
we're gonna be working through
the DMAIC model in different episodes.

92
00:05:36.615 --> 00:05:40.626
DMAIC stands for Define, Measure,
Analyze, Improve, and Control.

93
00:05:40.626 --> 00:05:44.439
And it said, just like I said DMAIC,
the probably the worst mistake that

94
00:05:44.439 --> 00:05:47.499
Lean Six Sigma people make off the bat,
right off the bat,

95
00:05:47.499 --> 00:05:51.153
is they'll call it like the DMAIC or
they'll have some other words.

96
00:05:51.153 --> 00:05:54.080
So just kinda think that DMAIC, and

97
00:05:54.080 --> 00:05:58.479
another term you hear a lot
in Six Sigma is root cause.

98
00:05:58.479 --> 00:06:02.398
So Six Sigma concentrates
on reducing variation,

99
00:06:02.398 --> 00:06:05.047
or in other words standardizing.

100
00:06:05.047 --> 00:06:08.645
To do that it depends on
a number of statistics.

101
00:06:08.645 --> 00:06:12.228
Now, a lot of times in a Six Sigma class,

102
00:06:12.228 --> 00:06:16.561
you're basically taking a statistics 101.

103
00:06:16.561 --> 00:06:19.310
And Lean,
they're a little bit more forgiving, and

104
00:06:19.310 --> 00:06:22.010
they let you use templates and
Excel spreadsheets.

105
00:06:22.010 --> 00:06:26.430
Even in Six Sigma, they're working
things out on a worksheet, but there's

106
00:06:26.430 --> 00:06:31.136
a kind of a, I don't know, attention paid
to how this statistic actually works.

107
00:06:31.136 --> 00:06:35.362
So, a Six Sigma program,
a lot of times when you hear pushback,

108
00:06:35.362 --> 00:06:38.429
is because it's so statistically oriented.

109
00:06:38.429 --> 00:06:42.021
In Lean Six Sigma projects,
which we'll also talk about later,

110
00:06:42.021 --> 00:06:45.296
those projects aren't quite
as big as Six Sigma projects.

111
00:06:45.296 --> 00:06:50.176
Six Sigma, the paradigm right
now is if it doesn't save, make,

112
00:06:50.176 --> 00:06:53.551
or avoid spending about $250,000,

113
00:06:53.551 --> 00:06:57.834
then it's probably not worthy
of a Six Sigma attention.

114
00:06:57.834 --> 00:07:01.068
So, there's a lot of companies that,
at the end of the year after they paid all

115
00:07:01.068 --> 00:07:03.530
their bills,
they'd be happy to make $250,000.

116
00:07:03.530 --> 00:07:08.591
So one of the things that Lean brings
to the Lean Six Sigma party is

117
00:07:08.591 --> 00:07:13.557
it says we could use a lot of
the basic Six Sigma principles, and

118
00:07:13.557 --> 00:07:19.110
just scale it down a bit so that we
can work with it on smaller projects.

119
00:07:19.110 --> 00:07:21.317
>> I know I've read
similar things out there.

120
00:07:21.317 --> 00:07:24.358
I read an article a while back
talking about Motorola, and

121
00:07:24.358 --> 00:07:27.163
how they don't actually strive for
a true Six Sigma.

122
00:07:27.163 --> 00:07:31.971
There's more like a four and a half or
something, cuz that's really where

123
00:07:31.971 --> 00:07:36.490
you start to hit that cost to benefit
break for a lot of smaller things.

124
00:07:36.490 --> 00:07:41.149
>> Yeah, and that's a good point because
in the manufacturing environment,

125
00:07:41.149 --> 00:07:45.317
a lot of times they use a different
calculation which is called Cpk.

126
00:07:45.317 --> 00:07:49.262
And as you know, whenever you see
the small K on something like that,

127
00:07:49.262 --> 00:07:51.584
that means it's a schedule or an index.

128
00:07:51.584 --> 00:07:56.905
And Cpk only has two numbers, 1 to 2, and
a lot of times in manufacturing they'll

129
00:07:56.905 --> 00:08:01.921
say, we're gonna shoot for a 1.33 Cpk,
which is equivalent to four sigma

130
00:08:01.921 --> 00:08:07.108
because sometimes we could make parts
better than what they're gonna fit into.

131
00:08:07.108 --> 00:08:09.035
So, absolutely.

132
00:08:09.035 --> 00:08:12.288
So, in the Lean environment what we're

133
00:08:12.288 --> 00:08:17.177
concentrating on is identifying waste and
reducing waste.

134
00:08:17.177 --> 00:08:19.104
We've said that several different times.

135
00:08:19.104 --> 00:08:23.660
But Lean has a little bit
more attention to people.

136
00:08:23.660 --> 00:08:27.761
Now, it's not that the Six Sigma body of
knowledge which is basically managed by

137
00:08:27.761 --> 00:08:32.046
the American Society of Quality, it's not
that it doesn't mention anything about

138
00:08:32.046 --> 00:08:35.083
people, there's just not that
concentration on people.

139
00:08:35.083 --> 00:08:38.798
It's just not strongly addressed
in their body of knowledge.

140
00:08:38.798 --> 00:08:42.631
Whereas, Lean has kind of the belief
that you can do everything right.

141
00:08:42.631 --> 00:08:47.277
But if you don't have the right people on
board or you don't have the right buy-in,

142
00:08:47.277 --> 00:08:51.087
or you don't have the right motivation
your project can still fail.

143
00:08:51.087 --> 00:08:54.122
The Project Management Institute
often does surveys and

144
00:08:54.122 --> 00:08:56.334
they found over the years consistently,

145
00:08:56.334 --> 00:09:00.204
that of the projects that fail,
most of them fail because of the people.

146
00:09:00.204 --> 00:09:03.522
And what's staggering about that
is that it's not the budget,

147
00:09:03.522 --> 00:09:07.955
it's not the intellectual capital, it's
people issues of the projects that fail.

148
00:09:07.955 --> 00:09:13.843
So Lean says, paying attention to
people is really, really important.

149
00:09:13.843 --> 00:09:19.175
The other thing that Lean talks a lot
about is value to the customer.

150
00:09:19.175 --> 00:09:22.849
It used to be, and I'm sure you may have
remembered hearing this at one point in

151
00:09:22.849 --> 00:09:25.085
your life,
that the customer is always right.

152
00:09:25.085 --> 00:09:26.873
We're supposed to serve the customer.

153
00:09:26.873 --> 00:09:31.143
Over the years a lot of
that has kind of gone away.

154
00:09:31.143 --> 00:09:35.649
For example, I live in a mountain
town that used to be kind of small.

155
00:09:35.649 --> 00:09:37.297
It's grown over the years.

156
00:09:37.297 --> 00:09:41.932
But we had a bank that was really
served the mountain clientele.

157
00:09:41.932 --> 00:09:46.572
It had donuts, and it had this great
place where you could weigh, and

158
00:09:46.572 --> 00:09:51.694
the restroom was always open to you,
and there was always these magazines,

159
00:09:51.694 --> 00:09:54.433
and they did all kinds of special stuff.

160
00:09:54.433 --> 00:09:56.964
And then over the years
a lot of that went away.

161
00:09:56.964 --> 00:10:00.801
It's a very sterile environment,
they don't have donuts on Friday anymore,

162
00:10:00.801 --> 00:10:04.236
you have to go get a key for the restroom,
there's no way to use a phone,

163
00:10:04.236 --> 00:10:05.226
that type of thing.

164
00:10:05.226 --> 00:10:08.917
And so they took away a lot of
the customer value and as a result,

165
00:10:08.917 --> 00:10:12.957
we now have eight banks in my community
that can really support two and

166
00:10:12.957 --> 00:10:17.504
might have just stuck with one if they
continued on with that customer value.

167
00:10:17.504 --> 00:10:21.291
So Lean has a big focus on spending
time with the customer and

168
00:10:21.291 --> 00:10:24.624
really, Lean believes that
the only way you know for

169
00:10:24.624 --> 00:10:28.439
sure that you're successful
is if the customer's happy.

170
00:10:28.439 --> 00:10:33.197
So Six Sigma, a lot of times, and
one of the things that people talk about

171
