00:10:33.197 --> 00:10:37.955
Six Sigma is a lot of times Six Sigma
bases its decisions on the numbers and

172
00:10:37.955 --> 00:10:40.072
the statistics and the graphs.

173
00:10:40.072 --> 00:10:44.897
Lean says hey that's pretty important,
but the people side is also important.

174
00:10:44.897 --> 00:10:49.109
And then the other thing that lean
does is it identifies something called

175
00:10:49.109 --> 00:10:53.458
the value stream, and when you hear
the word value stream, what that means

176
00:10:53.458 --> 00:10:57.626
is it looks at a product or a service,
and it basically cradle to grave.

177
00:10:57.626 --> 00:11:00.203
What are all the different things
that happen in this stream?

178
00:11:00.203 --> 00:11:02.501
What are all the people that are touched?

179
00:11:02.501 --> 00:11:05.874
What are all the steps,
in between steps, and

180
00:11:05.874 --> 00:11:11.682
sometimes value streams will even be
subject to something called a gemba walk.

181
00:11:11.682 --> 00:11:15.639
I think I mentioned that in another
episode, a lot of times in Lean,

182
00:11:15.639 --> 00:11:17.800
they kind of use the Japanese words.

183
00:11:17.800 --> 00:11:22.445
A gemba walk is where we walk the value
stream or any process, actually,

184
00:11:22.445 --> 00:11:25.351
it doesn't even have to
be the value stream.

185
00:11:25.351 --> 00:11:29.401
And it's advised that you take
a couple of people with you so

186
00:11:29.401 --> 00:11:34.840
that it's not just your opinion, because
sometimes you can be kind of biased.

187
00:11:34.840 --> 00:11:39.689
And the idea is that in Lean sometimes
they even call it staple yourself

188
00:11:39.689 --> 00:11:40.683
to the floor.

189
00:11:40.683 --> 00:11:43.237
>> [LAUGH] A little graphic there.

190
00:11:43.237 --> 00:11:46.745
>> Yeah, so then you see all
the steps that the form went through.

191
00:11:46.745 --> 00:11:52.037
Now echoing what I just said about
the Japanese terms, in Six Sigma you hear

192
00:11:52.037 --> 00:11:57.679
words at least that you've heard of
before, such as root cause and variation.

193
00:11:57.679 --> 00:12:01.553
Those are words that even if you
don't work Work with every day,

194
00:12:01.553 --> 00:12:04.995
you can kinda guess what they mean,
but on the lean side,

195
00:12:04.995 --> 00:12:09.747
you're likely to hear terms like Jidoka,
Heijunka, Poka-yoke, Kaizen.

196
00:12:09.747 --> 00:12:14.390
And I'm not going to go through
all the lean terms right now.

197
00:12:14.390 --> 00:12:17.100
But I just wanna give you kinda the high
level idea of what they mean so

198
00:12:17.100 --> 00:12:18.254
that they're not so scary.

199
00:12:20.414 --> 00:12:24.220
There are some popular
terms that aren't Japanese,

200
00:12:24.220 --> 00:12:27.190
standard work and value stream mapping.

201
00:12:27.190 --> 00:12:29.174
So I do wanna throw
that out there as well,

202
00:12:29.174 --> 00:12:32.602
that even though there's a lot of
terms in Just Lean that are Japanese.

203
00:12:32.602 --> 00:12:36.317
There's also non-Japanese terms as well.

204
00:12:36.317 --> 00:12:41.221
I know a lot of you are already saying,
if I take the exam which is available on

205
00:12:41.221 --> 00:12:46.451
the SSD global website, if I take the exam
am I gonna have to remember all of that?

206
00:12:46.451 --> 00:12:52.411
And remember it's open book, and just
like any other exam you have to study for

207
00:12:52.411 --> 00:12:58.657
it, but nobody expects you to remember or
know how to spell these Japanese words.

208
00:12:58.657 --> 00:13:02.731
So the first word we're
gonna talk about is jidoka.

209
00:13:02.731 --> 00:13:07.175
And one of the things I may
have forgotten to point out,

210
00:13:07.175 --> 00:13:12.102
is that a lot of the terms are named
after the people who either

211
00:13:12.102 --> 00:13:16.852
popularized the term, or
they created the actual graph.

212
00:13:16.852 --> 00:13:20.430
In this case, these are,
the ones that we're looking at,

213
00:13:20.430 --> 00:13:22.299
are actually Japanese words.

214
00:13:22.299 --> 00:13:27.637
So jidoka is just where we're
identifying defects in the process,

215
00:13:27.637 --> 00:13:29.705
and we're halting work.

216
00:13:29.705 --> 00:13:35.721
Now that sounds kind of simplistic, but
one of the main laws of lean six sigma or

217
00:13:35.721 --> 00:13:40.916
I mean rather lean cuz we're kind of
on the lean side is that if you see

218
00:13:40.916 --> 00:13:47.330
something wrong, you want to stop and fix
it right then before are moving forward.

219
00:13:47.330 --> 00:13:49.896
You're trying to keep things off WIP,

220
00:13:49.896 --> 00:13:55.050
which some people call work in progress,
some people call it work in process.

221
00:13:55.050 --> 00:13:59.940
And IT sometimes they even call it TIPs,
things in progress or things in process.

222
00:13:59.940 --> 00:14:04.476
So the idea, one of the key kind
of philosophies in Lean is stop,

223
00:14:04.476 --> 00:14:06.156
fix it before you go on.

224
00:14:11.656 --> 00:14:15.184
My slide is being a little
persnickety here.

225
00:14:15.184 --> 00:14:16.902
Heijunka.

226
00:14:16.902 --> 00:14:19.070
Now that's load leveling, and

227
00:14:19.070 --> 00:14:24.612
what that means is that if the production
doesn't match what the customer wants,

228
00:14:24.612 --> 00:14:30.450
and we have to look at fluctuation, and
this is just another example of waste.

229
00:14:30.450 --> 00:14:34.610
If I'm not producing on a timely manner,
and of course,

230
00:14:34.610 --> 00:14:40.160
this is kind of industry-specific
because a lot of things

231
00:14:40.160 --> 00:14:45.590
have to be made right away and other
things can have kind of a shelf life.

232
00:14:45.590 --> 00:14:47.790
But just kind of thinking about that,
that's what this one's about.

233
00:14:48.900 --> 00:14:51.339
So you can see they're really
pretty simplistic thoughts.

234
00:14:51.339 --> 00:14:57.864
And poka-yoke,
actually it's called poka-joke.

235
00:14:57.864 --> 00:14:59.442
I've heard it said a lot
of different ways.

236
00:14:59.442 --> 00:15:02.806
And this slide's a really good
example of not mistake proofing but

237
00:15:02.806 --> 00:15:06.828
[LAUGH] I'm not exactly sure what's going
on with these slides but we're almost

238
00:15:06.828 --> 00:15:10.849
through them and like I said I just wanted
to give you an idea of some of these words

239
00:15:10.849 --> 00:15:14.663
that they're not scary and they're
not really difficult to understand.

240
00:15:14.663 --> 00:15:18.867
It's just because we're using the Japanese
terms sometimes they're harder to recall.

241
00:15:18.867 --> 00:15:23.800
Poka-yoke is error proofing and as you see
on your bullets there's different ways

242
00:15:23.800 --> 00:15:27.970
that we can error proof and I'll just
give you a second to look at that.

243
00:15:27.970 --> 00:15:32.005
This is one of those things that is a
collateral on your student files, and it's

244
00:15:32.005 --> 00:15:36.119
gonna give you step by step instructions
on how you go about mistake-proofing.

245
00:15:36.119 --> 00:15:41.125
A lot of times in Lean Six Sigma,
you will hear the term mistake-proofing

246
00:15:41.125 --> 00:15:45.645
as opposed to Poka-yoke, and
that goes back to what I was saying,

247
00:15:45.645 --> 00:15:49.629
is that Lean Six Sigma's
trying to simplify everything.

248
00:15:49.629 --> 00:15:52.870
Now, Kaizen is a really interesting one.

249
00:15:52.870 --> 00:15:56.950
And you'll notice that events is bolded
because Kaizen really just means

250
00:15:56.950 --> 00:16:00.990
continually making everything better,
involving everyone.

251
00:16:00.990 --> 00:16:01.845
That's the purpose of the word.

252
00:16:01.845 --> 00:16:07.451
But as of late you might have
heard the term Kaizen events.

253
00:16:07.451 --> 00:16:12.990
And Kaizen event in the Six Sigma world is
referred to as a rapid improvement event.

254
00:16:12.990 --> 00:16:16.762
And what that means is that I have
to pick something immediately.

255
00:16:16.762 --> 00:16:22.004
Like, there's a problem on the warehouse
floor that stopped production, there's

256
00:16:22.004 --> 00:16:26.900
a form that wasn't filled out so I can't
get my medical device on to the market.

257
00:16:26.900 --> 00:16:28.222
I need to do something.

258
00:16:28.222 --> 00:16:30.696
I need a quick fix, basically.

259
00:16:30.696 --> 00:16:33.250
And I need it in as real time as possible.

260
00:16:33.250 --> 00:16:36.869
So the way Kaizen events and
rapid improvement events work, and

261
00:16:36.869 --> 00:16:40.823
sometimes you'll hear people refer
to them as we're doing a Kaizen,

262
00:16:40.823 --> 00:16:45.111
which just means a Kaizen event,
is that we're working through a model that

263
00:16:45.111 --> 00:16:49.493
we would normally have a long time to
work through, in a short period of time.

264
00:16:49.493 --> 00:16:53.859
So we're doing the same steps of models
that we'll be talking about later.

265
00:16:53.859 --> 00:16:58.324
Plan, do, check, act, PDCA, or
the DMAIC, define, measure, analyze,

266
00:16:58.324 --> 00:16:59.622
improve and control.

267
00:16:59.622 --> 00:17:02.945
We're taking those models that
typically we would have a lot of time

268
00:17:02.945 --> 00:17:04.343
to work through each phase,

269
00:17:04.343 --> 00:17:07.740
and we're trying to work through
the basics as quickly as possible.

270
00:17:07.740 --> 00:17:11.003
Typically, a Kaizen event
takes about five days.

271
00:17:11.003 --> 00:17:14.052
If it's something on
the manufacturing floor,

272
00:17:14.052 --> 00:17:16.960
sometimes that thing can
be fixed right away.

273
00:17:16.960 --> 00:17:21.531
If it's something in IT or in the service
side, usually what happens at

274
00:17:21.531 --> 00:17:25.718
the end of the Kaizen event,
you get a really good project plan and

275
00:17:25.718 --> 00:17:30.774
you have all the buy in and you can hand
that project plan to someone to execute.

276
00:17:30.774 --> 00:17:34.501
So the idea of a Kaizen event on
the service or IT side is we're going to

277
00:17:34.501 --> 00:17:39.070
bring all the players together, we're
going to quickly work through the project,

278
00:17:39.070 --> 00:17:41.513
we're going to come up
with a project plan and

279
00:17:41.513 --> 00:17:44.886
we're going to give that project
manager all the authority.

280
00:17:44.886 --> 00:17:47.892
There's nothing there that they need
to come back and ask department heads,

281
00:17:47.892 --> 00:17:48.778
can I have this money?

282
00:17:48.778 --> 00:17:49.765
Can I have this resource?

283
00:17:49.765 --> 00:17:51.344
So that's what I'm working on.

284
00:17:51.344 --> 00:17:54.257
But, oddly enough, that's not enough.

285
00:17:54.257 --> 00:17:57.092
We now have something called
mini-Kaizan events and

286
00:17:57.092 --> 00:18:00.748
mini-Kaizan events happen in about
a two and a half day time period.

287
00:18:00.748 --> 00:18:02.931
And there's no firm or fast law on this.

288
00:18:02.931 --> 00:18:06.781
But keep in mind, a typical Kaisan
event's about five days, and

289
00:18:06.781 --> 00:18:11.410
a mini-Kaisan event can be anywhere from
a day and a half to two and a half days.

290
00:18:11.410 --> 00:18:12.599
But same theory.
We're taking the model.

291
00:18:12.599 --> 00:18:15.049
We're working through
the logic of the model.

292
00:18:15.049 --> 00:18:16.894
But we're just doing it very quickly.

293
00:18:16.894 --> 00:18:20.834
>> Now, those were some Japanese terms,
but they're not all Japanese terms, right,

294
00:18:20.834 --> 00:18:23.971
there's plenty of regular English
terms involved in the process?

295
00:18:23.971 --> 00:18:24.646
>> There is.

296
00:18:24.646 --> 00:18:28.988
For example, Standard Work and
Value Stream Mapping.

297
00:18:28.988 --> 00:18:30.565
We just talked about value streams.

298
00:18:30.565 --> 00:18:35.268
But Value Stream Mapping is when
I actually articulate on paper

299
00:18:35.268 --> 00:18:36.784
that value stream.

300
00:18:36.784 --> 00:18:40.476
As a reminder, I'm looking at a product or
service cradle to grave.

301
00:18:40.476 --> 00:18:45.409
Standard Work is, sometimes you hear
Standard Work in other disciplines.

302
00:18:45.409 --> 00:18:48.357
Like an engineering field.

303
00:18:48.357 --> 00:18:51.759
And standard work is essentially,
this is the way that we're doing it.

304
00:18:51.759 --> 00:18:53.796
It's kind of like a best practice, but

305
00:18:53.796 --> 00:18:56.465
it's really just documenting
what you've done.

306
00:18:56.465 --> 00:18:58.884
So if the person behind you
has to do the same thing,

307
00:18:58.884 --> 00:19:00.472
they can go to the standard work.

308
00:19:00.472 --> 00:19:05.100
Now as I make improvements to the standard
work, then that becomes the standard,

309
00:19:05.100 --> 00:19:06.320
if that makes sense.

310
00:19:06.320 --> 00:19:08.886
>> So these got to be standard?

311
00:19:08.886 --> 00:19:10.210
>> That's right.

312
00:19:11.350 --> 00:19:15.704
And you might be asking yourself, do I
need to remember all of this for an exam?

313
00:19:15.704 --> 00:19:20.726
Just kinda keep in mind that it is open
book, and there's a study guide and

314
00:19:20.726 --> 00:19:25.910
a cheat sheet and all of that, so this
defection was really more just to kinda

315
00:19:25.910 --> 00:19:30.780
make you aware that, on the lean side,
you see a lot of Japanese words.

316
00:19:30.780 --> 00:19:33.556
Many of those Japanese words are,
for example,

317
00:19:33.556 --> 00:19:37.970
when you see something like a [INAUDIBLE]
chart where you see diagram.

318
00:19:37.970 --> 00:19:40.791
Those were named, or circle.

319
00:19:40.791 --> 00:19:45.492
These things were named after the person
who either created or popularized them,

320
00:19:45.492 --> 00:19:48.568
but there's also some just
regular Japanese words.

321
00:19:48.568 --> 00:19:51.761
But if you look at their definitions,
it's not that crazy.

322
00:19:54.477 --> 00:19:56.578
>> All right, well that's
a pretty good rundown on terms.

323
00:19:56.578 --> 00:20:00.947
Now, I know we've talked about defects and
we've talked about waste, and

324
00:20:00.947 --> 00:20:03.211
you mentioned mistakes in there also.

325
00:20:03.211 --> 00:20:04.802
Do we wanna spend some time on mistakes?

326
00:20:04.802 --> 00:20:06.609
>> Yeah, so mistakes, and again,

327
00:20:06.609 --> 00:20:10.620
remember defects are manufacturing,
mistakes are in the service side.

328
00:20:10.620 --> 00:20:15.438
Now defects are pretty easy to identify,
and I think I opened this session with

329
00:20:15.438 --> 00:20:19.236
saying if you see a hole in
the wall you know that's a mistake.

330
00:20:19.236 --> 00:20:22.345
Well we would actually probably
call that more of a defect, right?

331
00:20:22.345 --> 00:20:27.049
Mistakes and
times require a lot more research and

332
00:20:27.049 --> 00:20:31.085
a lot of conversation, a lot of dialogue.

333
00:20:31.085 --> 00:20:35.705
Because sometimes mistakes aren't,
we don't even.

334
00:20:35.705 --> 00:20:38.212
Even though there's a mistake there, so.

335
00:20:38.212 --> 00:20:41.872
>> It just goes unseen and it makes it
out there, and maybe somebody spots that

336
00:20:41.872 --> 00:20:44.907
eventually, or we do a little research and
find it on our own?

337
00:20:44.907 --> 00:20:45.673
>> Exactly.

338
00:20:45.673 --> 00:20:52.565
Now waste is a whole nother animal,
because waste is very subjective.

339
00:20:52.565 --> 00:20:54.031
What I see as waste you might not.

340
00:20:54.031 --> 00:20:58.365
So for example, if I were at a big box
store and I'm standing in line and

341
00:20:58.365 --> 00:21:02.203
I'm waiting to make a purchase,
I'm gonna call that waste.

342
00:21:02.203 --> 00:21:04.473
That's definitely waste,
that's wasting my time.

343
00:21:04.473 --> 00:21:07.497
But the big box store's already
done research that says,

344
00:21:07.497 --> 00:21:09.409
as long as you're standing in line,

345
00:21:09.409 --> 00:21:12.926
there's an average amount of time
that you would stand in line, and

346
00:21:12.926 --> 00:21:17.021
possibly buy all those myriad of products
that are there before you check out.

347
00:21:17.021 --> 00:21:19.574
So it's not really waste for them.

348
00:21:19.574 --> 00:21:23.336
I know a lot of you have probably seen
that, where you go to big box store,

349
00:21:23.336 --> 00:21:27.917
and half of the cash registers are empty,
and you're thinking, what's up with that?

350
00:21:27.917 --> 00:21:32.367
A big box store's gonna see waste in
a different way that we see waste, and so,

351
00:21:32.367 --> 00:21:36.840
there's more tools to identify waste,
then there are to identify mistakes.

352
00:21:36.840 --> 00:21:39.905
Now, in both the Six Sigma and
the Lean world,

353
00:21:39.905 --> 00:21:43.599
they are very concerned about
Critical to Quality, but

354
00:21:43.599 --> 00:21:48.565
I just want to continue with our
conversation about defects and mistakes.

355
00:21:48.565 --> 00:21:51.283
This is one of those
tests you can look at.

356
00:21:51.283 --> 00:21:56.975
Since there's lots of tools available
to help you identify waste.

357
00:21:56.975 --> 00:22:00.505
But not that many to help
identify defects and mistakes.

358
00:22:00.505 --> 00:22:02.425
I wanna address Critical to Quality.

359
00:22:02.425 --> 00:22:04.330
Now there was a movement for a while, and

360
00:22:04.330 --> 00:22:08.365
you'll see those bullet points, Critical
to Success, Critical to Satisfaction,

361
00:22:08.365 --> 00:22:12.360
certainly critical to making something
better, faster, more cost-effective.

362
00:22:12.360 --> 00:22:17.261
About ten years ago there was sort of a
bit of a movement in textbooks to call it

363
00:22:17.261 --> 00:22:21.934
Critical to Price, Critical to Speed,
Critical to Satisfaction, but

364
00:22:21.934 --> 00:22:25.687
it got just kind of crazy, so
now what's happened is CTQ,

365
00:22:25.687 --> 00:22:30.549
Critical to Quality, has become
an umbrella term for all of those things.

366
00:22:30.549 --> 00:22:36.665
And so by default customer
requirements are Critical to Quality.

367
00:22:36.665 --> 00:22:40.975
So, what the customer wants or
what their expectations,

368
00:22:40.975 --> 00:22:43.655
you might wanna give
them little extra things.

369
00:22:43.655 --> 00:22:46.138
That's another kind of
Lean Six Sigma principle.

370
00:22:46.138 --> 00:22:50.232
But what the customer wants,
by default, is a CTQ, but

371
00:22:50.232 --> 00:22:52.759
when you're looking at solving,

372
00:22:52.759 --> 00:22:57.640
when you're looking at fixing mistakes or
rectifying defects and

373
00:22:57.640 --> 00:23:02.695
even the Lean world, looking at ways,
you want to kind of consider,

374
00:23:02.695 --> 00:23:07.955
what do I need to do to make it good for
the person who's working with me.

375
00:23:07.955 --> 00:23:10.095
So, what's critical to their satisfaction.

376
00:23:10.095 --> 00:23:14.234
So, let's say I'm a facility's
director of a large college, and

377
00:23:14.234 --> 00:23:18.589
even though I have a staff and they do
all kinds of different things one of

378
00:23:18.589 --> 00:23:22.095
the things I can get zinged
on is at the campuses, right?

379
00:23:22.095 --> 00:23:27.615
So, that's certainly critical
to quality to my job, right?

380
00:23:27.615 --> 00:23:31.331
The feeling is almost
a little Steve I wanna go and

381
00:23:31.331 --> 00:23:35.992
make sure that the people who clean
my campus get what they need from me.

382
00:23:35.992 --> 00:23:38.408
I need to be aware of their CTQs.

383
00:23:38.408 --> 00:23:44.107
And so Lean Six Sigma and
often says that's where we drop the ball.

384
00:23:44.107 --> 00:23:47.101
We kinda know what our CTQs are,
but we don't know what yours are.

385
00:23:47.101 --> 00:23:51.448
So, for example, if I could get zinged
because the campus isn't clean,

386
00:23:51.448 --> 00:23:54.614
even though I don't do that,
I hire a firm to do that.

387
00:23:54.614 --> 00:23:59.412
Some of their CTQs might be a list of
expectations, like we were saying,

388
00:23:59.412 --> 00:24:00.995
for maids at the hotel.

389
00:24:00.995 --> 00:24:04.505
It could be something something
like access to the campus.

390
00:24:04.505 --> 00:24:07.654
I mean, if I can't get into
the campus to clean it,

391
00:24:07.654 --> 00:24:10.985
then there could be some
security issues there.

392
00:24:10.985 --> 00:24:15.309
The reason Critical to Quality is so
important is that,

393
00:24:15.309 --> 00:24:20.653
it gives us a way to even identify
things that we should be working on.

394
00:24:20.653 --> 00:24:26.334
If we think Critical to Quality,
if we actually think in those terms,

395
00:24:26.334 --> 00:24:32.612
then often, what it will do for us is
help us identify a process improvement.

396
00:24:32.612 --> 00:24:35.093
>> Now, that whole Critical
to Quality movement, I mean,

397
00:24:35.093 --> 00:24:37.018
there's a lot that goes into that, right?

398
00:24:37.018 --> 00:24:40.800
Because there's, you named a few examples,
but to try and figure out all

399
00:24:40.800 --> 00:24:45.009
the different things that are critical to
the quality of your product or service,

400
00:24:45.009 --> 00:24:47.094
that's a major undertaking isn't it?

401
00:24:47.094 --> 00:24:49.315
>> Yeah, it is.

402
00:24:49.315 --> 00:24:52.045
And I think what you have to
do is you have to kinda think,

403
00:24:52.045 --> 00:24:55.495
you have to think from
the view of the other person.

404
00:24:55.495 --> 00:25:00.355
So if I were looking at housekeeping
at a hotel we already came up with

405
00:25:00.355 --> 00:25:02.115
Critical to Quality, they need a list but

406
00:25:02.115 --> 00:25:06.255
they also need equipment,
right, and they need schedules.

407
00:25:06.255 --> 00:25:09.489
I don't know, there's just
lots of things I'm gonna need.

408
00:25:09.489 --> 00:25:14.275
If I were a rental car agency the idea
behind this Critical to Quality is,

409
00:25:14.275 --> 00:25:17.580
I wanna think of the rental
car agency as a person.

410
00:25:17.580 --> 00:25:21.927
And I know as the person renting the car,
I want a car that's clean,

411
00:25:21.927 --> 00:25:26.597
I want a car that's gassed up,
I want a car that's ready and available.

412
00:25:26.597 --> 00:25:32.873
But if I were the rental car agency,
what would my CTQ's be?

413
00:25:32.873 --> 00:25:35.591
What do I need from being
a rental car agency?

414
00:25:35.591 --> 00:25:37.031
Do you have any ideas, Don?

415
00:25:37.031 --> 00:25:39.592
Like if you were an entity,
a rental car agency,

416
00:25:39.592 --> 00:25:41.719
what are some of the things you'd want?

417
00:25:41.719 --> 00:25:45.217
>> So, you're gonna need to have a certain
amount of vehicles on hand so that when

418
00:25:45.217 --> 00:25:48.941
the demand is there for a vehicle that
you're able to fulfill that demand, right?

419
00:25:48.941 --> 00:25:49.685
>> Exactly.

420
00:25:49.685 --> 00:25:53.329
>> And then not just number of
vehicles but variations of vehicles.

421
00:25:53.329 --> 00:25:54.615
>> Exactly.

422
00:25:54.615 --> 00:25:57.305
>> Some people might need
two seats versus five seats,

423
00:25:57.305 --> 00:26:02.305
we need an easy way to call in and book,
an easy way to pay or be invoiced,

424
00:26:02.305 --> 00:26:04.735
there's all these different
pieces that aren't just the car.

425
00:26:04.735 --> 00:26:06.971
It's easy to think like,
you gotta have just a car.

426
00:26:06.971 --> 00:26:08.504
But how do I book that?

427
00:26:08.504 --> 00:26:09.920
Can I have a corporate account?

428
00:26:09.920 --> 00:26:11.870
Do I have to pay for it individually?

429
00:26:11.870 --> 00:26:13.658
Is there an easy insurance plan?

430
00:26:13.658 --> 00:26:19.628
All of that's gonna affect the customer's
experience as they interact with that,

431
00:26:19.628 --> 00:26:20.225
right?

432
00:26:20.225 --> 00:26:24.344
>> Exactly, and what Lean Six Sigma
promotes is that if I want to be

433
00:26:24.344 --> 00:26:27.454
a successful Lean Six Sigma professional,
and

434
00:26:27.454 --> 00:26:32.352
let's say I'm the manager of the car
rental place, I want to start looking

435
00:26:32.352 --> 00:26:37.359
at things through that lens instead of
what I need in order to be successful.

436
00:26:37.359 --> 00:26:40.354
And there's just a couple of other
things that you might wanna think about.

437
00:26:40.354 --> 00:26:44.364
If you were a supermarket, certainly,
I wanna walk into the supermarket and

438
00:26:44.364 --> 00:26:47.771
get my food right away, and
I hate it when they change the aisles.

439
00:26:47.771 --> 00:26:48.933
I used to teach change management.

440
00:26:48.933 --> 00:26:50.853
>> [LAUGH]
>> But when they change things on me,

441
00:26:50.853 --> 00:26:52.068
it's just crazy, right?

442
00:26:52.068 --> 00:26:55.692
But if I were a Supermarket,
I might want a lighted parking lot.

443
00:26:55.692 --> 00:26:58.668
People might not stop by my
supermarket if it´s too dark or

444
00:26:58.668 --> 00:27:00.318
if there´s not enough spaces.

445
00:27:00.318 --> 00:27:03.615
And the same thing would be for
an hospital emergency group.

446
00:27:03.615 --> 00:27:06.482
These are just things that
kind of get you thinking.

447
00:27:06.482 --> 00:27:10.443
If you were a hospital emergency room,
or you were a supermarket,

448
00:27:10.443 --> 00:27:13.005
what are your Critical to Quality things?

449
00:27:13.005 --> 00:27:16.354
And then if you're the professional
managing a project there,

450
00:27:16.354 --> 00:27:20.385
or even managing the entire institute,
that get you some clues about what you

451
00:27:20.385 --> 00:27:24.125
can do to make process improvement,
make sure your job goes smoothly.

452
00:27:24.125 --> 00:27:27.101
>> Now, a lot of that originates with
what they call, let me just see if I can,

453
00:27:27.101 --> 00:27:28.519
I'm digging back into the little,

454
00:27:28.519 --> 00:27:30.573
the few terms that I have in
the back of my head here.

455
00:27:30.573 --> 00:27:31.733
The voice of the customer, right?

456
00:27:31.733 --> 00:27:32.361
The VOC?

457
00:27:32.361 --> 00:27:33.916
>> Oh, absolutely.

458
00:27:33.916 --> 00:27:35.170
And that's a good place to look.

459
00:27:35.170 --> 00:27:39.516
The voice of the customer's an absolutely
excellent place to look for your CTQ's.

460
00:27:39.516 --> 00:27:41.932
>> Yeah, and
we can identify a lot of them on our own.

461
00:27:41.932 --> 00:27:44.774
If you you just sit there and
do your own research, but we have a saying

462
00:27:44.774 --> 00:27:47.724
here at the studio where sometimes
we look at things through blinders.

463
00:27:47.724 --> 00:27:50.396
We look at them the way that we see them.

464
00:27:50.396 --> 00:27:54.265
Your customers might have
a very different view.

465
00:27:54.265 --> 00:27:57.142
So if you're not listening to your
customer, you're gonna lose that customer,

466
00:27:57.142 --> 00:27:59.475
and that's a big deal regardless
of whether you're in a service or

467
00:27:59.475 --> 00:28:00.408
product based industry.

468
00:28:00.408 --> 00:28:02.312
>> Exactly.

469
00:28:02.312 --> 00:28:06.395
>> All right,
well that's a pretty good run down on.

470
00:28:06.395 --> 00:28:07.060
Well, we talked about waste.

471
00:28:07.060 --> 00:28:09.223
We talked about talk about defects,
right, and

472
00:28:09.223 --> 00:28:12.295
each of the different kind of variations
of that and how they fall in.

473
00:28:12.295 --> 00:28:16.372
I know we wanted to spend some time
on the different types of waste.

474
00:28:16.372 --> 00:28:16.895
>> Right.
>> But

475
00:28:16.895 --> 00:28:20.290
we kind of ran out of time on this episode
so we'll have to push that off to the next

476
00:28:20.290 --> 00:28:23.638
one, but be aware that in Lean that they
get very detailed about the difference

477
00:28:23.638 --> 00:28:26.703
types of waste that are out there, so
we wanna make sure we cover those.

478
00:28:26.703 --> 00:28:29.275
Stay tuned,
cuz we'll do that in the next episode, but

479
00:28:29.275 --> 00:28:32.365
before we wrap this one up do you
have anything else you want to add?

480
00:28:32.365 --> 00:28:37.335
>> Just that in Lean Six Sigma, one of
the things that is promoted heavily is

481
00:28:37.335 --> 00:28:40.565
that you can no longer walk away and say,
well, I did what I was supposed to do.

482
00:28:40.565 --> 00:28:44.206
Lean Six Sigma says you have
to look at everything 360, and

483
00:28:44.206 --> 00:28:47.916
if there are people that play
into the success of your project,

484
00:28:47.916 --> 00:28:51.012
you need to understand their
CTQs to be successful.

485
00:28:51.012 --> 00:28:53.319
>> All right, well, ladies and
gentlemen, this is a good spot for

486
00:28:53.319 --> 00:28:54.240
us to wrap this one up.

487
00:28:54.240 --> 00:28:58.122
Stay tuned though, we've got more
Lean Six Sigma coming down the line.

488
00:28:58.122 --> 00:29:01.442
But for now, signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

489
00:29:01.442 --> 00:29:02.674
>> And I'm Dr. Stern.

490
00:29:02.674 --> 00:29:07.735
>> And we'll see you next time.

491
00:29:07.735 --> 00:29:10.549
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In looking through specific types of waste and how to identify it, one should have a process in which they can quickly gather their thoughts and make decisions. Viewers will hear an in-depth explanation about the structured brainstorming exercise involving the acronym "TIM WOODS" to help identify waste related with transportation, inventory, motion, waiting, over production, over processing, defects, and skills.
episodes.title: Waste and Defects Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.043 --> 00:00:10.043
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.320 --> 00:00:15.107
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening and

3
00:00:15.107 --> 00:00:17.114
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:17.114 --> 00:00:21.793
I'm your host, Don Pezet, back again
with another episode of Lean Six Sigma.

5
00:00:21.793 --> 00:00:24.704
And, this is actually
the sequel to our last episode,

6
00:00:24.704 --> 00:00:27.121
where we talked a bit about waste and
defect.

7
00:00:27.121 --> 00:00:31.272
And this time we want to take a look
at some of the very specific different

8
00:00:31.272 --> 00:00:33.077
types of waste that are there.

9
00:00:33.077 --> 00:00:36.095
And, here to help us,
we've go Doctor Stetn back on the show.

10
00:00:36.095 --> 00:00:38.718
Thanks for being with us, and
where should we get started?

11
00:00:38.718 --> 00:00:42.566
>> Well, I'd like to go ahead and
start with my Tim Woods slide,

12
00:00:42.566 --> 00:00:46.195
cuz what we're gonna talk about
is how to identify waste.

13
00:00:46.195 --> 00:00:49.213
And I have some things that
I'd like to say about that.

14
00:00:49.213 --> 00:00:53.820
First, identifying waste,
you would never want to identify waste and

15
00:00:53.820 --> 00:00:57.757
then go right to your boss and
say, I've identified waste.

16
00:00:57.757 --> 00:01:00.880
This is just a place to get started.

17
00:01:00.880 --> 00:01:05.553
You might identify a waste
that's sensitive or political,

18
00:01:05.553 --> 00:01:07.484
you don't really know.

19
00:01:07.484 --> 00:01:11.072
It's just a place to get
started about where to look,

20
00:01:11.072 --> 00:01:13.718
so it truly is an identification tool.

21
00:01:13.718 --> 00:01:16.637
We had said in an earlier
episode that mistakes and

22
00:01:16.637 --> 00:01:21.081
defects are a little bit easier to reason
out because a lot of times you can get

23
00:01:21.081 --> 00:01:23.458
everyone to agree that it's a mistake.

24
00:01:23.458 --> 00:01:27.099
So the table is on fire,
everyone's like, that's wrong and

25
00:01:27.099 --> 00:01:28.786
they wanna put the fire out.

26
00:01:28.786 --> 00:01:30.516
But waste is very subjective.

27
00:01:30.516 --> 00:01:33.458
And what we had mentioned
before was that at

28
00:01:33.458 --> 00:01:38.458
supermarkets sometimes we're waiting
in line and we see that as waste.

29
00:01:38.458 --> 00:01:41.904
But the supermarket thinks maybe
we'll buy a few items, right?

30
00:01:41.904 --> 00:01:46.977
So it gets very challenging to identify
waste because waste is subjective.

31
00:01:46.977 --> 00:01:51.300
And if you see the terms on your screen
right now, transportation and inventory,

32
00:01:51.300 --> 00:01:55.499
motion, waiting, over production,
over processing, defects and skills,

33
00:01:55.499 --> 00:01:59.980
you'll see that the first letters
of those words spell Tim Woods.

34
00:01:59.980 --> 00:02:04.838
Now, another thing that's really cool
about Lean Six Sigma is there's lots

35
00:02:04.838 --> 00:02:06.193
of things like this.

36
00:02:06.193 --> 00:02:09.403
There's lots of structured brain
storming type exercises and

37
00:02:09.403 --> 00:02:11.592
lots of things that actually spell words.

38
00:02:11.592 --> 00:02:14.328
And the value of that is
that if we're in a meeting,

39
00:02:14.328 --> 00:02:16.119
we can remember it very quickly.

40
00:02:16.119 --> 00:02:19.555
Now we're going to use Tim Woods
to help us identify waste.

41
00:02:19.555 --> 00:02:23.162
But I would like to point out that
Tim Woods can also be used as

42
00:02:23.162 --> 00:02:24.910
a orientation tool.

43
00:02:24.910 --> 00:02:27.958
I'm sure no one's been in
this situation before, but

44
00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:32.342
sometimes you go to a new job and your
just kind of parachuted into a situation.

45
00:02:32.342 --> 00:02:35.930
And you don't really know where
to start and you have to kinda,

46
00:02:35.930 --> 00:02:37.903
self-oriented, is that right?

47
00:02:37.903 --> 00:02:38.728
Is that the word?

48
00:02:38.728 --> 00:02:40.016
>> Yeah, you learn on the job,

49
00:02:40.016 --> 00:02:41.096
basically, yeah
>> And so

50
00:02:41.096 --> 00:02:43.291
if you kind of think about
these categories, and

51
00:02:43.291 --> 00:02:46.716
you look through these categories and
find out as much information as you can

52
00:02:46.716 --> 00:02:50.220
about each one of these buckets,
it's a fast way to notice what´s going on.

53
00:02:50.220 --> 00:02:54.230
It´s great for consulting, for those of
you who are in the consulting business,

54
00:02:54.230 --> 00:02:57.151
especially if you go to an industry
you know nothing about.

55
00:02:57.151 --> 00:03:01.852
If you go through these items, a lot of
times you´ll be able to understand what´s

56
00:03:01.852 --> 00:03:03.362
going on at that company.

57
00:03:03.362 --> 00:03:05.915
Sometimes, even better
than the other people.

58
00:03:05.915 --> 00:03:10.611
It´s also a mini problem-solving model,
because if someone brings a problem to me,

59
00:03:10.611 --> 00:03:14.600
I can go through this structured
brainstorming exercise and say, well,

60
00:03:14.600 --> 00:03:16.750
how does transportation contribute?

61
00:03:16.750 --> 00:03:18.596
How does inventory contribute?

62
00:03:18.596 --> 00:03:22.230
But again, we're going to use
the model to apply towards waste.

63
00:03:22.230 --> 00:03:25.917
I just want everyone to remember that
you can use this model in a lot of

64
00:03:25.917 --> 00:03:26.896
different ways.

65
00:03:26.896 --> 00:03:30.901
So I wanna point out a few things before
we start doing some exercises and

66
00:03:30.901 --> 00:03:33.520
kinda playing around
around with the models.

67
00:03:33.520 --> 00:03:36.809
Transportation in this case,
means motorized.

68
00:03:36.809 --> 00:03:39.973
Now, in some models when you
see the word transportation,

69
00:03:39.973 --> 00:03:41.627
it could mean something else.

70
00:03:41.627 --> 00:03:46.000
In this particular model, transportation
is just anything that´s motorized.

71
00:03:46.000 --> 00:03:48.930
But, motion,
which is two words down, motion.

72
00:03:48.930 --> 00:03:51.580
That would be any physical movements.

73
00:03:51.580 --> 00:03:56.136
So, the difference between transportation
and motion, is transportation is

74
00:03:56.136 --> 00:04:00.290
motorized and motion is like walking and
bending and picking up things.

75
00:04:00.290 --> 00:04:04.587
One of the really wonderful things about
structured brainstorming exercises is you

76
00:04:04.587 --> 00:04:05.744
can't do them wrong.

77
00:04:05.744 --> 00:04:09.329
They're just a way to gather
your thoughts around,

78
00:04:09.329 --> 00:04:12.106
so that you can quickly make decisions.

79
00:04:12.106 --> 00:04:17.053
A lot of things in Lean Six Sigma assumes
that you've got more than one thing going

80
00:04:17.053 --> 00:04:18.084
on in your life.

81
00:04:18.084 --> 00:04:22.305
And so, if someone throws something at
you, you can pull one of these models and

82
00:04:22.305 --> 00:04:26.222
do some structured brain storming and
at least come up with some answers.

83
00:04:26.222 --> 00:04:29.380
So inventory,
that's anything to do with inventory.

84
00:04:29.380 --> 00:04:31.910
Waiting is kind of intuitive,
that's obvious.

85
00:04:31.910 --> 00:04:36.506
Now the difference is over production and
over processing.

86
00:04:36.506 --> 00:04:38.938
Production means I made too much, and

87
00:04:38.938 --> 00:04:42.208
processing means I've
touched it too many times.

88
00:04:42.208 --> 00:04:46.308
So I think we've all been in situations
where there were too many hamburgers,

89
00:04:46.308 --> 00:04:47.061
[LAUGH] right?

90
00:04:47.061 --> 00:04:51.647
And so I don't want that hamburger
because it's been sitting out too long.

91
00:04:51.647 --> 00:04:54.130
I know you've been keeping it warm for
me, but

92
00:04:54.130 --> 00:04:57.647
they might have produced too many
hamburgers for the lunch hour.

93
00:04:57.647 --> 00:05:01.920
Over processing could be something
as simple as too many signatures.

94
00:05:01.920 --> 00:05:05.204
For example, if you're in
the medical device industry and

95
00:05:05.204 --> 00:05:08.685
you're trying to make a modification
to your medical device,

96
00:05:08.685 --> 00:05:12.519
the FDA requires a certain amount
of signatures on it, change form.

97
00:05:12.519 --> 00:05:16.618
But sometimes over the years, people's
signatures don't fall off, and you might

98
00:05:16.618 --> 00:05:20.788
have as many as 30 or 40 signatures on a
change order that really only needed four.

99
00:05:20.788 --> 00:05:23.608
So that document's been over processed.

100
00:05:23.608 --> 00:05:27.431
I travel around the country a lot,
and I often rent cars.

101
00:05:27.431 --> 00:05:31.924
One of the rental car places that I went
to had a big customer service campaign,

102
00:05:31.924 --> 00:05:36.413
and they wanted to take me out the car and
show me the trunk and show me the tires,

103
00:05:36.413 --> 00:05:37.795
how to put gas in my car.

104
00:05:37.795 --> 00:05:40.800
And then when I left they were
asking me how my experience was.

105
00:05:40.800 --> 00:05:42.554
I was over processed, right?

106
00:05:42.554 --> 00:05:45.324
So, the difference
between over production,

107
00:05:45.324 --> 00:05:50.170
we made too many, over processing,
I've touched it too many times.

108
00:05:50.170 --> 00:05:54.656
Now, defects is an interesting one
because we said what we're trying to do,

109
00:05:54.656 --> 00:05:56.807
is we're trying to identify waste.

110
00:05:56.807 --> 00:05:59.430
And here's the word defects,
it's like a sixth sigma thing, right?

111
00:05:59.430 --> 00:06:02.110
And I'm trying to identify waste.

112
00:06:02.110 --> 00:06:07.815
But in this case, the lens I'm looking
at is, if I had to do that over again,

113
00:06:07.815 --> 00:06:13.003
so for example, if I made that mistake,
what am I wasting in rework?

114
00:06:13.003 --> 00:06:15.009
And so I'm looking at it from that lens.

115
00:06:15.009 --> 00:06:18.491
And if you get there and
you identify a mistake or a defect,

116
00:06:18.491 --> 00:06:20.633
it's not like that's a bad thing.

117
00:06:20.633 --> 00:06:23.503
It's just in this particular exercise,

118
00:06:23.503 --> 00:06:27.932
I'm trying to look at what is wasted time,
rework and defects.

119
00:06:27.932 --> 00:06:29.900
And then finally, skills.

120
00:06:29.900 --> 00:06:32.914
And skills can be anything
that you think about skills.

121
00:06:32.914 --> 00:06:38.339
Cross-training, someone's doing a job
that's maybe not up to their competency or

122
00:06:38.339 --> 00:06:41.220
their payscale, that type of thing.

123
00:06:41.220 --> 00:06:44.340
Now the words are meant to be general,
because back to what I said earlier,

124
00:06:44.340 --> 00:06:48.070
structured brainstorming,
you can't really do it wrong, so

125
00:06:48.070 --> 00:06:50.558
if you put something in
the wrong category, that's okay.

126
00:06:50.558 --> 00:06:54.063
It's just a way to quickly
gather your thoughts.

127
00:06:54.063 --> 00:06:56.582
So I'd like to try to do
a couple of exercises.

128
00:06:56.582 --> 00:07:01.484
My next slide gives you a little bit more
information about the different types

129
00:07:01.484 --> 00:07:02.160
of waste.

130
00:07:02.160 --> 00:07:07.808
So if you get stuck and you're trying to
think about a particular area of waste,

131
00:07:07.808 --> 00:07:11.447
and you can't think, well,
what are some ideas?

132
00:07:11.447 --> 00:07:16.490
This slide helps and it is included
as one of your collaterals on

133
00:07:16.490 --> 00:07:21.640
your lesson plan, both as a schematic and
actually a template.

134
00:07:21.640 --> 00:07:26.771
A lot of Lean Six Sigma tools were
meant to be paper and pencil tools,

135
00:07:26.771 --> 00:07:31.635
but they've sort of evolved into
these presentation tools, so

136
00:07:31.635 --> 00:07:34.898
you have templates for that on your files.

137
00:07:34.898 --> 00:07:42.020
So let's say for example, let's say
I was the manager of a paint store.

138
00:07:42.020 --> 00:07:45.705
And I was just a great manager and
now they've hired me for fast food.

139
00:07:45.705 --> 00:07:47.142
And they didn't hire me for

140
00:07:47.142 --> 00:07:51.462
my knowledge of fast food cuz I've never
worked in a fast food restaurant before.

141
00:07:51.462 --> 00:07:54.690
They hired me because I
was good problem solver.

142
00:07:54.690 --> 00:08:00.067
I was a great Lean Six practitioner and
now they want me to come over and

143
00:08:00.067 --> 00:08:05.649
make the fast food restaurant better,
faster, more cost effective.

144
00:08:05.649 --> 00:08:09.482
So the method I I'm gonna use first,
because this is my low-lying fruit.

145
00:08:09.482 --> 00:08:13.267
This is the easiest place for me to start,
if they don't know their problems.

146
00:08:13.267 --> 00:08:18.179
I'm going to use a waste identification
model, cuz if I can identify waste and

147
00:08:18.179 --> 00:08:21.381
then after that hopefully reduce or
eliminate it,

148
00:08:21.381 --> 00:08:25.560
I will have a quick process improvement
that I can show right away.

149
00:08:25.560 --> 00:08:29.190
And I can take this model and
apply to a simple project, but

150
00:08:29.190 --> 00:08:32.387
I'm applying it to my whole
fast food restaurant.

151
00:08:32.387 --> 00:08:38.783
So, at my fast food restaurant,
I'm thinking about transportation.

152
00:08:38.783 --> 00:08:41.805
So when I'm thinking about transportation,

153
00:08:41.805 --> 00:08:46.143
what are some things that could possibly,
I don't know for sure,

154
00:08:46.143 --> 00:08:51.343
cuz I'm just trying to get my thoughts
together, could possibly be wasteful?

155
00:08:51.343 --> 00:08:52.527
Don, do you have any ideas?

156
00:08:52.527 --> 00:08:55.591
>> I can think of one right off the top of
my head, and I'm trying to think of global

157
00:08:55.591 --> 00:08:58.622
scale here, cuz I'm sure there's
something much smaller that would work.

158
00:08:58.622 --> 00:09:01.805
But Toyota just went through
this not too long ago,

159
00:09:01.805 --> 00:09:04.926
where they would manufacture
cars over in Japan.

160
00:09:04.926 --> 00:09:07.237
And then they'd stick them
on giant freight liners.

161
00:09:07.237 --> 00:09:08.016
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

162
00:09:08.016 --> 00:09:11.623
they would travel across the Pacific ocean
to the United States to be sold over here.

163
00:09:11.623 --> 00:09:13.566
So when you bought a car
here in the United States,

164
00:09:13.566 --> 00:09:15.758
it had actually been on a two
month boat ride to get here.

165
00:09:15.758 --> 00:09:18.879
>> [LAUGH]
>> And so they said, wouldn't it be better

166
00:09:18.879 --> 00:09:22.870
if we just manufactured those cars in
the United States, and then that way, when

167
00:09:22.870 --> 00:09:26.765
somebody wants to buy a car, it actually
came from the factory that was there.

168
00:09:26.765 --> 00:09:29.464
And kind of eliminated that
two month boat ride and

169
00:09:29.464 --> 00:09:32.556
that was evaluated as basically
a type of waste for them.

170
00:09:32.556 --> 00:09:35.458
They were wasting two months from
manufacturing a vehicle to selling it.

171
00:09:35.458 --> 00:09:38.518
And I know what you're probably
thinking is, it's not really waste,

172
00:09:38.518 --> 00:09:41.785
they made a car, they sold a car, who
cares if it was on a boat for two months?

173
00:09:41.785 --> 00:09:47.735
But for two months, they had money tied up
in that vehicle that is stuck in transit,

174
00:09:47.735 --> 00:09:50.119
they can't do anything with it.

175
00:09:50.119 --> 00:09:52.679
And then once it gets here
ashore then they can sell it and

176
00:09:52.679 --> 00:09:53.939
they get their money back.

177
00:09:53.939 --> 00:09:57.224
By manufacturing it here in the US,
they can sell it that much faster,

178
00:09:57.224 --> 00:10:00.396
which meant they didn't have to
leave money sitting in inventory,

179
00:10:00.396 --> 00:10:01.915
that they could get it back out.

180
00:10:01.915 --> 00:10:02.518
>> That's perfect.

181
00:10:02.518 --> 00:10:07.703
And the same thing happens if you were
working in a fast food restaurant,

182
00:10:07.703 --> 00:10:10.934
a lot of those containers
are made overseas.

183
00:10:10.934 --> 00:10:14.040
The styrofoam,
I don't we use styrofoam anymore, but

184
00:10:14.040 --> 00:10:17.355
there's a lot of things like that,
that are transported.

185
00:10:17.355 --> 00:10:22.138
We could probably find a local
supplier and use them here, right?

186
00:10:22.138 --> 00:10:24.883
And some other transportation things,

187
00:10:24.883 --> 00:10:30.380
if you are thinking about a fast food
restaurant, maybe a drive-thru, right?

188
00:10:30.380 --> 00:10:32.179
I mean that's transportation?

189
00:10:32.179 --> 00:10:36.556
>> It is, yeah,
versus people coming inside the building.

190
00:10:36.556 --> 00:10:41.653
And in that standpoint I kind of look at
it and think, well, who's waste is that?

191
00:10:41.653 --> 00:10:43.417
Is it waste for the restaurant?

192
00:10:43.417 --> 00:10:47.097
Do they necessarily care whether you come
inside or come through the drive through?

193
00:10:47.097 --> 00:10:49.593
Or is it waste for the customer?

194
00:10:49.593 --> 00:10:52.298
It's kind of a tough one to measure.

195
00:10:52.298 --> 00:10:54.596
In a way you can see
where they both waste.

196
00:10:54.596 --> 00:11:01.992
Yeah, anytime you have that, not just
moving piece but actual transportation.

197
00:11:01.992 --> 00:11:04.870
I'm trying to think of other examples
that are on a smaller scale.

198
00:11:04.870 --> 00:11:10.168
>> Yeah, well let's go ahead and just move
to inventory, because the idea is that

199
00:11:10.168 --> 00:11:15.249
these categories aren't going to apply
to every project or to every place.

200
00:11:15.249 --> 00:11:19.231
It's just kind of a rundown list, and
you don't really have to do them in order.

201
00:11:19.231 --> 00:11:23.260
Tim Woods is just a way so that you
don't forget the different categories.

202
00:11:23.260 --> 00:11:29.247
And I think we can probably think of a lot
of things inventory-wise in fast food,

203
00:11:29.247 --> 00:11:34.632
like storage, and anything that's
related to inventory in fast food.

204
00:11:34.632 --> 00:11:37.790
>> Yeah,
anytime you sell a product, right?

205
00:11:37.790 --> 00:11:40.646
Inventory equals liability.

206
00:11:40.646 --> 00:11:42.035
>> Exactly.

207
00:11:42.035 --> 00:11:45.665
>> Especially if it's like fast food,
where you've got a consumable or

208
00:11:45.665 --> 00:11:46.335
a perishable, right?

209
00:11:46.335 --> 00:11:50.343
Where, if you sell apples,
how long is that apple good for?

210
00:11:50.343 --> 00:11:51.167
>> Exactly.

211
00:11:51.167 --> 00:11:51.862
>> It's gonna go bad.

212
00:11:51.862 --> 00:11:55.240
I actually don't know how long,
lets just say it's two weeks, right?

213
00:11:55.240 --> 00:11:57.098
>> Mm-hm.
They probably pump it full of chemicals

214
00:11:57.098 --> 00:11:59.304
now, it'll last for a year,
but lets say it's two weeks.

215
00:11:59.304 --> 00:12:01.083
When you have that apple,
you have two weeks to sell it.

216
00:12:01.083 --> 00:12:02.044
>> Exactly.

217
00:12:02.044 --> 00:12:05.891
>> And if it doesn't sell at the end of
two weeks, you just made your own waste.

218
00:12:05.891 --> 00:12:08.729
So you want to make sure you don't
have anymore inventory than you

219
00:12:08.729 --> 00:12:09.668
absolutely have to.

220
00:12:09.668 --> 00:12:11.967
But, what's the flip side of that coin?

221
00:12:11.967 --> 00:12:15.579
If I don't have enough inventory,
and customers start coming in and

222
00:12:15.579 --> 00:12:17.390
they want apples and I'm all out.

223
00:12:17.390 --> 00:12:19.071
I just kinda hurt my customer experience.

224
00:12:19.071 --> 00:12:19.605
>> [LAUGH] Exactly.

225
00:12:19.605 --> 00:12:20.881
Yeah, exactly.

226
00:12:20.881 --> 00:12:23.404
And so I already,
if I started a new job or

227
00:12:23.404 --> 00:12:26.161
even if I were in
the interviewing process.

228
00:12:26.161 --> 00:12:30.285
And my boss at this point would say
there are just things that are wrong,

229
00:12:30.285 --> 00:12:32.500
I don't even know how you can help me.

230
00:12:32.500 --> 00:12:35.101
I already have a couple ideas.

231
00:12:35.101 --> 00:12:37.376
So I can field those ideas too.

232
00:12:37.376 --> 00:12:38.583
So if they say where
are you going to start?

233
00:12:38.583 --> 00:12:39.674
What's you first step?

234
00:12:39.674 --> 00:12:43.250
Already just doing the T and
the I at my fast food restaurant.

235
00:12:43.250 --> 00:12:47.237
I can say, I can look at things that
we're making outside this country and

236
00:12:47.237 --> 00:12:51.567
the transportation costs to get them here
and maybe I can supply a local vendor.

237
00:12:51.567 --> 00:12:55.559
And I want to look at our inventory,
our inventory cost and

238
00:12:55.559 --> 00:12:58.310
our turnover and that type of thing.

239
00:12:58.310 --> 00:13:02.905
So another great thing about these
structured brainstorming things is

240
00:13:02.905 --> 00:13:07.417
that you literally, in just a few minutes,
can go back to your desk and

241
00:13:07.417 --> 00:13:11.566
come up with some kinda plan that
seems very seamless, I think.

242
00:13:11.566 --> 00:13:18.643
So motion in fast food there's some things
about motion that could be wasteful.

243
00:13:18.643 --> 00:13:21.452
We don't know for sure because
it's just an identification model.

244
00:13:21.452 --> 00:13:24.029
But what are some things in fast
food that might be wasteful?

245
00:13:24.029 --> 00:13:27.750
>> There is a quirky little fast food
restaurant on the other side of town,

246
00:13:27.750 --> 00:13:30.356
it's the oldest restaurant in Gainesville,
and

247
00:13:30.356 --> 00:13:33.690
it's really bizarre because
there's two buildings.

248
00:13:33.690 --> 00:13:36.602
There's one building that has
the drive thru that you pull up to and

249
00:13:36.602 --> 00:13:39.363
the people and even the cooks
are right there in that building.

250
00:13:39.363 --> 00:13:43.470
And then there's a second building, which
is where they have all of their buns and

251
00:13:43.470 --> 00:13:44.611
coolers and all that.

252
00:13:44.611 --> 00:13:46.929
>> [LAUGH]
>> So when they're making a hamburger or

253
00:13:46.929 --> 00:13:49.808
a sandwich, when they run out
of bread in the main building,

254
00:13:49.808 --> 00:13:53.549
somebody's gotta run over to the other
building to get more and bring it back.

255
00:13:53.549 --> 00:13:58.473
And it's not far away,
it's maybe 20 yards, all right?

256
00:13:58.473 --> 00:14:03.980
So not very far, or maybe 30 meters for
our metric users out there.

257
00:14:03.980 --> 00:14:05.633
So it's not too terribly far away.

258
00:14:05.633 --> 00:14:09.386
But somebody's actually got to physically
exit the building and go there and

259
00:14:09.386 --> 00:14:09.973
come back.

260
00:14:09.973 --> 00:14:11.667
What if that was just one building?

261
00:14:11.667 --> 00:14:12.630
>> Exactly.
>> What if it was right there,

262
00:14:12.630 --> 00:14:13.130
minimize the motions.

263
00:14:13.130 --> 00:14:15.452
>> Exactly,
it's something that you could look in to.

264
00:14:15.452 --> 00:14:20.381
And what's so great about Don's
example is that there's something that

265
00:14:20.381 --> 00:14:23.251
could fit in the motion and the inventory.

266
00:14:23.251 --> 00:14:27.939
And in structured brainstorming, if you

489
00:25:43.905 --> 00:25:44.425
Just like you said.

490
00:25:44.425 --> 00:25:46.234
>> Absolutely.

491
00:25:46.234 --> 00:25:47.540
And it happens all too often.

492
00:25:47.540 --> 00:25:50.148
We buy too much of something and
we buy things that we don't need.

493
00:25:50.148 --> 00:25:54.174
Then we have them in inventory, and
if they've got an expiration date,

494
00:25:54.174 --> 00:25:57.144
I know once a year we clean
out the medicine cabinet and

495
00:25:57.144 --> 00:25:59.910
throw out all sorts of
stuff that's expired.

496
00:25:59.910 --> 00:26:02.004
And it's sad because medicine is so
expensive.

497
00:26:02.004 --> 00:26:04.057
>> Yeah, exactly.
>> But that happens.

498
00:26:04.057 --> 00:26:08.737
>> And so when you think about motion,
I was just thinking one of the things,

499
00:26:08.737 --> 00:26:10.170
favors, that I did for

500
00:26:10.170 --> 00:26:14.421
myself is that I have a gymnasium
downstairs in my mountain house.

501
00:26:14.421 --> 00:26:17.903
And it's really cold there in the winter,
and I have to to really kind of way

502
00:26:17.903 --> 00:26:20.518
talk myself in to going down
there to use the treadmill.

503
00:26:20.518 --> 00:26:23.882
So I moved it up in to my office and
made a standing desk and so

504
00:26:23.882 --> 00:26:27.044
I think that motion was really,
just thinking about,

505
00:26:27.044 --> 00:26:31.513
I'm wasting time because first I'm
dreading it, and then I'm having to put

506
00:26:31.513 --> 00:26:35.877
on all those heavy clothes, and
then I'm having to go down there, right?

507
00:26:35.877 --> 00:26:41.237
So, one way that I eliminated some
waste and I think I'm more productive.

508
00:26:41.237 --> 00:26:43.605
Do you have any motion things
that happens in your house?

509
00:26:43.605 --> 00:26:45.756
>> Yeah, I'm having a hard
time thinking of that one.

510
00:26:45.756 --> 00:26:47.669
I know-
>> I guess that's a weird one.

511
00:26:47.669 --> 00:26:49.207
Its like where things are placed.

512
00:26:49.207 --> 00:26:54.087
And then two, motion is kind of
the because one of the things I try

513
00:26:54.087 --> 00:26:56.968
to do is I try to get
five miles in every day.

514
00:26:56.968 --> 00:27:00.580
So sometimes on purpose
I'm walking around, right?

515
00:27:00.580 --> 00:27:03.969
But motion a lot of times when
we're thinking about our houses,

516
00:27:03.969 --> 00:27:05.548
are where things are placed.

517
00:27:05.548 --> 00:27:08.567
So when you think about motion,
kind of think of it even bigger.

518
00:27:08.567 --> 00:27:12.743
Are the things in the garage I use most
of the time easy for me to get to or

519
00:27:12.743 --> 00:27:16.142
have I put them behind things
that I have to move around?

520
00:27:16.142 --> 00:27:18.795
So, motion kind of can encompass that.

521
00:27:18.795 --> 00:27:21.163
Do I have to go in to the other
room to answer the phone?

522
00:27:21.163 --> 00:27:21.865
That type of thing.

523
00:27:21.865 --> 00:27:23.217
Okay, so waiting.

524
00:27:23.217 --> 00:27:27.126
What are some things at home
that you're waiting for?

525
00:27:27.126 --> 00:27:29.373
>> I know, in our home,
we have two bathrooms,

526
00:27:29.373 --> 00:27:32.271
and you'd think that'd be enough but
it just isn't, and

527
00:27:32.271 --> 00:27:36.143
so sometimes the bathrooms are full and
you gotta wait to get into a bathroom.

528
00:27:36.143 --> 00:27:37.635
If we just had one more.

529
00:27:37.635 --> 00:27:38.223
I don't think you ever have

530
00:27:38.223 --> 00:27:38.761
enough bathrooms-
>> [LAUGH]

531
00:27:38.761 --> 00:27:39.774
>> Unless you have one for

532
00:27:39.774 --> 00:27:40.951
each person in the house.

533
00:27:40.951 --> 00:27:43.557
I know that's one example for us waiting.

534
00:27:43.557 --> 00:27:46.667
Or if I'm taking the kids to school,
I might be ready to go, but

535
00:27:46.667 --> 00:27:50.192
the kids are still getting ready for
school, or vice versa, they might

536
00:27:50.192 --> 00:27:54.111
be ready to go and I'm still getting
ready, so we end up waiting on each other.

537
00:27:54.111 --> 00:27:58.389
>> We do a lot of waiting in the mountains
for contractors to fix qindows, and

538
00:27:58.389 --> 00:27:59.012
do cable.

539
00:27:59.012 --> 00:28:01.299
I mean, sometimes you have
to take the whole day off.

540
00:28:01.299 --> 00:28:05.061
>> Isn't that awesome when they say we'll
be at your house sometime between noon

541
00:28:05.061 --> 00:28:05.577
and 4 PM.

542
00:28:05.577 --> 00:28:06.520
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, I know.

543
00:28:06.520 --> 00:28:07.921
It makes me crazy.

544
00:28:07.921 --> 00:28:09.088
Okay so overproduction,

545
00:28:09.088 --> 00:28:12.008
what's something at your house
that maybe you produce too much.

546
00:28:12.008 --> 00:28:18.020
I know food, I'm originally from Texas and
so I have a party and

547
00:28:18.020 --> 00:28:24.043
I just overproduce because I want
everyone to feel good about.

548
00:28:24.043 --> 00:28:26.602
And then I travel, so
the food's in the refrigerator,

549
00:28:26.602 --> 00:28:28.135
that's pretty wasteful [LAUGH].

550
00:28:28.135 --> 00:28:30.091
>> That's a great example.

551
00:28:30.091 --> 00:28:32.512
This one's kind of a tough one, isn't it?

552
00:28:32.512 --> 00:28:36.361
You could say like at the holiday season,
you over decorate the house, put way

553
00:28:36.361 --> 00:28:40.227
too much up for the amount of people that
are gonna see it, [CROSSTALK] example.

554
00:28:40.227 --> 00:28:43.716
>> Exactly, and then over-processing.

555
00:28:43.716 --> 00:28:47.780
I mean think about things that
we spend to much time doing.

556
00:28:47.780 --> 00:28:51.274
Now over processing can also be,
represent redundancy,

557
00:28:51.274 --> 00:28:55.351
like if you're constantly going
back in to turn off the coffee pot.

558
00:28:55.351 --> 00:28:58.995
Then maybe you should get a coffee
pot that turns itself off, right.

559
00:28:58.995 --> 00:29:03.890
So you kinda want to think about
processing sort of in those terms.

560
00:29:03.890 --> 00:29:08.180
And a lot of things, you know, it's not
meant to be quick, I mean we're doing it

561
00:29:08.180 --> 00:29:12.615
quickly here, but when you're at home,
I mean, these are things to think about.

562
00:29:12.615 --> 00:29:14.676
Things to talk about with your family and
things,

563
00:29:14.676 --> 00:29:18.358
if you're really trying to make your home
better, faster, and more cost-effective,

564
00:29:18.358 --> 00:29:19.597
this is a place you can start.

565
00:29:19.597 --> 00:29:23.335
Eliminating or reducing waste is
the quickest place that you can look.

566
00:29:23.335 --> 00:29:27.541
So defects, and this would be mistakes,
I mean, there's a lot of,

567
00:29:27.541 --> 00:29:29.654
my home in the mountains is older.

568
00:29:29.654 --> 00:29:32.214
I have a home on the beach
that's kind of modern.

569
00:29:32.214 --> 00:29:35.500
They don't have too many mistakes
there except beach weather.

570
00:29:35.500 --> 00:29:38.100
But my older home,
the home that I I actually live in.

571
00:29:38.100 --> 00:29:40.246
Oh my goodness.

572
00:29:40.246 --> 00:29:43.641
>> Yeah, just as your home gets older
you start to have things like equipment

573
00:29:43.641 --> 00:29:45.684
failures, appliance failures and stuff.

574
00:29:45.684 --> 00:29:49.959
But this could apply to processes
that don't work, also, right?

575
00:29:49.959 --> 00:29:54.384
So, for example, my son's school, we know
that Tuesday is library day and so in

576
00:29:54.384 --> 00:29:58.676
the morning, he's got to take his library
book from the last week in with him or

577
00:29:58.676 --> 00:29:59.996
he can't get a new one.

578
00:29:59.996 --> 00:30:03.919
And as we get him ready for school,
we might forget to put his library book in

579
00:30:03.919 --> 00:30:07.841
his backpack, and so we need a better
process to make sure that that library

580
00:30:07.841 --> 00:30:10.358
book makes it into his
backpack before he goes.

581
00:30:10.358 --> 00:30:14.579
So when that doesn't happen, it's kind
of like a defect in our process, not so

582
00:30:14.579 --> 00:30:17.918
much a defect in us [LAUGH],
I guess it sort of is, a defect in us,

583
00:30:17.918 --> 00:30:22.320
we forgot to put the backpack in there,
but that's another example.

584
00:30:22.320 --> 00:30:23.320
>> Yeah, exactly.

585
00:30:23.320 --> 00:30:26.263
And when we think about skills and
you and I were talking about

586
00:30:26.263 --> 00:30:29.204
skills a little earlier about how
there are things I can do and

587
00:30:29.204 --> 00:30:31.762
there are things I should
probably just outsource.

588
00:30:31.762 --> 00:30:33.068
[LAUGH] Right?

589
00:30:33.068 --> 00:30:34.235
>> Absolutely.

590
00:30:34.235 --> 00:30:38.632
Sometimes it's tough because you say,
I can do this, but

591
00:30:38.632 --> 00:30:41.253
do I have the time, is it worth it?

592
00:30:41.253 --> 00:30:43.116
Do I really want to mess with that?

593
00:30:43.116 --> 00:30:45.325
Sometimes other people are better
at things than you, and

594
00:30:45.325 --> 00:30:46.460
you just have to accept that.

595
00:30:46.460 --> 00:30:47.582
>> Exactly.

596
00:30:47.582 --> 00:30:51.176
So we aren't going to be able to
have the time to take every single

597
00:30:51.176 --> 00:30:54.182
Lean Six Sigma Tool and
apply it to our personal life.

598
00:30:54.182 --> 00:30:58.277
But this is just an example, so as you
move through some of the other episodes,

599
00:30:58.277 --> 00:31:01.316
I would like to challenge you
to think about those tools and

600
00:31:01.316 --> 00:31:04.379
how you can use them to improve
your personal life as well.

601
00:31:04.379 --> 00:31:08.846
>> All right well, I think that's a pretty
all encompassing run down of Tim Woods and

602
00:31:08.846 --> 00:31:11.631
the different areas that
we might identify waste,

603
00:31:11.631 --> 00:31:14.695
a pretty critical concept
as far as Lean's concerned.

604
00:31:14.695 --> 00:31:15.983
But I think that's a good spot for

605
00:31:15.983 --> 00:31:16.682
us to wrap it up-
>> Okay.

606
00:31:16.682 --> 00:31:19.101
>> Do you have anything else you want to
wanted to throw in before we wrap up?

607
00:31:19.101 --> 00:31:22.419
>> I just wanted to remind everyone that
the name of the game is we're trying to

608
00:31:22.419 --> 00:31:24.904
make things better, faster,
more cost-effective.

609
00:31:24.904 --> 00:31:29.835
Tim Woods is one method to identify waste
and we know that if we reduce or eliminate

610
00:31:29.835 --> 00:31:35.438
waste, we might automatically make things
better, faster, and more cost-effective.

611
00:31:35.438 --> 00:31:39.841
And Tim Woods can also be used for
other purposes, too.

612
00:31:39.841 --> 00:31:43.694
Like we were saying, like you're trying to
get yourself orientated to to a new job,

613
00:31:43.694 --> 00:31:46.152
or you're trying to do so
many problem solving, so.

614
00:31:46.152 --> 00:31:47.849
>> All right, so somewhere out there,

615
00:31:47.849 --> 00:31:50.532
maybe one of our is a gentleman
named Tim Woods watching and

616
00:31:50.532 --> 00:31:54.063
probably hates this episode because
now we've associated him with waste.

617
00:31:54.063 --> 00:31:57.933
But, hopefully you're not that person,
and that means you enjoyed the show,

618
00:31:57.933 --> 00:32:01.974
we hope you did, because we're going to be
back with more Lean Six Sigma coming up,

619
00:32:01.974 --> 00:32:04.486
but for now signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet

620
00:32:04.486 --> 00:32:05.792
>> And I'm Dr. Stearn.

621
00:32:05.792 --> 00:32:07.054
>> And we'll see you next time.

622
00:32:07.054 --> 00:32:07.617
>> Thank you.

623
00:32:07.617 --> 00:32:14.780
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Making sure a project effectively starts and finishes is an important objective. Viewers will hear discussions about process improvement, the project life cycle, and will be introduced to the primary models in Lean Six Sigma, which are PDCA, DMAIC, and DFSS.
episodes.title: Project Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.462 --> 00:00:14.420
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:14.420 --> 00:00:17.463
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:17.463 --> 00:00:18.130
I'm your host Don Pezet back again with
another episode of Lean Six Sigma.

5
00:00:18.130 --> 00:00:24.030
And in this episode we're gonna jump the
divide between kind of processed manager

6
00:00:24.030 --> 00:00:29.740
or processed improvement and
jumping over into

7
00:00:29.740 --> 00:00:34.830
the world of, project Management,
which is really closely related to this,

8
00:00:34.830 --> 00:00:37.726
and to help us understand why
I've got with me Dr. Stern again.

9
00:00:37.726 --> 00:00:39.990
Dr. Stern, thanks for being on the show.

10
00:00:39.990 --> 00:00:41.060
>> Thank you.

11
00:00:41.060 --> 00:00:43.080
>> And helps us understand here,
because I know for me,

12
00:00:43.080 --> 00:00:45.270
I have a project management background.

13
00:00:45.270 --> 00:00:48.160
And I'll tell you there is a ton of
overlap between the stuff we see

14
00:00:48.160 --> 00:00:50.310
in Six Sigma and Lean and
well, Lean Six Sigma, and

15
00:00:50.310 --> 00:00:52.730
what we see in the project
management world.

16
00:00:52.730 --> 00:00:54.610
So how does all that work together?

17
00:00:55.750 --> 00:00:59.300
>> Okay, well first,
I would like to point out,

18
00:00:59.300 --> 00:01:04.320
that any project management tool by
default is also a Lean Six Sigma tool.

19
00:01:04.320 --> 00:01:09.080
And the reason is because
every process improvement

20
00:01:09.080 --> 00:01:13.930
at some point, goes back to being
a project that needs to be managed.

21
00:01:13.930 --> 00:01:17.233
So, no matter what process
improvement methodology you use,

22
00:01:17.233 --> 00:01:20.265
if you use Lean Six Sigma or
use a combination.

23
00:01:20.265 --> 00:01:22.064
When you get the problem solved, and

24
00:01:22.064 --> 00:01:25.429
we're gonna talk about that in a second,
but when you get the problem

25
00:01:25.429 --> 00:01:29.047
solved you go back to being a project
manager to get the project executed.

26
00:01:29.047 --> 00:01:34.915
So, probably where I'm gonna start is I
wanna talk about the project lifecycle.

27
00:01:34.915 --> 00:01:36.720
And I have a slide on that.

28
00:01:36.720 --> 00:01:41.190
And it's a bit of a busy slide that
this is in your sample files, so

29
00:01:41.190 --> 00:01:45.280
later when you have some time if you
wanna print it out and look at it.

30
00:01:45.280 --> 00:01:52.320
Now, I wanna explain something that
I brought up in an earlier episode.

31
00:01:52.320 --> 00:01:56.310
For the most part of the last I would say,
gosh,

32
00:01:56.310 --> 00:02:00.280
30, 40 years, the PEMBAC has been sort
of the bible of project management.

33
00:02:00.280 --> 00:02:04.260
And in their project management
life cycle varies a little bit.

34
00:02:05.550 --> 00:02:09.240
And then the new project life cycle,
that introduced by ISO,

35
00:02:09.240 --> 00:02:10.260
12 500 has some nuances.

36
00:02:10.260 --> 00:02:16.146
And then I think I also mentioned in an
earlier episode that some universities and

37
00:02:16.146 --> 00:02:20.750
even four-year degree programs sort
of have a little bit of a different

38
00:02:20.750 --> 00:02:21.660
spin on the project life cycle.

39
00:02:21.660 --> 00:02:27.045
They're very, very similar, but
in some cycles there's five steps.

40
00:02:27.045 --> 00:02:28.185
In some cycles, there's six.

41
00:02:28.185 --> 00:02:31.315
What you're looking at right now
on the screen and again you have

42
00:02:31.315 --> 00:02:35.335
a copy of this in your sample files, what
you're looking at is kind of a composite.

43
00:02:35.335 --> 00:02:39.325
These are the things that if you took
everyone's idea about what the project

44
00:02:39.325 --> 00:02:40.645
life cycle would be, and

45
00:02:40.645 --> 00:02:44.515
you had slammed them into one model,
this would be the model.

46
00:02:44.515 --> 00:02:45.815
Does that make sense, Don?

47
00:02:45.815 --> 00:02:47.330
>> It does.
Yeah and we've We've seen this, and

48
00:02:47.330 --> 00:02:49.870
any of you guys who have taken
PMP training, CAPM training,

49
00:02:49.870 --> 00:02:51.220
any of the PMI stuff.

50
00:02:51.220 --> 00:02:54.640
Even inside of ITIL,
we see it, or Prince 2,

51
00:02:54.640 --> 00:02:58.230
you've got it there, this idea of
moving through a set of phases.

52
00:02:58.230 --> 00:03:00.400
And I know your slide show is four phases.

53
00:03:00.400 --> 00:03:02.020
Some people break it down into five.

54
00:03:02.020 --> 00:03:04.070
I've even seen six phases,
but at the end of the day,

55
00:03:04.070 --> 00:03:07.280
they really do boil down
to the same concepts.

56
00:03:07.280 --> 00:03:11.740
And it's just how we make sure something
effectively starts and finishes.

57
00:03:11.740 --> 00:03:13.980
>> Exactly.
And so when you're looking at this,

58
00:03:13.980 --> 00:03:18.950
you see that there's a start up phase and
in some models that's called initiation,

59
00:03:18.950 --> 00:03:24.100
and then there's a planning and executing
stage, and then there's a close out phase.

60
00:03:24.100 --> 00:03:28.220
Some of the things that you might
see in other models are control.

61
00:03:28.220 --> 00:03:31.960
Some models pay a little bit more
attention to risk management, but

62
00:03:31.960 --> 00:03:36.110
essentially when Lean Six Sigma
looks at it's time for

63
00:03:36.110 --> 00:03:37.810
this process improvement to be a project.

64
00:03:37.810 --> 00:03:42.180
These are the basics,
there's gotta be some kind of startup and

65
00:03:42.180 --> 00:03:46.610
that would be, where you're going out and
you're explaining what you're doing.

66
00:03:46.610 --> 00:03:48.650
You're figuring out your scope.

67
00:03:48.650 --> 00:03:50.530
A lot of times this is where
your project charter comes in,

68
00:03:50.530 --> 00:03:54.440
and you do have a sample project
charter or a project charter template,

69
00:03:54.440 --> 00:03:57.420
rather in your sample files and
we'll be looking.

70
00:03:57.420 --> 00:04:02.090
Nets and other project charter stuff
a little bit later in the class.

71
00:04:02.090 --> 00:04:04.680
Planning is where you really
get the team together and

72
00:04:04.680 --> 00:04:07.440
you figure out who's gonna be doing what.

73
00:04:07.440 --> 00:04:11.500
Executing is getting a schedule together,
and then closeout is

74
00:04:11.500 --> 00:04:14.840
obviously really important so
people know that the project is over.

75
00:04:14.840 --> 00:04:18.630
Now, I do this for a living, and
I shared in an earlier episode

76
00:04:18.630 --> 00:04:23.520
I mostly teach I mostly teach, and
I teach other instructors how to teach,

77
00:04:23.520 --> 00:04:25.980
but sometimes I have
a consulting hat that I wear.

78
00:04:25.980 --> 00:04:28.240
And not too long ago I was working for

79
00:04:28.240 --> 00:04:32.310
a company where we were
meeting every Monday morning.

80
00:04:32.310 --> 00:04:35.755
And because I travel a lot, sometimes
I would have to call into the meeting.

81
00:04:35.755 --> 00:04:40.581
Well, the week before I went to California
we had this big dinner, and we gave

82
00:04:40.581 --> 00:04:45.569
prizes, and we patted everyone on their
back and we said what a great job we did.

83
00:04:45.569 --> 00:04:48.745
And I felt like we had
closed out the project.

84
00:04:48.745 --> 00:04:52.190
And the next Monday,
when I was in California, I get this panic

85
00:04:52.190 --> 00:04:56.296
call that the team was meeting at
the company, and I hadn't called in yet.

86
00:04:56.296 --> 00:04:59.580
And so obviously, they didn't
realize the project was closed out.

87
00:04:59.580 --> 00:05:01.559
So, closing out is really,
really important.

88
