309
00:17:39.280 --> 00:17:43.230
in structure brainstorming what
we do is spread that list.

310
00:17:43.230 --> 00:17:47.470
We pick one and then supposedly we
implement it, and then we go back and

311
00:17:47.470 --> 00:17:48.420
we kind of tweak it up.

312
00:17:48.420 --> 00:17:52.150
But in structure problem solving,
a lot of times we drop the ball even and

313
00:17:52.150 --> 00:17:55.480
that particular situation
we forget to go back or

314
00:17:55.480 --> 00:18:01.000
we might even send out surveys and stuff,
but we don't really tweak it up, right?

315
00:18:01.000 --> 00:18:05.570
The big difference in the demaic model,
is that I define, I measure, I analyze and

316
00:18:05.570 --> 00:18:11.520
after I do those three steps, then I come
up with my brainstorm list of solutions.

317
00:18:11.520 --> 00:18:14.400
So define just means I make sure
I'm working on the right thing,

318
00:18:14.400 --> 00:18:18.630
measure which isn't as intuitive
as some of the other models,

319
00:18:18.630 --> 00:18:23.220
it just means I'm going to get a clear
as a picture of where I'm at today.

320
00:18:23.220 --> 00:18:26.590
A analyze means I'm going to go back and
say, hey why is that picture that way?

321
00:18:26.590 --> 00:18:29.880
And then after I do that That, I come up
with my brain storm list of solutions.

322
00:18:29.880 --> 00:18:35.610
Now what that buys me is I'm not going to
have someone in the back of the room say,

323
00:18:35.610 --> 00:18:38.460
we tried that last year and
it didn't work, because I defined,

324
00:18:38.460 --> 00:18:39.710
I measured, I analyzed.

325
00:18:39.710 --> 00:18:40.750
I'm gonna know that.

326
00:18:40.750 --> 00:18:45.040
I'm not gonna have someone say, that's not
politically going to fly with our company.

327
00:18:45.040 --> 00:18:46.660
It's not green enough.

328
00:18:46.660 --> 00:18:50.480
We don't have the intellectual capital,
which is kind of a mean thing to say.

329
00:18:50.480 --> 00:18:53.290
But I'm not gonna have any of those
things come back at me because because

330
00:18:53.290 --> 00:18:56.290
I spent the time to define,
measure and analyze.

331
00:18:56.290 --> 00:19:01.170
And when I come out of analyze I shoot for
three to five solutions,

332
00:19:01.170 --> 00:19:06.150
so when I get to improve where I became a
project manager again I have some choices.

333
00:19:06.150 --> 00:19:08.770
Right?
And then I mentioned earlier, the DMAIC

334
00:19:08.770 --> 00:19:12.280
model has a whole phase at the very end
which is different than typical project

335
00:19:12.280 --> 00:19:16.620
management, and that's the control piece
and in control I'm documenting what I did

336
00:19:18.070 --> 00:19:22.670
but I'm telling you how
to keep it that way.

337
00:19:22.670 --> 00:19:26.670
And finally, there's a model that we don't
really actually- we briefly discuss in

338
00:19:26.670 --> 00:19:31.160
this class but I just want to put it out
there, called the design for six sigma and

339
00:19:31.160 --> 00:19:35.370
now you're seeing the term a lot of
times like say in the Wall Street where

340
00:19:35.370 --> 00:19:39.090
they'll say design for lean six sigma so
that acronym is DFLSS.

341
00:19:39.090 --> 00:19:43.300
It's the same set of models and the major
difference is in the demaic model,

342
00:19:43.300 --> 00:19:46.900
I am working with an existing process.

343
00:19:46.900 --> 00:19:51.720
And Lean Six Sigma is typically working
with a process that's already in place and

344
00:19:51.720 --> 00:19:54.030
trying to make it, what?

345
00:19:54.030 --> 00:19:56.030
Better, faster, more cost effective.

346
00:19:56.030 --> 00:20:01.570
In the design for Six Sigma models,
and there's many of them,

347
00:20:01.570 --> 00:20:05.280
I'm taking something from nothing and
creating it.

348
00:20:05.280 --> 00:20:08.430
And so one thing that makes it different
is I have to have a design phase.

349
00:20:08.430 --> 00:20:11.670
I have to have some kind of
phase where I actually build it.

350
00:20:11.670 --> 00:20:15.390
The DMAIC model typically doesn't really
allow for building, because I'm taking

351
00:20:15.390 --> 00:20:19.090
an existing process and making it better,
faster, more cost effective.

352
00:20:19.090 --> 00:20:22.910
So, Design for Six Sigma is when I'm
building something from scratch.

353
00:20:22.910 --> 00:20:25.400
There's over 100 Design for
Six Sigma models, but

354
00:20:25.400 --> 00:20:29.960
the good news is that the DMADV model,
which we discussed earlier,

355
00:20:29.960 --> 00:20:34.930
in another episode is probably
the most popular, and so

356
00:20:34.930 --> 00:20:39.080
the first three letters of that, define,
measure and analyze, are exactly the same

357
00:20:39.080 --> 00:20:42.690
as they are in DMAIC and then there's
a design phase, and a verifying phase.

358
00:20:42.690 --> 00:20:46.460
So if you were a Lean Six Sigma
practitioner, and

359
00:20:46.460 --> 00:20:51.300
you went to a company and they said we
don't use the DMAIC, we use the DFSS.

360
00:20:51.300 --> 00:20:53.730
Your first question is,
what model do you use?

361
00:20:53.730 --> 00:20:57.130
Because they could have a model
that was just indigenous

362
00:20:57.130 --> 00:20:59.460
to their company that they just made up,
right?

363
00:20:59.460 --> 00:21:03.170
But, most likely, they're going to use the
DMADV model, and you could absolutely help

364
00:21:03.170 --> 00:21:06.300
them manage that project because,
you know the first three phases.

365
00:21:06.300 --> 00:21:09.390
>> Alright, so when we go to implement
a process improvement in general,

366
00:21:11.690 --> 00:21:17.480
we kind of have our choice over which
of these models we're gonna follow,

367
00:21:17.480 --> 00:21:20.620
which one works the best for us.

368
00:21:20.620 --> 00:21:22.110
We're gonna spend a bit of time,

369
00:21:22.110 --> 00:21:26.070
talking about In the following episodes
we're gonna spend a lot of time on DMAIC,

370
00:21:26.070 --> 00:21:27.410
because that one is the-
>> Flag ship.

371
00:21:27.410 --> 00:21:28.250
>> Prevalent model.

372
00:21:28.250 --> 00:21:30.130
And then we talked a bit DFSS.

373
00:21:30.130 --> 00:21:31.860
So those are some of the good
ones that are out there.

374
00:21:31.860 --> 00:21:36.550
Can you think of anything else you wanna
throw in before we wrap this one up?

375
00:21:36.550 --> 00:21:38.870
>> I really can't think of
anything at this time, Don.

376
00:21:38.870 --> 00:21:39.610
Thank you for asking.

377
00:21:39.610 --> 00:21:43.700
>> All right, well, like I said we
are gonna spend time talking about each

378
00:21:43.700 --> 00:21:44.710
model in depth.

379
00:21:44.710 --> 00:21:45.654
So stay tuned for that.

380
00:21:45.654 --> 00:21:49.664
We're gonna do Plan, Do, Check,
Act first before moving into the others.

381
00:21:49.664 --> 00:21:52.824
We'll definitely get a chance to see
that in our upcoming episodes, but for

382
00:21:52.824 --> 00:21:54.514
now, we're gonna wrap this one up.

383
00:21:54.514 --> 00:21:57.924
Thank you guys for watching,
signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pizett.

384
00:21:57.924 --> 00:21:59.304
>> And I'm Dr. Stern.

385
00:22:00.774 --> 00:22:05.230
>> And we'll see you next time.

386
00:22:05.230 --> 00:22:07.790
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: The Plan-Do-Check-Act (PDCA) cycle, or otherwise known as the Shewhart Cycle or the Deming Cycle, is a four-step model for carrying out change and is big in the realm of project management. Viewers will hear a brief history of PDCA and its relevance in planning a project.
episodes.title: Plan-Do-Check-Act
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.713 --> 00:00:15.126
All right good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:15.126 --> 00:00:17.727
And welcome back to another
episode of IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:17.727 --> 00:00:22.533
I'm your host Don Pezet, back again
with another episode of Lean Six Sigma.

5
00:00:22.533 --> 00:00:27.387
And in this episode we're gonna be taking
a look, at the PDCA, the plan, do, check,

6
00:00:27.387 --> 00:00:30.198
act, what I've always
called the Deming cycle.

7
00:00:30.198 --> 00:00:32.356
We've talked a little about
it in the last episode.

8
00:00:32.356 --> 00:00:36.616
It's pretty important, not just in terms
of process improvement in Six Sigma, but

9
00:00:36.616 --> 00:00:38.777
in terms of all sorts of different things.

10
00:00:38.777 --> 00:00:42.199
And we're gonna look at it from
the Lean Six Sigma angle, which is pretty

11
00:00:42.199 --> 00:00:45.863
important, and to help us with that,
we've got Dr. Stern back on the show.

12
00:00:45.863 --> 00:00:46.628
Thanks for being back with us.

13
00:00:46.628 --> 00:00:47.441
>> Thank you.

14
00:00:47.441 --> 00:00:49.833
>> And well, where do you want to start?

15
00:00:49.833 --> 00:00:54.608
Well I think I'd like to start talking
first about the Plan, Do, Check,

16
00:00:54.608 --> 00:00:55.389
Act model.

17
00:00:55.389 --> 00:01:01.009
I wanna remind our viewers that when
we decide that we have a project.

18
00:01:01.009 --> 00:01:03.795
We just move forward and
we do the project.

19
00:01:03.795 --> 00:01:07.714
When we don't know the answer to
the problem then it becomes a process

20
00:01:07.714 --> 00:01:09.345
improvement opportunity.

21
00:01:09.345 --> 00:01:13.889
The nice thing about the PDCA model is
that it can be used in both situations,

22
00:01:13.889 --> 00:01:17.230
and it's very popular
with project management.

23
00:01:17.230 --> 00:01:19.900
It's actually covered as
part of the PMP exam.

24
00:01:19.900 --> 00:01:23.943
So there's a lot of good reasons
to learn about the PBCA.

25
00:01:23.943 --> 00:01:29.151
Technically you would want to reach for
the flagship model, which is DMAIC.

26
00:01:29.151 --> 00:01:32.243
Which we'll be discussing in
the next episode, define, measure,

27
00:01:32.243 --> 00:01:33.748
analyze, improve and control.

28
00:01:33.748 --> 00:01:38.398
But there's a lot of times that the PBCA
model is going to be more handy, or

29
00:01:38.398 --> 00:01:41.929
more suitable for
the problem that you're working on.

30
00:01:41.929 --> 00:01:44.089
>> If nothing else, it's easier to
remember, cuz it's got one less letter.

31
00:01:44.089 --> 00:01:45.853
[LAUGH]
>> Exactly, exactly, and

32
00:01:45.853 --> 00:01:47.409
the words are really intuitive.

33
00:01:47.409 --> 00:01:51.658
Plan, Do, which means execute,
and Check, or study.

34
00:01:51.658 --> 00:01:58.158
So that would be C, and then
the A stands for Adopt, Abandon, or Act.

35
00:01:58.158 --> 00:01:58.972
So.

36
00:01:58.972 --> 00:02:02.175
All right, so
I have a slide on this, the PDCA.

37
00:02:02.175 --> 00:02:06.990
And you'll see the wheel, and sometimes
this is referred to by a number of

38
00:02:06.990 --> 00:02:10.187
other names which we'll
be talking about next.

39
00:02:10.187 --> 00:02:14.483
The Plan-Do-Check-Act is a four-step
model for carrying out change.

40
00:02:14.483 --> 00:02:17.107
And it's meant to be continuous.

41
00:02:17.107 --> 00:02:21.157
So when I get to that last phase,
unless I'm acting,

42
00:02:21.157 --> 00:02:24.492
then I just go back
around the circle again.

43
00:02:24.492 --> 00:02:28.348
What's important about this is that
a lot of process improvement models

44
00:02:28.348 --> 00:02:29.240
are waterfall.

45
00:02:29.240 --> 00:02:32.637
And what that means is you have to do
step one, before you do step two, and

46
00:02:32.637 --> 00:02:34.727
when you get to the very end, you're done.

47
00:02:34.727 --> 00:02:36.407
But in the circular models,

48
00:02:36.407 --> 00:02:40.615
you can keep going around the circle
until you're problem's solved.

49
00:02:40.615 --> 00:02:43.888
I can give you a little
bit of PDCA history.

50
00:02:43.888 --> 00:02:48.025
Walter Shewhart wrote a book in
1939 called Statistical Method From

51
00:02:48.025 --> 00:02:50.072
the Viewpoint of Quality Control.

52
00:02:50.072 --> 00:02:51.394
That's a mouthful.

53
00:02:51.394 --> 00:02:55.138
And we had talked a little bit
earlier about Edwards Deming and

54
00:02:55.138 --> 00:02:57.880
also Joseph Juran, who isn't on my slides.

55
00:02:57.880 --> 00:03:01.711
They were students of Walter,
or Walter Shewhart, sorry.

56
00:03:01.711 --> 00:03:05.067
They were students of his that
kind of took different directions.

57
00:03:05.067 --> 00:03:07.678
Edwards Deming went on
the lecture circuit, and

58
00:03:07.678 --> 00:03:09.912
Joseph Juran started writing material.

59
00:03:09.912 --> 00:03:13.360
Now, closer to the end of their lives,
they were both doing both.

60
00:03:13.360 --> 00:03:16.538
But that's kind of where they started out,
and they were really,

61
00:03:16.538 --> 00:03:18.944
really excited about
the Plan Do Check Act model.

62
00:03:18.944 --> 00:03:23.514
So, what happened is that
sometimes the PDCA model, or

63
00:03:23.514 --> 00:03:29.072
PDSA model, is called the Shewhart cycle,
or the Shewhart wheel.

64
00:03:29.072 --> 00:03:32.131
And sometimes it's called the Deming
wheel or the Deming Cycle.

65
00:03:32.131 --> 00:03:33.803
It all means the same thing.

66
00:03:33.803 --> 00:03:38.876
And one of the things I think is
really interesting piece of trivia,

67
00:03:38.876 --> 00:03:44.578
is that during World War II, this was
a classified model that the army used.

68
00:03:44.578 --> 00:03:48.945
So what you're looking at right now
is Continuous Improvement Cycle.

69
00:03:48.945 --> 00:03:53.881
And there's just a little bit of
verbiage on each thing because it's

70
00:03:53.881 --> 00:03:55.850
meant to be a simple model.

71
00:03:55.850 --> 00:03:59.295
Sometimes you don't have
time to do the DEMAIC.

72
00:03:59.295 --> 00:04:01.803
Even though that is the preferred
model in Lean Six Sigma.

73
00:04:01.803 --> 00:04:05.332
So that's one reason why you
might reach for the PDCA.

74
00:04:05.332 --> 00:04:09.256
Sometimes your boss says
I need it on Monday.

75
00:04:09.256 --> 00:04:12.425
So you don't really even have
a choice about that, right?

76
00:04:12.425 --> 00:04:17.370
Sometimes, the problem is so simple,
or so easy, that you use a PDCA.

77
00:04:18.650 --> 00:04:22.360
And then in large companies,
such as Northrop Grumman, Raytheon,

78
00:04:22.360 --> 00:04:23.580
Lockheed Martin,

79
00:04:23.580 --> 00:04:26.990
that have whole departments of
Six Sigma and/or Lean Six Sigma people.

80
00:04:26.990 --> 00:04:32.710
They require that you run it through
a hypothetical PDCA before you

81
00:04:32.710 --> 00:04:35.270
bring it to them for
them to apply the DMAIC model.

82
00:04:35.270 --> 00:04:41.594
So, there's a lot of reasons why you
might choose the PDCA over the DMAIC.

83
00:04:41.594 --> 00:04:44.021
Now, in the Plan phase of the DMAIC model,

84
00:04:44.021 --> 00:04:47.202
I'm discovering the current
condition of my problem.

85
00:04:47.202 --> 00:04:50.767
And so, I'm really doing all the kinds
of things that you would do when you're

86
00:04:50.767 --> 00:04:51.750
planning a project.

87
00:04:51.750 --> 00:04:55.710
So Don, what are some of the generic
things you do when you're planning

88
00:04:55.710 --> 00:04:56.371
a project?

89
00:04:56.371 --> 00:05:00.388
>> Well, the first thing I always do is,
I verify my scope, right?

90
00:05:00.388 --> 00:05:03.522
So we've got our triple constraints
that we always deal with.

91
00:05:03.522 --> 00:05:09.419
The budget, time, and we'd say quality or
sometimes requirements, right?

92
00:05:09.419 --> 00:05:12.670
So I need to make sure that
I'm building around that.

93
00:05:12.670 --> 00:05:13.785
So that's usually where I start.

94
00:05:13.785 --> 00:05:14.783
>> Okay, good.

95
00:05:14.783 --> 00:05:18.208
And so that's the same thing that
the Plan, Do, Check, Act model does.

96
00:05:18.208 --> 00:05:22.126
Now when you look at this model,
again it's gonna seem very simplistic,

97
00:05:22.126 --> 00:05:24.602
like of course this is
the way things are done.

98
00:05:24.602 --> 00:05:28.895
But we live in a very reactive society,
I've mentioned that in an earlier episode.

99
00:05:28.895 --> 00:05:33.614
So a lot of times, things come to us, and
we just go out and we try to solve them.

100
00:05:33.614 --> 00:05:35.178
One of the advantages of the PDCA model,

101
00:05:35.178 --> 00:05:37.711
is that we can apply something
called work breakdown structure.

102
00:05:37.711 --> 00:05:44.080
And work breakdown structure,
which is abbreviated W-B-S, is an outline.

103
00:05:44.080 --> 00:05:45.890
Where we say number one,
we're gonna do this.

104
00:05:45.890 --> 00:05:47.307
Number two, we're gonna do that.

105
00:05:47.307 --> 00:05:49.388
Number three,
we're gonna do this other thing.

106
00:05:49.388 --> 00:05:54.644
And then if there are items under
number one, they'd become 1.1, 1.2,

107
00:05:54.644 --> 00:06:00.695
and 1.3, and if there's an item under
1.3 that becomes 1.3.1 and 1.3.2.

108
00:06:00.695 --> 00:06:07.316
Well the PDCA model plan would be one and
then do or execute would be two.

109
00:06:07.316 --> 00:06:11.690
Now, there's a lot of things that
I might do under execute that I

110
00:06:11.690 --> 00:06:14.208
determined by my planning process.

111
00:06:14.208 --> 00:06:15.374
I'm sure a lot of you, and

112
00:06:15.374 --> 00:06:17.869
I think we mentioned this in
an earlier episode as well.

113
00:06:17.869 --> 00:06:21.907
A lot of you have probably been in
situations where there's a lot of planning

114
00:06:21.907 --> 00:06:23.115
but nothing happens.

115
00:06:23.115 --> 00:06:26.085
This model kind of forces you
to go to that next level,

116
00:06:26.085 --> 00:06:29.259
because number two is to do
things that are in execution.

117
00:06:29.259 --> 00:06:32.684
And when you're thinking about execution,
you wanna think about this is

118
00:06:32.684 --> 00:06:35.846
where I'm gonna build,
even though I'm planning out my project.

119
00:06:35.846 --> 00:06:40.404
My project plan kinda happens
almost between plan and do.

120
00:06:40.404 --> 00:06:42.345
When I'm in Do and I'm executing,

121
00:06:42.345 --> 00:06:46.486
the types of things that I need to think
about is I need to think about my cost,

122
00:06:46.486 --> 00:06:49.488
my timeline,
what resources are gonna be doing what.

123
00:06:49.488 --> 00:06:53.750
And I need to start building
in some kind of plan to make

124
00:06:53.750 --> 00:06:56.509
sure that I keep everyone on task.

125
00:06:56.509 --> 00:07:00.974
Now when I get to, on my work breakdown
structure, which would be Check, and

126
00:07:00.974 --> 00:07:03.531
I'm going back and looking at the results.

127
00:07:03.531 --> 00:07:06.224
If I did it correctly when I was in plan,

128
00:07:06.224 --> 00:07:09.663
I would have set up some success metrics,
right?

129
00:07:09.663 --> 00:07:13.523
So that when I get to check, or study,
I know what it is I'm looking for.

130
00:07:13.523 --> 00:07:17.661
So plan, in the plan do check act,
takes longer than any other phase.

131
00:07:17.661 --> 00:07:20.260
So I'm in check, and
I'm evaluating the results.

132
00:07:20.260 --> 00:07:22.590
And this says the results of a pilot,

133
00:07:22.590 --> 00:07:25.531
because PDCA is often
used to pilot a project.

134
00:07:25.531 --> 00:07:30.890
So let's say I actually did a full
DMAIC project, and I didn't really I

135
00:07:30.890 --> 00:07:36.088
haven't really done my pilot till
I'm almost at the end of my DMAIC.

136
00:07:36.088 --> 00:07:40.834
I could actually use my PDCA as
the pilot even though I'm working in

137
00:07:40.834 --> 00:07:42.115
a DMAIC program.

138
00:07:42.115 --> 00:07:45.992
Just to see if my idea works, but
it doesn't have to be a pilot.

139
00:07:45.992 --> 00:07:48.870
And then I move over to four, maybe.

140
00:07:48.870 --> 00:07:54.315
[LAUGH] I move over to four, and
remember this is Act, Abandon, or Adopt.

141
00:07:54.315 --> 00:07:57.241
Now if I'm going to Adopt, or Act.

142
00:07:57.241 --> 00:07:59.470
I may need to go through the circle again.

143
00:07:59.470 --> 00:08:01.467
If I'm acting, I'm just done.

144
00:08:01.467 --> 00:08:06.124
Now, what are some of the things
that are really interesting

145
00:08:06.124 --> 00:08:11.072
about the PDCA model is that I can
use it in a number of other ways.

146
00:08:11.072 --> 00:08:15.597
For example, in an interviewing, even
though we're talking about Lean Six Sigma.

147
00:08:15.597 --> 00:08:18.086
If you were in
an interviewing situation and

148
00:08:18.086 --> 00:08:22.467
you were asked a hypothetical question and
it's a popular way to interview.

149
00:08:22.467 --> 00:08:25.134
I'm not saying it's good or
bad, but it is a popular way,

150
00:08:25.134 --> 00:08:29.008
where somebody throws you a scenario, and
they just wanna see how you reason it out.

151
00:08:29.008 --> 00:08:31.570
If you think in terms of plan,
and then I would do,

152
00:08:31.570 --> 00:08:33.217
and this is how I would check it.

153
00:08:33.217 --> 00:08:37.044
And then I would make a decision from
there if I would act or abandon.

154
00:08:37.044 --> 00:08:42.157
So, you can also use that method to field
hypothetical questions in an interview or

155
00:08:42.157 --> 00:08:45.531
if you're kind of talking
things around in a meeting.

156
00:08:45.531 --> 00:08:49.319
Another place where the PDCA
is really super valuable,

157
00:08:49.319 --> 00:08:54.167
is if you're trying to pull your
presentation together very quickly.

158
00:08:54.167 --> 00:08:58.107
Someone says, do you mind doing a quick
report on what you did last week?

159
00:08:58.107 --> 00:08:59.885
And you did a lot of things, but

160
00:08:59.885 --> 00:09:04.133
you need to kind of laser focus on how
to explain it and explain it quickly,

161
00:09:04.133 --> 00:09:07.719
cuz maybe you only have five
minutes to explain your project.

162
00:09:07.719 --> 00:09:11.779
So once again, if you think in terms
of what I planned, what I did,

163
00:09:11.779 --> 00:09:12.877
how I checked it.

164
00:09:12.877 --> 00:09:15.410
Then, you're gonna be
a little bit more successful.

165
00:09:15.410 --> 00:09:16.020
So Plan, Do,

166
00:09:16.020 --> 00:09:20.980
Check, Act, is a really simplistic model,
but it's incredibly powerful.

167
00:09:20.980 --> 00:09:24.940
Especially when you don't really
have time to do a full demand.

168
00:09:24.940 --> 00:09:28.140
>> You know, I think the simplicity of
this model is why we see it used so

169
00:09:28.140 --> 00:09:31.640
frequently outside of
even process improvement.

170
00:09:31.640 --> 00:09:32.888
You see it everywhere.

171
00:09:32.888 --> 00:09:36.470
Just to use an IT example,
well if I have a new update that I need to

172
00:09:36.470 --> 00:09:40.480
roll out some servers I'm not just
gonna install it and say I'm done.

173
00:09:40.480 --> 00:09:42.425
I don't just act and that's it, right?

174
00:09:42.425 --> 00:09:44.748
I've got to plan when we're
going to deploy that.

175
00:09:44.748 --> 00:09:48.879
I have to test it out in a testing pool
with a couple of servers that aren't

176
00:09:48.879 --> 00:09:49.574
critical.

177
00:09:49.574 --> 00:09:52.204
I need to check to verify that
the updates still work and

178
00:09:52.204 --> 00:09:55.649
it didn't break all my software and
any other services on the network.

179
00:09:55.649 --> 00:10:01.550
And only when all that is done, am I ready
to actually act I can push that out.

180
00:10:01.550 --> 00:10:03.686
But if I encounter problems
during that process.

181
00:10:03.686 --> 00:10:06.750
I'm going right back to plan,
or do, or check.

182
00:10:06.750 --> 00:10:09.677
So you'll kinda cycle through
this a good bit in that process.

183
00:10:09.677 --> 00:10:14.504
And that's not a process improvement
project, that's just change management.

184
00:10:14.504 --> 00:10:18.315
It's applying and updating, making
sure that you keep your network safe.

185
00:10:18.315 --> 00:10:21.241
You keep your systems up and
that it's all very accountable.

186
00:10:21.241 --> 00:10:24.490
You've got that kind of paper
record of what's being done.

187
00:10:24.490 --> 00:10:26.230
It's really critical.

188
00:10:26.230 --> 00:10:29.065
So you'll see Plan, Do, Check, Act used
in a number of different environments.

189
00:10:29.065 --> 00:10:32.146
And you mentioned several of
the different names for it, and I know,

190
00:10:32.146 --> 00:10:34.006
I've always called it the Deming Cycle,

191
00:10:34.006 --> 00:10:36.949
cuz that was how I learned it in
the first textbook I read about it.

192
00:10:36.949 --> 00:10:39.224
And it doesn't matter
what name you give it.

193
00:10:39.224 --> 00:10:41.825
If you just kind of watch
out there in the real world.

194
00:10:41.825 --> 00:10:45.436
You'll see people using that model
even if they don't know what it is or

195
00:10:45.436 --> 00:10:46.769
know a single name for it.

196
00:10:46.769 --> 00:10:48.186
>> Yeah.

197
00:10:48.186 --> 00:10:49.812
>> That's definitely
one of the cooler ones.

198
00:10:49.812 --> 00:10:54.582
Now the simplicity of it, it really is
kind of one of the shining factors for it.

199
00:10:54.582 --> 00:10:58.947
And what we've covered is probably all we
really need to know about PDCA, right?

200
00:10:58.947 --> 00:10:59.528
>> Right.

201
00:10:59.528 --> 00:11:04.499
I only have one other point to make, and
that's that when you're working with

202
00:11:04.499 --> 00:11:09.113
the DMAIC model, which we're gonna
be discussing in the next episode.

203
00:11:09.113 --> 00:11:14.081
The DMAIC model has additional tools
that you can apply to the PDCA.

204
00:11:14.081 --> 00:11:17.990
So the PDCA, comes with a certain
set of project management tools.

205
00:11:17.990 --> 00:11:20.184
And I've mentioned in other episodes,

206
00:11:20.184 --> 00:11:23.870
project management tools by default
are also Lean Six Sigma tools.

207
00:11:23.870 --> 00:11:26.958
Cuz Lean Six Sigma uses all
the project management tools.

208
00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:30.728
But one of the things that Lean Six Sigma
does with the PDCA, and you got kind of

209
00:11:30.728 --> 00:11:34.870
a slide of the DMAIC up there,
just to kind of remember those steps.

210
00:11:34.870 --> 00:11:40.401
Is that there are tools within the DMAIC
that, even though they are not

211
00:11:40.401 --> 00:11:45.849
in the same order as PDCA, you can
apply to make the PDCA more robust.

212
00:11:45.849 --> 00:11:48.611
So, for example, do, which is execute.

213
00:11:48.611 --> 00:11:52.466
Happens in the second
phase of the PDCA model.

214
00:11:52.466 --> 00:11:56.413
It doesn't happen until the fourth
phase of the DMAIC model.

215
00:11:56.413 --> 00:12:00.799
But those tools to execute, you can kind
of slide those over to help you execute

216
00:12:00.799 --> 00:12:03.270
better, faster, more cost effectively.

217
00:12:05.110 --> 00:12:08.650
>> So using the example you gave of
the company that would have, you

218
00:12:08.650 --> 00:12:13.470
have to model something through PDCA first
before you submit it to the full DMAIC.

219
00:12:13.470 --> 00:12:18.570
It's really just a matter of
taking that first set of data and

220
00:12:18.570 --> 00:12:22.520
kind of bolting it into DMAIC so
they kind of are compatible.

221
00:12:22.520 --> 00:12:23.530
>> Exactly.

222
00:12:23.530 --> 00:12:24.579
>> Excellent.

223
00:12:24.579 --> 00:12:28.207
All right well,
I know it's one of our shorter episodes.

224
00:12:28.207 --> 00:12:31.224
We don't have a ton to go in on
PDCA not that it isn't important.

225
00:12:31.224 --> 00:12:33.640
It's just that it's simple, and
that's kinda the glory of it.

226
00:12:33.640 --> 00:12:36.695
We're certainly gonna spend
quite a bit more time on DMAIC.

227
00:12:36.695 --> 00:12:39.539
So we'll get a chance to see
that coming up, but for now,

228
00:12:39.539 --> 00:12:43.467
it's a pretty good spot for us to wrap
this one up, so let's close it off here.

229
00:12:43.467 --> 00:12:44.953
I do thank you guys for watching.

230
00:12:44.953 --> 00:12:45.510
Stay tuned.

231
00:12:45.510 --> 00:12:47.808
We've got more Lean Six Sigma coming up.

232
00:12:47.808 --> 00:12:50.038
I know I've left us with
a cliffhanger here, right?

233
00:12:50.038 --> 00:12:53.637
DMAIC coming up, we're excited about
that so stay tuned for it as well.

234
00:12:53.637 --> 00:12:55.331
All right I hope you guys enjoyed it.

235
00:12:55.331 --> 00:12:57.908
Signing off for ITPROTV, I'm Don Pezet.

236
00:12:57.908 --> 00:13:00.556
>> And I'm Dr. Stern
>> And will see you next time.

237
00:13:00.556 --> 00:13:07.612
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Define' is the first phase in the five phase process of the DMAIC model. In the Define Phase, there are two rules: you have to have a process map and you have to end with a project charter. Viewers will hear discussions of tools and activities that help people in the define phase and hear how the phase helps everyone understand what a project is trying to achieve.
episodes.title: Define Phase
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.276 --> 00:00:10.276
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.456 --> 00:00:13.132
All right.

3
00:00:13.132 --> 00:00:14.824
Good morning, good afternoon and
good evening.

4
00:00:14.824 --> 00:00:17.326
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:17.326 --> 00:00:21.784
I'm your host, Don Pezet, back again
with another episode of Lean Six Sigma.

6
00:00:21.784 --> 00:00:25.849
And today, this is gonna be a pretty
exciting episode because we're kicking off

7
00:00:25.849 --> 00:00:26.880
the DMAIC process.

8
00:00:26.880 --> 00:00:28.652
So we've mentioned it in
more than one episode.

9
00:00:28.652 --> 00:00:31.408
Now we're actually gonna take the deep
dive in there and look at each of

10
00:00:31.408 --> 00:00:34.069
the different phases that make that
process of seeing how it can be so

11
00:00:34.069 --> 00:00:35.345
valuable to our organization.

12
00:00:35.345 --> 00:00:39.156
And back again to help me with this, we've
got Dr.Stern on the show, thank you for

13
00:00:39.156 --> 00:00:40.090
being back with us.

14
00:00:40.090 --> 00:00:41.054
>> Thank you.

15
00:00:41.054 --> 00:00:43.376
>> And well, let's kick this thing off.

16
00:00:43.376 --> 00:00:47.024
So you wanna tell us a little bit about
the DMAIC process, and how that works?

17
00:00:47.024 --> 00:00:50.201
>> I do, but
before we get started on Define,

18
00:00:50.201 --> 00:00:55.766
which is the very first phase of the DMAIC
model, I wanna remind the viewers

19
00:00:55.766 --> 00:01:01.270
that the DMAIC model is the primary
model used in Lean Six Sigma.

20
00:01:01.270 --> 00:01:05.310
Now sometimes, you can't use the DMAIC,
because you just don't have time to do it.

21
00:01:05.310 --> 00:01:07.670
So there's other models
in the previous episode.

22
00:01:07.670 --> 00:01:12.510
We talked about PBCA, but primarily,
you're reaching for the DMAIC model.

23
00:01:12.510 --> 00:01:16.661
Now the really wonderful thing
about the DMAIC model is that

24
00:01:16.661 --> 00:01:19.329
you can use it to do complete reports.

25
00:01:19.329 --> 00:01:21.959
Or you can engage in something
I call DMAIC thinking,

26
00:01:21.959 --> 00:01:24.939
which means when you have
a smaller problem, like you don't

27
00:01:24.939 --> 00:01:28.926
have a huge problem that you're trying
to solve that requires an entire report.

28
00:01:28.926 --> 00:01:33.154
You can just go through the phases of
the model and solve a lot of problems.

29
00:01:33.154 --> 00:01:38.546
>> Yep, and so, like you said, even places
that use DMAIC as their primary model

30
00:01:38.546 --> 00:01:44.197
might also use PDCA just to get started
quickly and then transition over to DMAIC.

31
00:01:44.197 --> 00:01:45.017
It's very powerful.

32
00:01:45.017 --> 00:01:46.549
It's got a lot of flexibility.

33
00:01:46.549 --> 00:01:48.274
It does break apart into five phases, and

34
00:01:48.274 --> 00:01:50.359
that's how we're gonna tackle it here,
right?

35
00:01:50.359 --> 00:01:51.321
So, in this episode,

36
00:01:51.321 --> 00:01:54.630
we're gonna focus in on the first phase,
which is the Define phase, right?

37
00:01:54.630 --> 00:01:55.905
>> That's correct.

38
00:01:55.905 --> 00:01:58.173
And the first thing I'd like to show is,

39
00:01:58.173 --> 00:02:00.919
I have a slide that's
called my activity sheet.

40
00:02:00.919 --> 00:02:04.641
Now, this particular slide is also
part of your course files, and

41
00:02:04.641 --> 00:02:08.637
I know you can't really see it that well,
because it's kind of small.

42
00:02:08.637 --> 00:02:11.093
But I wanted you to be aware of this, and

43
00:02:11.093 --> 00:02:14.970
I will be referring back to this
collateral from time to time.

44
00:02:14.970 --> 00:02:20.220
You'll notice at the very top is the topic
we're gonna be talking about right now,

45
00:02:20.220 --> 00:02:21.356
which is Define.

46
00:02:21.356 --> 00:02:24.963
And in Define, the major goal
is that when you leave Define,

47
00:02:24.963 --> 00:02:29.300
you wanna make sure that everyone
understands what you're working on.

48
00:02:29.300 --> 00:02:32.782
Now it's kind of funny because we
used to say that everyone agrees

49
00:02:32.782 --> 00:02:35.013
that you're working on the right thing.

50
00:02:35.013 --> 00:02:39.378
And that's almost impossible, but you
don't want anyone walking down the hall

51
00:02:39.378 --> 00:02:42.475
going they have no clue what
you're working on, right?

52
00:02:42.475 --> 00:02:46.637
So part of that is just naming
your project something simple.

53
00:02:46.637 --> 00:02:49.419
It's kind of fun to have
a really exciting name, but

54
00:02:49.419 --> 00:02:52.707
you just want to name it something simple,
so when you say it,

55
00:02:52.707 --> 00:02:55.379
people know exactly what
you're talking about.

56
00:02:55.379 --> 00:02:57.283
>> And
that one almost seems like common sense.

57
00:02:57.283 --> 00:03:00.428
You'd think, why would I need to
specifically call this out, but

58
00:03:00.428 --> 00:03:04.191
I personally have been on a project where
after the initial kick-off meeting,

59
00:03:04.191 --> 00:03:07.466
I didn't really understand what
the project was trying to achieve.

60
00:03:07.466 --> 00:03:08.627
It certainly happens.

61
00:03:08.627 --> 00:03:12.828
And if you're trying to improve a process,
you kinda need to understand exactly

62
00:03:12.828 --> 00:03:17.050
what your goal is so, otherwise you
don't know what you've achieved, right?

63
00:03:17.050 --> 00:03:18.527
>> Right.
>> You don't know if you're victorious.

64
00:03:18.527 --> 00:03:19.718
>> Exactly.

65
00:03:19.718 --> 00:03:21.152
That's some really good point.

66
00:03:21.152 --> 00:03:26.330
On the handout that you're looking at,
I do wanna point out

67
00:03:26.330 --> 00:03:32.249
too that it's divided into what
the phase is trying to accomplish.

68
00:03:32.249 --> 00:03:39.280
In the middle is the activities, and
on the far right hand side are the tools.

69
00:03:39.280 --> 00:03:43.729
Now, this is not to say there aren't
other activities and other tools.

70
00:03:43.729 --> 00:03:47.921
These are just the major activities and
tools, and sometimes you use all of them,

71
00:03:47.921 --> 00:03:49.888
sometimes you don't use any of them.

72
00:03:49.888 --> 00:03:54.424
But what it doesn't include on this
handout is industry specific tool, so

73
00:03:54.424 --> 00:03:56.584
if you're in a specific industry,

74
00:03:56.584 --> 00:04:00.629
sometimes you're gonna have tools
that no one else has in define.

75
00:04:00.629 --> 00:04:05.147
So I wanted to point that out, and then
also I'm gonna be taking this slide down

76
00:04:05.147 --> 00:04:07.620
and referring back to
it from time to time.

77
00:04:07.620 --> 00:04:11.291
And I think we're just gonna launch
right into Define right now.

78
00:04:11.291 --> 00:04:11.957
>> Absolutely.

79
00:04:11.957 --> 00:04:15.189
That's where we're going to kick off
our process improvement anyway, so

80
00:04:15.189 --> 00:04:16.583
let's start at the beginning.

81
00:04:16.583 --> 00:04:17.430
>> Okay.

82
00:04:17.430 --> 00:04:22.896
So, my first slide says DMAIC activity,
and that was the sheet that you looked at.

83
00:04:22.896 --> 00:04:26.080
I want to warn you,
before we move forward,

84
00:04:26.080 --> 00:04:30.569
that Define takes a lot longer
to cover than the other phases.

85
00:04:30.569 --> 00:04:34.947
Part of the reason is, in the DMAIC model,
we have Define, Measure,

86
00:04:34.947 --> 00:04:37.189
Analyze, Improve, and Control.

87
00:04:37.189 --> 00:04:42.315
Define, Measure, and Analyze are very,
very creative phases, and lots of choices.

88
00:04:42.315 --> 00:04:47.620
So, there's lots of things I can teach you
and lots of directions that you can go in,

89
00:04:47.620 --> 00:04:51.582
and however, when you get down
to improving control, easy for

90
00:04:51.582 --> 00:04:55.137
me to teach because it's a basic map,
not so easy to do.

91
00:04:55.137 --> 00:04:58.451
But it's just a list of things
that you have to make sure.

92
00:04:58.451 --> 00:04:59.765
It's almost like a check sheet.

93
00:04:59.765 --> 00:05:02.099
So we're gonna look at that,
and I have some tips and

94
00:05:02.099 --> 00:05:04.823
tricks when we get to those phases
that are going to help you.

95
00:05:04.823 --> 00:05:08.520
So don't be concerned if we're
spending a lot of time in Define.

96
00:05:08.520 --> 00:05:10.680
In fact, the Lean Six Sigma saying is,

97
00:05:10.680 --> 00:05:13.940
if you don't have a lot of time,
you spend it in Define.

98
00:05:13.940 --> 00:05:15.624
Why do you think that is, Don?

99
00:05:15.624 --> 00:05:18.185
>> Well, if you make a mistake
in the Define kind of phase,

100
00:05:18.185 --> 00:05:22.014
at the very beginning, that's just gonna
cascade through the rest of it, right?

101
00:05:22.014 --> 00:05:23.640
>> Exactly, exactly.

102
00:05:23.640 --> 00:05:24.308
>> And you know what?

103
00:05:24.308 --> 00:05:26.833
While you talk about this, I always kind
of put it in the frame of mind of project

104
00:05:26.833 --> 00:05:28.996
management, cuz that's where a lot
of my experience comes from.

105
00:05:28.996 --> 00:05:32.811
And we have the Plan phase at
the beginning, and if you have that bad

106
00:05:32.811 --> 00:05:36.714
planning, it just cascades and
becomes worse and worse and worse.

107
00:05:36.714 --> 00:05:39.723
And if you're trying to improve a process,
you'll get that same effect.

108
00:05:39.723 --> 00:05:41.258
>> Exactly.

109
00:05:41.258 --> 00:05:46.580
So, one of the things that I want to talk
about is the methodology behind the model.

110
00:05:46.580 --> 00:05:49.685
And I did mention this briefly
in another episode, but

111
00:05:49.685 --> 00:05:52.121
I think it will help as
we move into Define.

112
00:05:52.121 --> 00:05:57.203
In normal problem solving, well, in fact,
let's say human problem solving.

113
00:05:57.203 --> 00:06:00.848
Sometimes in human problem solving,
I will present a problem or an issue, and

114
00:06:00.848 --> 00:06:04.548
keep in mind, that when we say problem
statement, it could be an actual problem

115
00:06:04.548 --> 00:06:07.668
we're trying to solve, or
just the task that we're trying to do.

116
00:06:07.668 --> 00:06:10.574
But let's say that I present
a problem to a friend.

117
00:06:10.574 --> 00:06:15.060
Sometimes I don't even get the problem
out before my friend might say,

118
00:06:15.060 --> 00:06:17.920
I know the solution to that problem,
right?

119
00:06:17.920 --> 00:06:24.070
Well, so structured problem solving
isn't really that much different.

120
00:06:24.070 --> 00:06:27.830
We put the problem out there, and
then we brainstorm a list of solutions.

121
00:06:27.830 --> 00:06:32.714
And then we're supposed to pick a solution
and then implement that solution, and

122
00:06:32.714 --> 00:06:36.136
then we're supposed to go back and
