00:19:52.690 --> 00:19:56.120
you'll actually have the information
from the easier tool and

343
00:19:56.120 --> 00:19:58.780
it will make that more
complicated tool easier.

344
00:19:58.780 --> 00:20:02.550
So, one of the tools that I'd like to talk
about first because it's just a fun tool,

345
00:20:02.550 --> 00:20:06.380
is the 5 Whys and so, I'm going to
be bringing up another presentation

346
00:20:06.380 --> 00:20:11.465
and Don have you had any
experience with the 5 whys?

347
00:20:11.465 --> 00:20:13.714
>> The 5 whys are kind of interesting.

348
00:20:13.714 --> 00:20:15.833
If you're asking yourself,
what are the 5 whys,

349
00:20:15.833 --> 00:20:19.104
well the odds are you've probably
actually dealt with these before, right.

350
00:20:19.104 --> 00:20:20.869
When you have a problem.

351
00:20:20.869 --> 00:20:24.034
If we go back to one of our early
episodes, where we said Process

352
00:20:24.034 --> 00:20:27.997
improvement is all about having a problem
and not knowing a solution, right?

353
00:20:27.997 --> 00:20:32.417
So the five lives are all to help us
understand not just what our problem is,

354
00:20:32.417 --> 00:20:35.027
but what leads to
the cause of that problem.

355
00:20:35.027 --> 00:20:38.672
It's almost like a root cause analysis,
would you say?

356
00:20:38.672 --> 00:20:39.668
>> Yeah, it is.
In fact,

357
00:20:39.668 --> 00:20:43.903
often it's refered to as an RCA tool,
which stands for root cause analysis.

358
00:20:43.903 --> 00:20:48.643
I have a slide up that's kind of a fun
example, and, Don, if you don't mind going

359
00:20:48.643 --> 00:20:53.387
through this, I'll start it off, and
then if you could answer these questions,

360
00:20:53.387 --> 00:20:57.150
and you can follow along in
the audience if you'd like.

361
00:20:57.150 --> 00:20:58.989
You're on your way home from work and
your car stops.

362
00:20:58.989 --> 00:21:00.150
Why did your car stop?

363
00:21:00.150 --> 00:21:01.764
>> All right, well.

364
00:21:01.764 --> 00:21:03.784
We have to think about why it happened,
right?

365
00:21:03.784 --> 00:21:05.524
So in this scenario,
maybe I ran out of gas.

366
00:21:05.524 --> 00:21:07.313
>> And why did you run out of gas?

367
00:21:07.313 --> 00:21:12.176
>> So, I ran out of gas because
I didn't put more gas in the car

368
00:21:12.176 --> 00:21:14.270
when it was running low.

369
00:21:14.270 --> 00:21:16.700
>> And
why didn't you buy gas this morning?

370
00:21:16.700 --> 00:21:19.222
>> Well, I know in our example,
because I didn't have any money.

371
00:21:19.222 --> 00:21:20.918
In real life,
I hate going to the gas station.

372
00:21:20.918 --> 00:21:22.659
So, any one of those scenarios.

373
00:21:22.659 --> 00:21:24.958
>> [LAUGH] And
why didn't you have any money?

374
00:21:24.958 --> 00:21:28.081
>> Because I lost it all
last night at a poker game.

375
00:21:28.081 --> 00:21:32.595
>> So this is a common example that
you'll see when people are talking about

376
00:21:32.595 --> 00:21:33.338
Five Whys.

377
00:21:33.338 --> 00:21:37.875
Why I like this example is that if you
notice and you're looking at your slide,

378
00:21:37.875 --> 00:21:39.476
we only ask why four times.

379
00:21:39.476 --> 00:21:42.373
So even though it's called The Five Whys,

380
00:21:42.373 --> 00:21:45.354
you might get your answer
in the second why.

381
00:21:45.354 --> 00:21:48.362
And if you're just on the verge
of getting your answer,

382
00:21:48.362 --> 00:21:52.152
Lean Six Sigma doesn't care if you
have to ask a sixth and seventh why.

383
00:21:52.152 --> 00:21:54.568
The theory is, if I ask why five times,

384
00:21:54.568 --> 00:21:59.621
I keep packaging it back to you after five
times, that I probably need to bump up and

385
00:21:59.621 --> 00:22:03.602
use some more sophisticated tools,
this isn't gonna help me.

386
00:22:03.602 --> 00:22:07.798
Also you wanna use some caution, when you
are using the Five Whys, if you are in

387
00:22:07.798 --> 00:22:12.645
the Advisory role, and you're talking to a
subordinate, it can be quite intimidating.

388
00:22:12.645 --> 00:22:14.963
So you might wanna let
them in on the game.

389
00:22:14.963 --> 00:22:16.129
Right?
Now in reality,

390
00:22:16.129 --> 00:22:19.969
it's more likely you would
have a question such as this.

391
00:22:19.969 --> 00:22:23.945
Customers are unhappy because they're
being shipped products that don't meet

392
00:22:23.945 --> 00:22:25.122
their specification.

393
00:22:25.122 --> 00:22:28.003
So, Don, in that case,
what would be your first why?

394
00:22:28.003 --> 00:22:28.570
>> All right.

395
00:22:28.570 --> 00:22:32.858
So if we know that our customers are
unhappy that we've been delivering this

396
00:22:32.858 --> 00:22:34.139
product, the first.

397
00:22:34.139 --> 00:22:37.494
Question will probably start at a high
level like why are they unhappy?

398
00:22:37.494 --> 00:22:40.486
>> Exactly and we could also
say it in another way such as

399
00:22:40.486 --> 00:22:45.750
why are they being shipped products that
don't meet their specifications, right?

400
00:22:45.750 --> 00:22:46.690
>> Right.

401
00:22:46.690 --> 00:22:50.470
>> And so the Five Whys can take two
different directions so is that okay?

402
00:22:50.470 --> 00:22:53.207
Absolutely.
Because remember Lean 6 Sigma is all about

403
00:22:53.207 --> 00:22:58.000
capitalizing on your critical thinking
skills, getting your own mind thinking

404
00:22:58.000 --> 00:23:02.509
because Lean 6 Sigma partners with
your own subject matter expertise, and

405
00:23:02.509 --> 00:23:05.196
these are just tools to
get the ball rolling.

406
00:23:05.196 --> 00:23:07.728
Right?
So, I think it would be kind of fun to do

407
00:23:07.728 --> 00:23:11.860
some practice and if you're sitting with
someone out there I would like you to

408
00:23:11.860 --> 00:23:14.423
pause the tape and
do some practice on your own.

409
00:23:14.423 --> 00:23:18.538
I'm going to introduce a couple of things
we can practice on and I think Don and

410
00:23:18.538 --> 00:23:20.010
I will do one or two of them.

411
00:23:20.010 --> 00:23:21.400
>> Sure.

412
00:23:21.400 --> 00:23:24.713
>> Okay, so if you have your own idea,
then, you know, go ahead

413
00:23:24.713 --> 00:23:26.455
>> Go ahead and practice on that one,

414
00:23:26.455 --> 00:23:30.599
but if you don't have an idea, these are
good ones, and Don, do any of those sound

415
00:23:30.599 --> 00:23:34.407
appealing to you or would you to possibly
like to choose your own question?

416
00:23:34.407 --> 00:23:37.390
>> All right, let's do,
I'm always late to work.

417
00:23:37.390 --> 00:23:39.364
>> Why are you always late to work?

418
00:23:39.364 --> 00:23:43.496
>> Because I hit traffic on
the road on the way here.

419
00:23:43.496 --> 00:23:45.390
>> And why do you hit traffic on the way?

420
00:23:45.390 --> 00:23:48.383
>> Because when I leave at
eight o'clock in the morning,

421
00:23:48.383 --> 00:23:51.516
there's school zones that I hit,
and they slow me down.

422
00:23:51.516 --> 00:23:55.522
>> And why do you allow those
school zones to slow you down?

423
00:23:55.522 --> 00:24:01.465
>> Because I don't wanna leave earlier
because I don't get up in time.

424
00:24:01.465 --> 00:24:03.068
>> Okay.
So the root cause.

425
00:24:03.068 --> 00:24:04.888
In this particular scenario,

426
00:24:04.888 --> 00:24:08.670
what we're gonna say is the root
cause of Don being late to work.

427
00:24:08.670 --> 00:24:09.265
But he's really not.

428
00:24:09.265 --> 00:24:10.851
>> [LAUGH]
>> Cuz it's just a hypothetical scenario.

429
00:24:10.851 --> 00:24:15.193
That the reason he's late to work is
because he doesn't want to get up early.

430
00:24:15.193 --> 00:24:19.707
Now, if we had taken another example
like why is my closet a mess,

431
00:24:19.707 --> 00:24:25.227
the beauty of the five whys is that if
someone said, my closet is a mess, right?

432
00:24:25.227 --> 00:24:31.113
We might immediately jump to I
have someone who cleans closets or

433
00:24:31.113 --> 00:24:35.910
I just bought this great closet organizer,
right?

434
00:24:35.910 --> 00:24:37.918
We might go ahead and
try to tackle that problem.

435
00:24:37.918 --> 00:24:42.624
When if we went through the Five Why
scenario just like we did on being

436
00:24:42.624 --> 00:24:47.346
late to work, we might discover
that the person is staying at work.

437
00:24:47.346 --> 00:24:49.270
They don't have time to
clean their closet, right?

438
00:24:49.270 --> 00:24:53.074
And so the root cause of their closet
being a mess is because they're staying

439
00:24:53.074 --> 00:24:53.975
at work too long.

440
00:24:53.975 --> 00:24:57.492
They get there late so
of course they have to stay later, right?

441
00:24:57.492 --> 00:25:00.373
And so that's the problem
that we want to tackle and

442
00:25:00.373 --> 00:25:02.852
that's I think the beauty
of the Five Whys.

443
00:25:02.852 --> 00:25:07.952
Now I'm gonna go back to my normal
presentation I just wanted to deviate

444
00:25:07.952 --> 00:25:12.464
a bit to let you know that the tools
that are covered in the define

445
00:25:13.497 --> 00:25:17.874
Phase, sorry, sorry [LAUGH].

446
00:25:17.874 --> 00:25:19.135
>> [LAUGH]
>> You know,

447
00:25:19.135 --> 00:25:23.156
I struggle with that sometimes
because some books call them phases,

448
00:25:23.156 --> 00:25:27.867
some people call them stages, but in the
define phase, one of the things that you

449
00:25:27.867 --> 00:25:32.819
can do are these really simple tools, so
things don't have to be as complicated as.

450
00:25:32.819 --> 00:25:36.776
>> And you know, the Five Whys
are a great example of a really simple,

451
00:25:36.776 --> 00:25:37.847
easy to use tool.

452
00:25:37.847 --> 00:25:39.960
Who’s the best practitioner of the 5 Whys?

453
00:25:39.960 --> 00:25:41.458
A four year old child.

454
00:25:41.458 --> 00:25:42.979
>> [LAUGH]
>> I think we’ve all had that, you know?

455
00:25:42.979 --> 00:25:43.942
Why is the sky blue?

456
00:25:43.942 --> 00:25:45.903
Well the sun reflects off the ocean.

457
00:25:45.903 --> 00:25:48.400
Wait, why does the sun
reflect off the ocean, right?

458
00:25:48.400 --> 00:25:51.945
And they start drilling you down with
the whys until eventually you get

459
00:25:51.945 --> 00:25:54.770
to an answer that actually
solves the problem.

460
00:25:54.770 --> 00:25:58.212
As adults, we usually get to an answer
ss a child, the whys just continue and.

461
00:25:58.212 --> 00:25:58.718
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

462
00:25:58.718 --> 00:25:59.736
>> You get the 200 whys for them.

463
00:25:59.736 --> 00:26:02.840
But It just shows how it's almost
ingrained in our inquisitive nature to do

464
00:26:02.840 --> 00:26:06.370
it this way, but I like what you
said about you probably want to let

465
00:26:06.370 --> 00:26:07.982
your coworkers in on the game, because.

466
00:26:07.982 --> 00:26:08.700
>> [LAUGH]
>> Otherwise,

467
00:26:08.700 --> 00:26:13.040
they're gonna think you're an annoying
four-year-old, but it is a great, very

468
00:26:13.040 --> 00:26:16.810
easy to use tool versus some of the more
advanced things that we can go through for

469
00:26:16.810 --> 00:26:18.220
doing root cause analysis.

470
00:26:18.220 --> 00:26:20.380
>> Exactly, and when you hear the term,
root cause analysis,

471
00:26:20.380 --> 00:26:25.010
you could go all the way over to the dark
side, which black belts and master black

472
00:26:25.010 --> 00:26:28.590
black belts work on where they are doing
things such as hypothesis analysis and

473
00:26:28.590 --> 00:26:29.970
design of experiments.

474
00:26:29.970 --> 00:26:33.975
But even in those scenarios, Lean Six
Sigma says even when you’re working with

475
00:26:33.975 --> 00:26:36.867
something complicated start
with that easy tool first.

476
00:26:36.867 --> 00:26:39.685
Because that tool’s gonna
give you some information and

477
00:26:39.685 --> 00:26:41.156
you might solve the problem.

478
00:26:41.156 --> 00:26:45.705
So back to our presentation, tools we
know that are going to help us in define

479
00:26:45.705 --> 00:26:50.414
are the 5 Whys, which we just saw an
example of, SIPOC which is very similar.

480
00:26:50.414 --> 00:26:53.612
If you were watching
the episode on Tim Woods,

481
00:26:53.612 --> 00:26:59.606
it's very similar that type of exercise,
because it's structured brainstorming.

482
00:26:59.606 --> 00:27:03.895
And we called structured brainstorming
when we have a list of ideas, but

483
00:27:03.895 --> 00:27:06.935
we kind of jump over to
the affinity diagram first.

484
00:27:06.935 --> 00:27:10.342
So in regular brainstorming we say
we just write everything down and

485
00:27:10.342 --> 00:27:12.909
if we have too many things and
we put it in buckets and

486
00:27:12.909 --> 00:27:15.682
structured brainstorming
dtarts from the other way.

487
00:27:15.682 --> 00:27:19.402
And SIPOC stands for Suppliers Input
Process Output and Customer, and

488
00:27:19.402 --> 00:27:22.507
like I said, we'll be working
on an exercise in that area.

489
00:27:22.507 --> 00:27:27.221
Tim Woods we covered in another episode,
but the reason why it's here is

490
00:27:27.221 --> 00:27:32.182
it's possible you already have a project
charter before you enter define.

491
00:27:32.182 --> 00:27:35.160
However, you could
possibly enter define and

492
00:27:35.160 --> 00:27:40.271
not have a clue what you need to work on,
and SIPOC along with Tim Woods could help

493
00:27:40.271 --> 00:27:45.106
you possibly identify some waste or
an area that you wanna start studying.

494
00:27:45.106 --> 00:27:50.632
So, and a process map which we’ve
covered a lot and also that WBS.

495
00:27:50.632 --> 00:27:54.347
>> All right so, we’ve got a lot of great
tools to help us defining, with getting

496
00:27:54.347 --> 00:27:58.593
our system moving along, getting into the
process improvements actually gonna occur.

497
00:27:58.593 --> 00:28:01.193
I know we’ve got a lot more to talk
about with the define phase, but

498
00:28:01.193 --> 00:28:02.872
we’re kind of out of time on this episode.

499
00:28:02.872 --> 00:28:06.722
Do you have any last thoughts you want to
impart on our viewers before we wrap up?

500
00:28:06.722 --> 00:28:10.530
>> Just that to remember define is so
creative.

501
00:28:10.530 --> 00:28:11.923
There's two rules.

502
00:28:11.923 --> 00:28:13.165
And this is very important.

503
00:28:13.165 --> 00:28:16.520
The two rules is that in define,
you have to have a process map and

504
00:28:16.520 --> 00:28:18.586
you have to end with a project charter.

505
00:28:18.586 --> 00:28:19.446
>> All right.

506
00:28:19.446 --> 00:28:21.929
Well, ladies and gentlemen,
I hope you guys enjoyed the episode.

507
00:28:21.929 --> 00:28:22.993
Stay tuned.
We've got more

508
00:28:22.993 --> 00:28:25.964
of the Define phase coming up and
then the whole rest of the model coming.

509
00:28:25.964 --> 00:28:29.366
Moving down the line too,
you don't want to miss out on that.

510
00:28:29.366 --> 00:28:30.794
So stay tuned and
keep your eyes on the screen.

511
00:28:30.794 --> 00:28:34.590
But for right now for this episode,
we're going to go ahead and sign off.

512
00:28:34.590 --> 00:28:37.132
So signing off for
IT Pro TV, I'm Don Pezet.

513
00:28:37.132 --> 00:28:38.642
And I'm Dr. Stern.

514
00:28:38.642 --> 00:28:39.849
>> And we'll see you next time.

515
00:28:39.849 --> 00:28:45.660
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In further elaboration of the Define Phase in the DMAIC process, concepts like Voice of the Customer (VOC), the SIPOC diagram, Critical to Quality (CTQ), and the Thought Process Mapping (TPM) tool are explained to viewers so that they can capitalize on these critical thinking tools and identify areas in a process that need to be looked at.
episodes.title: Define Phase Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.170 --> 00:00:14.636
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:14.636 --> 00:00:17.352
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:17.352 --> 00:00:21.796
I'm your host, Don Pezet, back again
with another episode of Lean Six Sigma.

5
00:00:21.796 --> 00:00:24.680
And in this episode,
we're gonna be continuing on with D,

6
00:00:24.680 --> 00:00:28.604
the define phase that we kind of started
with the DMAIC model in the last episode,

7
00:00:28.604 --> 00:00:30.005
and ran out of time, right?

8
00:00:30.005 --> 00:00:33.588
We talked about some of the tools, but
we've got a lot more to go over here.

9
00:00:33.588 --> 00:00:35.672
So we're gonna be kicking
back off with that.

10
00:00:35.672 --> 00:00:38.797
And back here to help with this,
we've got Dr. Stern on the show again.

11
00:00:38.797 --> 00:00:40.755
And Dr. Stern, where do we wanna start?

12
00:00:40.755 --> 00:00:45.094
>> Well I think I'd like to start
addressing some more tools in the define

13
00:00:45.094 --> 00:00:47.680
phase, because there's tons of tools.

14
00:00:47.680 --> 00:00:49.704
And as we mentioned in
the previous episode,

15
00:00:49.704 --> 00:00:52.381
If you don't have a lot of time
you wanna spend it in Define.

16
00:00:52.381 --> 00:00:55.452
And I just wanna remind you
of the goal in Define is that

17
00:00:55.452 --> 00:00:58.731
we don't wanna leave Define
without a project charter,

18
00:00:58.731 --> 00:01:03.512
but we also wanna make absolutely sure
that everyone knows what we're working on,

19
00:01:03.512 --> 00:01:07.088
and we wanna make sure that we're
working on the right issue.

20
00:01:07.088 --> 00:01:10.799
One of the beauties of the DMAIC
model is that attention to,

21
00:01:10.799 --> 00:01:12.963
am I working on the right problem?

22
00:01:12.963 --> 00:01:17.172
I've mentioned in many episodes that
we have a tendency to be reactive,

23
00:01:17.172 --> 00:01:18.213
someone runs in.

24
00:01:18.213 --> 00:01:21.520
In our last episode we had
the opportunity to look at five Y's and

25
00:01:21.520 --> 00:01:23.922
we could even be working
on the wrong problem.

26
00:01:23.922 --> 00:01:27.895
So Define is just as much about making
sure you know what you're working on,

27
00:01:27.895 --> 00:01:31.496
as the people that you're working for
know what you're working on,

28
00:01:31.496 --> 00:01:32.630
if that makes sense.

29
00:01:32.630 --> 00:01:37.006
>> Absolutely, and we talked about
some of the ways to do that.

30
00:01:37.006 --> 00:01:40.506
We touched on the WBS
a couple of times now.

31
00:01:40.506 --> 00:01:41.796
That's one that we've seen.

32
00:01:41.796 --> 00:01:44.515
But there are a few other tools that we
looked at that we haven't really spent

33
00:01:44.515 --> 00:01:45.630
a lot of time on yet, correct?

34
00:01:45.630 --> 00:01:48.885
>> That's correct.
And one that we didn't get to address

35
00:01:48.885 --> 00:01:54.131
fully in the last episode is the very
powerful tool called the SIPOC.

36
00:01:54.131 --> 00:01:58.980
And the SIPOC works an awful lot like Tim
Woods, so if you saw that episode you'll

37
00:01:58.980 --> 00:02:02.422
know that this is a structured
brainstorming exercise.

38
00:02:02.422 --> 00:02:06.880
And the SIPOC is used kind of to
replace the old quality circles.

39
00:02:06.880 --> 00:02:11.561
In the TQM days, one of the things
that happened was people started

40
00:02:11.561 --> 00:02:16.922
realizing that we need to talk to
the people who actually touch the process.

41
00:02:16.922 --> 00:02:21.256
And so quality circles, which still happen
sometimes in manufacturing environments,

42
00:02:21.256 --> 00:02:24.954
quality circles bring everyone that's
working together on the process and

43
00:02:24.954 --> 00:02:26.297
they have a conversation.

44
00:02:26.297 --> 00:02:31.422
Over the years, sometimes it's turned
out that that's just not cost effective.

45
00:02:31.422 --> 00:02:35.356
And sometimes there's challenges,
like people are in different buildings or

46
00:02:35.356 --> 00:02:37.422
even in different countries sometimes.

47
00:02:37.422 --> 00:02:40.927
So, the SIPOC is a way to quickly
identify the players on the process

48
00:02:40.927 --> 00:02:45.296
that you're working on, and then make sure
that you're including everyone in that

49
00:02:45.296 --> 00:02:48.088
circle when you're doing
the process improvement.

50
00:02:48.088 --> 00:02:54.213
So, SIPOC is, as I mentioned earlier,
kind of replaces those quality circles.

51
00:02:54.213 --> 00:02:58.559
You'll see that SIPOC stands for
suppliers, input,

52
00:02:58.559 --> 00:03:01.213
process, output and customer.

53
00:03:01.213 --> 00:03:03.714
It's not as jazzy as Tim Woods.

54
00:03:03.714 --> 00:03:06.172
Tim Woods is a little easier for
me to remember.

55
00:03:06.172 --> 00:03:11.630
I have heard people call this a SIPOC but
technically it's called a SIPOC.

56
00:03:11.630 --> 00:03:14.446
But again structured brainstorming,
and the idea here,

57
00:03:14.446 --> 00:03:17.505
I'm gonna show you some other
ways that you can use this model.

58
00:03:17.505 --> 00:03:21.442
But when you're in Define and
you're using the SIPOC model,

59
00:03:21.442 --> 00:03:24.631
what we're trying to do
is identify the players.

60
00:03:24.631 --> 00:03:28.870
And Don, I'd just like to talk a little
bit about what is value in that,

61
00:03:28.870 --> 00:03:32.838
just in general, about knowing
who's involved in your project?

62
00:03:32.838 --> 00:03:36.297
>> Well, if you think about it, we're
trying to do process improvement, right?

63
00:03:36.297 --> 00:03:39.672
And, when you're talking of process
improvement, that means there's probably

64
00:03:39.672 --> 00:03:42.673
something wrong, and if we can improve
on it, we can make things better.

65
00:03:42.673 --> 00:03:46.672
Well, where could the possible
sources of that problem be?

66
00:03:46.672 --> 00:03:50.030
There's a lot of people involved
in any given process, and so

67
00:03:50.030 --> 00:03:54.099
looking at this list, when you see
supplier, input, process, output,

68
00:03:54.099 --> 00:03:57.797
customer, it just reads as a list
of possible sources of a problem.

69
00:03:57.797 --> 00:04:00.058
I could have a problem at any
one of these spots, and so

70
00:04:00.058 --> 00:04:03.797
I'm gonna need feedback and input from all
of them to make that determination, right?

71
00:04:03.797 --> 00:04:08.778
>> Exactly, and as in all other
structured brainstorming models

72
00:04:08.778 --> 00:04:13.666
covered in Lean Six Sigma,
this template is available in your

73
00:04:13.666 --> 00:04:18.554
course files and also is part of
the study package if you decide

74
00:04:18.554 --> 00:04:23.172
that you wanna take the Lean Six Sigma,
yellow belt exam.

75
00:04:23.172 --> 00:04:27.610
The thing that's kinda cool about SIPOC
is that it was meant to be a paper,

76
00:04:27.610 --> 00:04:32.192
pencil tool, but there's a really jazzy
way use that you can present this if

77
00:04:32.192 --> 00:04:36.588
you're trying to give some information
to your sponsor or to your boss.

78
00:04:36.588 --> 00:04:41.922
So, I think the easiest way to do this
is just to kinda jump into an exercise.

79
00:04:41.922 --> 00:04:44.397
And we'll use the same example we used for

80
00:04:44.397 --> 00:04:47.380
Tim Woods where we were
trying to identify waste.

81
00:04:47.380 --> 00:04:50.755
I'm going to pretend like we're
managing a fast-food company.

82
00:04:50.755 --> 00:04:55.660
So, I'm trying to figure out, in this
scenario I don't even know what it is

83
00:04:55.660 --> 00:05:00.140
I wanna work on yet, but
I wanna identify the players, right?

84
00:05:00.140 --> 00:05:03.300
I could also use this model if I
knew what I was gonna work on,

85
00:05:03.300 --> 00:05:04.380
it might be even easier.

86
00:05:04.380 --> 00:05:07.210
But, in this case I'm using
it kind of in a generic way.

87
00:05:07.210 --> 00:05:11.045
So, if I were a fast-food company,
who are some of my suppliers?

88
00:05:11.045 --> 00:05:14.062
Of course the first person I
think about is the meat supplier,

89
00:05:14.062 --> 00:05:17.384
cuz if it's a fast-food place,
they probably serve hamburgers.

90
00:05:17.384 --> 00:05:20.337
Can you think of any other suppliers, Don?

91
00:05:20.337 --> 00:05:22.850
>> There's a lot of inventory,
just look at your inventory list.

92
00:05:22.850 --> 00:05:25.296
So we've got wrappers for the hamburgers.

93
00:05:25.296 --> 00:05:25.921
You have got cups.

94
00:05:25.921 --> 00:05:27.212
You've got soda, syrup.

95
00:05:27.212 --> 00:05:30.553
You've got all those various [INAUDIBLE],
and they might all come from one supplier

96
00:05:30.553 --> 00:05:33.910
if you're lucky, but the odds are they're
going from many different suppliers.

97
00:05:33.910 --> 00:05:40.253
>> Exactly, and input, and try to remember
these are meant to be broad terms.

98
00:05:40.253 --> 00:05:44.455
They're meant to kick off your critical
thinking, so someone's dropped a problem

99
00:05:44.455 --> 00:05:47.130
in your lap that this case
we just started the new job.

100
00:05:47.130 --> 00:05:48.712
And so how long do you do this?

101
00:05:48.712 --> 00:05:53.177
You do it until you run out of ideas
because it’s supposed to help you think

102
00:05:53.177 --> 00:05:55.421
about things that you wanna look at.

103
00:05:55.421 --> 00:05:59.424
The other rule about structured
brainstorming is that if something shows

104
00:05:59.424 --> 00:06:03.876
up in more than one category, that’s kind
of a cool thing because it’s giving you

105
00:06:03.876 --> 00:06:06.087
an automatic prioritization, right?

106
00:06:06.087 --> 00:06:07.003
Okay, so input.

107
00:06:07.003 --> 00:06:08.606
And when we think of input,

108
00:06:08.606 --> 00:06:12.378
anything that actually comes
into our fast-food restaurant.

109
00:06:12.378 --> 00:06:15.700
And of course the first thing that
comes to my mind is customers.

110
00:06:15.700 --> 00:06:17.087
>> Customers are a big part of it.

111
00:06:17.087 --> 00:06:19.546
You've also got other things.

112
00:06:19.546 --> 00:06:23.665
If you're part of a franchise,
you might receive marketing materials from

113
00:06:23.665 --> 00:06:26.962
the franchisee, franchisor,
I always get those mixed up.

114
00:06:26.962 --> 00:06:27.796
>> Yeah, me too.

115
00:06:27.796 --> 00:06:31.598
>> So there's other types of input
that might happen besides people, but,

116
00:06:31.598 --> 00:06:34.253
it all really kinda factors
into the full process.

117
00:06:34.253 --> 00:06:36.297
>> Sure, and other things come in.

118
00:06:36.297 --> 00:06:40.399
Cleaning supplies, things that
your suppliers might bring to you,

119
00:06:40.399 --> 00:06:42.670
you have money, all of these things.

120
00:06:42.670 --> 00:06:46.422
So, yes, you just wanna think
of everything that is an input.

121
00:06:46.422 --> 00:06:47.420
Now, process.

122
00:06:47.420 --> 00:06:50.905
For fast-food we have of course
the cooking process, but

123
00:06:50.905 --> 00:06:53.548
what are some other
processes that we have?

124
00:06:53.548 --> 00:06:55.004
>> New employee onboarding.

125
00:06:55.004 --> 00:06:59.750
>> Absolutely, and we have the change
process and the delivery process, and

126
00:06:59.750 --> 00:07:03.379
we might even have a process
to keep our bathrooms clean.

127
00:07:03.379 --> 00:07:04.754
I hope, right?

128
00:07:04.754 --> 00:07:09.670
[LAUGH] And output is anything that's
going out of the restaurant, so

129
00:07:09.670 --> 00:07:13.753
think about things that
are going out of the restaurant.

130
00:07:13.753 --> 00:07:15.547
>> And that's usually gonna
be your product, right, so

131
00:07:15.547 --> 00:07:16.797
whatever it is that you're selling.

132
00:07:16.797 --> 00:07:17.797
>> Absolutely.

133
00:07:17.797 --> 00:07:24.087
>> It could be employees and customers,
too, going out of the organization.

134
00:07:24.087 --> 00:07:27.171
Reputation and marketing, those are all
things that come out of an organization.

135
00:07:27.171 --> 00:07:30.685
>> Exactly, and then we get to
the final one, customer, and

136
00:07:30.685 --> 00:07:34.504
of course if I'm buying the hamburger
I would be the customer.

137
00:07:34.504 --> 00:07:39.869
But in a fast-food restaurant think
about all the other types of customers,

138
00:07:39.869 --> 00:07:44.670
and Don already mentioned one,
like the franchisee, franchiser.

139
00:07:44.670 --> 00:07:47.600
>> Yeah, and you may have,
I don't wanna call it,

140
00:07:47.600 --> 00:07:50.546
I wanna say companies within a company,
right?

141
00:07:50.546 --> 00:07:53.812
A lot of larger organizations
have different departments, and

142
00:07:53.812 --> 00:07:57.630
they have to do internal billing and
code of accounting and all that stuff.

143
00:07:57.630 --> 00:08:01.619
So you're kind of a customer of
your own business in a way, and

144
00:08:01.619 --> 00:08:06.087
so that can happen, it's a very
real thing in large organizations.

145
00:08:06.087 --> 00:08:06.639
>> Exactly,

146
00:08:06.639 --> 00:08:10.879
and yesterday when we were working on,
I mean in our former episode, I'm sorry.

147
00:08:10.879 --> 00:08:15.618
In our former episode, we were working
with Tim Woods, and we took Tim Woods and

148
00:08:15.618 --> 00:08:17.755
we applied it to our own household.

149
00:08:17.755 --> 00:08:20.781
So I just wanna quickly,
we're not gonna go in depth here, but

150
00:08:20.781 --> 00:08:24.337
just remember you can use Lean Six Sigma
tools to help your personal life.

151
00:08:24.337 --> 00:08:28.379
If I'm trying to identify
the players in my household,

152
00:08:28.379 --> 00:08:32.421
who are some of the suppliers
in our house, utilities?

153
00:08:32.421 --> 00:08:35.411
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, you have your facility itself,

154
00:08:35.411 --> 00:08:39.373
the house itself which in here
you have like a breadwinner or

155
00:08:39.373 --> 00:08:43.588
someone in the family who's
generating money to pay for that.

156
00:08:43.588 --> 00:08:48.125
You've got your utilities that come in,
your cable, your phone, electric,

157
00:08:48.125 --> 00:08:49.421
water, all of those.

158
00:08:49.421 --> 00:08:51.224
>> There's a lot.
>> There's a lot of different components

159
00:08:51.224 --> 00:08:51.921
that go into a home.

160
00:08:51.921 --> 00:08:56.670
>> And then when you think input, that's
anyone that walks across your front door.

161
00:08:56.670 --> 00:09:02.046
Well, your family comes in your front
door, you hope, pets, neighbors, right?

162
00:09:02.046 --> 00:09:03.337
>> Yeah, bugs.

163
00:09:03.337 --> 00:09:03.879
>> Bugs.

164
00:09:03.879 --> 00:09:04.927
[LAUGH]
>> In Florida,

165
00:09:04.927 --> 00:09:06.921
we have to deal with that, not everywhere.

166
00:09:06.921 --> 00:09:10.071
[LAUGH]
>> And then processes would be,

167
00:09:10.071 --> 00:09:12.379
there's a dishwashing process.

168
00:09:12.379 --> 00:09:15.004
There's a clothes washing process.

169
00:09:15.004 --> 00:09:18.338
There's an overall cleaning process,
that type of thing.

170
00:09:18.338 --> 00:09:20.945
And output would be anything
that goes out your door, so

171
00:09:20.945 --> 00:09:23.504
what are some things that go
out your door at your home?

172
00:09:23.504 --> 00:09:25.421
>> You would hope a happy family.

173
00:09:25.421 --> 00:09:27.840
[LAUGH]
>> Oh, yes, I love that.

174
00:09:27.840 --> 00:09:30.500
>> Not always, but
that's what you hope for.

175
00:09:30.500 --> 00:09:32.379
That's hard to think of.

176
00:09:32.379 --> 00:09:33.087
How about garbage?

177
00:09:33.087 --> 00:09:34.810
[LAUGH]
>> Garbage goes out.

178
00:09:34.810 --> 00:09:35.337
Sure.

179
00:09:35.337 --> 00:09:38.571
And then customers are people like
your family and your neighbors and

180
00:09:38.571 --> 00:09:40.254
your friends and things like that.

181
00:09:40.254 --> 00:09:44.587
So, okay, so we kind of got the basic idea
of the SIPOC, but what do we do with it?

182
00:09:44.587 --> 00:09:46.505
Why do we care about the SIPOC?

183
00:09:46.505 --> 00:09:53.256
So, the reason we care about the SIPOC is
because, well, there's a lot of reasons.

184
00:09:53.256 --> 00:09:58.128
Just knowing who's involved is just huge,
as we mentioned, but

185
00:09:58.128 --> 00:10:01.504
also, it might help us
identify a champion.

186
00:10:01.504 --> 00:10:05.462
It might help us identify someone
who's already worked on this project.

187
00:10:05.462 --> 00:10:09.048
One of the things that Lean strives for
is to reduce redundancy.

188
00:10:09.048 --> 00:10:12.962
You'd be surprised at how many people
are doing the same or similar reports.

189
00:10:12.962 --> 00:10:17.327
So sometimes when you go through a SIPOC
you're able to identify things such

190
00:10:17.327 --> 00:10:17.880
as that.

191
00:10:17.880 --> 00:10:20.382
Also, on a more negative note,

192
00:10:20.382 --> 00:10:25.482
you might identify people that
could possibly get in your way, so

193
00:10:25.482 --> 00:10:30.879
that you can start doing a bit of
a risk management strategy, right?

194
00:10:30.879 --> 00:10:31.587
>> Yeah, that's a good point.

195
00:10:31.587 --> 00:10:35.125
Then we could use this before a problem
occurs as opposed to waiting until

196
00:10:35.125 --> 00:10:36.759
afterwards, and then using it.

197
00:10:36.759 --> 00:10:37.462
It really works both ways.

198
00:10:37.462 --> 00:10:41.772
>> Exactly, and there's a real
advantage to doing one large SIPOC for

199
00:10:41.772 --> 00:10:44.504
the department that you're working for.

200
00:10:44.504 --> 00:10:49.630
Because then, if you focus in on a
particular project, so for example, at our

201
00:10:49.630 --> 00:10:55.087
fast-food maybe we decide what we want to
improve is our cooking process, right?

202
00:10:55.087 --> 00:11:00.961
And then I would go back and do a SIPOC
but just on that one particular process.

203
00:11:00.961 --> 00:11:05.191
Sometimes you can use the same
SIPOC from project to project, so

204
00:11:05.191 --> 00:11:07.629
it's just a really good thing to do.

205
00:11:07.629 --> 00:11:12.051
Now before we move on I wanna point out
that there's a couple of other things that

206
00:11:12.051 --> 00:11:13.379
SIPOC is valuable for.

207
00:11:13.379 --> 00:11:16.820
It can be used as a mini
problem solving model.

208
00:11:16.820 --> 00:11:19.900
So let's say you're in a project
management situation and an employee comes

209
00:11:19.900 --> 00:11:25.190
to you and you've already decided that's
not human resource worthy problem,

210
00:11:25.190 --> 00:11:29.460
you can sit down and even though you might
not be sitting there going, supplier,

211
00:11:29.460 --> 00:11:34.130
input, process, you can use this as a map
to kind of talk through their problems.

212
00:11:34.130 --> 00:11:35.400
Who's contributing to the problem?

213
00:11:35.400 --> 00:11:36.961
Which would be your supplier, right?

214
00:11:36.961 --> 00:11:39.255
What is the input you're getting,
what's the output?

215
00:11:39.255 --> 00:11:42.796
You would use words that make
more sense to the employee.

216
00:11:42.796 --> 00:11:47.629
It would just be kind of a map,
a map to help you do some problem solving.

217
00:11:47.629 --> 00:11:52.547
Again, it's just amazing all
the things they do a SIPOC now, and

218
00:11:52.547 --> 00:11:57.824
you can make it just really beautiful
presentation, and a lot of times

219
00:11:57.824 --> 00:12:04.462
just giving That information to someone in
the C-Suite about your department is huge.

220
00:12:04.462 --> 00:12:09.052
To be able to tell them who contributes
to your particular department,

221
00:12:09.052 --> 00:12:13.879
how the processes work, and being able
to put that on just one simple form.

222
00:12:13.879 --> 00:12:17.614
It's very much appreciated, especially
in large companies that might not

223
00:12:17.614 --> 00:12:19.962
really understand what you or
your group does.

224
00:12:22.171 --> 00:12:24.763
So the next thing I'm gonna move on to,
and

225
00:12:24.763 --> 00:12:27.440
we'll cover this quickly is a thought map.

226
00:12:27.440 --> 00:12:33.005
And these were quite popular about 20
years ago but they've sort of revived.

227
00:12:33.005 --> 00:12:35.430
And they've been known by
a lot of different names.

228
00:12:35.430 --> 00:12:38.712
We're calling it a thought process map,
TPM.

229
00:12:38.712 --> 00:12:42.747
So if you were hypothetically
taking a online exam and

230
00:12:42.747 --> 00:12:48.587
it asked you what TPM meant, then you
would know it was a thought process map.

231
00:12:48.587 --> 00:12:50.642
And there's lots of different
ways you can do this,

232
00:12:50.642 --> 00:12:53.440
and there's tons and tons of software
out there that can assist you.

233
00:12:53.440 --> 00:12:58.025
But if you want to do just a simple bot
process map, in the center of the map you

234
00:12:58.025 --> 00:13:02.628
would put your process, whatever
process that you're trying to improve.

235
00:13:02.628 --> 00:13:05.331
And in this case we were saying we were
were gonna try to improve the cooking

236
00:13:05.331 --> 00:13:06.510
process, right?

237
00:13:06.510 --> 00:13:09.570
So I put the cooking process
in the middle of the map.

238
00:13:09.570 --> 00:13:13.070
And I would just look at all
the different things that are connected.

239
00:13:13.070 --> 00:13:17.837
>> And we're not necessarily worried
about degree of connectivity.

240
00:13:17.837 --> 00:13:19.287
>> Exactly.
>> Like there might be significant things,

241
00:13:19.287 --> 00:13:20.462
there might be insignificant things.

242
00:13:20.462 --> 00:13:23.087
We're just trying to map
out al the things, right?

243
00:13:23.087 --> 00:13:23.961
>> Exactly!

244
00:13:23.961 --> 00:13:27.717
And it's just that again, designed to
capitalize on this critical thinking

245
00:13:27.717 --> 00:13:30.212
tools, get me thinking and
get me moving forward.

246
00:13:30.212 --> 00:13:34.104
And then finally, the last thing
we're gonna be talking about,

247
00:13:34.104 --> 00:13:35.671
is the different voices.

248
00:13:35.671 --> 00:13:41.060
Lean Six Sigma is quite married to paying
attention to the different voices.

249
00:13:41.060 --> 00:13:45.254
Now most of us are familiar with VOC,
which stands for Voice Of the Customer.

250
00:13:45.254 --> 00:13:50.960
However, Lean really emphasizes Voice Of
the Customer to the point that they

251
00:13:50.960 --> 00:13:57.212
say we do not have a successful Lean Six
Sigma project unless the customer's happy.

252
00:13:57.212 --> 00:14:01.879
Now, I'm sure a lot of you have heard of
the term Internal and External Customer.

253
00:14:01.879 --> 00:14:06.522
So, examples of internal customers would
be any be one that you have a little bit

254
00:14:06.522 --> 00:14:07.504
dependence on.

255
00:14:07.504 --> 00:14:10.629
That you had to please in order
to get your job done, right?

256
00:14:10.629 --> 00:14:14.703
And external customers are obvious,
the people who are buying our product or

257
00:14:14.703 --> 00:14:15.838
buying our service.

258
00:14:15.838 --> 00:14:21.296
There is a thought in Lean Six Sigma that
when we think about voice of the customer,

259
00:14:21.296 --> 00:14:23.920
we want to start including suppliers.

260
00:14:23.920 --> 00:14:27.590
Now remember in the SIPOC,
we called them suppliers.

261
00:14:27.590 --> 00:14:30.340
Vendors by default are suppliers.

262
00:14:30.340 --> 00:14:32.950
>> But suppliers could be
anyone that we have to depend

263
00:14:32.950 --> 00:14:34.980
on to get information to get our job done.

264
00:14:34.980 --> 00:14:40.587
So, having a really good understanding of
the voice of the customer is important.

265
00:14:40.587 --> 00:14:44.046
Now, there's tools that
you can use to do that.

266
00:14:44.046 --> 00:14:49.007
And probably the most common tools
would be things such as surveys,

267
00:14:49.007 --> 00:14:52.588
interviews, short forum,
I mean small forum.

268
00:14:52.588 --> 00:14:53.885
I don't know if you can
have a short forum.

269
00:14:53.885 --> 00:14:54.631
>> [LAUGH]
>> Don, can you?

270
00:14:54.631 --> 00:14:56.322
[LAUGH] It would just
have to be really fast.

271
00:14:56.322 --> 00:14:59.361
>> [LAUGH]
>> The next term is called,

272
00:14:59.361 --> 00:15:01.671
Voice Of the Employee.

273
00:15:01.671 --> 00:15:06.270
Now Voice Of the Employee, we spend a lot
of time in business, taking about how

274
00:15:06.270 --> 00:15:11.080
important the Voice Of Employee is because
it can give us ideas about the product,

275
00:15:11.080 --> 00:15:14.216
it can give us ideas about
how things are working now,

276
00:15:14.216 --> 00:15:16.754
lots of different pieces of information.

277
00:15:16.754 --> 00:15:21.990
Many times employees have innovative ideas
that just really don't get explored.

278
00:15:21.990 --> 00:15:27.370
Now even though we do a lot of
talking about voice of the employee,

279
00:15:27.370 --> 00:15:32.250
it sometimes gets a little swept under the
carpet, people don't really pay attention.

280
00:15:32.250 --> 00:15:33.449
And the thing that is so

281
00:15:33.449 --> 00:15:37.490
cool about voice of the employee is that
you can use the same exact tools to get

282
00:15:37.490 --> 00:15:41.171
the voice of the employee that you
get from the voice of the customer.

283
00:15:41.171 --> 00:15:44.684
Because you can use surveys and
interviews and

284
00:15:44.684 --> 00:15:49.920
you could duplicate those tools, so
it's kind of a Lean way to do it.

285
00:15:49.920 --> 00:15:53.714
You could be asking your employees almost
the same thing that you're asking your

286
00:15:53.714 --> 00:15:54.337
customers.

287
00:15:54.337 --> 00:15:57.023
>> And a lot of times you'll be surprised
with the input that you get from your

288
00:15:57.023 --> 00:15:57.830
own employees.

289
00:15:57.830 --> 00:16:02.040
There are some employees who may not
be very high up in the responsibility

290
00:16:02.040 --> 00:16:06.520
hierarchy but might have very valuable
feedback they can provide you that can

291
00:16:06.520 --> 00:16:09.630
immediately isolate the source of
a problem or have a process improvement.

292
00:16:09.630 --> 00:16:14.290
It's as simple as having that
suggestion box stuck on the wall that

293
00:16:14.290 --> 00:16:15.600
people put in suggestions.

294
00:16:15.600 --> 00:16:17.170
Voice of the employee.

295
00:16:17.170 --> 00:16:18.045
It comes right from there.

296
00:16:18.045 --> 00:16:18.879
>> Exactly.

297
00:16:18.879 --> 00:16:22.421
I'm always amazed at employee suggestions,
and many,

298
00:16:22.421 --> 00:16:27.067
many of the Lean Six Sigma projects that
I've worked on have come from a very

299
00:16:27.067 --> 00:16:31.850
simple idea that the employee had but
was not able to get to the right person.

300
00:16:31.850 --> 00:16:34.270
And that's one of the things
that Lean Six Sigma does.

301
00:16:34.270 --> 00:16:36.289
It helps you organize your thoughts so

302
00:16:36.289 --> 00:16:39.961
you can get your suggestions to
the right person and really be heard.

303
00:16:39.961 --> 00:16:44.602
The next one is VOP and this stands for
Voice of the Process and

304
00:16:44.602 --> 00:16:48.337
Lean Six Sigma has a lot
of these types of things.

305
00:16:48.337 --> 00:16:50.171
When they say Voice of the Process,

306
00:16:50.171 --> 00:16:53.300
they want you to actually
pretend like you're the process.

307
00:16:53.300 --> 00:16:55.409
And if the process could speak,

308
00:16:55.409 --> 00:16:59.087
what kinds of things might
that process be telling you?

309
00:16:59.087 --> 00:17:02.489
Can you think of anything that the process
might be telling you that could be

310
00:17:02.489 --> 00:17:03.254
helpful, Don?

311
00:17:03.254 --> 00:17:08.055
>> You know, this has always been a hard
one for me because to think in terms of

312
00:17:08.055 --> 00:17:13.243
the process itself, but when things
are maybe overly complex, you can -- you

313
00:17:13.243 --> 00:17:18.295
can kind of see that just by looking at
the checklist or workflow of a process.

314
00:17:18.295 --> 00:17:19.893
If it looks overly complex to you,

315
00:17:19.893 --> 00:17:23.379
then that's something that process
would probably say to you if it could.

316
00:17:23.379 --> 00:17:28.170
>> And that's such a great point because
one of the lean six sigma goals is to make

317
00:17:28.170 --> 00:17:29.212
things simple.

318
00:17:29.212 --> 00:17:33.830
When we build complexity into
the process it slows us down.

319
00:17:33.830 --> 00:17:36.711
The process could also be saying
something like help me, I’m melting.

320
00:17:36.711 --> 00:17:37.755
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right?

321
00:17:37.755 --> 00:17:40.754
Or it could say I’m outdated.

322
00:17:40.754 --> 00:17:45.912
Now the reason why we need to look at the
voice of the process is that our boss or

323
00:17:45.912 --> 00:17:50.749
our work environment might actually
be a asking us to do something where

324
00:17:50.749 --> 00:17:53.754
our process is simply
not capable of doing.

325
00:17:53.754 --> 00:17:58.566
And so in define especially in the black
belt world a lot of attention is paid to

326
00:17:58.566 --> 00:18:01.462
things called process capability analysis.

327
00:18:01.462 --> 00:18:05.671
And that's just looking at the process and
saying hey, let's be reasonable here.

328
00:18:05.671 --> 00:18:08.212
Can this process even really do it?

329
00:18:08.212 --> 00:18:09.613
Now if you determine and

330
00:18:09.613 --> 00:18:12.905
define that there's something
that needs to be done but

331
00:18:12.905 --> 00:18:17.962
Your process isn't capable of doing it,
you're not necessarily dead in the water.

332
00:18:17.962 --> 00:18:19.122
But you do have to stop and

333
00:18:19.122 --> 00:18:21.895
have that conversation with
whoever you're working for.

334
00:18:21.895 --> 00:18:25.158
Because if your process isn't capable,
nothing's going to work.

335
00:18:25.158 --> 00:18:29.756
But there are a myriad of things you can
do to make your process capable once

336
00:18:29.756 --> 00:18:32.885
you identify that it can't
do what you want it do.

337
00:18:32.885 --> 00:18:38.882
So for example, one of the ones everyone
jumps to is we need more resources.

338
00:18:38.882 --> 00:18:44.195
A lot of times in business that isn't
a particularly popular for concept.

339
00:18:44.195 --> 00:18:47.614
But there are other things that you
can do, like maybe better equipment,

340
00:18:47.614 --> 00:18:50.280
more office space, more training,
that type of thing.

341
00:18:50.280 --> 00:18:52.978
So, if you do a capability analysis, and

342
00:18:52.978 --> 00:18:57.849
sometimes they could be very
uncomplicated, like observation, right?

343
00:18:57.849 --> 00:18:58.525
You can just go and watch the process.

344
00:18:58.525 --> 00:19:03.188
If you determine it's simply not capable,
remember, it's not over,

345
00:19:03.188 --> 00:19:07.784
that you wanna just kind of think in
terms of how can I make this capable?

346
00:19:07.784 --> 00:19:12.876
And then finally, on this voices is
something called voice of the business.

347
00:19:12.876 --> 00:19:16.704
Now, voice of the business is kind of
interesting, because you could read 300

348
00:19:16.704 --> 00:19:19.769
pages about it, or you can just
trust what I'm about to tell you.

349
00:19:19.769 --> 00:19:21.294
It says voice of the business,

350
00:19:21.294 --> 00:19:24.001
but what it's really saying
is voice of the industry.

351
00:19:24.001 --> 00:19:27.877
Now, because Lean Six Sigma likes
you to think from different lenses,

352
00:19:27.877 --> 00:19:29.492
from different viewpoints,

353
00:19:29.492 --> 00:19:33.575
I think voice of your business is still
something that you wanna consider.

354
00:19:33.575 --> 00:19:34.185
The voice of your culture.

355
00:19:34.185 --> 00:19:37.473
How things are going in your department,
even.

356
00:19:37.473 --> 00:19:40.699
So, I wouldn't discount
that as part of the voices.

357
00:19:40.699 --> 00:19:45.403
But when you hear the term Lean Six Sigma,
VOB, it says Voice Of the Business.

358
00:19:45.403 --> 00:19:48.055
But just kind of be aware that
means Voice Of the Industry.

359
00:19:48.055 --> 00:19:53.493
So, if the industry could speak,
what might it tell you?

360
00:19:53.493 --> 00:19:57.158
And first, let's kind of think about,
what are some compliance,

361
00:19:57.158 --> 00:19:58.843
OSHA is a compliance, right?

362
00:19:58.843 --> 00:20:00.328
So, that would be an industry thing.

363
00:20:00.328 --> 00:20:03.695
So, the IRS.

364
00:20:03.695 --> 00:20:04.345
Yikes.

365
00:20:04.345 --> 00:20:04.879
FDA.

366
00:20:04.879 --> 00:20:05.437
Right?

367
00:20:05.437 --> 00:20:10.336
So, certainly, one of the industries
could be just talking about compliance.

368
00:20:10.336 --> 00:20:14.051
Don, can you think of any other things
that the industry might be telling us?

369
00:20:14.051 --> 00:20:15.094
>> We see a lot of it, I mean,

370
00:20:15.094 --> 00:20:18.137
it just kind of building off of compliance
with EPA rules that are coming up.

371
00:20:18.137 --> 00:20:19.274
>> Oh, absolutely.

372
00:20:19.274 --> 00:20:23.391
>> And so you might be in an industry
where you have a factory that has certain

373
00:20:23.391 --> 00:20:24.750
emissions that occur.

374
00:20:24.750 --> 00:20:28.662
And you might feel that those
are perfectly normal and safe, but

375
00:20:28.662 --> 00:20:31.994
then the EPA comes along and
passes a rule tightening or

376
00:20:31.994 --> 00:20:35.349
increasing governance of
whatever that emission is.

377
00:20:35.349 --> 00:20:38.012
Well, that's their way of
communicating to you, hey,

378
00:20:38.012 --> 00:20:40.620
it doesn't matter what you
necessarily think is safe,

379
00:20:40.620 --> 00:20:43.965
we're telling you, these
are the standards we're putting in place.

380
00:20:43.965 --> 00:20:45.057
And so we have to react to that.

381
00:20:45.057 --> 00:20:46.124
>> Exactly.

382
00:20:46.124 --> 00:20:50.790
Exactly, and the industry might
even tell you some things that

383
00:20:50.790 --> 00:20:54.312
you learned from the process,
like trends, or

384
00:20:54.312 --> 00:20:59.435
what other people are doing or
what's outdated, what's in vogue.

385
00:20:59.435 --> 00:21:01.625
So, finally, I'd like to address CTQ's.

386
00:21:01.625 --> 00:21:05.355
We mentioned this in another episode,
earlier in the program and

387
00:21:05.355 --> 00:21:09.265
we said that CTQ stood for
Critical To Quality.

388
00:21:09.265 --> 00:21:14.093
And we said that there's actually a little
bit of a movement to call it Critical to

389
00:21:14.093 --> 00:21:17.505
Price, Critical to Satisfaction,
Critical to Speed.

390
00:21:17.505 --> 00:21:19.606
But it just got too confusing, so

391
00:21:19.606 --> 00:21:22.765
now everyone refers to it
as Critical To Quality.

392
00:21:22.765 --> 00:21:27.435
Customer requirements by default are
Critical to Quality, and as a reminder,

393
00:21:27.435 --> 00:21:31.225
Critical to Success, Satisfaction,
Better,Faster, More Cost Effective.

394
00:21:31.225 --> 00:21:32.995
These are the things
that we're looking at.

395
00:21:32.995 --> 00:21:37.129
Now the reason I'm bringing them up here,
back in defined,

396
00:21:37.129 --> 00:21:41.101
is that if we're trying to come
up with CTQs and we can't,

397
00:21:41.101 --> 00:21:44.910
two of the tools that we just looked at,
the SIPOC's and

398
00:21:44.910 --> 00:21:49.801
the thought process map, are gonna
help us determine some of our CTQs.

399
00:21:49.801 --> 00:21:53.931
So if we're having a little bit of
an issue of what really is Critical to

400
00:21:53.931 --> 00:21:58.201
Success of this project, we can go back
and we can look at our SIPOC's and

401
00:21:58.201 --> 00:22:02.058
we can say, well, what is Critical
to Quality for my suppliers?

402
00:22:02.058 --> 00:22:04.175
And make sure that we write down a list.

403
00:22:04.175 --> 00:22:07.355
What's critical to input,
output, or to process.

404
00:22:07.355 --> 00:22:10.769
On our thought map, because our
thought map is a little messier.

405
00:22:10.769 --> 00:22:14.185
SIPOC's a bit more structured,
and so you can guess,

406
00:22:14.185 --> 00:22:16.273
the Six Sigma world likes SIPOC.

407
00:22:16.273 --> 00:22:19.152
The Lean world kind of likes
the thought process map.

408
00:22:19.152 --> 00:22:22.015
Because they're a little
bit more creative.

409
00:22:22.015 --> 00:22:25.356
But if I'm looking at
my thought process map,

410
00:22:25.356 --> 00:22:30.756
since it's just a bunch of ideas and
how these ideas connect to my process,

411
00:22:30.756 --> 00:22:34.287
it might give me some ideas
about some of my CTQs.

412
00:22:34.287 --> 00:22:39.859
So, we have other tools that we
wanna cover in other episodes.

413
00:22:39.859 --> 00:22:41.414
>> Right, but these are really important.

414
00:22:41.414 --> 00:22:44.185
I mean you guys have probably
noticed the pattern so

415
00:22:44.185 --> 00:22:47.736
far with SIPOC, with CTQ,
it's all about identifying things.

416
00:22:47.736 --> 00:22:49.245
Right?
Identifying

417
00:22:49.245 --> 00:22:50.795
the areas that we need to look at.

418
00:22:50.795 --> 00:22:54.195
The possible sources of a problem,
the areas that we can measure.

419
00:22:54.195 --> 00:22:59.318
Measure success on critical quality that
reads as almost like a report card for us.

420
00:22:59.318 --> 00:23:02.335
How do we know if our process
is where it needs to be?

421
00:23:02.335 --> 00:23:04.285
So, all of this is really important, and

422
00:23:04.285 --> 00:23:07.463
it's right here in the define phase
at the very beginning, and Dr.

423
00:23:07.463 --> 00:23:11.029
Stern, you said it best, that there's
a lot of stuff that we need to achieve

424
00:23:11.029 --> 00:23:14.483
before we can move out of the define
phase, but if we were to jump ahead into

425
00:23:14.483 --> 00:23:19.195
our later phases, then we don't actually
understand what's Critical for Quality.

426
00:23:19.195 --> 00:23:21.705
Think about the catastrophe
that could come out of that.

427
00:23:21.705 --> 00:23:25.547
We might luck out and do okay but there's
just so many things that could cascade and

428
00:23:25.547 --> 00:23:29.292
become worse and worse if we don't pay
attention so, these are all important.

429
00:23:29.292 --> 00:23:31.498
We do still have a little bit more
to cover on the Define phase, right?

430
00:23:31.498 --> 00:23:32.635
>> We do.

431
00:23:32.635 --> 00:23:36.375
>> So, I know we're running short on this
episode so why don't we pause here we'll

432
00:23:36.375 --> 00:23:39.895
wrap this episode up and then we'll
come back with more on the Define phase,

433
00:23:39.895 --> 00:23:41.930
get a chance to see some other,
like I know,

434
00:23:41.930 --> 00:23:44.466
I have the advantage of being
able to see her computer.

435
00:23:44.466 --> 00:23:45.685
>> [LAUGH]
>> So she's got some great stuff that

436
00:23:45.685 --> 00:23:46.928
we're gonna be seeing
here in a few minutes.

437
00:23:46.928 --> 00:23:49.018
But for right now,
we'll go ahead and wrap this one up.

438
00:23:49.018 --> 00:23:56.065
Do you have any parting words
you wanted to throw in?

439
00:23:56.065 --> 00:23:56.814
>> No,
just something that I keep reiterating,

440
00:23:56.814 --> 00:23:57.628
remember Define is a very,
very creative phase.

441
00:23:57.628 --> 00:24:02.556
But your challenge is not to leave
Define without people understanding what

442
00:24:02.556 --> 00:24:04.665
it is you're working on.

443
00:24:04.665 --> 00:24:05.580
>> Right, not necessarily.

444
00:24:05.580 --> 00:24:09.238
Really agreeing with, but at least
understanding and being on the same page.

445
00:24:09.238 --> 00:24:11.097
All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed the episode.

446
00:24:11.097 --> 00:24:11.769
Stay tuned.

447
00:24:11.769 --> 00:24:16.257
We've got more Lean Six Sigma coming up,
but for now, signing off for ITProTV,

448
00:24:16.257 --> 00:24:17.184
I'm Don Pezet.

449
00:24:17.184 --> 00:24:18.414
>> And I'm Dr. Stern.

450
00:24:18.414 --> 00:24:25.218
>> And we'll see you next time.

451
00:24:25.218 --> 00:24:27.010
[SOUND]

episodes.description: Aligning the goals with business initiatives on the project charter and putting projected return on investments (ROI) are the last portions of the Define Phase that should be covered before one moves on to the Measure Phase. Viewers will hear further explanations of activities and tools before transitioning to the next phase in the DMAIC process.
episodes.title: Define Phase Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.004
[SOUND]

2
00:00:03.004 --> 00:00:12.273
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:12.273 --> 00:00:14.245
>> Alright good morning good afternoon and

4
00:00:14.245 --> 00:00:17.093
good evening welcome back to
another episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:17.093 --> 00:00:19.541
I'm your host Don Pezet back again with
another episode of Lean Six Sigma.

6
00:00:19.541 --> 00:00:25.030
In this episode we're going to be winding
down on the defined phase of the DuMaic

7
00:00:25.030 --> 00:00:29.470
model we've started it off, we've
talked about it for two episodes now.

8
00:00:29.470 --> 00:00:33.860
It's really good stuff we need to jump
into to kind of wrap that up and make sure

9
00:00:33.860 --> 00:00:39.220
we're where we need to be before we
transition into the next four phases.

10
00:00:39.220 --> 00:00:40.464
So I've got back on the show with us Dr.

11
00:00:40.464 --> 00:00:41.937
Stern is gonna walk us
through that process and

12
00:00:41.937 --> 00:00:43.271
I know you've got some good stuff for us.

13
00:00:43.271 --> 00:00:44.650
So I'm gonna turn the floor over to you.

14
00:00:44.650 --> 00:00:45.880
>> Thank you Don.

15
00:00:45.880 --> 00:00:51.943
I'm actually gonna go back to something
you saw in the last episode and

16
00:00:51.943 --> 00:00:55.740
that's the activity and tool sheet.

17
00:00:55.740 --> 00:00:58.870
We're gonna be spending a lot of
time on this particular collateral.

18
00:00:58.870 --> 00:01:03.600
However, we're just gonna
focus on the define part.

19
00:01:03.600 --> 00:01:06.620
Now, I know you can't see it, and
I'm gonna enlarge the define part as we

20
00:01:06.620 --> 00:01:10.220
speak about it, but
I wanna let you know why we're doing this.

21
00:01:10.220 --> 00:01:12.270
One, this is an incredible collateral.

22
00:01:12.270 --> 00:01:17.740
I think the first time my company
developed this collateral was 2010.

23
00:01:17.740 --> 00:01:21.090
So, over the last 14 years,
we've streamlined it, made it great.

24
00:01:21.090 --> 00:01:23.270
A lot of times if you're
in a consulting role,

25
00:01:23.270 --> 00:01:28.350
you can use this particular schematic
when you're talking to your client,

26
00:01:28.350 --> 00:01:33.060
and you can kinda figure out
where on the swarm they're at,

27
00:01:33.060 --> 00:01:36.550
because maybe they've already
accomplished some of these things.

28
00:01:36.550 --> 00:01:38.800
Now, in this episode, because define is so

29
00:01:38.800 --> 00:01:42.450
important, we're gonna just talk
about the things in define.

30
00:01:42.450 --> 00:01:43.930
When we move onto the other phases,

31
00:01:43.930 --> 00:01:48.580
I'll refer to the handout, but
we won't be going step by step through it.

32
00:01:48.580 --> 00:01:52.165
The reason we're doing this is
because this is the same for everyone,

33
00:01:52.165 --> 00:01:56.662
it doesn't matter if you're Six Sigma, it
doesn't matter if you're Lean Six Sigma,

34
00:01:56.662 --> 00:01:58.998
it does not matter what
level of belt you are.

35
00:01:58.998 --> 00:02:03.061
If you're a yellow, green,
black, or master black belt.

36
00:02:03.061 --> 00:02:05.750
Define is always the same, and
again it's a very creative phase.

37
00:02:05.750 --> 00:02:10.726
So I'm going to go ahead and
enlarge this portion.

38
00:02:13.327 --> 00:02:17.892
And again, I wanna point out that
the end result of this phase is that

39
00:02:17.892 --> 00:02:22.060
we wanna make sure everyone
understands the project goal.

40
00:02:22.060 --> 00:02:26.670
Now, this is incredibly important, and
we're gonna be addressing this later

41
00:02:26.670 --> 00:02:30.890
in the program, but if you want buy in,
one of the number one reasons people don't

42
00:02:30.890 --> 00:02:34.510
buy into your project is they flat don't
understand what it is you're working on.

43
00:02:34.510 --> 00:02:38.073
The other side of this is that we want

Now in the second column, and again,

So, you've got two different ways that you

the project name and purpose, getting that

00:03:15.060 --> 00:03:17.290
And I think Don and I agree.

00:03:17.290 --> 00:03:21.579

00:04:11.940 --> 00:04:14.701
So then what you're going to want to do,

00:04:19.838 --> 00:04:23.646

You want to make sure that you can

00:04:31.461 --> 00:04:32.374

00:04:32.374 --> 00:04:36.315

The number one most important

00:05:30.020 --> 00:05:32.520

If you don't Have that charter

00:06:14.400 --> 00:06:18.390

00:06:26.390 --> 00:06:30.720
You're just trying to get

00:06:30.720 --> 00:06:33.200

00:06:33.200 --> 00:06:36.070
Okay, so we've also said that

00:06:36.070 --> 00:06:37.220
it says over and over again, and

00:06:37.220 --> 00:06:43.690

00:06:43.690 --> 00:06:48.129
You need to develop a high level process

00:06:48.129 --> 00:06:50.739

I basically just need

00:06:50.739 --> 00:06:55.009

00:06:55.009 --> 00:06:57.891
Now, the next thing that

00:06:57.891 --> 00:07:01.178
we addressed a little bit in

00:07:01.178 --> 00:07:05.920
that's where we identified the process

00:07:05.920 --> 00:07:09.700
Now remember the process owner is the

121
00:07:09.700 --> 00:07:13.930
the champion might be our rah-rah

00:07:16.940 --> 00:07:21.560

00:07:21.560 --> 00:07:25.689

125
00:07:25.689 --> 00:07:30.470
You're asking for

00:07:30.470 --> 00:07:34.260

00:07:34.260 --> 00:07:38.030

In fact,
you want to do all the footwork and

00:07:40.478 --> 00:07:42.728

00:07:42.728 --> 00:07:44.074
You want to reach out to your team.

00:07:44.074 --> 00:07:49.220
You might not be able to get

00:07:49.220 --> 00:07:52.020
And frankly, there's been a lot

00:07:53.180 --> 00:07:54.960

00:07:54.960 --> 00:07:55.870

00:07:55.870 --> 00:07:56.550
But, at this point,

00:07:56.550 --> 00:08:01.270
in the beginning of your project,

00:08:01.270 --> 00:08:04.540
And sometimes that SIPOC that we

00:08:04.540 --> 00:08:06.290

00:08:06.290 --> 00:08:13.676
Now I wanna define my customer and

And we spent a lot of time in

00:08:18.390 --> 00:08:20.837
Now there's two that we haven't

00:08:20.837 --> 00:08:22.110

143
00:08:22.110 --> 00:08:26.490
And that's, we wanna align the goals and
business Initiatives and

144
00:08:26.490 --> 00:08:34.000
on our project charter or our email, we
wanna put projected return on investments.

00:08:34.000 --> 00:08:38.270
I'm gonna talk about

146
00:08:38.270 --> 00:08:41.020
Aligning the goals and
business initiatives,

147
00:08:41.020 --> 00:08:46.590
what that means is that when I'm

00:08:46.590 --> 00:08:51.050
I need to be able to tie it to the
department goals or to the company Goals.

149
00:08:51.050 --> 00:08:52.960
That's even better, if I can do that.

150
00:08:52.960 --> 00:08:56.660
If you're working for a public company,

00:08:56.660 --> 00:09:00.180

152
00:09:00.180 --> 00:09:01.110

153
00:09:01.110 --> 00:09:03.330
These are our values.

154
00:09:03.330 --> 00:09:04.230
These are our mission.

155
00:09:04.230 --> 00:09:07.730
We wanna tie that process
improvement program to that or

156
00:09:07.730 --> 00:09:11.270
to what those similar things that
are going on in our department.

00:09:11.270 --> 00:09:13.070
It does not have to be a dot
to dot connection, but

00:09:13.070 --> 00:09:18.360
if you're honestly looking at

00:09:18.360 --> 00:09:21.170
you don't really understand

160
00:09:21.170 --> 00:09:25.600

161
00:09:25.600 --> 00:09:29.850
The now projects going to be
the very first project to

162
00:09:29.850 --> 00:09:32.670
be dumped if you have

163
00:09:32.670 --> 00:09:37.415
So it's really important to spend
time thinking about how does

00:09:37.415 --> 00:09:41.040
this impact the business as a whole.

165
00:09:41.040 --> 00:09:44.660
>> Yeah, and that's really critical for

166
00:09:44.660 --> 00:09:49.100
And we really blend the lines here

167
00:09:49.100 --> 00:09:50.390

00:09:50.390 --> 00:09:53.910
But process improvement
generally becomes a project, so

169
00:09:53.910 --> 00:09:56.330
it really kind of falls in that mix.

00:09:56.330 --> 00:09:58.940
And a lot of things we can apply

171
00:09:58.940 --> 00:09:59.750

00:09:59.750 --> 00:10:02.760
You want to make sure that everybody's
aligned, has the same vision,

173
00:10:02.760 --> 00:10:04.670
working towards the same goal.

174
00:10:04.670 --> 00:10:10.012
Otherwise you get disarray and
I think we've all seen that at least once.

175
00:10:10.012 --> 00:10:11.540
>> Oh, absolutely.

176
00:10:11.540 --> 00:10:13.277
Then we want to determine
projected return on investment.

177
00:10:13.277 --> 00:10:21.800
Now this gets a little different
in Six Sigma than Lean Six Sigma.

178
00:10:21.800 --> 00:10:26.190
In Six Sigma, if I were to tell you that I
invested $10,000 and I got $10,000 back,

179
00:10:26.190 --> 00:10:33.190
in Lean Six Sigma we're going to say
we got a zero return on investment.

180
00:10:33.190 --> 00:10:36.890
In Six Sigma, they'll say, well,
actually, you're kind of behind.

181
00:10:36.890 --> 00:10:41.790
Because you spent your time and resources,
and if all you got back was $10,000,

182
00:10:41.790 --> 00:10:44.620
then you probably have
a negative return on investment.

183
00:10:44.620 --> 00:10:49.220
So one of the kind of fun things about
Lean Six Sigma is that when you're

184
00:10:49.220 --> 00:10:54.490
doing regular return on investment, which
you'll do at the end of your project,

185
00:10:54.490 --> 00:10:58.660
you have definitive numbers and
so it's not as difficult to do.

186
00:10:58.660 --> 00:11:03.020
But in the projected return
on investment world,

187
00:11:03.020 --> 00:11:06.140
Lean Six Sigma takes a more flexible view.

188
00:11:06.140 --> 00:11:07.680
So they would say, if you put $10,000 in,

189
00:11:07.680 --> 00:11:10.640
and got $10,000 back,
it's zero return on investment.

190
00:11:10.640 --> 00:11:14.810
Because projected return on
investment is just your guess.

191
00:11:14.810 --> 00:11:18.320
Now how do I come up with
a guess when I don't even know

00:11:18.320 --> 00:11:21.640
what I'm gonna have to do
to solve this problem?

193
00:11:21.640 --> 00:11:27.470
What you want to do is you wanna step back
and you wanna look at if this problem did

194
00:11:27.470 --> 00:11:32.530
not exist, how much could it potentially
make, save, or avoid spending my company?

195
00:11:32.530 --> 00:11:36.580
And it's very important to get that on
your initial project charter because why

196
00:11:36.580 --> 00:11:41.870
would your boss want you to even do
something if it's not gonna make save or

197
00:11:41.870 --> 00:11:43.500
avoid spending something.

198
00:11:43.500 --> 00:11:46.456
Now it can get kinda tricky
Don because I don't wanna say,

199
00:11:46.456 --> 00:11:50.621
I don't wanna overestimate because then
everyone has this high expectation that

200
00:11:50.621 --> 00:11:52.750
I'm going to bring in a million dollars.

201
00:11:52.750 --> 00:11:57.607
So there's some things to think about
when I'm populating projected return on

202
00:11:57.607 --> 00:11:58.485
investment.

203
00:11:58.485 --> 00:12:03.732
Certainly, if you've done the same thing
at another company, you can use that.

204
00:12:03.732 --> 00:12:06.708
And projected return on investment,
a lot of times,

00:12:06.708 --> 00:12:09.301
just is being able to
have a logical argument.

206
00:12:09.301 --> 00:12:10.786
When someone says hey,

207
00:12:10.786 --> 00:12:15.627
how did you come up with that number
that you're able to answer back fluidly.

208
00:12:15.627 --> 00:12:18.727
And certainly, if you did it at another
company, you could say that, right?

209
00:12:18.727 --> 00:12:20.857
Or you could go out to the Internet and

00:12:20.857 --> 00:12:25.484
see another company that did the same
thing and use that as a case study, right?

211
00:12:25.484 --> 00:12:31.381
There are a lot of tools to kind of figure
out projected return on investment.

212
00:12:31.381 --> 00:12:35.563
But again, it goes back to observing and
looking at labor and

213
00:12:35.563 --> 00:12:37.208
those types of things.

214
00:12:37.208 --> 00:12:39.677
>> Yeah, and
you're gonna find on return on investment,

215
00:12:39.677 --> 00:12:42.526
that historical data is really critical,

00:12:42.526 --> 00:12:44.690
And you might have that internally

00:12:44.690 --> 00:12:46.240

00:12:46.240 --> 00:12:48.841
I know in the IT world a lot of
times we'll use Gartner Group or

00:12:48.841 --> 00:12:49.665
places like that.

00:12:49.665 --> 00:12:54.042
And we can say well, this other company or

00:12:54.042 --> 00:12:56.069
When they deployed a storage area network,

00:12:56.069 --> 00:12:58.986
here's the amount of savings

00:12:58.986 --> 00:13:02.530
So when we do it,

It's safe to assume,
I know we don't normally want to assume,

00:13:06.400 --> 00:13:09.700

00:13:09.700 --> 00:13:12.370
But sometimes you've got

You're doing something that's different

00:13:29.151 --> 00:13:34.283
And it may take not just one person or

00:13:34.283 --> 00:13:37.491
It may take outside consultants

00:13:37.491 --> 00:13:38.904

A cost in time and

00:13:43.488 --> 00:13:47.620
So when we're looking at the define phase,
