266
00:15:18.578 --> 00:15:22.293
That as a yellow belt,
I'm not gonna do all of this stuff.

267
00:15:22.293 --> 00:15:24.163
It'll probably just be a handful
of things, kind of pick and

268
00:15:24.163 --> 00:15:25.160
choose throughout it, right?

269
00:15:25.160 --> 00:15:27.238
>> Exactly, exactly.

270
00:15:27.238 --> 00:15:30.338
Okay, so graphing software,
when we talk about graphing software.

271
00:15:30.338 --> 00:15:35.255
Lean Six Sigma has a tendency
to depend on Microsoft products,

272
00:15:35.255 --> 00:15:39.729
because Excel has all kinds
of easy ways to graph things.

273
00:15:39.729 --> 00:15:43.922
And almost every Lean Six Sigma
environment kind

274
00:15:43.922 --> 00:15:48.634
of sticks to the Excel,
Microsoft product type line.

275
00:15:48.634 --> 00:15:53.364
However, there's also software
that's independent and

276
00:15:53.364 --> 00:15:57.631
you've probably heard names such as SPC or
Minitab.

277
00:15:57.631 --> 00:16:01.775
And those are standalone statistics
packages that do graphing and statistics.

278
00:16:01.775 --> 00:16:04.485
And so sometimes,
as a Lean Six Sigma person,

279
00:16:04.485 --> 00:16:08.320
you might run into standalone
software that also does graphing.

280
00:16:10.470 --> 00:16:17.932
There are a number of products, the one
I use is QI Macros, that lay into Excel.

281
00:16:17.932 --> 00:16:21.291
And what I mean by that is when
you purchase those products,

282
00:16:21.291 --> 00:16:25.130
Northwestern University is also
developing one right as we speak.

283
00:16:25.130 --> 00:16:30.259
When you go into Excel,
you see an extra menu item and

284
00:16:30.259 --> 00:16:34.697
that menu item just aids
you in doing graphs.

285
00:16:34.697 --> 00:16:39.478
Excel however does a great job just on
it's own, even without the add-ins.

286
00:16:39.478 --> 00:16:44.455
Now one of the graphs that's incredibly
popular is something called house

287
00:16:44.455 --> 00:16:45.330
of quality.

288
00:16:45.330 --> 00:16:50.310
This is a little bit more popular
in the manufacturing world,

289
00:16:50.310 --> 00:16:52.910
than it is in the service world.

290
00:16:52.910 --> 00:16:56.211
However, it's kind of making
a comeback in a different way and

291
00:16:56.211 --> 00:16:59.214
that's why I wanted to include
it in this presentation.

292
00:16:59.214 --> 00:17:02.620
A house of quality used to be a very,
very,

293
00:17:02.620 --> 00:17:07.932
in some environments still is,
kind of a very intricate diagram.

294
00:17:07.932 --> 00:17:12.669
In the middle of the diagram,
it shows something called the CTQ tree.

295
00:17:12.669 --> 00:17:15.989
And if you remember,
CTQ is critical to quality.

296
00:17:15.989 --> 00:17:20.865
And in the critical to quality tree,
it lists all the customer requirements and

297
00:17:20.865 --> 00:17:23.210
anything that's really important.

298
00:17:23.210 --> 00:17:25.411
Then along the top part of the house,

299
00:17:25.411 --> 00:17:29.688
it says what are our technical
capabilities on a scale from one to five.

300
00:17:29.688 --> 00:17:34.471
It's very subjective for fulfilling
that particular customer requirement.

301
00:17:34.471 --> 00:17:38.792
And then different parts of the house
might show relationships between

302
00:17:38.792 --> 00:17:41.970
the requirements and
the technical capabilities.

303
00:17:41.970 --> 00:17:45.290
In some house of quality,
one shutter might say,

304
00:17:45.290 --> 00:17:47.750
how well the competitors are doing.

305
00:17:47.750 --> 00:17:50.610
In another shutter,
it might be some benchmarking.

306
00:17:50.610 --> 00:17:56.281
So there's a lot of flexibility, there is
a template available on your course files,

307
00:17:56.281 --> 00:17:59.013
so that you can kind of
get the swing of it.

308
00:17:59.013 --> 00:18:03.552
Now the reason why I'm bringing this up
is because there's kind of a new thing in

309
00:18:03.552 --> 00:18:04.910
Lean Six Sigma.

310
00:18:04.910 --> 00:18:07.991
Where people are taking this concept,
house of quality, and

311
00:18:07.991 --> 00:18:10.492
they're doing some really
crazy things with it.

312
00:18:10.492 --> 00:18:11.332
For example,

313
00:18:11.332 --> 00:18:15.959
they might have pillars on their house
that represents their company values.

314
00:18:15.959 --> 00:18:20.908
They might have steps leading
up to their house that says

315
00:18:20.908 --> 00:18:23.970
these are some of our major goals.

316
00:18:23.970 --> 00:18:26.257
The sun is their vision.

317
00:18:26.257 --> 00:18:31.934
They sometimes even have a chimney,
and that represents their waste.

318
00:18:31.934 --> 00:18:35.880
And so you hear the term house of quality,
it used to be, like I said,

319
00:18:35.880 --> 00:18:40.257
a fairly intricate schematic that you
have an example on your sample files.

320
00:18:40.257 --> 00:18:43.168
But these days, people are getting very,
very clever with their house

321
00:18:43.168 --> 00:18:45.605
of quality and they're using
it to do lots of other things.

322
00:18:46.815 --> 00:18:48.985
Now in define, why is that important?

323
00:18:48.985 --> 00:18:53.132
If you're working for a company that
has created a house of quality,

324
00:18:53.132 --> 00:18:55.643
which is becoming more and more popular.

325
00:18:55.643 --> 00:19:00.240
You wanna make sure that when you're in
define, that you are recognizing those

326
00:19:00.240 --> 00:19:04.563
values and missions and things that
they recorded in at house og quality and

327
00:19:04.563 --> 00:19:07.880
make sure that somehow partners
with what you are doing.

328
00:19:07.880 --> 00:19:10.730
Now, so, stakeholders analysis
is an interesting one.

329
00:19:10.730 --> 00:19:16.160
In the project management world,
we are told that a stakeholder's

330
00:19:16.160 --> 00:19:21.495
analysis that one thing we can
use a stakeholder's analysis for,

331
00:19:21.495 --> 00:19:24.271
is to see what is one of the things.

332
00:19:24.271 --> 00:19:26.025
Sorry, I lost my train
of thought there Don.

333
00:19:26.025 --> 00:19:29.421
That one of the things that we
can use a stakeholders analysis,

334
00:19:29.421 --> 00:19:32.817
just to say who's for us,
who's against us, who's for us but

335
00:19:32.817 --> 00:19:37.005
,they're not gonna help us, who's
against us, but won't get in our way.

336
00:19:37.005 --> 00:19:39.984
Me personally, that's the one
piece of project management,

337
00:19:39.984 --> 00:19:41.905
that's always made me kind of nervous.

338
00:19:41.905 --> 00:19:45.711
And I am certainly, wouldn't want
a document like that circulating around.

339
00:19:45.711 --> 00:19:47.154
>> The challenge with it is,

340
00:19:47.154 --> 00:19:50.309
doing it in a way that actually
makes sense to everybody.

341
00:19:50.309 --> 00:19:52.604
And at the end of the day,
and the way you describe it,

342
00:19:52.604 --> 00:19:54.549
that's exactly how we wanna use it, right?

343
00:19:54.549 --> 00:19:56.704
But, there are ways to do it
that's a little more tactful.

344
00:19:56.704 --> 00:19:58.968
At a minimum,
you wanna do a stakeholder analysis so,

345
00:19:58.968 --> 00:20:00.999
that you can build up
your communications plan.

346
00:20:00.999 --> 00:20:03.183
How do I wanna communicate
with each of these people?

347
00:20:03.183 --> 00:20:06.316
And that can be as simple as,
I need to email this person.

348
00:20:06.316 --> 00:20:08.139
I need to call this person on the phone.

349
00:20:08.139 --> 00:20:12.383
This person likes face to face meetings,
and so, when you build your stakeholder

350
00:20:12.383 --> 00:20:16.320
list, that's kinda the premise that we
use to initially build it, but then

351
00:20:16.320 --> 00:20:20.811
you start assigning responsibilites, and
we can get into things like responsibility

352
00:20:20.811 --> 00:20:25.052
assignment matrixes or matrices and all
that goodness, but at the end of the day,

353
00:20:25.052 --> 00:20:28.860
what you really need to know is,
how do I handle each of these people?

354
00:20:28.860 --> 00:20:30.737
And some people,
this is the one that I always run into.

355
00:20:30.737 --> 00:20:32.770
It's not they're for my project.

356
00:20:32.770 --> 00:20:34.268
It's not that they're against my project.

357
00:20:34.268 --> 00:20:36.851
It's that they just don't care, right?

358
00:20:36.851 --> 00:20:37.432
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

359
00:20:37.432 --> 00:20:39.625
even that is something that
we've gotta say, all right,

360
00:20:39.625 --> 00:20:42.523
I don't wanna over communicate to
this person, because they don't care.

361
00:20:42.523 --> 00:20:44.235
>> [LAUGH]
>> But, I don't wanna under communicate,

362
00:20:44.235 --> 00:20:46.794
cuz I do need them to be aware, and
you gotta find that sweet spot.

363
00:20:46.794 --> 00:20:49.466
So, there's a lot of
benefit to having this,

364
00:20:49.466 --> 00:20:54.264
it is something you don't necessarily want
to share with people because it's your

365
00:20:54.264 --> 00:20:58.054
intimate knowledge of the people
that you work with, I suppose.

366
00:20:58.054 --> 00:21:03.219
>> Exactly, and that's the way that Lean
Six Sigma uses a stakeholder's analysis,

367
00:21:03.219 --> 00:21:07.598
just as Don was expressing,
is that it's more a communication plan.

368
00:21:07.598 --> 00:21:14.360
And I don't know I still am
very careful when I do it.

369
00:21:14.360 --> 00:21:16.720
But, it does bring
insight to your project.

370
00:21:16.720 --> 00:21:19.309
Now the next one is called,
if you're looking at the schematic,

371
00:21:19.309 --> 00:21:20.635
the next one is historical data.

372
00:21:20.635 --> 00:21:26.040
Now this is really an interesting one,
because original leans that Sigma

373
00:21:26.040 --> 00:21:31.370
thinking considered historical data
things such as the annual report.

374
00:21:31.370 --> 00:21:35.043
Like I need to to know what my company's
doing, and I have to tell you for

375
00:21:35.043 --> 00:21:39.086
anyone out there that's looking for
a job or working in the consulting world,

376
00:21:39.086 --> 00:21:43.435
it's amazing all the things that companies
have on their websites that I feed back to

377
00:21:43.435 --> 00:21:46.643
my client, and they go, wow,
really that's interesting.

378
00:21:46.643 --> 00:21:48.397
I read it on their website.

379
00:21:48.397 --> 00:21:54.254
So, we started including, if you're
new to a job or you're in a consulting

380
00:21:54.254 --> 00:21:59.855
situation that certainly go to
the website and look at historical data.

381
00:21:59.855 --> 00:22:04.261
And examples of that would be press
releases, who was in charge before,

382
00:22:04.261 --> 00:22:05.499
that kind of stuff.

383
00:22:05.499 --> 00:22:07.759
So it sounds kind of simplistic,
but it really,

384
00:22:07.759 --> 00:22:10.750
really can help you when you're
trying to define your project.

385
00:22:10.750 --> 00:22:14.916
But ,then we even took
it one step further.

386
00:22:14.916 --> 00:22:17.693
If you're in a department
looking at historical data,

387
00:22:17.693 --> 00:22:19.294
how do they put forms together?

388
00:22:19.294 --> 00:22:21.313
How do they communicate with each other?

389
00:22:21.313 --> 00:22:23.380
How are things things handled culturally.

390
00:22:23.380 --> 00:22:27.320
Now in the Six Sigma world,
this is not particularly addressed.

391
00:22:27.320 --> 00:22:31.695
But, in the Lean Six Sigma world,
which is a little bit more concerned with

392
00:22:31.695 --> 00:22:36.435
the people factor, knowing how people work
and how to partner with them is huge.

393
00:22:36.435 --> 00:22:41.077
Because remember, Lean Six Sigma isn't
out to get you to do things differently.

394
00:22:41.077 --> 00:22:44.263
It's out to enhance the ways
you're already doing things and

395
00:22:44.263 --> 00:22:47.891
make those things, again, better,
faster, more cost effective.

396
00:22:47.891 --> 00:22:50.504
And finally,
the last thing I wanna address,

397
00:22:50.504 --> 00:22:53.998
is return on investment formulas and
cost benefit analysis.

398
00:22:53.998 --> 00:22:58.780
In your sample files, you have an Excel
spreadsheet that will help you calculate

399
00:22:58.780 --> 00:23:02.030
return on investment,
it's just an easy way to do it.

400
00:23:02.030 --> 00:23:06.268
I wanna caution you that, if you're
working for a company and you're not

401
00:23:06.268 --> 00:23:11.187
a consultant, you're working for an actual
company, you wanna make sure that you go

402
00:23:11.187 --> 00:23:15.990
to the finance department and find out how
do they calculate return on Investment?

403
00:23:15.990 --> 00:23:20.238
Now in define, you're doing
projected return on investment, but,

404
00:23:20.238 --> 00:23:22.398
it's still a good time to find out,

405
00:23:22.398 --> 00:23:25.939
how do they actually discern
that they're making money?

406
00:23:25.939 --> 00:23:31.702
Because in some finance departments, they
have a little bit more bigger formula,

407
00:23:31.702 --> 00:23:36.643
they might wanna consider things
like interest and immatization, and

408
00:23:36.643 --> 00:23:39.110
different things like that.

409
00:23:39.110 --> 00:23:42.800
But having a calculator just to
kind of get a quick idea, and

410
00:23:42.800 --> 00:23:46.110
if you're trying to throw some
numbers at a projected return on

411
00:23:46.110 --> 00:23:51.080
investment it really kind of helps, just
to have return on investment formulas.

412
00:23:51.080 --> 00:23:56.260
A cost benefit analysis, and that is also
available to you on your sample files,

413
00:23:56.260 --> 00:24:00.020
the value there is when
you're trying to come up with

414
00:24:00.020 --> 00:24:04.590
projected return on investment, sometimes
it just helps to look at the categories,

415
00:24:04.590 --> 00:24:08.610
so we're not really actually saying a cost
benefit analysis is an actual tool so

416
00:24:08.610 --> 00:24:10.290
much as just a place to get some ideas.

417
00:24:10.290 --> 00:24:13.749
Oh, yeah,
did I consider facilities expenses?

418
00:24:13.749 --> 00:24:14.980
Did I consider salaries?

419
00:24:14.980 --> 00:24:18.680
Did I consider equipment and
those types of things?

420
00:24:18.680 --> 00:24:23.870
So, as I mentioned, moving forward
into the other phases, we won't

421
00:24:23.870 --> 00:24:28.650
be going in depth for each one of these
these phases, like we did on this handout.

422
00:24:28.650 --> 00:24:31.160
But, the defined phase is so
important that you get that straight.

423
00:24:31.160 --> 00:24:35.427
>> Well I think that's a pretty
good rundown there of the phase,

424
00:24:35.427 --> 00:24:39.625
our activities, our tools,
all things that are involved.

425
00:24:39.625 --> 00:24:42.386
Remember, you're not necessarily
going to use 100% of those.

426
00:24:42.386 --> 00:24:44.948
You're going to use the ones that
are appropriate for your environment,

427
00:24:44.948 --> 00:24:46.821
and you may not be responsible for
all of them either.

428
00:24:46.821 --> 00:24:48.481
You might have multiple
people working on these.

429
00:24:48.481 --> 00:24:50.735
But, they're all very critical and
very important,

430
00:24:50.735 --> 00:24:53.362
so, I think at this point though
>> That's a pretty good wrap up of

431
00:24:53.362 --> 00:24:54.355
the define phase for us.

432
00:24:54.355 --> 00:24:56.470
We still have four more phases
to get through, though, so

433
00:24:56.470 --> 00:24:58.512
those are gonna be coming up
in our following episodes.

434
00:24:58.512 --> 00:25:00.477
Definitely stay tuned for those,

435
00:25:00.477 --> 00:25:04.214
but do we have anything else we
wanna throw in on the define phase?

436
00:25:04.214 --> 00:25:08.441
>> The only thing that I'd like to add
is that, typically with my students,

437
00:25:08.441 --> 00:25:13.285
that whole concept of projected return on
investment is usually something that kind

438
00:25:13.285 --> 00:25:14.460
of stymies people.

439
00:25:14.460 --> 00:25:16.188
And just remember that the goal,

440
00:25:16.188 --> 00:25:19.827
when you're doing projected return
on investment for your self or for

441
00:25:19.827 --> 00:25:22.614
your company is just to be
able to defend that number.

442
00:25:22.614 --> 00:25:24.378
How did you come up with that number.

443
00:25:24.378 --> 00:25:29.777
Having a clear logic that you can explain
to your boss or to your family is huge.

444
00:25:29.777 --> 00:25:31.054
>> Definitely important.

445
00:25:31.054 --> 00:25:32.737
All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed this.

446
00:25:32.737 --> 00:25:35.353
Definitely an area were gonna
spend a lot of time in,

447
00:25:35.353 --> 00:25:39.457
some good information to have there
absolutely stay tune though, because we've

448
00:25:39.457 --> 00:25:43.262
got four more phases to move through,
as we round off that [INAUDIBLE] model,

449
00:25:43.262 --> 00:25:46.601
that kind of key and critical part
of the Lean Six Sigma processes.

450
00:25:46.601 --> 00:25:49.365
So, definitely stay tuned for
that, but for

451
00:25:49.365 --> 00:25:52.900
right now, signing off for
ITPRO TV, I'm Don.

452
00:25:52.900 --> 00:25:53.850
>> And I'm Dr Stern.

453
00:25:55.220 --> 00:25:59.016
>> And we'll see you

454
00:25:59.016 --> 00:26:04.120
next time.

episodes.description: Entering into the second phase of the DMAIC model is the Measure Phase. In the Measure Phase one has to determine what it is they want to measure and what the best tool is to do so. Viewers will be shown key tools like benchmarking, data collection plans, Sigma levels, and others to help measure and figure out what one should measure, to get a 'clear as is' picture of where one is today.
episodes.title: Measure Phase
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.009 --> 00:00:10.009
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.945 --> 00:00:12.525
>> All right.

3
00:00:12.525 --> 00:00:14.289
Good morning, good afternoon and
good evening.

4
00:00:14.289 --> 00:00:16.971
And welcome back to another
episode of IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:16.971 --> 00:00:21.100
I'm your host Don Pezet back again with
another episode of Lean Six Sigma and

6
00:00:21.100 --> 00:00:25.423
finally, ready to move past the define
phase that we spent the last few episodes

7
00:00:25.423 --> 00:00:28.927
on and were gonna be jumping passed
that into the measure phase.

8
00:00:28.927 --> 00:00:30.727
Lots of exciting things here.

9
00:00:30.727 --> 00:00:34.987
We're gonna break out our rulers and
measure some stuff it's going to amazing.

10
00:00:34.987 --> 00:00:38.284
So back on the show again to help
us out here we've got Dr Stern.

11
00:00:38.284 --> 00:00:39.689
Dr. Stern thank you for being on the show.

12
00:00:39.689 --> 00:00:41.651
>> And thank you for having me.

13
00:00:41.651 --> 00:00:44.477
>> Now the measure phase,
when we talk of measuring,

14
00:00:44.477 --> 00:00:48.486
there is no end to the amount of stuff
that we could measure at a given point

15
00:00:48.486 --> 00:00:51.600
in a process or a project or
just in business in general.

16
00:00:51.600 --> 00:00:54.362
Where do we start in terms of domain?

17
00:00:54.362 --> 00:00:58.815
>> Well what's kind of interesting about
the measure phase is that word isn't

18
00:00:58.815 --> 00:00:59.587
intuitive.

19
00:00:59.587 --> 00:01:02.988
You are measuring, and so
that's a good way to remember it.

20
00:01:02.988 --> 00:01:07.296
But what you're really trying to do in the
measure phase is get a clear as is picture

21
00:01:07.296 --> 00:01:08.553
of where you are today.

22
00:01:08.553 --> 00:01:14.052
And we did talk about and define how we
have to have a high level process map,

23
00:01:14.052 --> 00:01:19.203
in fact it's a requirement in define
to have a high level process map,

24
00:01:19.203 --> 00:01:24.176
but when we get to measure what we're
trying to do is make sure we have

25
00:01:24.176 --> 00:01:28.148
a very accurate picture of
what's happening today.

26
00:01:28.148 --> 00:01:30.005
And we're doing that for
a couple of reasons.

27
00:01:30.005 --> 00:01:35.126
One, we have to establish a good before
picture so that when we rollout our

28
00:01:35.126 --> 00:01:40.097
awesome process improvement we can
go back and show our after picture.

29
00:01:40.097 --> 00:01:43.530
And if we don't have a good clear before
picture then we can do all kinds of

30
00:01:43.530 --> 00:01:46.080
process improvement and
maybe not get credit for it.

31
00:01:47.220 --> 00:01:51.539
>> Absolutely, and so this is another
one of those that is gonna be kind of

32
00:01:51.539 --> 00:01:54.926
an ongoing things that
we're constantly measuring.

33
00:01:54.926 --> 00:01:58.535

00:21:15.396 --> 00:21:18.952

many times is in a bell curve and

478
00:27:46.523 --> 00:27:52.831
I don't actually have a slide, but
I know all of you have seen a bell curve.

479
00:27:52.831 --> 00:27:55.262
And in the middle of the bell curve,

480
00:27:55.262 --> 00:28:00.126
I'm just gonna remind you that in
the middle there's usually a line and

481
00:28:00.126 --> 00:28:03.952
that line denotes the middle or
the average or the mean.

482
00:28:03.952 --> 00:28:07.411
And on this bell curve,
you might see slices and

483
00:28:07.411 --> 00:28:12.531
those slices represents the two,
three, four, five and Six Sigma.

484
00:28:12.531 --> 00:28:17.193
So when you get down on the sides of the
bell curve, kind of the very, very bottom,

485
00:28:17.193 --> 00:28:19.775
that's where the Five and
Six Sigma show up.

486
00:28:19.775 --> 00:28:23.966
So sometimes you see it that way nd
many times when you're looking at that

487
00:28:23.966 --> 00:28:28.158
particular diagram or even the chart
that you're looking at right now,

488
00:28:28.158 --> 00:28:30.513
people start talking about deviation.

489
00:28:30.513 --> 00:28:35.129
Deviation from the middle and we'll talk
a little bit about that later, as well.

490
00:28:35.129 --> 00:28:38.589
>> Well, Dr. Stern, I know it's a pretty
good rundown of the measure phase, but

491
00:28:38.589 --> 00:28:41.083
we still have a few more tools
that you want to talk about.

492
00:28:41.083 --> 00:28:42.996
Unfortunately, we've kinda run
out of time for this episode.

493
00:28:42.996 --> 00:28:45.481
So let's break into a part two on this and
we'll come back and

494
00:28:45.481 --> 00:28:48.699
we'll talk about some of the other tools
that are out there like score cards and

495
00:28:48.699 --> 00:28:50.864
benchmarking, all really
good important option.

496
00:28:50.864 --> 00:28:53.656
We wanna make sure we spend
the right amount of time on those.

497
00:28:53.656 --> 00:28:55.680
So we'll come back for a part two on it.

498
00:28:55.680 --> 00:28:56.915
Before we break on this one,

499
00:28:56.915 --> 00:28:59.392
do you have any last minute
thoughts you want to throw in?

500
00:28:59.392 --> 00:29:04.109
>> I just want to remind our audience
that it's not enough to get that clear as

501
00:29:04.109 --> 00:29:06.012
a picture where we are today,

502
00:29:06.012 --> 00:29:10.367
you wanna make sure that it's
believable before you move forward.

503
00:29:10.367 --> 00:29:11.895
>> We want that credibility.

504
00:29:11.895 --> 00:29:13.896
Otherwise, we can make
some really fun reports.

505
00:29:13.896 --> 00:29:16.289
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well, ladies and gentlemen,

506
00:29:16.289 --> 00:29:16.855
hope you guys enjoyed it.

507
00:29:16.855 --> 00:29:20.935
Stay tuned, cuz we'll be back with more
measure phase in the next episode.

508
00:29:20.935 --> 00:29:21.887
So, I hope to see you there.

509
00:29:21.887 --> 00:29:26.039
But for right now, signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

510
00:29:26.039 --> 00:29:27.207
>> And I'm Dr. Stern.

511
00:29:27.207 --> 00:29:28.447
>> And we'll see you next time.

512
00:29:28.447 --> 00:29:35.300
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Final remarks of the Measure Phase include discussions of tools like Balanced Scorecards, different types of benchmarking tools, and a reiteration of the use of the SIPOC model and data collection plan to help measure and generate ideas before moving on to the Analyze Phase.
episodes.title: Measure Phase Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.821 --> 00:00:12.422
All right.

3
00:00:12.422 --> 00:00:14.010
Good morning, good afternoon and

4
00:00:14.010 --> 00:00:16.900
good evening and welcome back
to another episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:16.900 --> 00:00:21.361
I'm your host Don Pezet, back again
with another episode of Lean Six Sigma.

6
00:00:21.361 --> 00:00:24.916
And in this episode we're gonna be
continuing with the measure phase we

7
00:00:24.916 --> 00:00:26.397
left off in our last episode,

8
00:00:26.397 --> 00:00:29.791
ready to talk about some of the tools
we can use in the measure phase.

9
00:00:29.791 --> 00:00:31.491
We've got a couple of great
ones that are coming up.

10
00:00:31.491 --> 00:00:34.331
And I'm gonna turn the floor over to Dr.
Stern.

11
00:00:34.331 --> 00:00:38.310
Once again whose gonna tell us about these
tools, Dr. Stern, where do we start?

12
00:00:38.310 --> 00:00:43.640
>> Okay well, where I'd like to start this
episode is saying that Lean Six Sigma,

13
00:00:43.640 --> 00:00:46.340
in our first episode we did
kind of mention this, but

14
00:00:46.340 --> 00:00:50.810
Lean Six Sigma is mostly Six Sigma
with a strong lean influence.

15
00:00:50.810 --> 00:00:56.598
But over the last few years,
what's happened as it's evolved so

16
00:00:56.598 --> 00:01:03.241
much that it just started kinda stealing
tools from other methodologies.

17
00:01:03.241 --> 00:01:08.826
And so one of the popular tools in
Lean Six Sigma didn't originate in Lean or

18
00:01:08.826 --> 00:01:09.721
Six Sigma.

19
00:01:09.721 --> 00:01:11.841
And that's called the balanced scorecard.

20
00:01:11.841 --> 00:01:14.056
I wanna remind you that
in the measure phase,

21
00:01:14.056 --> 00:01:17.741
what we're trying to do is get a clear
as-is picture of where we are today.

22
00:01:17.741 --> 00:01:22.840
And sometimes the hardest part is figuring
out what the heck we should be looking at.

23
00:01:24.620 --> 00:01:27.470
We have already discussed
some great ideas.

24
00:01:27.470 --> 00:01:29.350
We could look at a detailed process map,

25
00:01:29.350 --> 00:01:32.490
we can see how well
we're doing on our CTQs.

26
00:01:32.490 --> 00:01:35.630
We could check ROI,
we could look at sigma.

27
00:01:35.630 --> 00:01:39.710
But another method we might choose to use
is something called Balance Scorecard.

28
00:01:39.710 --> 00:01:44.732
Now the reason that Lean Six Sigma loves
Balance Scorecard, is that in Fortune

29
00:01:44.732 --> 00:01:50.134
500 companies, the last set of statistics
that I looked at, over half of Fortune

30
00:01:50.134 --> 00:01:56.171
500 companies use the Balance Scorecard as
their enterprise-wide measurement system.

31
00:01:56.171 --> 00:02:01.094
So what that means is if you are trying
to give a clear as is picture of where

32
00:02:01.094 --> 00:02:02.224
you are today and

33
00:02:02.224 --> 00:02:07.637
you're already in a company that uses
Balance Scorecard by using this method,

34
00:02:07.637 --> 00:02:13.590
they might bond with this a lot faster
than if you were using a different method.

35
00:02:13.590 --> 00:02:17.790
Now I also want to point out before we
get started on our Balance Scorecard, and

36
00:02:17.790 --> 00:02:20.780
I do have a slide on this,
before we get really started on this,

37
00:02:20.780 --> 00:02:25.040
I want to point out there's
something called scorecards period.

38
00:02:25.040 --> 00:02:30.038
So if you were to go to Google and
you to type in anything like,

39
00:02:30.038 --> 00:02:35.041
human resource scorecard,
a scorecard is going to come up.

40
00:02:35.041 --> 00:02:39.655
Generally speaking, students have done
this, sometimes they're no cost, sometimes

41
00:02:39.655 --> 00:02:43.971
there's a nominal fee and it will list all
the things that you should be measuring.

42
00:02:43.971 --> 00:02:46.353
Some of them are pretty
darn sophisticated and

43
00:02:46.353 --> 00:02:48.622
even have the excel measurements in there.

44
00:02:48.622 --> 00:02:52.229
Now the advantage to this is let's
say you've never worked on a supply

45
00:02:52.229 --> 00:02:55.423
chain project before and
you don't even know where to start.

46
00:02:55.423 --> 00:02:57.063
You have no clue where to start.

47
00:02:57.063 --> 00:03:00.073
You could type in supply
chain scorecard and

48
00:03:00.073 --> 00:03:03.011
a lot of people's ideas are gonna come up.

49
00:03:03.011 --> 00:03:05.342
Now granted it's usually
an Excel spreadsheet, and

50
00:03:05.342 --> 00:03:08.101
some things you're going to
eliminate from the spreadsheet.

51
00:03:08.101 --> 00:03:09.710
Some things you're going to add.

52
00:03:09.710 --> 00:03:11.990
You're certainly going to want
to check their calculations.

53
00:03:11.990 --> 00:03:14.954
But it's better than looking at
a blank piece of paper, Don,

54
00:03:14.954 --> 00:03:18.441
if you get into a situation where you
don't even know what to start with.

55
00:03:18.441 --> 00:03:21.010
>> Yeah, and it's kind of that
idea of why reinvent the wheel.

56
00:03:21.010 --> 00:03:24.490
There's other people that have already
gone through this process that at

57
00:03:24.490 --> 00:03:27.620
a minimum you could use their
scorecards as a starting point.

58
00:03:27.620 --> 00:03:28.180
>> Exactly.

59
00:03:28.180 --> 00:03:29.200
>> And adapt it for your needs.

60
00:03:29.200 --> 00:03:29.900
>> Exactly.

61
00:03:29.900 --> 00:03:34.190
It's just kind of a lean,
quick way to get some measurements.

62
00:03:34.190 --> 00:03:37.743
Now the balance score card always
works with four categories and

63
00:03:37.743 --> 00:03:39.520
the categories are learning and

64
00:03:39.520 --> 00:03:43.691
growth, although most companies now
will call it training or education.

65
00:03:43.691 --> 00:03:46.605
When Kaplan and Norton,
who were from Harvard,

66
00:03:46.605 --> 00:03:51.310
originally created this scorecard,
I think they meant learning and growth.

67
00:03:51.310 --> 00:03:54.530
And I think learning and growth kind of
means more than training and education.

68
00:03:54.530 --> 00:03:58.728
But typically at companies you'll
see that category called training or

69
00:03:58.728 --> 00:04:01.291
education or something along those lines.

70
00:04:01.291 --> 00:04:06.831
The second category is financial, and
that's actually one of the easier ones.

71
00:04:06.831 --> 00:04:10.056
If I'm trying to look at my
project through a financial lens,

72
00:04:10.056 --> 00:04:14.721
because finance probably already has a set
of metrics, which just means measurements.

73
00:04:14.721 --> 00:04:17.590
They already have a set of
financial metrics that I could use.

74
00:04:18.620 --> 00:04:24.074
An example of that would be cost of
inventory returned or cost of hire.

75
00:04:24.074 --> 00:04:24.774
Those types of things.

76
00:04:24.774 --> 00:04:28.129
So those are probably already
established in my company, so

77
00:04:28.129 --> 00:04:30.383
that category often goes very quickly.

78
00:04:30.383 --> 00:04:35.312
Customer means customer service and
here's the kind of sticky wicket,

79
00:04:35.312 --> 00:04:40.180
I'm not sure exactly why but
some people call that final one business.

80
00:04:40.180 --> 00:04:41.201
They might call it process.

81
00:04:41.201 --> 00:04:42.621
They might call it operation.

82
00:04:42.621 --> 00:04:44.281
They might use any combination.

83
00:04:44.281 --> 00:04:46.844
So they might call it business processes,

84
00:04:46.844 --> 00:04:50.271
operation processes, but
what it means is the process.

85
00:04:50.271 --> 00:04:53.904
So once again, it's a little like
structured brainstorming which

86
00:04:53.904 --> 00:04:56.271
another reason why
Lean Six Sigma likes it.

87
00:04:56.271 --> 00:05:00.145
I'm looking at the project that I'm
trying to make better, faster, or

88
00:05:00.145 --> 00:05:01.680
more cost effective.

89
00:05:01.680 --> 00:05:05.563
I'm trying to figure out what
the heck I should be measuring and so

90
00:05:05.563 --> 00:05:10.231
I take a step back and I say, what from
a training aspect should I be measuring?

91
00:05:10.231 --> 00:05:11.951
What's from a financial aspect?

92
00:05:11.951 --> 00:05:14.850
And of course, a lot of times,
ROI's gonna come in there, but

93
00:05:14.850 --> 00:05:17.831
there's gonna be other financial
things I might wanna look at.

94
00:05:17.831 --> 00:05:21.611
From a customer service perspective,
what should I be measuring?

95
00:05:21.611 --> 00:05:25.571
And then from a process standpoint,
what should I be measuring?

96
00:05:25.571 --> 00:05:30.471
And it's just a way to get our arms around
quickly getting a list of measurements.

97
00:05:30.471 --> 00:05:35.451
Now, typically, on the Balance Scorecard,
they tell us we don't want more then

98
00:05:35.451 --> 00:05:39.370
three to five major measurements
in each one of these phases.

99
00:05:39.370 --> 00:05:40.841
What do you think about that, Don?

100
00:05:40.841 --> 00:05:44.006
>> Well, I think eventually you get
just measure yourself to death, right?

101
00:05:44.006 --> 00:05:45.688
>> [LAUGH]
>> You spend so much time,

102
00:05:45.688 --> 00:05:48.572
the return on it's really
not going to be equal.

103
00:05:48.572 --> 00:05:49.532
Would you say that's true?

104
00:05:49.532 --> 00:05:50.752
>> Exactly.
It is true.

105
00:05:50.752 --> 00:05:52.886
And that's another one of those,

106
00:05:52.886 --> 00:05:56.720
what's the difference between
Lean Six Sigma and Six Sigma?

107
00:05:56.720 --> 00:06:00.974
Lean Six Sigma is either looking at
the methodology in the process and

108
00:06:00.974 --> 00:06:05.612
if I'm spending too much time in measure,
I'm not being cost effective.

109
00:06:05.612 --> 00:06:08.912
So I thought we could take
just a quick example.

110
00:06:08.912 --> 00:06:13.612
So let's thing of a company,
or let's think of a industry.

111
00:06:13.612 --> 00:06:16.180
What's an industry that
you're interested in, Don?

112
00:06:16.180 --> 00:06:17.000
>> Let's say automotive.

113
00:06:18.180 --> 00:06:20.090
>> Okay, so automotive industry.

114
00:06:20.090 --> 00:06:23.575
Now automotive industry sometimes
has that challenge that

115
00:06:23.575 --> 00:06:27.554
we come up with a good process
improvement that is illegal or against

116
00:06:27.554 --> 00:06:28.234
>> [LAUGH]

117
00:06:28.234 --> 00:06:28.854
>> compliance code.

118
00:06:28.854 --> 00:06:31.254
So you always want to
consider those things too.

119
00:06:31.254 --> 00:06:35.334
But let's say we have
a automotive industry plant.

120
00:06:35.334 --> 00:06:40.494
Can you think that just a simple process
improvement that we'd want to do?

121
00:06:40.494 --> 00:06:41.554
>> Automation?

122
00:06:41.554 --> 00:06:42.694
>> Okay, great!

123
00:06:42.694 --> 00:06:44.314
And what do you want to automate, Don?

124
00:06:44.314 --> 00:06:45.834
>> Maybe painting a vehicle.

125
00:06:45.834 --> 00:06:48.360
>> Okay, so we're going to
automate painting a vehicle.

126
00:06:48.360 --> 00:06:53.111
We're a small company and
we want to make this a quicker process.

127
00:06:53.111 --> 00:06:55.691
So we want to make painting
the vehicle faster.

128
00:06:55.691 --> 00:06:57.480
Would you say that's
the goal of our automation?

129
00:06:57.480 --> 00:06:59.690
>> Sure,
we know we could use people to do it.

130
00:06:59.690 --> 00:07:03.427
They can get out their sprayers and
do two or three coats or whatever, but

131
00:07:03.427 --> 00:07:07.302
I bet we could get some kind of robot or
machine in there to do the same thing.

132
00:07:07.302 --> 00:07:11.825
>> Okay, and so our first challenge, if
that's what we want to do, we want to make

133
00:07:11.825 --> 00:07:16.620
the automation process better or create
an automation process, and it's still not

134
00:07:16.620 --> 00:07:20.631
going from scratch cuz we're obviously
pinging the car somehow now.

135
00:07:20.631 --> 00:07:24.133
So in this scenario what we
would do is we would try to look

136
00:07:24.133 --> 00:07:26.600
through a training education lens.

137
00:07:26.600 --> 00:07:30.811
Because I'm trying to see where are we now
in the picture with painting our vehicles.

138
00:07:30.811 --> 00:07:35.839
So when I am looking at a training aspect,
some of the things

139
00:07:35.839 --> 00:07:40.580
that I might look at is how
long was the average trainer.

140
00:07:40.580 --> 00:07:42.540
How long was the average
car painter trained?

141
00:07:43.610 --> 00:07:48.201
How many hours of education,
if any, do they have?

142
00:07:48.201 --> 00:07:52.281
How long does it take to teach
someone how to paint a car?

143
00:07:52.281 --> 00:07:55.081
Those types of things.

144
00:07:55.081 --> 00:07:59.062
>> I almost wanna call them like an unseen
cost that we don't think about all that

145
00:07:59.062 --> 00:08:02.919
goes into getting somebody trained in
that skill for them to be able to go and

146
00:08:02.919 --> 00:08:04.220
then paint the vehicle.

147
00:08:04.220 --> 00:08:04.890
>> Exactly.

148
00:08:04.890 --> 00:08:08.620
And then, because I'm trying to get a
clear as is picture of where we are today,

149
00:08:08.620 --> 00:08:11.340
I'm using the Balance Scorecard
as one of the tools,

150
00:08:11.340 --> 00:08:13.480
because I have lots of
tools to choose from.

151
00:08:13.480 --> 00:08:15.400
But I decided to use this one.

152
00:08:15.400 --> 00:08:17.901
I'm looking from a financial lens.

153
00:08:17.901 --> 00:08:23.406
Certainly the cost of painting the car
would be something on my financial docket,

154
00:08:23.406 --> 00:08:26.596
I'm trying to think of
other things that I might

155
00:08:26.596 --> 00:08:29.571
be concerned about in the financial world.

156
00:08:29.571 --> 00:08:34.092
>> You might have like,
waste disposal costs.

157
00:08:34.092 --> 00:08:35.078
>> Absolutely.
>> As far as when you're paying,

158
00:08:35.078 --> 00:08:35.880
that might come up.

159
00:08:35.880 --> 00:08:36.750
>> Exactly.

160
00:08:36.750 --> 00:08:40.340
Those types of things that maybe
components or different vendors,

161
00:08:40.340 --> 00:08:42.290
what they charge for their paint.

162
00:08:42.290 --> 00:08:45.631
I would report all of that information.

163
00:08:45.631 --> 00:08:47.611
Now I'm in the customer service world.

164
00:08:47.611 --> 00:08:51.497
Generally speaking, this is across
the board, where I look for information,

165
00:08:51.497 --> 00:08:53.300
is customer complaint department.

166
00:08:54.640 --> 00:08:56.352
How many complaints are we getting and

167
00:08:56.352 --> 00:09:00.001
what kinds of complaints are we getting
and how often do we get those complaints?

168
00:09:00.001 --> 00:09:01.581
And I gather those measurements.

169
00:09:01.581 --> 00:09:07.239
Now remember one of our goals in measure
is to not be biased, because we're just

170
00:09:07.239 --> 00:09:12.911
trying to get a picture of where we are
now, so that we form that before picture.

171
00:09:12.911 --> 00:09:15.651
And so now I down to processes.

172
00:09:15.651 --> 00:09:23.371
And so what things can I maybe checkout
with metrics about the processes?

173
00:09:23.371 --> 00:09:26.411
>> So maybe how many people
are involved in the process?

174
00:09:26.411 --> 00:09:27.211
>> Absolutely.

175
00:09:27.211 --> 00:09:30.272
>> How long the process takes?

176
00:09:30.272 --> 00:09:30.992
>> Exactly.

177
00:09:30.992 --> 00:09:34.612
>> Would you put the current
amount of defects in that?

178
00:09:34.612 --> 00:09:36.892
>> Yeah, absolutely, yeah,
the current amount of defects.

179
00:09:36.892 --> 00:09:38.032
That's excellent.

180
00:09:38.032 --> 00:09:42.529
So now what I think is kind of fun about
the Balance Scorecard, you still have to

181
00:09:42.529 --> 00:09:46.990
go on from here and figure out how
you're going to measure these things.

182
00:09:46.990 --> 00:09:52.880
But sometimes just getting that
picture through a financial lens,

183
00:09:52.880 --> 00:09:57.030
through an education lens,
through customer service lens,

184
00:09:57.030 --> 00:10:00.440
through a process lens,
you can put that on a presentation slide.

185
00:10:00.440 --> 00:10:04.090
And especially if you're working for a
really large company, it's an easy way to

186
00:10:04.090 --> 00:10:07.720
tell them what your department does,
and your state of affairs.

187
00:10:08.970 --> 00:10:15.431
Okay so Balance Scorecard is one way that
I can discern what I should be measuring.

188
00:10:15.431 --> 00:10:19.071
Now from there obviously I'd have
to go and develop some metrics.

189
00:10:19.071 --> 00:10:22.631
Some metrics are really easy,
I would just literally count.

190
00:10:22.631 --> 00:10:25.476
Others I'd have to probably
dig through some records,

191
00:10:25.476 --> 00:10:28.259
or in the case of finance I
might have to go to finance and

192
00:10:28.259 --> 00:10:31.245
figure out what metrics they're using and
map to those.

193
00:10:31.245 --> 00:10:37.020
So another way that we
measure its benchmarking and

194
00:10:37.020 --> 00:10:40.550
what's fun about benchmarking is that
you can use it in two different ways.

195
00:10:40.550 --> 00:10:45.260
You can use it as the actual benchmark or

196
00:10:45.260 --> 00:10:48.180
just like I was explaining
about the scorecards,

197
00:10:48.180 --> 00:10:51.430
you can use it to try to figure out
what the heck people are measuring.

198
00:10:51.430 --> 00:10:53.947
So let's say again I am in a department or

199
00:10:53.947 --> 00:10:58.683
industry that I'm not familiar with and
I know what I'm supposed to do, but

200
00:10:58.683 --> 00:11:02.101
I need to get as clear as
a picture of where we are today.

201
00:11:02.101 --> 00:11:06.172
I could go to benchmarking studies and
say, well,

202
00:11:06.172 --> 00:11:11.581
what do other people in my particular
field, what do they measure?

203
00:11:11.581 --> 00:11:14.461
And so that would be a good
place to get measurements.

204
00:11:14.461 --> 00:11:18.772
Now the other thing about benchmarking is,
if I were actually to benchmark,

205
00:11:18.772 --> 00:11:22.420
it's a good way for
people to believe my story.

206
00:11:22.420 --> 00:11:27.560
Earlier we mention that when
you say the benchmark is here,

207
00:11:27.560 --> 00:11:30.710
even if you don't truly
understand the benchmark,

208
00:11:30.710 --> 00:11:34.320
and you say our company is here,
or our company is here,

209
00:11:34.320 --> 00:11:37.240
that gives a clear picture, and
people understand that picture.

210
00:11:38.270 --> 00:11:42.525
Part of your objective is to make
it easy for them to understand.

211
00:11:42.525 --> 00:11:46.183
We can do so many clever, wonderful,
fun things with graphs and

212
00:11:46.183 --> 00:11:49.386
make them colorful, and 3D,
and all kinds of things.

213
00:11:49.386 --> 00:11:53.596
But if people don’t understand what we’re
trying to say, then it’s all for naught.

214
00:11:53.596 --> 00:11:58.176
So benchmarking is just a simple way to
get people onboard of where we are today.

215
00:11:58.176 --> 00:12:01.872
Now, the only problem with benchmarking
Benchmarking is that there are several

216
00:12:01.872 --> 00:12:05.313
types of benchmarking, and we're just
going to briefly talk about them.

217
00:12:05.313 --> 00:12:10.645
For example, internal benchmarking
is a benchmarking process where

218
00:12:10.645 --> 00:12:16.889
you're just measuring internally what
department gets another, for example.

219
00:12:16.889 --> 00:12:22.055
Now the reason why we need to know about
the different types of benchmarking

220
00:12:22.055 --> 00:12:26.880
is it tells us what kind of back up
data we need to bring to the meeting.

221
00:12:26.880 --> 00:12:31.470
So when we're in measure, even if we
don't actually do this, we want to always

222
00:12:31.470 --> 00:12:35.770
pretend like we're going to a meeting and
we're presenting the as is pitcher.

223
00:12:35.770 --> 00:12:38.540
And that someone asks a question and
I wanna make sure that I have backup data.

224
00:12:38.540 --> 00:12:43.235
Well if I'm using benchmarking backup data
becomes quite important, so if I'm doing

225
00:12:43.235 --> 00:12:48.300
an internal benchmarking I did all the
research, I have all that information in

226
00:12:48.300 --> 00:12:53.270
my file and I can pretty much trust
that if I did the internal benchmarking.

227
00:12:53.270 --> 00:12:55.950
And you might say, well what's an example?

228
00:12:55.950 --> 00:13:01.129
And probably the best example that
I can think of is that when the,

229
00:13:01.129 --> 00:13:07.551
I don't remember what they called the
swine flu virus, the injection, the HV.

00:13:07.551 --> 00:13:08.479
>> I know what you're talking about,
I don't remember the name.

231
00:13:09.960 --> 00:13:14.530
>> Okay, well there was a point not too
long ago in our history where people

232
00:13:14.530 --> 00:13:18.850
were very, very concerned about getting,
what slang-wise we called the swine flu.

233
00:13:18.850 --> 00:13:23.178
And there is actually a more
official name for it.

234
00:13:23.178 --> 00:13:24.595
But people were really concerned.

235
00:13:24.595 --> 00:13:28.554
And so what they were trying to do
in internal benchmarking studies to

236
00:13:28.554 --> 00:13:33.129
try to figure out if our company got hit
with this epidemic, what is the absolute

237
00:13:33.129 --> 00:13:37.520
minimum amount of workforce that we
could work with and keep the doors open?

238
00:13:37.520 --> 00:13:41.098
So they had to determine
an internal benchmark,

239
00:13:41.098 --> 00:13:45.210
which basically meant how
many absences do we have now?

240
00:13:46.750 --> 00:13:49.200
And how well do our services work?

241
00:13:49.200 --> 00:13:52.010
So, a lot of companies were just
kind of saying, on an average,

242
00:13:52.010 --> 00:13:53.410
how many absences in HR?

243
00:13:53.410 --> 00:13:56.966
How many absences in operations?

244
00:13:56.966 --> 00:14:01.230
How many absences in
the finance department?

245
00:14:01.230 --> 00:14:04.420
And then they would put all
of those figures together and

246
00:14:04.420 --> 00:14:05.440
come up with an average.

247
00:14:05.440 --> 00:14:09.736
And then they would go back and
plot HR against the average

248
00:14:09.736 --> 00:14:14.110
finance against the average and
so forth and so forth.

249
00:14:14.110 --> 00:14:16.567
And that would give them a kind
of an internal benchmark.

250
00:14:16.567 --> 00:14:19.925
Now since they created
that data themselves,

251
00:14:19.925 --> 00:14:23.210
it's not a big a deal
to validate that data.

252
00:14:23.210 --> 00:14:26.492
If someone were to stand up and
go where did you get those numbers?

253
00:14:26.492 --> 00:14:27.792
You're just like right here in my folder.

254
00:14:27.792 --> 00:14:28.767
Right?

255
00:14:28.767 --> 00:14:34.530
Well it becomes very different when
you're looking at competitive benchmarks.

256
00:14:34.530 --> 00:14:38.030
And competitive benchmark means your
measuring yourself against a company or

257
00:14:38.030 --> 00:14:40.300
an industry that's doing
the same thing you're doing.

258
00:14:40.300 --> 00:14:42.910
And unfortunately we found that
with competitive benchmark,

259
00:14:42.910 --> 00:14:45.570
sometimes people aren't all
the time truthful, right?

260
00:14:45.570 --> 00:14:48.260
And so
if I'm doing a competitive benchmark,

261
00:14:48.260 --> 00:14:52.476
someone might actually ask me where
did you get that benchmarking study?

262
00:14:52.476 --> 00:14:54.670
Who did you actually look at, right?

263
00:14:54.670 --> 00:15:00.750
And so sometimes it might be necessary to
look at more than one benchmarking source.

264
00:15:00.750 --> 00:15:04.230
So If I were trying to prove my point,

265
00:15:04.230 --> 00:15:07.640
I might wanna look at two
different benchmarking studies.

266
00:15:07.640 --> 00:15:11.886
One of the associations that
I was with a few years ago,

267
00:15:11.886 --> 00:15:17.161
we had volunteers, but we had
an executive director that was paid.

268
00:15:17.161 --> 00:15:22.460
And so we were trying to figure out
if we were paying enough or more.

269
00:15:22.460 --> 00:15:26.744
And he produced a benchmarking study from
the Association of Associations who said

270
00:15:26.744 --> 00:15:28.221
we were paying way too less.

271
00:15:28.221 --> 00:15:29.830
>> Of course.

272
00:15:29.830 --> 00:15:31.990
>> Now do we discount that completely,
absolutely not.

273
00:15:31.990 --> 00:15:34.897
But it's something that
we'd have to consider and

274
00:15:34.897 --> 00:15:37.067
look at another benchmarking study.

275
00:15:37.067 --> 00:15:39.948
So-
>> Yeah, competitive benchmarks,

276
00:15:39.948 --> 00:15:42.337
they can work in either sides advantage.

277
00:15:42.337 --> 00:15:43.870
Easy to get bias into those.

278
00:15:43.870 --> 00:15:47.755
And the way that you do your pool for
collecting that data can always influence

279
00:15:47.755 --> 00:15:50.830
the results too, so
you gotta take that with a grain of salt.

280
00:15:50.830 --> 00:15:54.450
If all competitive benchmarks were
accurate then we wouldn't need

281
00:15:54.450 --> 00:15:56.895
like a consumer protection agency.

282
00:15:56.895 --> 00:16:00.136
[LAUGH] Those things exist because

283
00:16:00.136 --> 00:16:01.970
>> Exactly.

284
00:16:01.970 --> 00:16:04.840
And so then we move to something
called functional benchmarking.

285
00:16:04.840 --> 00:16:10.200
And functional benchmarking is where I'm
actually benchmarking a function and

286
00:16:10.200 --> 00:16:12.930
the challenge there is that you want to

287
00:16:12.930 --> 00:16:17.480
benchmark a function against someone

288
00:16:17.480 --> 00:16:22.058
So for example, if I were looking

289
00:16:22.058 --> 00:16:27.360
I was working and I was at one of the big
defense firms where there is literally,

290
00:16:27.360 --> 00:16:32.180
500 people in payroll it wouldn't
be fair to benchmark that against

00:16:32.180 --> 00:16:36.227

00:16:36.227 --> 00:16:39.157
So, functional benchmarks we
have to just make sure that

00:16:39.157 --> 00:16:42.220
we're measuring apples to apples and

294
00:16:42.220 --> 00:16:44.280
And you say well what's an example?

295
00:16:44.280 --> 00:16:47.420
Well most companies have
a recruiting process, right?

296
00:16:47.420 --> 00:16:52.350
Most companies have a way that, they have

00:16:52.350 --> 00:16:57.350
a way that they advertise their
job postings and stuff like that.

298
00:16:57.350 --> 00:17:02.110
And so,
looking at how fast do they fill a job.

299
00:17:02.110 --> 00:17:06.190
So if they were doing a similar
method of employment recruiting,

300
00:17:06.190 --> 00:17:09.300
how fast are they filling
the job on an average, right?

301
00:17:09.300 --> 00:17:13.850
So there's a lot of things that are just
generic to different departments.

302
00:17:13.850 --> 00:17:15.655
We've mentioned payroll
a couple of different times.

303
00:17:15.655 --> 00:17:19.931
So functional benchmark admissions
would be a good functional

304
00:17:19.931 --> 00:17:23.482
benchmark because we admit
people into hospitals,

305
00:17:23.482 --> 00:17:28.880
we admit people into the library,
we admit people into fast food, right?

306
00:17:28.880 --> 00:17:32.640
I mean so how fast do we process
people coming in, that type of thing.

307
00:17:32.640 --> 00:17:34.540
So that would be a functional benchmark.

308
00:17:34.540 --> 00:17:37.947
And like I said, if you were presenting
your functional benchmark you would just

309
00:17:37.947 --> 00:17:41.422
want to make sure that you're comparing
apples to apples and oranges to oranges.

310
00:17:41.422 --> 00:17:44.243
Just not a big company
against a small one, or

311
00:17:44.243 --> 00:17:47.820
a company that's just known
to have great expertise.

312
00:17:47.820 --> 00:17:52.420
Sometimes small colleges benchmark
themselves against larger colleges, and

313
00:17:52.420 --> 00:17:54.901
it's really just not particularly fair.

314
00:17:54.901 --> 00:17:59.855
Collaborative benchmarking is similar
to competitive benchmarking in the fact

315
00:17:59.855 --> 00:18:04.731
that you want to make sure you know what
benchmarking study you're looking at,

316
00:18:04.731 --> 00:18:08.181
and possibly look at a couple

317
00:18:08.181 --> 00:18:13.904
Collaborative benchmarking is when
the industry has got together And

00:18:13.904 --> 00:18:18.851
that would be something like
a utility company, or energy or

00:18:18.851 --> 00:18:22.731
the automotive industry
have come together and

00:18:22.731 --> 00:18:27.295

00:18:27.295 --> 00:18:32.149
And the UN sometimes collectively

00:18:32.149 --> 00:18:35.600

323
00:18:35.600 --> 00:18:41.545
But again if you're doing something,

00:18:41.545 --> 00:18:46.930

325
00:18:46.930 --> 00:18:49.995
So, someone might say,

00:18:49.995 --> 00:18:51.376
Where did those benchmarks come from?

00:18:51.376 --> 00:18:56.370
So, just something that
you want to be aware of.

328
00:18:56.370 --> 00:18:59.760
And then finally,

329
00:18:59.760 --> 00:19:01.847
And all that means is it doesn't

00:19:01.847 --> 00:19:03.414
And what does that mean to you?

00:19:03.414 --> 00:19:07.623
What that means to you is that if you're
going to present a benchmark that doesn't

332
00:19:07.623 --> 00:19:12.080

00:19:12.080 --> 00:19:14.828
Because probably people are going

00:19:17.661 --> 00:19:18.769
>> All right.
So benchmarking.
