418
00:23:44.550 --> 00:23:45.735
>> Absolutely.

419
00:23:45.735 --> 00:23:47.255
Well we tackled the define phase.

420
00:23:47.255 --> 00:23:48.973
We tackled the measure phase.

421
00:23:48.973 --> 00:23:52.212
I think we're probably about ready to
move on into the analyze phase next.

422
00:23:52.212 --> 00:23:54.987
But this is a pretty good
spot to wrap this episode up.

423
00:23:54.987 --> 00:23:57.994
Do you have any final thoughts on
the measure phase before we move on?

424
00:23:57.994 --> 00:24:01.394
>> I think I've said everything
about measure I can think about.

425
00:24:01.394 --> 00:24:02.591
>> Excellent, all right.

426
00:24:02.591 --> 00:24:04.332
Well ladies and gentlemen,
I do hope you you guys enjoyed us.

427
00:24:04.332 --> 00:24:06.549
Stay tuned, we've got three
more phases to move through.

428
00:24:06.549 --> 00:24:09.387
We'll be moving into that analyze
phase in the next episode so

429
00:24:09.387 --> 00:24:11.472
hopefully you'll tune back in for
that one.

430
00:24:11.472 --> 00:24:15.129
But for right now, signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

431
00:24:15.129 --> 00:24:16.429
>> And I'm Dr. Stern.

432
00:24:16.429 --> 00:24:18.286
>> And we'll see you next time.

433
00:24:18.286 --> 00:24:24.580
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: The purpose of the Analyze Phase is to come up with a number of viable solutions to one's process improvement project. Viewers will see ways of how to put some of the collected data to use through graphs, charts, and models like the Seven Tools of Quality. Viewers will also see the rest of the steps involved in the Analyze Phase that include, identifying potential root causes, finding sources of variation, conducting a correlation analysis, and others.
episodes.title: Analyze Phase
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.631 --> 00:00:14.992
All right good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:14.992 --> 00:00:17.552
And welcome back to another
episode of ITpro TV.

4
00:00:17.552 --> 00:00:21.891
I'm your host Don Pezet back again with
another episode of Lean Six Sigma.

5
00:00:21.891 --> 00:00:25.980
Now we've been slowly working through the
DMAIC model and we've reached the point

6
00:00:25.980 --> 00:00:29.020
where we're jumping into
the third phase the analyze phase.

7
00:00:29.020 --> 00:00:33.270
We're gonna see how we can try to put some
of that data we collected in the last

8
00:00:33.270 --> 00:00:35.950
phase to use and
actually do something with it.

9
00:00:35.950 --> 00:00:38.412
Here to help us with that, we've got Dr.
Stern back on the show.

10
00:00:38.412 --> 00:00:39.132
How's it going Dr. Stern?

11
00:00:39.132 --> 00:00:41.572
>> It's going fine, thank you.

12
00:00:41.572 --> 00:00:44.417
>> All right so, with the analyze phase,
this is where we jump in,

13
00:00:44.417 --> 00:00:47.804
we start to take a look at some of that
data and we actually make it work for us.

14
00:00:47.804 --> 00:00:50.464
So, where do we begin with that?

15
00:00:50.464 --> 00:00:55.297
>> Well, what we're wanting to do is,
we want to take a critical look at we've

16
00:00:55.297 --> 00:00:58.996
been measuring and
basically we're taking a step back and

17
00:00:58.996 --> 00:01:02.262
we're seeing why does
the picture look like that?

18
00:01:02.262 --> 00:01:09.611
And the whole purpose of analyze is to end
up with three to five viable solutions and

19
00:01:09.611 --> 00:01:14.841
we do that by looking at
the series of tools and exercises.

20
00:01:14.841 --> 00:01:19.017
>> I know for me, when I'm doing the whole
measure where we're collecting the data,

21
00:01:19.017 --> 00:01:20.509
we're getting it together,

22
00:01:20.509 --> 00:01:24.070
I've got a bad habit of basically
analyzing while I'm measuring.

23
00:01:24.070 --> 00:01:27.664
And you really shouldn't do that,
because sometimes you don't have the whole

24
00:01:27.664 --> 00:01:29.874
picture, but
it really is two separate phases.

25
00:01:29.874 --> 00:01:32.684
We gather the data and
then we interpret it right, and

26
00:01:32.684 --> 00:01:35.003
that's basically what we're doing here.

27
00:01:35.003 --> 00:01:39.655
>> Exactly and that is a very
important point because in measure we

28
00:01:39.655 --> 00:01:44.304
just want to get a clean idea of
how things look like right now and

29
00:01:44.304 --> 00:01:46.700
we don't want to over think it.

30
00:01:46.700 --> 00:01:49.810
We just want to be recorders and
get that down.

31
00:01:49.810 --> 00:01:54.801
Because that way when we get to analyze,
we're able to sort through the data and

32
00:01:54.801 --> 00:01:57.493
try to figure out why
does it look that way.

33
00:01:57.493 --> 00:02:01.867
>> All right, so when it comes to
the analyze phase, I've got all of my data

34
00:02:01.867 --> 00:02:07.053
collected, I have it in nice little charts
or however it is that we've collected it.

35
00:02:07.053 --> 00:02:10.815
And I'm ready to try and
locate those root causes or

36
00:02:10.815 --> 00:02:15.453
whatever it is that I'm gonna
actually go to work to improve and

37
00:02:15.453 --> 00:02:19.493
is there one tool,
ten tools where do we go from there?

38
00:02:19.493 --> 00:02:22.550
>> Again there's just
a myriad of tools in analyze.

39
00:02:22.550 --> 00:02:25.540
The ones that we're gonna look
at are the most popular tools.

40
00:02:25.540 --> 00:02:30.299
And one of the things we're going to
be spending time on today is something

41
00:02:30.299 --> 00:02:32.621
called the seven tools of quality.

42
00:02:32.621 --> 00:02:35.615
Now these are also called the seven
tools of process improvement,

43
00:02:35.615 --> 00:02:37.390
the seven tools of critical thinking.

44
00:02:37.390 --> 00:02:41.020
I've heard it referred to as the seven
seven tools of management app.

45
00:02:41.020 --> 00:02:44.931
Even though there is a different set,
seven tools of management.

46
00:02:44.931 --> 00:02:47.983
But when you hear that word seven,
generally speaking,

47
00:02:47.983 --> 00:02:50.560
it has to do with these quality tools.

48
00:02:50.560 --> 00:02:53.641
So we're probably gonna be
concentrating a lot on that.

49
00:02:53.641 --> 00:02:58.201
I have a slide that kinda talks about
what we'll be looking at in this

50
00:02:58.201 --> 00:02:59.561
particular phase.

51
00:02:59.561 --> 00:03:02.681
We're gonna be identifying
potential root causes.

52
00:03:02.681 --> 00:03:08.240
We're gonna look for sources or variation,
we're gonna try to figure out what factors

53
00:03:08.240 --> 00:03:13.441
contribute to variation and I wanna spend
a little time talking about variation.

54
00:03:13.441 --> 00:03:18.550
And we're gonna look at how we would
go about conducting a correlation

55
00:03:18.550 --> 00:03:23.061
analysis and look at studying impacts and
what if scenarios.

56
00:03:23.061 --> 00:03:25.177
Now we're not actually
going to do all that, but

57
00:03:25.177 --> 00:03:27.561
those are the things that
happen in the analyze phase.

58
00:03:31.282 --> 00:03:35.042
When we're looking at the data
that we gathered for measure,

59
00:03:35.042 --> 00:03:37.862
when we're looking at
that particular data,

60
00:03:37.862 --> 00:03:41.860
the data analysis that we're
doing falls into four categories.

61
00:03:41.860 --> 00:03:47.567
Now data analysis has other things
that you might want to study but

62
00:03:47.567 --> 00:03:52.131
the four key things in
Lean Six Sigma are root cause,

63
00:03:52.131 --> 00:03:55.580
correlation, variation and impact.

64
00:03:55.580 --> 00:03:59.318
Now, root cause,
we already did one root cause tool,

65
00:03:59.318 --> 00:04:02.500
which was the five whys,
in another episode.

66
00:04:02.500 --> 00:04:06.970
So, it's important,
when I'm looking at this data for

67
00:04:06.970 --> 00:04:11.050
measure, to figure out what is
the root cause of this condition.

68
00:04:11.050 --> 00:04:14.520
And hopefully, that will lead
me to three to five solutions.

69
00:04:14.520 --> 00:04:15.940
So, even though we in analyze, and

70
00:04:15.940 --> 00:04:20.370
we have all these tools that we're using,
and sometimes there's so

71
00:04:20.370 --> 00:04:24.670
much data, we have to put it in a graph or
chart to actually digest it.

72
00:04:24.670 --> 00:04:28.161
We're still depending on our own minds
to come up with those three to five

73
00:04:28.161 --> 00:04:28.800
solutions.

74
00:04:28.800 --> 00:04:31.219
The theory is that with
all this information,

75
00:04:31.219 --> 00:04:33.830
that's just going to be
a little bit easier to do.

76
00:04:33.830 --> 00:04:38.638
So another thing I'm looking at is
correlation, however, this is one of those

77
00:04:38.638 --> 00:04:43.447
kind of strange things in Lean Six Sigma,
they talk about correlation, we're

78
00:04:43.447 --> 00:04:48.257
gonna look at some correlation charts and
certainly a correlation can be used to

79
00:04:48.257 --> 00:04:53.670
come up with different types of solutions
or lead to different types of solutions.

80
00:04:53.670 --> 00:04:58.670
But when they talk about correlation
it is really more about triggers.

81
00:04:58.670 --> 00:05:00.670
I'm sure you remember
from statistics 101 that

82
00:05:01.930 --> 00:05:06.270
people say correlation doesn't
necessarily mean causation.

83
00:05:06.270 --> 00:05:10.790
But in Lean Six Sigma it is really what
they're looking so, it's kinda funny.

84
00:05:10.790 --> 00:05:15.560
Even though technically it's not,
we're looking more for triggers.

85
00:05:15.560 --> 00:05:18.161
Like when this happens, does that happen?

86
00:05:18.161 --> 00:05:22.280
And it's all kind of lumped together
under correlation because the graphs look

87
00:05:22.280 --> 00:05:25.491
similar to correlation, so
that's just what we labeled it.

88
00:05:25.491 --> 00:05:29.366
But, the reason that we're looking at
that again, the reason why we're looking

89
00:05:29.366 --> 00:05:33.320
at root cause, is we want to make sure
we're working on the right problem, right?

90
00:05:33.320 --> 00:05:37.713
The reason we're looking at triggers is if
we come up with three to five solutions

91
00:05:37.713 --> 00:05:40.426
and when we do one thing
this other thing happens,

92
00:05:40.426 --> 00:05:43.610
we wanna make sure our solution
handles both conditions.

93
00:05:43.610 --> 00:05:47.130
And another thing that we're
looking at is variation.

94
00:05:47.130 --> 00:05:52.197
Now this is very important because in the
Six Sigma world all variation is really,

95
00:05:52.197 --> 00:05:53.010
really bad.

96
00:05:53.010 --> 00:05:58.042
In the Lean Six Sigma world sometimes
there's variation that we say

97
00:05:58.042 --> 00:06:03.350
doesn't have a large impact and so
maybe we'll let that variation go.

98
00:06:03.350 --> 00:06:06.861
Now impact,
the fourth condition covers variation, but

99
00:06:06.861 --> 00:06:09.660
it also looks at what is
the financial impact?

100
00:06:09.660 --> 00:06:11.860
What is the human resource impact?

101
00:06:11.860 --> 00:06:14.200
What is the longevity impact?

102
00:06:14.200 --> 00:06:15.680
What is the political impact?

103
00:06:15.680 --> 00:06:18.123
So, impact covers more things.

104
00:06:18.123 --> 00:06:21.971
And backing back up just
a little bit to variation again,

105
00:06:21.971 --> 00:06:25.511
there's a number of different
types of variation.

106
00:06:25.511 --> 00:06:30.339
But the types of variation Lean Six Sigma
is mostly concerned about is something

107
00:06:30.339 --> 00:06:32.730
called special and common variation.

108
00:06:32.730 --> 00:06:35.117
And to make it simple to understand,

109
00:06:35.117 --> 00:06:39.891
we're saying common variation are things
that are within our control and

110
00:06:39.891 --> 00:06:43.820
special variation are things
that are outside our control.

111
00:06:43.820 --> 00:06:48.300
Now common variation also
can kind of consider,

112
00:06:48.300 --> 00:06:51.911
the cost of doing business type thing.

113
00:06:51.911 --> 00:06:56.257
So common variation would include
things such as, if I bought a new car,

114
00:06:56.257 --> 00:07:00.050
at some point, I know I'm gonna
have to get new tires, right?

115
00:07:00.050 --> 00:07:02.323
I have tires for awhile,
but at some point,

116
00:07:02.323 --> 00:07:05.530
I'm gonna have to replace the tires
before I replace the car.

117
00:07:05.530 --> 00:07:09.260
So common variation,
things that are within my control,

118
00:07:09.260 --> 00:07:12.162
things that I can make the decision,
right?

119
00:07:12.162 --> 00:07:15.801
Special variation,
things outside my control.

120
00:07:15.801 --> 00:07:21.109
Now, the interesting thing about

121
00:07:21.109 --> 00:07:27.885
special variations is
it can run the gamut.

122
00:07:27.885 --> 00:07:32.765
It can be anywhere from, I'm a visitor at
the facility and I don't know how to fill

123
00:07:32.765 --> 00:07:37.241
the coffee pot because I don't have
the key, all the way to an earthquake.

124
00:07:37.241 --> 00:07:39.600
So it really runs the gamut.

125
00:07:39.600 --> 00:07:42.947
Common variation is where
we usually try to work

126
00:07:42.947 --> 00:07:47.549
in Lean Six Sigma because we don't
have to ask for permissions and

127
00:07:47.549 --> 00:07:52.420
it's something that we can impact and
something that we can change.

128
00:07:52.420 --> 00:07:57.160
So another thing that we look
at when we're in analyze.

129
00:07:57.160 --> 00:08:02.467
If you were in the green belt,
black belt, or master black belt class,

130
00:08:02.467 --> 00:08:08.129
this is where we study statistics and
statistics such as competence level,

131
00:08:08.129 --> 00:08:12.730
sigma levels, design of experiment,
hypothesis testing,

132
00:08:12.730 --> 00:08:16.371
that's where those types
of exercises happen.

133
00:08:16.371 --> 00:08:19.639
So in a green, black, or
master black belt class,

134
00:08:19.639 --> 00:08:23.895
you'd still be working in the DMAIC model,
but when you got here,

135
00:08:23.895 --> 00:08:29.560
you'd kind of take a bit of a detour into
a lot of math, and a lot of statistics.

136
00:08:29.560 --> 00:08:33.201
Now the good news about that is
that there's some basic statistics,

137
00:08:33.201 --> 00:08:36.673
that a lot of times that's all you
need in a Lean Six Sigma report.

138
00:08:36.673 --> 00:08:41.850
Now even though green, black and master
black belt learn a lot of statistics,

139
00:08:41.850 --> 00:08:45.471
sometimes they revert back
to the simple statistics.

140
00:08:45.471 --> 00:08:50.271
And those are mean, mode, median,
range and order of operators.

141
00:08:50.271 --> 00:08:55.171
And so mean, and I know a lot of you
already know this but mean average and

142
00:08:55.171 --> 00:08:57.792
mean average all mean the same thing.

143
00:08:57.792 --> 00:09:01.322
Mode is the number of times
a number shows up in a string,

144
00:09:01.322 --> 00:09:05.827
so if you had a string of numbers like,
15 numbers and the number eight

145
00:09:05.827 --> 00:09:10.283
showed up more times then any other
number that would become our mode.

146
00:09:10.283 --> 00:09:14.186
A median is where you take the numbers and
you line them up and

147
00:09:14.186 --> 00:09:16.621
you choose the number in the middle.

148
00:09:16.621 --> 00:09:21.080
In order to do that you have to line
them up sequentially first, right?

149
00:09:21.080 --> 00:09:27.880
So, if I were grading a test, I probably
wouldn't be getting a 30, 40, 70, 90.

150
00:09:27.880 --> 00:09:29.700
I'd probably be getting
them in a different order.

151
00:09:29.700 --> 00:09:33.326
So, I would want to line those
up in sequential order and

152
00:09:33.326 --> 00:09:35.110
pick the one in the middle.

153
00:09:35.110 --> 00:09:37.603
Now, the reason why mean mode and

154
00:09:37.603 --> 00:09:43.034
median mode are such a big deal in
Lean Six Sigma, is a lot of statistics,

155
00:09:43.034 --> 00:09:48.222
a lot of measurements a lot of
presentations are based on the middle.

156
00:09:48.222 --> 00:09:53.368
So, when we're trying to talk about
something like the average number of

157
00:09:53.368 --> 00:09:59.012
customer complaints, the average number
of absences, those types of things,

158
00:09:59.012 --> 00:10:03.670
we're looking at a mean, and
we're gauging things on that mean.

159
00:10:03.670 --> 00:10:08.214
If our mode and our median are close to
the mean, then we can pretty much say,

160
00:10:08.214 --> 00:10:11.558
on an average,
we have 15 customer complaints a day.

161
00:10:11.558 --> 00:10:15.532
But if our mode and
our median are way off from that,

162
00:10:15.532 --> 00:10:19.710
then maybe that's not really
depicting the number.

163
00:10:19.710 --> 00:10:24.504
So since things such as control charts and
run charts and a few other charts work off

164
00:10:24.504 --> 00:10:29.320
the middle, we wanna make sure that we're
giving a true depiction of the middle.

165
00:10:29.320 --> 00:10:33.320
So we're always kinda testing that
average against mode and median.

166
00:10:34.610 --> 00:10:39.477
Then the reason why range is important
in statistical thinking is that if

167
00:10:39.477 --> 00:10:44.181
I'm looking at the number of defects,
I might be looking at a range for

168
00:10:44.181 --> 00:10:45.481
a couple of weeks.

169
00:10:45.481 --> 00:10:48.734
And there could be special conditions,
so rather than,

170
00:10:48.734 --> 00:10:52.750
I just want to consider that in
the mix when I'm analyzing something.

171
00:10:52.750 --> 00:10:55.010
It could have been an off week for
example.

172
00:10:55.010 --> 00:11:00.087
So when I'm increasing my range,
let's say I'm going to study something,

173
00:11:00.087 --> 00:11:05.413
a condition for four or five weeks, well
then I might get different statistics.

174
00:11:05.413 --> 00:11:07.780
And then the order of
operators are kind of funny.

175
00:11:07.780 --> 00:11:11.202
Because we learned that in third grade,
but a lot of times we forgot about it.

176
00:11:11.202 --> 00:11:14.090
And that's just the way that
formulas are determined.

177
00:11:14.090 --> 00:11:18.530
And I think, I can't remember what it was
that they taught us in or fifth grade.

178
00:11:18.530 --> 00:11:20.140
>> It was that please,
my dear Aunt Sally or-

179
00:11:20.140 --> 00:11:22.616
>> Yeah, please excuse my dear Aunt Sally,

180
00:11:22.616 --> 00:11:23.120
right.

181
00:11:23.120 --> 00:11:25.050
So, a lot you probably remember that.

182
00:11:25.050 --> 00:11:29.576
And the reason why that's important
is that a lot of times when we're

183
00:11:29.576 --> 00:11:33.869
looking at formulas we just forget
to do it in the correct order and

184
00:11:33.869 --> 00:11:36.851
we're just going to get
a different number.

185
00:11:36.851 --> 00:11:40.316
So, when you are in analyze and
you're in the green, black or

186
00:11:40.316 --> 00:11:44.396
master black belt class, this is
where you start studying statistics.

187
00:11:44.396 --> 00:11:49.058
Now in Lean Six Sigma, the good news is
that what we want to do is make sure you

188
00:11:49.058 --> 00:11:53.668
understand the statistic and you
understand why you might want to use it.

189
00:11:53.668 --> 00:11:56.455
For example, why would I want
to use a confidence level?

190
00:11:56.455 --> 00:12:02.006
Once we're comfortable in those classes
knowing that You actually have a choice,

191
00:12:02.006 --> 00:12:05.413
and your choice is to just
let Excel do it for you, or

192
00:12:05.413 --> 00:12:10.430
you can learn the long way of doing that,
the actual mathematic formulas.

193
00:12:10.430 --> 00:12:15.758
But the task is more, the testing for Six
Sigma is more about that you understand

194
00:12:15.758 --> 00:12:20.009
why you would be using this statistic and
why you would reach for that.

195
00:12:20.009 --> 00:12:23.206
Now the reason why in
the Six Sigma environment and

196
00:12:23.206 --> 00:12:28.004
this is one of the big complaints
about Six Sigma versus Six Sigma is

197
00:12:28.004 --> 00:12:32.650
that when Six Sigma was created in
the 80s by Bill Smith for Motorola.

198
00:12:32.650 --> 00:12:37.470
We didn't have all these great statistical
packages, and Excel can just do so

199
00:12:37.470 --> 00:12:40.476
many incredible things at
the touch of a button.

200
00:12:40.476 --> 00:12:43.052
So it's not always important.

201
00:12:43.052 --> 00:12:47.051
In an earlier episode I mentioned
that on your course files

202
00:12:47.051 --> 00:12:51.716
you have a sigma calculator and
a return on investment calculator.

203
00:12:51.716 --> 00:12:55.728
Well in the 1980s they had a,
things like that as well, but

204
00:12:55.728 --> 00:12:58.847
they just weren't as easy
to use as they are now.

205
00:12:58.847 --> 00:13:04.379
And you still had to really understand
the mathematical formula to go back and

206
00:13:04.379 --> 00:13:08.307
test your work,
you just really don't need that now.

207
00:13:08.307 --> 00:13:13.664
So, what happens sometimes when we go from
measure to analyze is that we just have so

208
00:13:13.664 --> 00:13:14.440
much data.

209
00:13:14.440 --> 00:13:18.606
We cant process that data, and remember,
we're looking at that that data because

210
00:13:18.606 --> 00:13:21.830
we're hoping it's going to lead
us to three to five solutions.

211
00:13:21.830 --> 00:13:25.910
And so sometimes it's important
to organize that data so

212
00:13:25.910 --> 00:13:27.953
that we can really study it.

213
00:13:27.953 --> 00:13:32.759
And what we're going to be doing next
is just looking at some of the popular

214
00:13:32.759 --> 00:13:37.643
graphs and charts which are included
in that seven tools of quality which is

215
00:13:37.643 --> 00:13:42.930
sometimes called the seven tools of
process improvement or critical thinking.

216
00:13:42.930 --> 00:13:44.314
The first one I want to look at,

217
00:13:44.314 --> 00:13:47.744
even though the slide said the first
one we're gonna look at is process map.

218
00:13:47.744 --> 00:13:49.521
But we're going to still talk about that.

219
00:13:49.521 --> 00:13:51.576
But we've talked about
process mapping a lot.

220
00:13:51.576 --> 00:13:57.530
Now when I get to analyze I'm looking
a process map in a different way.

221
00:13:57.530 --> 00:14:02.630
In define, I was looking at
the process map to get a high level

222
00:14:02.630 --> 00:14:05.910
idea of what is happening with my process,
right?

223
00:14:05.910 --> 00:14:09.884
And then in measure I might have
taken that high-level process map and

224
00:14:09.884 --> 00:14:14.527
kind of segmented it out a little bit, but
when I get to analyze what I'm looking at

225
00:14:14.527 --> 00:14:19.138
that process now, I'm thinking from
the terms of what boxes could I eliminate?

226
00:14:19.138 --> 00:14:22.068
What boxes could I maybe
combine with another box, or

227
00:14:22.068 --> 00:14:26.431
what boxes could I maybe move around in
a different order to make things better,

228
00:14:26.431 --> 00:14:31.397
faster, more cost effective, because those
are the goals we have for Six Sigma.

229
00:14:31.397 --> 00:14:35.750
So the first one we're going to
look at is the Fishbone Diagram.

230
00:14:35.750 --> 00:14:40.413
I mentioned in an earlier episode that on
the lean side this is called ichikawa,

231
00:14:40.413 --> 00:14:44.329
on the Six Sigma side it's often
called a cause and effect matrix.

232
00:14:44.329 --> 00:14:49.277
Which brings me to another quick point,
even though matrixes, diagrams,

233
00:14:49.277 --> 00:14:53.084
charts, all of those things
are technically different.

234
00:14:53.084 --> 00:14:54.247
For some reason and

235
00:14:54.247 --> 00:14:59.196
I'm not sure why, in the Lean Six Sigma
world, they use them interchangeably.

236
00:14:59.196 --> 00:15:03.003
So if you were to look up
the word diagram versus a chart,

237
00:15:03.003 --> 00:15:05.360
it would have different nuances.

238
00:15:05.360 --> 00:15:08.580
But just remember, if you hear
something with the word chart or

239
00:15:08.580 --> 00:15:11.998
diagram or matrix after it,
it's actually the same collateral.

240
00:15:11.998 --> 00:15:16.412
So if someone said, I'm doing
a fishbone analysis, fishbone chart,

241
00:15:16.412 --> 00:15:20.610
a fishbone matrix which that
probably wouldn't make much sense.

242
00:15:20.610 --> 00:15:23.440
But if you hear those terms,
just know they're all the same tool.

243
00:15:23.440 --> 00:15:25.150
And I think that's kind of a good tip.

244
00:15:25.150 --> 00:15:29.193
So, anyway, one of the goals of Lean
Six Sigma is to simplify things and so

245
00:15:29.193 --> 00:15:31.161
this is called a fishbone diagram.

246
00:15:31.161 --> 00:15:34.969
And in this particular fishbone diagram in
the head of the fish we have the problem

247
00:15:34.969 --> 00:15:37.881
which is we're gonna say it's
some kind of quality problem,

248
00:15:37.881 --> 00:15:39.233
some sort of quality issue.

249
00:15:39.233 --> 00:15:42.964
And you'll notice in
this particular diagram,

250
00:15:42.964 --> 00:15:47.790
the big bones say measure,
measurement, human, machines.

251
00:15:47.790 --> 00:15:51.434
There's a lot of different ways
you can do a Fishbone Diagram, and

252
00:15:51.434 --> 00:15:54.702
we're gonna talk about some of
the models that you can use.

253
00:15:54.702 --> 00:15:57.859
But you can also name these
big bones whatever you want.

254
00:15:57.859 --> 00:16:01.932
When I have a lot of time and
I'm doing it as a facilitation exercise,

255
00:16:01.932 --> 00:16:06.709
like I'm bringing a group in so that we
can try to figure out what's contributing

256
00:16:06.709 --> 00:16:09.470
to the problem,
I like them to name the bones.

257
00:16:09.470 --> 00:16:12.740
Because that tells me a little
bit about their process.

258
00:16:12.740 --> 00:16:17.820
But the theory of the Fishbone Diagram
is that the further you

259
00:16:17.820 --> 00:16:21.370
get down in the process, the more likely
you are to identify the root cause.

260
00:16:21.370 --> 00:16:25.110
So, you would actually take something
like, for example, under Measurement where

261
00:16:25.110 --> 00:16:28.850
it says faulty testing equipment, and
you would try to do bones off that.

262
00:16:28.850 --> 00:16:32.260
And those bones are where you're
gonna find that root cause.

263
00:16:32.260 --> 00:16:36.759
Now, Fishbone Diagram is a terribly
under-utilized tool, and

264
00:16:36.759 --> 00:16:41.604
a lot of white papers will complain
that it didn't solve the problem.

265
00:16:41.604 --> 00:16:45.756
And what I would challenge you to
remember is that the Fishbone Diagram is

266
00:16:45.756 --> 00:16:47.340
an identification tool.

267
00:16:47.340 --> 00:16:51.040
We looked at another identification
tool called Tim Woods that helped us

268
00:16:51.040 --> 00:16:52.710
identify areas of waste.

269
00:16:52.710 --> 00:16:55.070
So kind of think of it in that aspect,

270
00:16:55.070 --> 00:17:00.400
all I'm trying to do is identify
the root cause, because

271
00:17:00.400 --> 00:17:04.810
if I identify the root cause I may be able
to come up with three to five solutions.

272
00:17:06.380 --> 00:17:09.710
Now there's a lot of really clever things
you can do with fishbone diagrams.

273
00:17:09.710 --> 00:17:12.681
And you'll see that this
is just an example,

274
00:17:12.681 --> 00:17:17.070
that you might wanna go back and
look at it in depth at another time.

275
00:17:17.070 --> 00:17:22.092
Or you might wanna stop the film and
look at it now, sorry.

276
00:17:22.092 --> 00:17:24.106
[LAUGH] I forgot that you could do that.

277
00:17:24.106 --> 00:17:25.890
>> [LAUGH]
>> So you might wanna stop and

278
00:17:25.890 --> 00:17:28.740
look at this when you have
a little bit more time.

279
00:17:28.740 --> 00:17:32.202
But I just wanna show you how you
can take these simple things and

280
00:17:32.202 --> 00:17:34.566
do some really pretty diagrams with them.

281
00:17:34.566 --> 00:17:38.720
Again most of the Lean Six Sigma tools and
certainly the Seven Tools of Quality,

282
00:17:38.720 --> 00:17:41.696
those were all developed
back in the 40s and 50s, and

283
00:17:41.696 --> 00:17:44.290
they were meant to be paper and
pencil tools.

284
00:17:44.290 --> 00:17:48.580
And so I think that there is a real
value in being able to use them and

00:17:48.580 --> 00:17:51.085

00:17:51.085 --> 00:17:54.167
But also if you're trying to

we have again templates on your sample

00:17:58.442 --> 00:18:02.928

diagrams is in your initial
drawing of that diagram,

00:18:06.293 --> 00:18:09.990
every possible cause is kind

00:18:09.990 --> 00:18:12.000

they actually put in the percentages for

So you can see like, yeah there might be

00:18:26.861 --> 00:18:28.370

00:18:28.370 --> 00:18:31.562
So remember that there is more than

00:18:31.562 --> 00:18:35.209
and you gotta find the one that kind of

00:18:35.209 --> 00:18:35.975
>> Exactly.

00:18:35.975 --> 00:18:40.648
And sometimes when you're
doing your fishbone diagram,

00:18:40.648 --> 00:18:44.520
sometimes it's better to

00:18:44.520 --> 00:18:48.260
And this system that I'm looking

So, I haven't really found

00:18:53.689 --> 00:18:55.630
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, I didn't put that on there.

00:18:55.630 --> 00:18:59.933
So, you can see it's saying machines,
methods, materials,

00:18:59.933 --> 00:19:03.053

310
00:19:03.053 --> 00:19:05.583
And, it's just another way

311
00:19:05.583 --> 00:19:10.401
So, let's say you're in a meeting,
someone presents a problem.

312
00:19:10.401 --> 00:19:12.381
You can put it in the head of the fish,
and

00:19:12.381 --> 00:19:16.306
if you didn't really have time to think
about all the factors that contribute.

314
00:19:16.306 --> 00:19:21.581
You could maybe use these six categories
to start getting your mind going and

315
00:19:21.581 --> 00:19:25.882
your critical thinking around
each one of these categories.

00:19:25.882 --> 00:19:29.181
And then there's what, and
you might want to stop the tape and

00:19:29.181 --> 00:19:32.101
look at these because they're very,
very valuable,

318
00:19:32.101 --> 00:19:36.610
even if you're just trying to figure

00:19:36.610 --> 00:19:39.778
There's a model that's even simpler,

00:19:42.019 --> 00:19:46.148

00:20:03.389 --> 00:20:06.785

00:20:06.785 --> 00:20:09.673

00:20:11.415 --> 00:20:15.231
Now, there's even a simpler one,

you've got a problem,

And then you'd have the process, right?

00:20:45.032 --> 00:20:50.310
Now, in my university classes a lot

00:20:50.310 --> 00:20:55.776
and the example I use to use is I'd say

But inevitably, a student would raise

00:20:59.810 --> 00:21:02.509
they would say things like,

Or do you mean human trafficking?

But sometimes,

So if I, in real life put

00:21:13.650 --> 00:21:18.070
that might not be as effective is

00:21:22.680 --> 00:21:27.090
So what are the rules that you want to

00:21:27.090 --> 00:21:30.780

352
00:21:36.000 --> 00:21:39.851
Now, we talked about flow charts, and

00:21:43.941 --> 00:21:47.225

It's kinda cute, but

00:21:51.409 --> 00:21:57.076
a lot of times we think about something

00:21:57.076 --> 00:22:02.045
SmartChart, or some of the really

00:22:02.045 --> 00:22:04.333
you can just draw it out, too.

00:22:04.333 --> 00:22:07.653
When you're in the analyze phase,

00:22:07.653 --> 00:22:10.835
So you don't necessarily always

361
00:22:10.835 --> 00:22:15.537
One of the things that I appreciate

362
00:22:15.537 --> 00:22:20.424
that it capitalizes on your mental
ability just as much as it does

363
00:22:20.424 --> 00:22:22.699
on your computerized skill.

364
00:22:22.699 --> 00:22:27.061
And so some things like the three Ps,
if you were using them more to just think

365
00:22:27.061 --> 00:22:30.967
about things or those voices that
we covered when we were in define.

366
00:22:30.967 --> 00:22:33.450
These are things that you can
think about on your walk, or

00:22:33.450 --> 00:22:34.656
when you are driving home.

00:22:34.656 --> 00:22:36.468
You don't always need to have a computer.

00:22:36.468 --> 00:22:39.972

00:22:39.972 --> 00:22:41.111
like flowcharting.

00:22:41.111 --> 00:22:44.230
We can just draw them
out on a piece of paper.

00:22:45.480 --> 00:22:47.952
Sometimes that's more lean.

00:22:47.952 --> 00:22:49.722
Now, one of the quality tools, and

00:22:49.722 --> 00:22:53.870
I always think this is kind of interesting
is something called check sheets.

00:22:53.870 --> 00:22:56.127
And check sheets are things

00:22:56.127 --> 00:23:00.975
And when you think about the seven,
what people are saying are the seven most

00:23:00.975 --> 00:23:05.523
important tools of quality or
the seven most important tools of process

378
00:23:05.523 --> 00:23:09.865
improvement or critical thinking and
check sheets makes the list.

00:23:09.865 --> 00:23:11.954
I think that's pretty phenomenal
cuz that's a simple tool.

00:23:11.954 --> 00:23:17.690
Now, like I said, to do list is

00:23:17.690 --> 00:23:20.511
Another example is something

00:23:20.511 --> 00:23:25.433
In very large Six Sigma projects, it

00:23:25.433 --> 00:23:30.207
projects, between the various phases,

Sometimes they put something

And a tollgate is just basically

In some cases if a project is incredibly

A tollgate Liaison that goes around and

00:24:07.890 --> 00:24:11.163
So a toll gate would be

00:24:11.163 --> 00:24:14.567
It's also a great way to

00:24:19.197 --> 00:24:24.257
So check sheet's a good way to,

00:24:29.414 --> 00:24:34.250
And it can also just be a list of

00:24:34.250 --> 00:24:36.024

00:24:36.024 --> 00:24:40.758
I think it's kinda funny in the old Steve

Another person, the people that

00:25:13.810 --> 00:25:16.972
All the things that we accomplish that so

00:25:16.972 --> 00:25:20.600

412
00:25:20.600 --> 00:25:22.540
So, and here's the, I'm sorry,

00:25:22.540 --> 00:25:25.672

414
00:25:31.012 --> 00:25:35.842
So the next thing we're gonna do is

00:25:35.842 --> 00:25:39.580
A histogram can do a number
of different things.

00:25:39.580 --> 00:25:40.823
In Lean Six Sigma,

00:25:40.823 --> 00:25:45.338
we're primarily using a histogram

00:25:45.338 --> 00:25:50.030
So, even though histograms can

00:25:50.030 --> 00:25:55.276

So, number of accidents on the shop floor,

And so in the frequency diagram

00:26:12.193 --> 00:26:14.410
you'll see that we were counting colors.

425
00:26:14.410 --> 00:26:16.291
And we thought there
were five blue colors.

426
00:26:16.291 --> 00:26:21.486
And you'll notice the bucket of blue,
red, yellow, and orange.

427
00:26:21.486 --> 00:26:25.072
Now the only problem that I
have with this particular idea,

428
00:26:25.072 --> 00:26:30.090
because we're taking a frequency diagram
and we're capturing it on a histogram,

429
00:26:30.090 --> 00:26:33.908
is that on this histogram,
they put the largest number first.

430
00:26:33.908 --> 00:26:37.998
And that can happen because histograms
can also be used to collect bins of

431
00:26:37.998 --> 00:26:38.877
information.

432
00:26:38.877 --> 00:26:43.836
But if you were tracking the history
of events, what you'd wanna do

433
00:26:43.836 --> 00:26:48.536
is you'd want to do it related to time and
not related to volume.

434
00:26:48.536 --> 00:26:52.855
And this is an example of an expense
histogram that we just used the other day.

435
00:26:52.855 --> 00:26:55.920
We had a small regional conference.

436
00:26:55.920 --> 00:26:59.153
And we were looking at a small
regional ASU conference.

437
00:26:59.153 --> 00:27:02.801
And we were trying to look at
the average expense money that people on

438
00:27:02.801 --> 00:27:03.768
the board spent.

439
00:27:03.768 --> 00:27:09.021
We already have the hotel room and
the meals kind of figured into the mix.

440
00:27:09.021 --> 00:27:13.033
And so we were just looking at the 40
people that we have on the leadership

441
00:27:13.033 --> 00:27:16.608
team and trying to get kind of
an idea of how much money they spent.

442
00:27:16.608 --> 00:27:20.938
And you can see on this histogram
that the biggest bulk of

443
00:27:20.938 --> 00:27:23.620
the people spent about $738.

444
00:27:23.620 --> 00:27:27.125
Now the reason why that's helpful is
next year when we're budgeting for

445
00:27:27.125 --> 00:27:30.470
another regional conference we'll
have these figures available.

446
00:27:30.470 --> 00:27:35.671
And this is just kind of a simple one.

447
00:27:35.671 --> 00:27:38.968
This is looking at parent ages for
pre-school children.

448
00:27:38.968 --> 00:27:42.000
And you'll see that most
of the parents in this

449
00:27:42.000 --> 00:27:45.748
particular group fall between
the ages of 30 and 34.

450
00:27:45.748 --> 00:27:49.728
And that might be helpful to the teacher
that's teaching that class to know the age

451
00:27:49.728 --> 00:27:50.833
group of the parents.

452
00:27:50.833 --> 00:27:52.255
And this one I had to throw in.

453
00:27:52.255 --> 00:27:57.236
You don't see these too often anymore but
if I have any shutterbug people out there,

454
00:27:57.236 --> 00:28:00.885
I have any people there are still
into the older photography,

455
00:28:00.885 --> 00:28:03.719
you might have seen
a histogram on your camera.

456
00:28:03.719 --> 00:28:07.551
Now the next thing we're gonna talk about
is something called a Pareto chart.

457
00:28:07.551 --> 00:28:12.827
So the way I wanna explain this is if you
were looking at the number of customer

458
00:28:12.827 --> 00:28:17.938
complaints you got every day,
your histogram would say something like,

459
00:28:17.938 --> 00:28:23.316
on Monday I got 15, on Tuesday I got 40,
on Wednesday I got 10, right?

460
00:28:23.316 --> 00:28:25.545
That's how your histogram would go.

461
00:28:25.545 --> 00:28:27.820
But then if you wanted to do Pareto chart,

462
00:28:27.820 --> 00:28:31.007
it might look at the types of
customer complaints you had.

463
00:28:31.007 --> 00:28:35.088
Now if I were looking at the types of
customer complaints I have, then I

464
00:28:35.088 --> 00:28:39.668
would arrange them in sequential order so
that the biggest bar would be on top.

465
00:28:39.668 --> 00:28:42.640
So let's say that you were
an IT help desk, for example.

466
00:28:42.640 --> 00:28:47.425
At the IT help desk, I might
determine that my largest amount of

467
00:28:47.425 --> 00:28:52.663
complaints came from people not being
able to access a new password or

468
00:28:52.663 --> 00:28:55.666
their password going bad in 30 days.

469
00:28:55.666 --> 00:28:58.708
And so I would know that that's
the problem that I wanna tackle.

470
00:28:58.708 --> 00:29:04.374
So it gets a little confusing sometimes,
because histograms track the history,

471
00:29:04.374 --> 00:29:07.833
whereas a pareto chart
tracks the type of events.

472
00:29:07.833 --> 00:29:11.533
>> It's funny you mentioned that because
you're example there is something that

473
00:29:11.533 --> 00:29:13.698
almost exactly a thing
that I did in real life.

474
00:29:13.698 --> 00:29:17.674
I used to work for an insurance
company and every six months we would

475
00:29:17.674 --> 00:29:23.200
take the helpdesk and their history of
calls and we would break it down by type.

476
00:29:23.200 --> 00:29:26.961
So they got hundreds or
thousands of calls in a six-month period.

477
00:29:26.961 --> 00:29:27.935
And we organize it.

478
00:29:27.935 --> 00:29:33.092
We'd say, okay, out of the thousands of
calls, there were 300 password resets,

479
00:29:33.092 --> 00:29:37.982
and then there were 100 instances of
people infected with spyware or malware.

480
00:29:37.982 --> 00:29:40.925
And then there were 50
people who couldn't print.

481
00:29:40.925 --> 00:29:42.225
And then we break it down like that.

482
00:29:42.225 --> 00:29:46.296
And the reason we did was because as we
planned our IT budget and software we

483
00:29:46.296 --> 00:29:50.497
rolled out if we could eliminate
the primary source of support esque calls,

484
00:29:50.497 --> 00:29:53.780
then that would give our end
users a better experience, and

485
00:29:53.780 --> 00:29:55.903
it would save us money in the long run.

486
00:29:55.903 --> 00:29:58.816
And so password resets were always
one of our big ones, and so

487
00:29:58.816 --> 00:30:01.731
we started introducing software
in like little key tokens,

488
00:30:01.731 --> 00:30:04.418
where you didn't have to
remember a password anymore,

489
00:30:04.418 --> 00:30:08.150
it was generated by your token,
things like that to eliminate those calls.

490
00:30:08.150 --> 00:30:09.380
And the key thing for

491
00:30:09.380 --> 00:30:13.248
us was making sure we we're putting
our effort in the right place.

492
00:30:13.248 --> 00:30:18.040
Because you wanna improve your process
using your pareto chart for example,

493
00:30:18.040 --> 00:30:19.300
it had operator errors.

494
00:30:19.300 --> 00:30:21.053
There were only three instances.

495
00:30:21.053 --> 00:30:23.955
Well if I go and
resolve the operator errors, that's great.

496
00:30:23.955 --> 00:30:27.925
But that was just three instances,
poor design was 64 instances.

497
00:30:27.925 --> 00:30:29.086
>> [LAUGH].

498
00:30:29.086 --> 00:30:32.513
>> If I had focused on that I would have
had a much greater impact on improving

499
00:30:32.513 --> 00:30:33.196
the process.

500
00:30:33.196 --> 00:30:37.329
And so, that's a key thing, and pareto
charts are great about showing that.

501
00:30:37.329 --> 00:30:38.119
>> Exactly.

502
00:30:38.119 --> 00:30:42.646
And I think that also brings
a good point that we're doing.

503
00:30:42.646 --> 00:30:47.453
We're looking at what it would be
like to do an entire DMAIC report.

504
00:30:47.453 --> 00:30:50.703
Defining measure, analyzing,
improving, rolling it out.

505
00:30:50.703 --> 00:30:52.282
We're looking at that whole process.

506
00:30:52.282 --> 00:30:55.152
But there's so
many tools in Lean Six Sigma that you

507
00:30:55.152 --> 00:30:58.644
can use to just fix the problem
right then just with the tools.

508
00:30:58.644 --> 00:31:03.210
So there's a double reason for learning
about the methodology because sometimes

509
00:31:03.210 --> 00:31:07.311
things can be solved without going
through the whole recording process,

510
00:31:07.311 --> 00:31:08.910
just based on the tool.

511
00:31:08.910 --> 00:31:11.900
So we have two more charts to look at.

512
00:31:11.900 --> 00:31:13.900
The next one is our scatter diagram.

513
00:31:13.900 --> 00:31:16.390
And a Scatter Diagram in Lean Six Sigma,

514
00:31:16.390 --> 00:31:20.390
again, all of these tools can be used for
multiple purposes.

515
00:31:20.390 --> 00:31:27.084
And Lean Six Sigma usually, a scatter
diagram is used to look at correlation.

516
00:31:27.084 --> 00:31:32.339
And here's a, the types of correlation
would be two things that are related

517
00:31:32.339 --> 00:31:37.365
like typing errors, how that's
affected by backlog, accident rate.

518
00:31:37.365 --> 00:31:41.372
How it's affected by overtime,
machine break down.

519
00:31:41.372 --> 00:31:45.719
It can be something as simple as people
are late to work when it's raining,

520
00:31:45.719 --> 00:31:49.801
people order soup in the kitchen
when it's cold, that type of thing.

521
00:31:49.801 --> 00:31:52.072
When you do a scattered diagram,

522
00:31:52.072 --> 00:31:57.586
they're very simple to do in Excel anymore
because you just set up two columns and

523
00:31:57.586 --> 00:32:02.881
you highlight and press scattered
diagram and they're very, very simple.

524
00:32:02.881 --> 00:32:06.828
But the patterns that you are likely
to see, here's some examples.

525
00:32:06.828 --> 00:32:10.627
Now the first two are positive because
they are both working together and

526
00:32:10.627 --> 00:32:13.242
because the data points
are very tight together,

527
00:32:13.242 --> 00:32:15.745
that's stronger correlation
than the other.

528
00:32:15.745 --> 00:32:20.395
Now the bottom left diagram
is what I usually see.

529
00:32:20.395 --> 00:32:23.918
I get so
excited when I actually see correlation.

530
00:32:23.918 --> 00:32:27.544
But sometimes what happens is that you're
trying to implement a solution, and

531
00:32:27.544 --> 00:32:31.166
the person that you're working for is so
married to the fact that if you do this,

532
00:32:31.166 --> 00:32:32.811
this other thing's gonna happen.

533
00:32:32.811 --> 00:32:36.827
That sometimes being able to show hey,
there's no correlation between these two

534
00:32:36.827 --> 00:32:39.692
things helps you get a little
bit more More of that by-in.

535
00:32:39.692 --> 00:32:44.652
The last one, I think's kinda funny
because on my slide that you might not be

536
00:32:44.652 --> 00:32:49.223
able to see unless you stop the film,
is that it says that the j-shaped

537
00:32:49.223 --> 00:32:52.420
association suggests
a complex relationship.

538
00:32:52.420 --> 00:32:55.205
What it suggests to me is that maybe
I need to use a different chart.

539
00:32:55.205 --> 00:32:58.977
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now here's just some more scatter

540
00:32:58.977 --> 00:33:00.280
diagram patterns.

541
00:33:00.280 --> 00:33:02.280
Positive you can see that's going up.

542
00:33:02.280 --> 00:33:05.580
No correlation, which I said,
is what I usually see.

543
00:33:05.580 --> 00:33:08.202
Now remember, we get all this
information from measure and

544
00:33:08.202 --> 00:33:09.940
we're trying to see if it correlates.

545
00:33:09.940 --> 00:33:12.400
If If this condition happens,
does this other condition happen?

546
00:33:12.400 --> 00:33:16.453
Even though technically, that's
called causation, in Lean Six Sigma,

547
00:33:16.453 --> 00:33:20.199
we call it correlation but
it's really we're looking at triggers.

548
00:33:20.199 --> 00:33:22.804
And then of course
the negative correlation, and

549
00:33:22.804 --> 00:33:24.920
see where the dots are kind of far apart?

550
00:33:24.920 --> 00:33:29.790
That's not as tight, negative
correlation is the second example.

551
00:33:29.790 --> 00:33:34.150
Now, correlation a lot of times is
gonna be something really simple.

552
00:33:34.150 --> 00:33:38.994
For example, in the the diagram
that we're looking at right now,

553
00:33:38.994 --> 00:33:43.075
we're looking at water consumption and
temperature.

554
00:33:43.075 --> 00:33:46.359
You wanna think each one of these
data points is a population,

555
00:33:46.359 --> 00:33:50.152
this diagram would certainly suggest
that as the temperature went up,

556
00:33:50.152 --> 00:33:52.380
water consumption went higher, right?

557
00:33:52.380 --> 00:33:56.850
So that's a real good example
of positive correlation.

558
00:33:56.850 --> 00:34:00.590
Now, the last one we're gonna be
talking about is control charts.

559
00:34:00.590 --> 00:34:03.440
And I'm going to just kind of
quickly build up to control chart so

560
00:34:03.440 --> 00:34:05.390
that it makes sense.

561
00:34:05.390 --> 00:34:09.875
Now, the charts that could be used to
create a control chart can also be

562
00:34:09.875 --> 00:34:11.330
used independently.

563
00:34:11.330 --> 00:34:14.950
So for example, what you're looking
at right now is a line chart.

564
00:34:14.950 --> 00:34:18.639
And what's kind of fun about line charts
is that you don't really have to have

565
00:34:18.639 --> 00:34:19.730
a lot of information.

566
00:34:19.730 --> 00:34:24.370
You identify a condition that you wanna
track and you just start tracking it.

567
00:34:24.370 --> 00:34:26.680
Now even though we don't
have a lot of information

568
00:34:28.060 --> 00:34:32.290
on the first diagram on the left
where it says stock value.

569
00:34:32.290 --> 00:34:33.910
We're probably pretty happy, right?

570
00:34:33.910 --> 00:34:37.350
I mean, we don't have a whole lot of
information but our stock is going up.

571
00:34:37.350 --> 00:34:41.078
In the second diagram, however,
we're looking at mistakes and even

572
00:34:41.078 --> 00:34:45.200
again we don't have a lot of information,
but we know mistakes are going up.

573
00:34:45.200 --> 00:34:49.354
And the reason that we would use a line
chart is like I said, there's a condition

574
00:34:49.354 --> 00:34:52.960
that's kind of curious, and
we're just gonna track it for awhile.

575
00:34:52.960 --> 00:34:55.332
And just by collecting the information,

576
00:34:55.332 --> 00:34:58.460
it might say,
hey this is a condition I need to look at.

577
00:34:58.460 --> 00:35:02.117
Now a step up from a line chart and keep
in mind you can just use the line chart,

578
00:35:02.117 --> 00:35:04.370
you don't have to go to the next step.

579
00:35:04.370 --> 00:35:08.438
But if you were building up to a control
chart the next thing you might consider is

580
00:35:08.438 --> 00:35:10.030
something called a run chart.

581
00:35:10.030 --> 00:35:12.670
Now the difference
between the run chart and

582
00:35:12.670 --> 00:35:17.302
the line chart is that at some point in my
line chart I might decide that I want to

583
00:35:17.302 --> 00:35:19.598
get more information about the data.

584
00:35:19.598 --> 00:35:23.418
So my first step is that I
need to create a center line.

585
00:35:23.418 --> 00:35:27.252
On run charts that center line is
almost always a mean or an average or

586
00:35:27.252 --> 00:35:31.713
a mean average because we said those are
all the same, but it could be a median.

587
00:35:31.713 --> 00:35:36.486
A lot of you've probably seen like on CNN
and the Wall Street, a lot of times they

588
00:35:36.486 --> 00:35:40.560
say median car prices or median house
prices so it could be a median.

589
00:35:40.560 --> 00:35:42.400
It's usually a mean.

590
00:35:42.400 --> 00:35:47.771
And the way I get that mean,
is I take all the data points that

591
00:35:47.771 --> 00:35:53.800
I got from my line chart, and
I divide by the number of line charts.

592
00:35:53.800 --> 00:35:55.740
And that's how I get my center line.

593
00:35:55.740 --> 00:36:00.000
Then I go back and I plot each one
of these individual conditions.

594
00:36:00.000 --> 00:36:05.160
So as a quick example, let's say I
have 14 students that took a test.

595
00:36:05.160 --> 00:36:08.730
And we're gonna say that the y-axis,
which is on the side,

596
00:36:08.730 --> 00:36:10.980
represents the grades that they got.

597
00:36:10.980 --> 00:36:16.480
So I took all 14 students,
I added their scores together.

598
00:36:16.480 --> 00:36:20.420
I divided by 14, and
I came up with my center line.

599
00:36:20.420 --> 00:36:22.307
Now I'm going to go back and

600
00:36:22.307 --> 00:36:28.480
plot each individual of the 14 students to
see how far they are away from the middle.

601
00:36:28.480 --> 00:36:29.890
And a lot of you probably remember that.

602
00:36:29.890 --> 00:36:32.920
Your teachers in elementary
school would say,

603
00:36:32.920 --> 00:36:36.110
there was an average of
80 on the spelling test.

604
00:36:36.110 --> 00:36:40.910
And then you would know if you
were above or below the average.

605
00:36:40.910 --> 00:36:45.390
Now kind of the simple way to
understand standard deviation is

606
00:36:45.390 --> 00:36:47.580
looking at this chart.

607
00:36:47.580 --> 00:36:50.820
And again, this is something that you
would cover in a much more advanced class.

608
00:36:50.820 --> 00:36:55.795
But just kind of a quick understanding,
is if I wanted to get an average at

609
00:36:55.795 --> 00:36:59.304
the average of how far
people were from the middle,

610
00:36:59.304 --> 00:37:02.910
that's a kind of an example
of standard deviation.

611
00:37:02.910 --> 00:37:06.670
Now, we get to the big one and so
we're almost done with analyze.

612
00:37:06.670 --> 00:37:08.950
We get to the big one and
this is the control chart.

613
00:37:08.950 --> 00:37:11.790
Now, here's the thing
about the control chart.

614
00:37:11.790 --> 00:37:19.150
That middle line could be a mean or
a median but it could also be a mode.

615
00:37:19.150 --> 00:37:20.970
It could be a benchmark.

616
00:37:20.970 --> 00:37:25.830
It could be a customer expectation
that has no science behind it at all.

617
00:37:25.830 --> 00:37:29.560
So the middle line is still
what we're shooting for but

618
00:37:29.560 --> 00:37:32.410
it could be a number of different things.

619
00:37:32.410 --> 00:37:36.896
The other thing that's different on
this chart is that you'll notice that

620
00:37:36.896 --> 00:37:41.250
there's an upper and lower control limit,
so that's your UCL and LCL.

621
00:37:41.250 --> 00:37:45.210
Those lines could also be an upper and
lower tolerance.

622
00:37:45.210 --> 00:37:47.570
Or a limit or upper and
lower specification limit.

623
00:37:47.570 --> 00:37:51.110
And so
the idea is to stay within those lines.

624
00:37:51.110 --> 00:37:54.190
And I'm sure a lot of you
are familiar with the term, outlier.

625
00:37:54.190 --> 00:37:58.090
So, on 7.5, we have an outlier.

626
00:37:58.090 --> 00:38:01.536
The concept here is if it
goes outside the upper or

627
00:38:01.536 --> 00:38:06.170
lower control limit,
that's a condition that I need to look at.

628
00:38:06.170 --> 00:38:09.460
>> Yeah, and you'll find with a lot of
things that we've set, our control limit.

629
00:38:10.500 --> 00:38:14.322
And it's not that we have to
hit that control line exactly,

630
00:38:14.322 --> 00:38:18.920
that we'll actually be okay if we're
a little above or a little below.

631
00:38:18.920 --> 00:38:22.300
The example I use is like when you go
to the hardware store to buy paint.

632
00:38:22.300 --> 00:38:25.901
They just have buckets of white paint and
then they put a little color in there and

633
00:38:25.901 --> 00:38:28.560
shake it up for you and
then you get the color that you want.

634
00:38:28.560 --> 00:38:33.440
But when they shake it that paint
needs to be mixed to a certain level.

635
00:38:33.440 --> 00:38:37.400
So the dye is certain parts per million,
spread throughout the paint.

636
00:38:37.400 --> 00:38:41.740
And it doesn't have to be perfect for
the human eye to visually see it the same.

637
00:38:41.740 --> 00:38:45.640
And so, if you were to mix it for
3 minutes, versus mixing it for

638
00:38:45.640 --> 00:38:49.396
2 minutes and 50 seconds,
or 3 minutes and 10seconds,

639
00:38:49.396 --> 00:38:53.170
you'd probably get what is
appreciatively the same result.

640
00:38:53.170 --> 00:38:54.270
But they are different, right?

641
00:38:54.270 --> 00:38:56.280
One's more mixed than the other.

642
00:38:56.280 --> 00:39:00.080
As long as they're within those control
limits, we see that and it works out.

643
00:39:00.080 --> 00:39:02.500
But we need to establish what
those limits are, right?

644
00:39:02.500 --> 00:39:04.240
The upper and lower control limits.

645
00:39:04.240 --> 00:39:07.882
And sometimes you might be measuring
something that doesn't have a lower

646
00:39:07.882 --> 00:39:10.480
control, it just has an upper or
it just has a lower.

647
00:39:10.480 --> 00:39:12.480
It happens like that sometimes.

648
00:39:12.480 --> 00:39:14.069
With something that could completely fail,

649
00:39:14.069 --> 00:39:15.960
you wouldn't necessarily
have a lower limit there.

650
00:39:15.960 --> 00:39:18.197
>> Exactly.
>> But they're just things that have to be

651
00:39:18.197 --> 00:39:21.780
established so that we can recognize
when we're moving beyond that.

652
00:39:21.780 --> 00:39:25.170
>> And Don brings up a good
point about control charts.

653
00:39:25.170 --> 00:39:27.890
Most control charts, you're gonna see
an upper and lower control limit.

654
00:39:27.890 --> 00:39:31.170
But absolutely, sometimes you're not
gonna have a lower control limit.

655
00:39:31.170 --> 00:39:33.709
If you're tracking accidents
on the shop floor,

656
00:39:33.709 --> 00:39:37.160
you're not gonna say we have to
have a certain amount of accidents.

657
00:39:37.160 --> 00:39:41.283
And statistical packages that you
work with typically set the upper and

658
00:39:41.283 --> 00:39:43.420
lower control limit at three sigma.

659
00:39:43.420 --> 00:39:46.570
So just kind of a little trivia there.

660
00:39:46.570 --> 00:39:50.948
So, I'd like to wrap up by saying that the
reason why you might be using one of these

661
00:39:50.948 --> 00:39:54.450
charts or graphs, remember,
is because you have information.

662
00:39:54.450 --> 00:39:58.940
You have a ton of information for
measure on a particular topic.

663
00:39:58.940 --> 00:40:03.270
And it's easier to digest if
you put it in a chart of graph.

664
00:40:03.270 --> 00:40:06.990
A lot of charts and graphs are generated
from an Excel spreadsheet.

665
00:40:06.990 --> 00:40:11.000
So if I only had ten data points,
I can look at the data points.

666
00:40:11.000 --> 00:40:12.490
I'm not going to make a correlation chart.

667
00:40:12.490 --> 00:40:14.727
I'm not gonna make a control chart.

668
00:40:14.727 --> 00:40:19.460
Because I can look at the data on the
spreadsheet without putting it on a chart.

669
00:40:19.460 --> 00:40:20.900
So the purpose of charts and

670
00:40:20.900 --> 00:40:25.040
graphs are always just to digest the
information that I receive from measure.

671
00:40:25.040 --> 00:40:29.843
But even on a higher leve,l I'm just
trying to come to those three to five

672
00:40:29.843 --> 00:40:30.720
solutions.

673
00:40:30.720 --> 00:40:31.359
>> Awesome.
Well,

674
00:40:31.359 --> 00:40:34.400
I think that's a pretty good
rundown of the whole phase.

675
00:40:34.400 --> 00:40:36.980
We've seen a lot of different
ways to use our data.

676
00:40:36.980 --> 00:40:41.465
Just remember, you're collecting all of
your data and now you gotta analyze it.

677
00:40:41.465 --> 00:40:45.420
You gotta put it to work in its raw form,
a lot of the data's not terribly useful.

678
00:40:45.420 --> 00:40:48.000
We refine it,
we turn it into useful information, and

679
00:40:48.000 --> 00:40:50.590
then we're ready to start
doing something with it.

680
00:40:50.590 --> 00:40:52.850
So, that's gonna wrap
up our analyze phase.

681
00:40:52.850 --> 00:40:56.083
We do still have a little bit more
because now that we've analyzed,

682
00:40:56.083 --> 00:40:59.825
we need to figure out how we can improve
and that's gonna be our next phase, but

683
00:40:59.825 --> 00:41:01.490
we are out of time on this episode.

684
00:41:01.490 --> 00:41:04.729
So stay tuned.
We're gonna be moving into that phase next

685
00:41:04.729 --> 00:41:09.753
but for right now signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet And I'm Dr Stern.

686
00:41:09.753 --> 00:41:11.433
>> And we'll see you next time.

687
00:41:11.433 --> 00:41:17.780
[SOUND]

episodes.description: The Improvement Phase is a less flexible phase compared to the prior phases in the DMAIC process, where all steps must be followed. Steps include: listing 3-5 solutions generated from the Analyze Phase, gaining consensus on which solution to try, conducting a pilot to measure the scale of improvement, and then implement the solution as per plan. Viewers will also hear about tools like SWOT analysis as a way to organize your thoughts, time analysis, and FMEA Thinking to mistake proof your project plan.
episodes.title: Improvement Phase
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.955 --> 00:00:15.620
All right good morning,
good afternoon and And good evening.

3
00:00:15.620 --> 00:00:17.980
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:17.980 --> 00:00:22.520
I'm your host, Don Pezet, back again
with another episode of Lean Six Sigma.

5
00:00:22.520 --> 00:00:25.760
And if you've been following along,
you know we've been slowly working our way

6
00:00:25.760 --> 00:00:29.790
through the model and
we've kind of reached the improved phase.

7
00:00:29.790 --> 00:00:32.170
Which is where we actually do
the stuff that we get paid for

8
00:00:32.170 --> 00:00:33.430
and improve a process.

9
00:00:33.430 --> 00:00:35.460
It's kinda the whole point
of this Six Sigma thing.

10
00:00:35.460 --> 00:00:38.240
So, that's what we're gonna
be diving into today.

11
00:00:38.240 --> 00:00:41.370
And back in the studios again Again
we've got Doctor Stern here to help us.

12
00:00:41.370 --> 00:00:43.120
And walk us through the improve phase.

13
00:00:43.120 --> 00:00:45.110
>> Thank you for having me.

14
00:00:45.110 --> 00:00:52.050
>> All right so basically we've defined
our issue, you know, what our problem is.

15
00:00:52.050 --> 00:00:53.790
We've measured it.

16
00:00:53.790 --> 00:00:55.490
We've analyzed our data.

17
00:00:55.490 --> 00:00:59.080
And now we're ready to actually
do something about it, right?

18
00:00:59.080 --> 00:01:03.000
The improve phase is where we
actually get to work, right?

19
00:01:03.000 --> 00:01:04.820
>> Exactly.
And I mentioned this Former episode I'd

20
00:01:04.820 --> 00:01:07.180
like to explain that define, measure, and

21
00:01:07.180 --> 00:01:11.560
analyze are very very creative processes
and so you have a lot of flexibility,

22
00:01:11.560 --> 00:01:14.680
there's only a couple of rules
in this first three phases.

23
00:01:14.680 --> 00:01:20.068
When you get to improve you have
to follow a specific map, and

24
00:01:20.068 --> 00:01:27.760
what that does is makes it incredibly
easy to explain and teach to you.

25
00:01:27.760 --> 00:01:32.390
It's not so easy to do But
because there's not a lot of deviation,

26
00:01:32.390 --> 00:01:36.060
there's not a lot of extra things that you
can do, it's almost like a check sheet.

27
00:01:36.060 --> 00:01:39.450
And in improve, one of the challenges,
and I have a slide about

28
00:01:39.450 --> 00:01:44.130
the major things that you're gonna do
in improve, one of the challenges is

29
00:01:44.130 --> 00:01:48.770
to remember this is where you're going
to be spending most of your actual time.

30
00:01:48.770 --> 00:01:54.230
So, earlier we said if you don't have
a lot of time, spend it in define, right?

31
00:01:54.230 --> 00:01:57.230
But the actual physical
work doesn't really happen

32
00:01:57.230 --> 00:01:58.520
until the bottom part of Improve.

33
00:01:58.520 --> 00:02:00.600
And so if you're working
through the demake model,

34
00:02:00.600 --> 00:02:03.950
you don't wanna spend too much
time in measure and analyze.

35
00:02:03.950 --> 00:02:07.160
You wanna be very careful on
that you're not measuring and

36
00:02:07.160 --> 00:02:10.370
analyzing too many things, and not having
enough time to actually do your project.

37
00:02:10.370 --> 00:02:14.860
So, when you enter the improve phase,
and i'm gonna go through it quickly and

38
00:02:14.860 --> 00:02:18.100
then go back and
talk a little bit more in depth.

39
00:02:18.100 --> 00:02:21.310
When you Enter the improve phase the very

40
00:02:21.310 --> 00:02:24.840
first thing you do is you list
your three to five solutions.

41
00:02:24.840 --> 00:02:28.470
Now, this is the easiest part of
improve because you got your solutions

42
00:02:28.470 --> 00:02:30.840
from the bottom part of analyze.

43
00:02:30.840 --> 00:02:36.270
So, I would not have left analyze
without my three to five solutions.

44
00:02:36.270 --> 00:02:40.360
The next thing is that I have to gain
some consensus on which solution to try.

45
00:02:40.360 --> 00:02:48.610
And then once I do that I want to pilot My
idea I want to make sure that it works.

46
00:02:48.610 --> 00:02:52.800
And then I'm going to start creating
my project plan using my WBS method.

47
00:02:52.800 --> 00:02:55.580
My work breakdown structure method.

48
00:02:55.580 --> 00:02:57.880
Now, something to keep in mind,

49
00:02:57.880 --> 00:03:03.200
is until you get to that fourth bullet
point create project plan using your

50
00:03:03.200 --> 00:03:07.950
WBS you really haven't done anything that
you could get in too much trouble for.

51
00:03:07.950 --> 00:03:09.230
Once you make your project Plan.

52
00:03:09.230 --> 00:03:11.300
The execution starts
going into full force.

53
00:03:11.300 --> 00:03:13.610
And when you come up with the baseline.

54
00:03:13.610 --> 00:03:18.070
And I'll remind you from a former
episode that a baseline is how

55
00:03:18.070 --> 00:03:20.140
long is this project going to take?

56
00:03:20.140 --> 00:03:22.350
And how much is it going to cost?

57
00:03:22.350 --> 00:03:24.240
Well.
Once I come up with my project baseline.

58
00:03:24.240 --> 00:03:26.320
And baseline is one of
those interesting words.

59
00:03:26.320 --> 00:03:30.220
Cuz it would mean something different
in some of the other phases.

60
00:03:30.220 --> 00:03:34.750
But on a project plan once I come
up with my time and my cost.

61
00:03:34.750 --> 00:03:37.420
That's what I'm going to be judged on for
the rest of the project.

62
00:03:37.420 --> 00:03:41.360
Sometimes this becomes very challenging
when you're just doing a regular project

63
00:03:41.360 --> 00:03:45.910
because you not have spent enough
time thinking about your baseline.

64
00:03:45.910 --> 00:03:49.330
If you're a little below the baseline
everyone's pretty happy.

65
00:03:49.330 --> 00:03:52.160
Certainly if you're on baseline,
they're great.

66
00:03:52.160 --> 00:03:55.340
But if you're a little above baseline,
people start getting panicky and

67
00:03:55.340 --> 00:04:00.140
if you're way above baseline you
might not have The job the next day.

68
00:04:00.140 --> 00:04:03.380
But if you're way below baseline,
there's also a problem with that,

69
00:04:03.380 --> 00:04:07.600
because sometimes people think
you were a poor project planner,

70
00:04:07.600 --> 00:04:12.350
or maybe they didn't get everything
that they were supposed to get.

71
00:04:12.350 --> 00:04:16.540
Now, the advantage of using
the DMAIC model is that when

72
00:04:16.540 --> 00:04:20.720
you get to this part where you're
building your project plan and

73
00:04:20.720 --> 00:04:24.070
you're creating your baseline,
you have so much information that you're,

74
00:04:24.070 --> 00:04:28.140
You're gonna be pretty close
to your baseline, right.

75
00:04:28.140 --> 00:04:32.140
So, now the next thing that happens
is I actually execute the plan, so

76
00:04:32.140 --> 00:04:36.390
quite a lot of things are happening
in the improve phase of this model.

77
00:04:36.390 --> 00:04:40.500
So, I'm actually gonna implement and
roll out the plan.

78
00:04:40.500 --> 00:04:43.830
Now, I stay in improve until
an improvement is made.

79
00:04:43.830 --> 00:04:47.620
The way I know an improvement
is made is that I take the after

80
00:04:47.620 --> 00:04:52.350
picture that I've created Created by
improvement and I look back at my picture

81
00:04:52.350 --> 00:04:57.200
that I created in measure and I compare
my after picture to my before picture.

82
00:04:57.200 --> 00:05:00.750
Now, I'm not really dead, and
I know this isn't proper english, but

83
00:05:00.750 --> 00:05:03.760
after I roll this out and
I notice and improvement or

84
00:05:03.760 --> 00:05:08.870
I'm starting towards improvement, me and
my project plan can move over to control.

85
00:05:08.870 --> 00:05:11.990
Now, there's still tons of things
I'm gonna do in control to close

86
00:05:11.990 --> 00:05:12.660
out my project.

87
00:05:12.660 --> 00:05:13.577
My project isn't over.

88
00:05:13.577 --> 00:05:16.170
But I get to,
[INAUDIBLE] Even prove when I can

89
00:05:16.170 --> 00:05:18.680
honestly say an improvement's been made.

90
00:05:18.680 --> 00:05:23.610
So, if I use, balance scorecard,
and I assigned a, and

91
00:05:23.610 --> 00:05:29.510
I looked at certain conditions, and
maybe I assigned myself a grade.

92
00:05:29.510 --> 00:05:33.700
It's usually articulated in a number, but
let's say I assign that the way I handle

93
00:05:33.700 --> 00:05:39.670
customer complaints on a scale from one
to five, let's say I gave myself a three.

94
00:05:39.670 --> 00:05:43.410
After I rolled out my process improvement
solution I'm going to give myself a four.

95
00:05:43.410 --> 00:05:48.140
Well, that would indicate that I did make
some sort of process improvement and

96
00:05:48.140 --> 00:05:50.990
that would allow me to go over in control.

97
00:05:50.990 --> 00:05:56.660
So, now I want to go back and we're
going to talk about a couple of tools.

98
00:05:56.660 --> 00:05:58.750
I list my three to five solutions.

99
00:05:58.750 --> 00:06:01.270
One of the things that I want to be aware

100
00:06:01.270 --> 00:06:05.020
of is that my boss is probably going
to say which one would you choose.

101
00:06:05.020 --> 00:06:06.910
Now, I want them to pick a solution.

102
00:06:06.910 --> 00:06:09.340
And why do I want them to pick one?

103
00:06:09.340 --> 00:06:11.623
>> Accountability?

104
00:06:11.623 --> 00:06:12.279
>> Yeah.

105
00:06:12.279 --> 00:06:14.450
>> [LAUGH]
>> Accountability.

106
00:06:14.450 --> 00:06:15.410
I want their buy-in.

107
00:06:15.410 --> 00:06:19.690
I want to make sure they've got some They
have some confidence in that solution.

108
00:06:19.690 --> 00:06:21.420
And this gets really challenging.

109
00:06:21.420 --> 00:06:24.630
After you've had a couple of really
successful projects people will start

110
00:06:24.630 --> 00:06:26.530
saying, well,
you picked the one that you like best.

111
00:06:26.530 --> 00:06:31.140
Now, the other thing that
makes this a little bit

112
00:06:31.140 --> 00:06:34.260
difficult is that sometimes they're
not going to agree with you and

113
00:06:34.260 --> 00:06:38.170
they're not going to pick the solution but
they are going to ask you.

114
00:06:38.170 --> 00:06:40.800
And so
we're going to look at a couple of tools

115
00:06:40.800 --> 00:06:44.490
that we can use if we don't have a good
idea why we picked one over the other.

116
00:06:44.490 --> 00:06:46.100
It doesn't really do good for

117
00:06:46.100 --> 00:06:49.100
your credibility if you say well all
three of these or all five of these.

118
00:06:49.100 --> 00:06:49.730
I like all of them.
Now,

119
00:06:49.730 --> 00:06:54.410
sometimes you're automatically going to
know which one to say that you like best,

120
00:06:54.410 --> 00:06:58.180
even though they might not pick this
Because when you were in analog,

121
00:06:58.180 --> 00:07:03.160
you looked at some things.

122
00:07:03.160 --> 00:07:08.540
Like, perhaps you found out in define or
in measure

123
00:07:08.540 --> 00:07:13.350
that they wanted to do anything as long
as it didn't mean hiring an extra person.

124
00:07:13.350 --> 00:07:14.600
So, you already know that, right.

125
00:07:14.600 --> 00:07:17.060
So, you might say something
about your solution.

126
00:07:17.060 --> 00:07:19.960
Well, I pick solution one because
we had existing resources.

127
00:07:19.960 --> 00:07:21.330
You might have found out something.

128
00:07:21.330 --> 00:07:25.570
Being about the budget when you were
defining and measuring and analyzing, and

129
00:07:25.570 --> 00:07:26.570
you might use that.

130
00:07:26.570 --> 00:07:28.180
They might have told you something like,

131
00:07:28.180 --> 00:07:30.000
we're not gonna do any
solutions unless they're green,

132
00:07:30.000 --> 00:07:34.670
unless they're environmental friendly,
so you might be able to use that.

133
00:07:34.670 --> 00:07:35.800
You might be able to say,

134
00:07:35.800 --> 00:07:41.270
I pick solution number one because it's
the most environmentally friendly.

135
00:07:41.270 --> 00:07:43.280
But in some cases you're at a loss, so

136
00:07:43.280 --> 00:07:47.390
we're gonna talk a little bit, we'll look
at a tool that you're Probably already

137
00:07:47.390 --> 00:07:50.880
familiar with to kinda help
us reason through which one.

138
00:07:50.880 --> 00:07:53.210
So I list my three to five solutions, and

139
00:07:53.210 --> 00:07:57.720
I'm gonna probably be ready to answer
that question, which one would I pick.

140
00:07:57.720 --> 00:07:59.850
And I'm gonna gain consensus.

141
00:07:59.850 --> 00:08:03.610
Now, this is really simple if
I'm only working for one person.

142
00:08:03.610 --> 00:08:05.170
I send them an email.

143
00:08:05.170 --> 00:08:07.160
They send me an email back.

144
00:08:07.160 --> 00:08:10.290
But it can also be a very complicated
process if you're talking to

145
00:08:10.290 --> 00:08:11.120
a steering committee.

146
00:08:11.120 --> 00:08:14.920
Or that's really ultimately deciding
which direction you're gonna go.

147
00:08:14.920 --> 00:08:16.850
Any kind of evaluation panel,

148
00:08:16.850 --> 00:08:22.360
sometimes there could be compliance
issues involved, and other people.

149
00:08:22.360 --> 00:08:27.250
And so
you might have to go about developing, or

150
00:08:27.250 --> 00:08:30.860
using, I should say,
some consensus gathering tools.

151
00:08:30.860 --> 00:08:35.620
So, if you have a lot of solutions,
let's say you have five solutions,

152
00:08:35.620 --> 00:08:38.030
cuz you're You're shooting for
three to five.

153
00:08:38.030 --> 00:08:39.920
Let's say you have five solutions and

154
00:08:39.920 --> 00:08:44.560
you have ten people in the room that
are trying to make this decision.

155
00:08:44.560 --> 00:08:47.290
You might go about listing
all five solutions and

156
00:08:47.290 --> 00:08:51.230
telling the people in the room
everyone can choose three.

157
00:08:51.230 --> 00:08:54.030
And then maybe one or
two will just naturally fall off, right,

158
00:08:54.030 --> 00:08:57.730
and then you could narrow it down and
say pick two then pick one.

159
00:08:57.730 --> 00:09:00.150
So, that's an example of
a consensus gathering tool.

160
00:09:00.150 --> 00:09:06.240
And there's an Number of consensus
gathering tools that you could use.

161
00:09:06.240 --> 00:09:10.770
And some of those are part of the Lean
Six Sigma kind of philosophy or body of

162
00:09:10.770 --> 00:09:16.640
knowledge, and some of them are just
ones that you can find on the Internet.

163
00:09:16.640 --> 00:09:19.190
So, once you gain consensus,
it gets kind of tricky,

164
00:09:19.190 --> 00:09:22.340
because Lean Six Sigma says
you have to do a pilot.

165
00:09:22.340 --> 00:09:26.090
And a formal pilot, sometimes it's
hard to get buy in on a formal pilot

166
00:09:26.090 --> 00:09:27.490
Because people just want
you to get it done.

167
00:09:27.490 --> 00:09:30.630
Or you don't have the money
to do a formal pilot.

168
00:09:30.630 --> 00:09:35.169
So, what you want to think about
is what is the idea of a pilot?

169
00:09:35.169 --> 00:09:38.072
Why do you do a pilot in the first place?

170
00:09:38.072 --> 00:09:40.347
Don, why would you do
a pilot in the first place?

171
00:09:40.347 --> 00:09:42.905
>> Sometimes you're unsure of whether
the solution is actually going to

172
00:09:42.905 --> 00:09:45.503
improve anything, and so you don't
want to roll it out wide-scale and

173
00:09:45.503 --> 00:09:46.560
affect all of your systems.

174
00:09:46.560 --> 00:09:51.120
You might want to do it on a small scale
so you can measure the improvement.

175
00:09:51.120 --> 00:09:55.110
Determine whether your plan is
actually coming to fruition.

176
00:09:55.110 --> 00:10:00.060
If you have ten automotive factories,
you might retrofit just

177
00:10:00.060 --> 00:10:05.290
one of those factories as a test and that
way if it doesn't work you're exposure or

178
00:10:05.290 --> 00:10:09.090
your impact is a lot smaller,
your wasted effort.

179
00:10:09.090 --> 00:10:12.400
If you succeed, well you just
roll it out to the other nine.

180
00:10:12.400 --> 00:10:14.820
It helps minimize that
risk of implementation.

181
00:10:14.820 --> 00:10:19.220
>> Exactly, and in a perfect world they'd
just let us do a pilot, but sometimes, as

182
00:10:19.220 --> 00:10:22.800
