00:23:32.411 --> 00:23:34.989
Because those are the things
I'm really stuck with, right?

396
00:23:34.989 --> 00:23:39.566
In the next box,
where it says Important Not Urgent,

397
00:23:39.566 --> 00:23:43.445
that's the list of stuff
I'd like to get to.

398
00:23:43.445 --> 00:23:45.941
In a perfect world that
everything goes okay,

399
00:23:45.941 --> 00:23:48.379
that's the types of
things that I want to do.

400
00:23:48.379 --> 00:23:52.795
Now, Urgent Not Important and that means
Urgent Not Important for that day.

401
00:23:52.795 --> 00:23:54.663
So it could be really
urgent to someone else.

402
00:23:54.663 --> 00:23:56.545
Someone else might want my time.

403
00:23:56.545 --> 00:24:00.088
Someone else needs me
to fill out a form but

404
00:24:00.088 --> 00:24:04.652
it's really not Urgent Important to me for
that day.

405
00:24:04.652 --> 00:24:06.552
It could be tomorrow but not that day.

406
00:24:06.552 --> 00:24:08.758
So that's what I'm gonna
put in that category.

407
00:24:08.758 --> 00:24:13.637
And the Not Important/Not Urgent just
means if I don't, I might have to do

408
00:24:13.637 --> 00:24:18.225
it tomorrow but if I don't get to
it even tomorrow maybe that's okay.

409
00:24:18.225 --> 00:24:24.015
Now in this particular model
in personal time management,

410
00:24:24.015 --> 00:24:28.395
how that helps us like I said is if we
wake up and we're just kinda overwhelmed.

411
00:24:28.395 --> 00:24:31.049
We can do it on a week or monthly model or

412
00:24:31.049 --> 00:24:36.645
an annual model but
when we feel like we run out of

413
00:24:36.645 --> 00:24:41.705
time a lot of time it's because we don't
get to the important not urgent things.

414
00:24:41.705 --> 00:24:42.920
We get to the end of the day and

415
00:24:42.920 --> 00:24:45.415
it's like I didn't really get
to do anything for myself.

416
00:24:45.415 --> 00:24:49.213
Covey points out in his original
model that we have a tendency to go

417
00:24:49.213 --> 00:24:52.874
from urgent important right over
to urgent not important and so

418
00:24:52.874 --> 00:24:56.347
we're all of a sudden doing
things that don't even count.

419
00:24:56.347 --> 00:24:59.186
Where what we should be doing
is urgent important and

420
00:24:59.186 --> 00:25:03.006
then moving to important not urgent so
that's kind of the structure.

421
00:25:03.006 --> 00:25:06.885
Now, let's say I'm building my project
plan, I already know I'm gonna use

422
00:25:06.885 --> 00:25:10.479
work breakdown structure because
that's a good way to mistake proof.

423
00:25:10.479 --> 00:25:14.877
But if I'm trying to get a handle on
things that are dependent on other things,

424
00:25:14.877 --> 00:25:19.335
things that absolutely have to happen
in this project, I can use this model.

425
00:25:19.335 --> 00:25:23.425
I can say you know what, these are the key
things that have to happen in the project

426
00:25:23.425 --> 00:25:25.405
and I'm gonna put those
under urgent important.

427
00:25:25.405 --> 00:25:29.614
And then here's some things
that are important, not urgent.

428
00:25:29.614 --> 00:25:33.165
And that would be sort of my wish list,
right?

429
00:25:33.165 --> 00:25:36.545
And then I would move to the things
that are urgent, not important.

430
00:25:36.545 --> 00:25:39.995
And those are the things that other people
are telling me need to be done, right?

431
00:25:39.995 --> 00:25:43.925
And I'd like to get to them, but
they're not gonna be my first choice.

432
00:25:43.925 --> 00:25:45.165
They're things that people would,

433
00:25:45.165 --> 00:25:48.745
it's things like when people want
me go a little out of scope or

434
00:25:48.745 --> 00:25:52.685
they're wanting me to come and
do something for their project.

435
00:25:52.685 --> 00:25:56.298
It's stuff I might really feel
committed to but they're not,

436
00:25:56.298 --> 00:26:00.950
they're urgent but not important to
the project that I'm working on right now.

437
00:26:00.950 --> 00:26:04.249
And then of course the not important,
not urgent,

438
00:26:04.249 --> 00:26:09.234
are just things that I want you to kinda
think of those as, if I get to them there

439
00:26:09.234 --> 00:26:13.555
are ancillary benefits but,
if I don't get to them that's okay.

440
00:26:13.555 --> 00:26:15.415
Now, the stuff that ends
up in the not important,

441
00:26:15.415 --> 00:26:18.615
not urgent could be delighters and
Lean Six Sigma

442
00:26:18.615 --> 00:26:23.035
likes to do things a little bit more than
what the boss or the client asked for.

443
00:26:23.035 --> 00:26:26.255
So, in a regular project
we try to stay in scope,

444
00:26:26.255 --> 00:26:31.060
cuz if we go outside scope it's going
to cost us more time and more money.

445
00:26:31.060 --> 00:26:34.798
In the Lean Six Sigma world,
we try to give a few delighters.

446
00:26:34.798 --> 00:26:36.585
So, kinda think of that
as your delighters box.

447
00:26:36.585 --> 00:26:39.311
If you can do them, that'd be really
great, but not to worry about them.

448
00:26:39.311 --> 00:26:43.575
And then, I organize my project
around there to make sure that my

449
00:26:43.575 --> 00:26:47.075
Urgent Important things to get done,
and the things that I really

450
00:26:47.075 --> 00:26:50.675
want to get done get done next,
and then I don't get sidetracked.

451
00:26:50.675 --> 00:26:53.145
So, it's just a great way
to mistake proof a project,

452
00:26:53.145 --> 00:26:54.975
it's also a great way to manage your time.

453
00:26:58.957 --> 00:27:01.675
And I'd like to say again,
these templates, and

454
00:27:01.675 --> 00:27:05.431
you'll notice the templates are very
lean because all of the stuff in

455
00:27:05.431 --> 00:27:08.640
Lean Six Sigma was meant to be paper and
pencil tools.

456
00:27:08.640 --> 00:27:11.515
But a set of these templates
are in your sample file just so

457
00:27:11.515 --> 00:27:12.427
that you have something.

458
00:27:12.427 --> 00:27:15.931
Eventually you'll get to the point
where you don't need the template and

459
00:27:15.931 --> 00:27:17.355
that's even really better.

460
00:27:17.355 --> 00:27:23.035
So I have one more collateral that I would
like to talk about as far as mistake

461
00:27:23.035 --> 00:27:28.465
proofing your project plan and
then we'll be wrapping up the improve.

462
00:27:28.465 --> 00:27:32.641
Because like I said, there's not a lot I
can teach you in improve because it's just

463
00:27:32.641 --> 00:27:34.505
a map of how to do things.

464
00:27:34.505 --> 00:27:39.259
So I'd like to explain
FMEA thinking quickly.

465
00:27:39.259 --> 00:27:42.906
The idea is that I look at
each task individually, and

466
00:27:42.906 --> 00:27:46.393
then I try to figure out
the potential failure, and

467
00:27:46.393 --> 00:27:51.280
the potential cause of the failure,
and the current process control.

468
00:27:51.280 --> 00:27:55.375
And that means, what do I have in place
now to make sure that that doesn't happen?

469
00:27:56.515 --> 00:28:01.160
Now, FMEA thinking is sort of
the inside of an FMEA form.

470
00:28:01.160 --> 00:28:04.341
And FMEA forms are often
used in the control phase.

471
00:28:04.341 --> 00:28:08.160
The thinking is sort of
the psychology behind the form, right?

472
00:28:08.160 --> 00:28:13.275
And so
a form has all kinds of functions on it.

473
00:28:13.275 --> 00:28:16.852
When you're doing FMEA thinking, you're
trying to take each thing at one time.

474
00:28:16.852 --> 00:28:20.927
So for example the function is,
and sometimes it's called task,

475
00:28:20.927 --> 00:28:23.625
you can use a word that feels good to you.

476
00:28:23.625 --> 00:28:26.355
The function is nurses wash their hands.

477
00:28:26.355 --> 00:28:26.995
Now, for

478
00:28:26.995 --> 00:28:31.145
some reason, the hardest part of this
whole thing is to remember to flip it.

479
00:28:31.145 --> 00:28:35.365
So the potential failure is nurses
don't wash their hands, right.

480
00:28:35.365 --> 00:28:39.345
The potential effect of the failure
could be nosocomial infection, and

481
00:28:39.345 --> 00:28:42.525
that's the infection you get
when you go into a hospital, and

482
00:28:42.525 --> 00:28:47.265
you didn't have that infection, but
you were in the hospital, okay.

483
00:28:47.265 --> 00:28:49.955
And there's a lot of studies that
say the number one reason for

484
00:28:49.955 --> 00:28:52.635
nosocomial infection is, guess what?

485
00:28:52.635 --> 00:28:53.604
Nurses don't wash their hands.

486
00:28:53.604 --> 00:28:58.542
Now, the potential cause of the failure,
not enough hand-washing stations, okay?

487
00:28:58.542 --> 00:29:02.945
And in this case, if you've been into
a modern hospital then you know that there

488
00:29:02.945 --> 00:29:05.851
are hand-washing stations every three or
so feet.

489
00:29:05.851 --> 00:29:06.710
Right?

490
00:29:06.710 --> 00:29:09.852
Well, now when you're
looking at this model,

491
00:29:09.852 --> 00:29:12.925
notice I put a couple of
extra things on there.

492
00:29:12.925 --> 00:29:16.865
It's just column one and
two that can be singular.

493
00:29:16.865 --> 00:29:21.073
So I've got the task and the opposite of
task since the other three columns work

494
00:29:21.073 --> 00:29:23.127
off the opposite of the task, right?

495
00:29:23.127 --> 00:29:26.870
But the potential effect of the failure,
cause of the failure, and

496
00:29:26.870 --> 00:29:29.705
current process control can be multiple,
right?

497
00:29:29.705 --> 00:29:33.365
If I were using this FMEA
thinking process in define,

498
00:29:33.365 --> 00:29:38.545
and let's say identified a function and
the potential failure.

499
00:29:38.545 --> 00:29:41.575
And the effect and
the cause of the failure,

500
00:29:41.575 --> 00:29:43.725
and there was nothing in that
process improvement box,

501
00:29:43.725 --> 00:29:47.255
guess what, that's an automatic
opportunity to do a process improvement.

502
00:29:47.255 --> 00:29:49.935
But sometimes,
there's not enough stuff in that box.

503
00:29:49.935 --> 00:29:55.875
When you consider that a person could die,
you can just have an infected finger,

504
00:29:55.875 --> 00:30:00.435
but you could also die from a nosocomial
infection, that's pretty severe, right?

505
00:30:00.435 --> 00:30:05.155
And maybe the control I have,
hand washing stations, isn't enough.

506
00:30:05.155 --> 00:30:09.165
Maybe I need to put some other
controls in place, right,

507
00:30:09.165 --> 00:30:11.075
based on the potential failure.

508
00:30:11.075 --> 00:30:13.152
Okay, so you can use this even in measure,

509
00:30:13.152 --> 00:30:16.000
because you could say how well
is the control working now?

510
00:30:16.000 --> 00:30:19.634
I'm sure a lot of you have been in
situations where there's a control in

511
00:30:19.634 --> 00:30:24.135
place, like this is what's gonna
be in place, so it doesn't happen.

512
00:30:24.135 --> 00:30:25.835
But nobody's paying
attention to that control.

513
00:30:25.835 --> 00:30:26.875
So it could also be used there.

514
00:30:26.875 --> 00:30:31.735
But what I'd like to wrap up with,
is that if you're doing a project plan,

515
00:30:31.735 --> 00:30:36.745
because remember this is the first time
you have accountability in the model.

516
00:30:36.745 --> 00:30:39.777
Up to this point, you're just talking and
drawing pretty pictures and thinking and

517
00:30:39.777 --> 00:30:40.597
reasoning out stuff.

518
00:30:40.597 --> 00:30:45.243
I do my project plan and another
method I could use to mistake proof my

519
00:30:45.243 --> 00:30:49.644
project plan to move forward is I
could look at the key things that

520
00:30:49.644 --> 00:30:54.655
must happen on my project plan and
run them very quickly through an FMEA.

521
00:30:54.655 --> 00:30:58.325
And if there isn't a control in
place to make sure that happens,

522
00:30:58.325 --> 00:31:00.075
make sure that I build that into my plan.

523
00:31:01.155 --> 00:31:04.155
>> And just a quick question,
I apologize if you said this, but

524
00:31:04.155 --> 00:31:06.725
I don't think I caught
what FMEA stood for.

525
00:31:06.725 --> 00:31:10.095
>> Oh yeah,
it's Failure Mode Effect Analysis.

526
00:31:10.095 --> 00:31:14.915
And most people don't really
remember that, and there are forms.

527
00:31:14.915 --> 00:31:17.025
We'll look at a form in the control model.

528
00:31:17.025 --> 00:31:20.415
Sometimes, you'll see
forms that say P-FMEA,

529
00:31:20.415 --> 00:31:23.485
which is a process failure
mode effect analysis.

530
00:31:23.485 --> 00:31:26.625
Or you might see E-FMEA,
which is equipment.

531
00:31:26.625 --> 00:31:30.668
And then every now and
then you'll see FMECA,

532
00:31:30.668 --> 00:31:35.644
which includes a criticality
column that says, again,

533
00:31:35.644 --> 00:31:41.674
on a scale from one to ten how bad is
this if this really happens or not?

534
00:31:41.674 --> 00:31:42.535
>> That's a good point.

535
00:31:43.565 --> 00:31:46.670
I mean you gotta know the impact,
because you have a possible failure,

536
00:31:46.670 --> 00:31:49.049
you have an effect that's
gonna come as a result of it,

537
00:31:49.049 --> 00:31:52.102
if it's not a terribly critical effect,
we might not worry about it,

538
00:31:52.102 --> 00:31:54.624
versus if it is critical,
then we do need to deal with it.

539
00:31:54.624 --> 00:31:56.250
>> Exactly.

540
00:31:56.250 --> 00:32:00.729
>> Excellent, well, you know, we got
a chance to see quite a bit in here,

541
00:32:00.729 --> 00:32:04.163
we got to see SWOT,
we saw time analysis, we saw FMEA,

542
00:32:04.163 --> 00:32:06.551
so a lot of good things there as we go and

543
00:32:06.551 --> 00:32:11.665
we implement whatever our solution happens
to be to try and improve our process.

544
00:32:11.665 --> 00:32:14.052
Is there anywhere else we need to
go on the improvement phase, or

545
00:32:14.052 --> 00:32:14.948
is that pretty much it?

546
00:32:14.948 --> 00:32:16.876
>> I think that's pretty much it, and

547
00:32:16.876 --> 00:32:20.860
the only thing we have to keep in mind
is if you were doing the DMAIC report,

548
00:32:20.860 --> 00:32:24.996
you're doing a full blown report,
you literally have to follow each step.

549
00:32:24.996 --> 00:32:28.864
There's lots of flexibility in
the other phases, but in order for it

550
00:32:28.864 --> 00:32:33.695
to be a legitimate Lean Six Sigma report,
you really have to follow those steps.

551
00:32:33.695 --> 00:32:36.215
>> All right, well we do still
have one more phase to get

552
00:32:36.215 --> 00:32:38.845
through in the DMAIC model,
the control phase.

553
00:32:38.845 --> 00:32:42.175
So we're going to tackle that one next,
but we're out of time for this episode.

554
00:32:42.175 --> 00:32:44.162
So we'll wrap this one up right here.

555
00:32:44.162 --> 00:32:47.155
Definitely stay tuned as we wrap up
the model and move in to some of the other

556
00:32:47.155 --> 00:32:49.925
remaining topics before we wrap up
our whole yellow belt training.

557
00:32:49.925 --> 00:32:51.307
So all coming down the line.

558
00:32:51.307 --> 00:32:52.561
We definitely hope to see you then.

559
00:32:52.561 --> 00:32:56.043
But for now, signing off for
IT Pro TV I'm Don Pisette.

560
00:32:56.043 --> 00:32:57.285
>> And I'm Doctor Stern.

561
00:32:57.285 --> 00:32:58.922
>> And we'll see you next time.

562
00:32:58.922 --> 00:33:06.330
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: The moment one notices they made an improvement is when they should move over to the Control Phase, the final phase in the DMAIC model. First one must articulate the benefit and why a client should care about it. Viewers will hear discussions on how to close a project as well as key tools in this phase, which include return on investment formulas or cost savings calculations, Sigma calculations, FMEA forms, and others.
episodes.title: Control Phase
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:00.815
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:00.815 --> 00:00:06.130
Alright, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:06.130 --> 00:00:10.320
Welcome back to another
episode of ITPro TV.

4
00:00:10.320 --> 00:00:16.860
I'm you host Don Pizzette, back again
with another episode of Lean Six Sigma,

5
00:00:16.860 --> 00:00:24.010
and this episode we're
gonna be winding down,

6
00:00:25.130 --> 00:00:30.000
the domaic model as we get to that
final phase, the control phase.

7
00:00:30.000 --> 00:00:32.620
We've gone through our define, and
measure, our analyze, our improve.

8
00:00:32.620 --> 00:00:35.840
And now, we're ready to kinda
wind this whole thing down, and

9
00:00:35.840 --> 00:00:37.070
see where we go from there.

10
00:00:37.070 --> 00:00:39.660
And so, back on the show with us
we've got Doctor Stern here, and

11
00:00:39.660 --> 00:00:42.730
she's gonna help us kinda see, what's
necessary as a part of that control phase,

12
00:00:42.730 --> 00:00:44.230
and kinda walk through there.

13
00:00:44.230 --> 00:00:47.130
So, Doctor Stern where do we start?

14
00:00:47.130 --> 00:00:50.210
Well, I have a slide about what
we're gonna do in the control phase.

15
00:00:50.210 --> 00:00:54.460
And I'd like to point out that
control is a lot like improve.

16
00:00:54.460 --> 00:00:56.060
It's not as long.

17
00:00:56.060 --> 00:00:59.080
It's only gonna take me
a short period of time

18
00:00:59.080 --> 00:01:03.530
to make sure that you
have the gist of control.

19
00:01:03.530 --> 00:01:06.770
But control, similar to improve,
is a map, and

20
00:01:06.770 --> 00:01:10.680
we have to do it in the correct order,
and the correct way.

21
00:01:10.680 --> 00:01:13.140
Not a lot of flexibility.

22
00:01:13.140 --> 00:01:17.870
>> Alright, so basically
>> We've implemented our improve,

23
00:01:17.870 --> 00:01:22.190
we know we've achieved what we want.

24
00:01:22.190 --> 00:01:26.310
And now, we have effectively like
a checklist that we run through, to-

25
00:01:26.310 --> 00:01:27.430
>> Kind of similar.

26
00:01:27.430 --> 00:01:29.580
One of the things that we
want to think about is,

27
00:01:29.580 --> 00:01:33.140
we might, when we get to control, we could
be almost finished or completely finished.

28
00:01:33.140 --> 00:01:36.910
But sometimes we still have other things
that we need to do in our project.

29
00:01:36.910 --> 00:01:40.800
So, the moment we notice that we have made
an improvement, it doesn't somehow we

30
00:01:40.800 --> 00:01:45.210
don't have to realize the entire
improvement, but the moment we know that

31
00:01:45.210 --> 00:01:49.190
we've made an improvement, that's when
we can move over to the control phase.

32
00:01:49.190 --> 00:01:53.310
The very first thing that happens is
that we have to articulate the benefit.

33
00:01:53.310 --> 00:01:57.240
What I mean by that is that
when we were in improve and

34
00:01:57.240 --> 00:02:00.740
we compared that after picture
to the before picture,

35
00:02:00.740 --> 00:02:05.480
we're going to have to tell
the person that we're working for.

36
00:02:05.480 --> 00:02:07.710
Why they care.
So, if we use a financial metric,

37
00:02:07.710 --> 00:02:08.970
it's sort of downhill.

38
00:02:08.970 --> 00:02:14.440
So, if I use return on
investment in measure,

39
00:02:14.440 --> 00:02:16.530
and then, and let's say in improve,

40
00:02:16.530 --> 00:02:21.740
I was able to show that we now have
a better return on investment, right?

41
00:02:21.740 --> 00:02:25.300
That's not as hard to
articulate at this point.

42
00:02:25.300 --> 00:02:28.100
However, if I said hey, we were
three-sigma when this happened, and

43
00:02:28.100 --> 00:02:31.810
now, I'm at the end of the improve,
and we're four More sigma, and

44
00:02:31.810 --> 00:02:33.790
that's an amazing improvement.

45
00:02:33.790 --> 00:02:38.380
I'm still going to have to say in dollars,
and

46
00:02:38.380 --> 00:02:41.710
cents what did I make you,
save you or avoid you spending.

47
00:02:41.710 --> 00:02:43.690
RIght?
Now, keep in mind the other

48
00:02:43.690 --> 00:02:47.500
challenge is that if I went after
the process to make it better then,

49
00:02:47.500 --> 00:02:48.970
that means that cost you money.

50
00:02:48.970 --> 00:02:51.100
So, when I'm in the control phase, and

51
00:02:51.100 --> 00:02:56.050
I'm explaining how much the improvement

now define's gonna be different because
I'm defining a different problem, but

272
00:16:34.954 --> 00:16:40.080
I can use it on a repetitive basis that
information, and measure, and analyze.

273
00:16:40.080 --> 00:16:43.940
In our control phase too it's always
kinda nice if you came up with some

274
00:16:43.940 --> 00:16:44.970
ancillary benefits.

275
00:16:44.970 --> 00:16:48.440
So, even though you did what
you said you were gonna do,

276
00:16:48.440 --> 00:16:53.730
and I think I mentioned this earlier
lean six sigma calls those delighters.

277
00:16:53.730 --> 00:16:55.390
I call them ancillary benefits so,

278
00:16:55.390 --> 00:17:00.280
when you get done telling the client all
the wonderful things that you've done for

279
00:17:00.280 --> 00:17:04.040
them you might wanna say here's
some byproducts of what I did.

280
00:17:04.040 --> 00:17:05.040
>> Yeah.

281
00:17:05.040 --> 00:17:08.280
There's a lot of times where we get
those kind of unseen benefits, and

282
00:17:08.280 --> 00:17:08.960
it's a nice thing.

283
00:17:08.960 --> 00:17:11.040
I mean the flip side of that
can be true too though.

284
00:17:11.040 --> 00:17:12.940
There could be some unseen
negative effects, but

285
00:17:12.940 --> 00:17:14.590
that's why we do our pilot programs,

286
00:17:14.590 --> 00:17:17.485
and other things to test that out before
we sign off on all this at the end.

287
00:17:17.485 --> 00:17:21.800
Alright, well, I know the control
phase is one of the shorter ones.

288
00:17:21.800 --> 00:17:23.460
I think we've done a pretty
good run through on it.

289
00:17:23.460 --> 00:17:25.590
Is there anything else
we need to add on that?

290
00:17:25.590 --> 00:17:28.830
>> You know, just to keep in mind that
when you're looking at the demaic

291
00:17:28.830 --> 00:17:30.500
model as a whole.

292
00:17:30.500 --> 00:17:34.190
Whole.
If you do everything you're supposed to

293
00:17:34.190 --> 00:17:38.110
do, and define, you're gonna have a good
idea of what you do to add measure.

294
00:17:38.110 --> 00:17:41.170
If you do measure correctly,
you're gonna know what to analyze, and

295
00:17:41.170 --> 00:17:45.810
if you analyze correctly you're gonna come
up with those three to five solutions,

296
00:17:45.810 --> 00:17:47.990
so just kind of trust the model.

297
00:17:47.990 --> 00:17:54.580
I use the model certainly when there's
a problem, and I don't know the solution.

298
00:17:54.580 --> 00:17:57.380
That's It's probably
the number one reason.

299
00:17:57.380 --> 00:17:59.020
But sometimes I still
go through the model.

300
00:17:59.020 --> 00:18:01.100
If I'm absolutely positive I
know the solution because that

301
00:18:01.100 --> 00:18:01.930
could be the a red flag too.

302
00:18:01.930 --> 00:18:02.530
>> Alright.
>> Well,

303
00:18:02.530 --> 00:18:06.710
that's a pretty good spot for
us to wrap this one up.

304
00:18:06.710 --> 00:18:09.190
We got to see the final
phase of the Demag model.

305
00:18:09.190 --> 00:18:13.620
We do still have a little more to cover
before we wrap up our whole yellow

306
00:18:13.620 --> 00:18:15.335
belt training shows.

307
00:18:15.335 --> 00:18:19.815
You should definitely stay tuned for
another episode coming up next, but for

308
00:18:19.815 --> 00:18:23.300
now heres a pretty good thought for
us to wrap up, so signing off for

309
00:18:23.300 --> 00:18:25.565
ITpro.tv I'm your host Dom Pizzette
>> And I'm Dr. Stern.

310
00:18:25.565 --> 00:18:30.734
>> And we'll see you,

311
00:18:30.734 --> 00:18:33.781
next time.

episodes.description: Buy-in is an important factor when trying to implement Lean Six Sigma into a prospective client. Viewers will hear discussions on ways one can achieve buy-in and top reasons why people sometimes have trouble with buy-in.
episodes.title: Achieving Buy-in
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.904
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.904 --> 00:00:11.948
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and

3
00:00:11.948 --> 00:00:17.245
good evening welcome back to
another episode of ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:17.245 --> 00:00:22.840
I'm your host Don Pezet back again with
another episode of Lean Six Sigma.

5
00:00:22.840 --> 00:00:25.180
And in this episode we're going
to be wrapping things up.

6
00:00:25.180 --> 00:00:27.340
We've moved through the DMAIC model,

7
00:00:27.340 --> 00:00:31.660
we've seen a lot of other components that
make up the Lean Six Sigma process and

8
00:00:31.660 --> 00:00:35.608
got a chance to see the methodology and
just tons of great information.

9
00:00:35.608 --> 00:00:39.034
Now what we want to do
is wrap all this up.

10
00:00:39.034 --> 00:00:43.898
A little bit of closure on buy in and
how you get your organization

11
00:00:43.898 --> 00:00:48.682
to adopt the processes and
really make the best use out of them.

12
00:00:48.682 --> 00:00:51.236
So, we got Dr. Stern back on
the show with us to jump in there.

13
00:00:51.236 --> 00:00:53.488
Dr. Stern,
where do we want to go with this?

14
00:00:53.488 --> 00:00:57.595
>> First, I want to say that
I would like to use this

15
00:00:57.595 --> 00:01:02.910
time to review the DMAIC
model in kind of a fun way.

16
00:01:02.910 --> 00:01:07.332
And what I mean by that is that I'm going
to show you ways that you can gain buy in,

17
00:01:07.332 --> 00:01:11.754
not just for your project, just anything
that you're looking for in life, but

18
00:01:11.754 --> 00:01:14.868
I'm going to use the DMAIC
principles to show you that.

19
00:01:14.868 --> 00:01:19.950
And I have a slide just to kind
of remind you of DMAIC terms.

20
00:01:21.070 --> 00:01:22.710
And here's the deal,

21
00:01:22.710 --> 00:01:28.460
there's a lot of different reasons why
people don't buy into our ideas or

22
00:01:28.460 --> 00:01:32.970
we get push back or people are reluctant
in a change management situation.

23
00:01:32.970 --> 00:01:37.640
Lots of different reasons, but the top
five reasons that people don't buy into

24
00:01:37.640 --> 00:01:44.290
our ideas or our projects or our thoughts
actually map directly to the DMAIC model.

25
00:01:44.290 --> 00:01:45.520
So for example,

26
00:01:45.520 --> 00:01:50.650
the number one reason people don't buy
into our ideas is something really simple.

27
00:01:50.650 --> 00:01:52.060
They don't understand it.

28
00:01:52.060 --> 00:01:53.689
They don't understand the idea.

29
00:01:53.689 --> 00:01:57.825
So in the defined portion
of the DMAIC methodology,

30
00:01:57.825 --> 00:02:04.080
there's all kinds of ways that we can
get people to buy into our project.

31
00:02:04.080 --> 00:02:06.150
A lot of tools that we could use.

32
00:02:06.150 --> 00:02:09.302
For example, if I feel I'm getting
some push back, the first thing

33
00:02:09.302 --> 00:02:12.697
I wanna think is that maybe they just
don't understand what I'm doing.

34
00:02:12.697 --> 00:02:16.136
And so one way I can solve that,
is to take a step back, and

35
00:02:16.136 --> 00:02:17.798
think about those voices.

36
00:02:17.798 --> 00:02:23.086
Think about looking through the lens of
the customer, the lens of the employee,

37
00:02:23.086 --> 00:02:28.009
the lens of the process, the lens of
the industry or the business, right?

38
00:02:28.009 --> 00:02:29.450
So that's one way.

39
00:02:29.450 --> 00:02:33.884
Sometimes putting a side pot together is
gonna give me some ideas on how to relate

40
00:02:33.884 --> 00:02:37.925
to people, how to explain it to
them in their particular language.

41
00:02:37.925 --> 00:02:41.555
Certainly the stakeholder's analysis,
we said that we

42
00:02:41.555 --> 00:02:45.475
expanded that to kinda say how do
people like to be communicated with.

43
00:02:45.475 --> 00:02:49.425
So let's say on our stakeholder analysis,
I've reported even on another project,

44
00:02:49.425 --> 00:02:50.715
that someone likes to be emailed or

45
00:02:50.715 --> 00:02:55.800
someone else wants me to verbally come and
talk to them.

46
00:02:55.800 --> 00:02:59.930
Sometimes the fact that I emailed someone
who would prefer verbal communication,

47
00:02:59.930 --> 00:03:01.000
they're just not listening.

48
00:03:01.000 --> 00:03:02.190
They don't understand.

49
00:03:02.190 --> 00:03:04.090
They don't get what I want to do.

50
00:03:04.090 --> 00:03:07.020
So, one of the biggest reasons
people don't buy into your

51
00:03:07.020 --> 00:03:09.460
idea is that they flat
don't understand the idea.

52
00:03:09.460 --> 00:03:14.180
The second biggest reason people
don't buy into our ideas, and

53
00:03:14.180 --> 00:03:17.820
you've probably heard this, they're trying
to fix something that's not broken.

54
00:03:17.820 --> 00:03:19.280
It's just not broken.

55
00:03:19.280 --> 00:03:24.334
So what's really kind of fun is that
the measure phase of the DMAIC model

56
00:03:24.334 --> 00:03:29.150
is teaching us how to give a clear
as is picture of where we are today.

57
00:03:29.150 --> 00:03:31.518
So sometimes people just don't believe us.

58
00:03:31.518 --> 00:03:35.553
When you're in the DMAIC model, sometimes
you get to the end of measure and

59
00:03:35.553 --> 00:03:38.830
you find out, you know what,
it's not really that bad.

60
00:03:38.830 --> 00:03:41.550
So what I'm gonna do is
I'm gonna go back up and

61
00:03:41.550 --> 00:03:43.780
pick a different process improvement.

62
00:03:43.780 --> 00:03:47.552
But generally speaking,
when we get to the end of Measure,

63
00:03:47.552 --> 00:03:52.229
we have a lot of proof, a lot of
documentation, that shows where we are and

64
00:03:52.229 --> 00:03:54.281
why we need to fix that problem.

65
00:03:54.281 --> 00:03:57.881
And so Measure is filled with
all kinds of ideas on charts and

66
00:03:57.881 --> 00:04:01.697
graphs that you can use,
that you can also use and analyze, but

67
00:04:01.697 --> 00:04:05.892
some of the analyze tools that we
looked at, you can use and measure.

68
00:04:05.892 --> 00:04:10.235
So, if you think people are having
a problem understanding that something's

69
00:04:10.235 --> 00:04:14.509
broken, you might use something simple
like a Prado chart, that says look,

70
00:04:14.509 --> 00:04:18.625
here's the biggest problem that we have,
and here's the next biggest.

71
00:04:18.625 --> 00:04:20.385
And sometimes people see it visually,

72
00:04:20.385 --> 00:04:23.598
they get over that you're trying to
fix something that's not broken.

73
00:04:23.598 --> 00:04:28.430
Now, it's interesting,
the number three reason people have

74
00:04:28.430 --> 00:04:33.580
trouble with buy-in,
is that they don't understand our logic.

75
00:04:33.580 --> 00:04:36.130
Actually, you have the buy-in as far
as they think it's a real problem, and

76
00:04:36.130 --> 00:04:38.870
they know it's broken.

77
00:04:38.870 --> 00:04:41.801
But they just can't figure out
why you made that decision.

78
00:04:41.801 --> 00:04:47.270
Why did you go with that one
instead of this other decision?

79
00:04:47.270 --> 00:04:50.230
And that's why in Analyze,
when you're analyzing and

80
00:04:50.230 --> 00:04:53.940
thinking about your solutions,
if someone's made a suggestion to you.

81
00:04:53.940 --> 00:04:57.478
You definitely wanna take the time,
even if you think it's the silliest thing

82
00:04:57.478 --> 00:04:59.958
you've ever heard, and
kind of reason through that.

83
00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:04.231
Because when you get to improve,
if someone says, well I'm surprised that

84
00:05:04.231 --> 00:05:08.904
didn't make the list, you're going to be
able to have solid information on why you

85
00:05:08.904 --> 00:05:14.130
made the decision that you did, and why
you may have discounted that situation.

86
00:05:14.130 --> 00:05:17.602
So in Analyze, analyze is all about
thinking through our logic and

87
00:05:17.602 --> 00:05:21.825
getting our story right, so that we can
get to the right three to five solutions.

88
00:05:21.825 --> 00:05:25.213
So again, someone might even believe
it's a problem and say, wow,

89
00:05:25.213 --> 00:05:26.510
this is really messed up.

90
00:05:26.510 --> 00:05:30.802
And where you might lose their buy-in is
that they're just thinking you should have

91
00:05:30.802 --> 00:05:32.077
done it a different way.

92
00:05:32.077 --> 00:05:35.890
The number four reason that people
don't buy into our solutions,

93
00:05:35.890 --> 00:05:38.352
is they don't believe they have a choice.

94
00:05:38.352 --> 00:05:42.996
So, people don't like it when we
say it's my way or the highway.

95
00:05:42.996 --> 00:05:48.871
In Improve, it tells us how to
present those three to five solutions.

96
00:05:48.871 --> 00:05:53.230
How to gain consensus, how to get
that passed on to that person, like,

97
00:05:53.230 --> 00:05:56.438
here are the three or
five things that I came up with.

98
00:05:56.438 --> 00:05:57.819
What do you think?

99
00:05:57.819 --> 00:06:02.272
Because even when, and there are some
times that you're shooting for three

100
00:06:02.272 --> 00:06:07.630
to five solutions, but there are times
where you only come up with two solutions.

101
00:06:07.630 --> 00:06:09.630
Well, it's best to take
those two solutions and

102
00:06:09.630 --> 00:06:11.090
unless they're mutually exclusive,

103
00:06:11.090 --> 00:06:15.250
create a third decision by saying,
or we could do both of those things.

104
00:06:15.250 --> 00:06:19.550
So coming up with three isn't
really as difficult as it sounds.

105
00:06:19.550 --> 00:06:22.080
Now, there are times, however,

106
00:06:22.080 --> 00:06:27.940
where there really is only one solution
because it's a compliance-related thing.

107
00:06:27.940 --> 00:06:30.781
You still want to try to come
up with other things to say,

108
00:06:30.781 --> 00:06:34.362
because people don't like to be told
there's only one way to do this.

109
00:06:34.362 --> 00:06:39.327
We used to get something, well, we still
do it, we just do it computerized now.

110
00:06:39.327 --> 00:06:42.597
In our master black belt class,
we do a disk profile,

111
00:06:42.597 --> 00:06:46.980
which is similar to Myers-Briggs,
it's just not as exclusive.

112
00:06:46.980 --> 00:06:50.580
In the old days,
this particular profile that helped you

113
00:06:50.580 --> 00:06:54.880
understand your personality,
was a manual form that could only be,

114
00:06:54.880 --> 00:06:58.670
you could only use a dime to
scrape off these bubbles.

115
00:06:58.670 --> 00:07:01.660
And the manufacturer told you be
sure to take a bunch of dimes so

116
00:07:01.660 --> 00:07:03.070
you can scrape this off.

117
00:07:03.070 --> 00:07:05.089
Well, I gave it to a group
of engineers once, and

118
00:07:05.089 --> 00:07:07.275
they had about an hour to
take this particular test.

119
00:07:07.275 --> 00:07:10.767
Most of them spent their entire
hour trying to figure out

120
00:07:10.767 --> 00:07:15.020
if there was something else other
than the dime to scratch this off.

121
00:07:15.020 --> 00:07:17.930
So they tried staples and paperclips.

122
00:07:17.930 --> 00:07:21.700
So we're that married to the idea that
when someone tells us there's only one way

123
00:07:21.700 --> 00:07:26.290
to do things, something psychological
happens in our brains where we go,

124
00:07:26.290 --> 00:07:29.004
I bet there's some other way to do that,
right?

125
00:07:29.004 --> 00:07:33.570
So, finally of the top reasons,
and like I said, there's many, but

126
00:07:33.570 --> 00:07:37.880
of the top five reasons,
the number five reason, the fifth reason

127
00:07:37.880 --> 00:07:42.340
is that people think it, why bother?

128
00:07:42.340 --> 00:07:45.300
It's just gonna go back
to the way it was before.

129
00:07:45.300 --> 00:07:48.255
And control is all about
explaining your sustainability.

130
00:07:48.255 --> 00:07:53.130
And I'm sure you've heard
this many times as well.

131
00:07:53.130 --> 00:07:55.927
I would go ahead and do the effort, but

132
00:07:55.927 --> 00:07:59.960
on Monday it's just gonna
go back to the same, right?

133
00:07:59.960 --> 00:08:04.190
And sometimes our kids say why bother
cleaning the room, or the dishes,

134
00:08:04.190 --> 00:08:07.030
they're just gonna be dirty tomorrow,
right?

135
00:08:07.030 --> 00:08:11.144
So the fifth reason of the popular reasons
people don't buy into things is that they

136
00:08:11.144 --> 00:08:12.988
don't believe it's sustainable.

137
00:08:12.988 --> 00:08:16.830
They think it's just gonna go back,
why bother putting in the effort.

138
00:08:16.830 --> 00:08:20.410
And so in each phase of the debate model,
there are tools.

139
00:08:20.410 --> 00:08:23.740
There's tools in Define
to help you understand or

140
00:08:23.740 --> 00:08:27.258
get people to understand what it
is that you're trying to explain.

141
00:08:27.258 --> 00:08:31.890
There's tools in Measure that
help you show people the true,

142
00:08:31.890 --> 00:08:33.040
clear as this picture.

143
00:08:33.040 --> 00:08:38.473
There are tools in Analyze that
are gonna help you explain your logic.

144
00:08:38.473 --> 00:08:41.530
There's tools in Improve
that are gonna show you how

145
00:08:41.530 --> 00:08:45.350
to present the three to five solutions and
how to get consensus and

146
00:08:45.350 --> 00:08:50.180
explain to people, make them feel
like they really do have the choice.

147
00:08:50.180 --> 00:08:53.120
And finally there's all kinds of tools
that control if you think you're

148
00:08:53.120 --> 00:08:56.140
running up against kind
of a lack of motivation.

149
00:08:56.140 --> 00:09:00.100
So when you're listening to people, and
they're not buying into your ideas,

150
00:09:00.100 --> 00:09:02.390
if you can kind of identify which area,

151
00:09:02.390 --> 00:09:06.680
you have the automatic tools
to cover those top five.

152
00:09:06.680 --> 00:09:09.540
>> And it's kind of funny because
after you've gotten your first two or

153
00:09:09.540 --> 00:09:14.340
three process improvement projects under
your belt, the buy-in becomes easy, right?

154
00:09:14.340 --> 00:09:17.266
They say well you've saved us money or
helped us avoid spending money or

155
00:09:17.266 --> 00:09:18.204
whatever in the past.

156
00:09:18.204 --> 00:09:20.966
We know you're gonna do it again,
it's easy.

157
00:09:20.966 --> 00:09:23.578
So it's really just the first
couple of times that you do this.

158
00:09:23.578 --> 00:09:28.016
And it's really, one of the parts I like
the most about Lean Six Sigma is that you

159
00:09:28.016 --> 00:09:32.673
can adopt it just yourself, and you don't
have to have the whole company adopt it.

160
00:09:32.673 --> 00:09:35.713
And you can start implementing it
even if you don't have that buy-in.

161
00:09:35.713 --> 00:09:39.551
And as soon as people start seeing those
results they will say, how do you do that?

162
00:09:39.551 --> 00:09:40.758
How did you achieve that result?

163
00:09:40.758 --> 00:09:44.856
And you say well, I'm actually
applying this methodology, and

164
00:09:44.856 --> 00:09:47.997
we should consider getting
everybody to do that.

165
00:09:47.997 --> 00:09:49.866
It kind of just falls all into place.

166
00:09:49.866 --> 00:09:50.411
>> Right.

167
00:09:50.411 --> 00:09:54.699
And probably the final thing that you
wanna remember about the DMAIC model is

168
00:09:54.699 --> 00:09:58.480
that there are a lot of companies
now that formally use this model.

169
00:09:58.480 --> 00:10:02.860
But there's also a lot of people that just
want you to come into that department and

170
00:10:02.860 --> 00:10:03.823
fix the problem.

171
00:10:03.823 --> 00:10:07.140
And they may not be as
excited about the model.

172
00:10:07.140 --> 00:10:11.396
The model is really your map to
keep your thoughts organized and

173
00:10:11.396 --> 00:10:14.150
to easily go from one phase to another.

174
00:10:14.150 --> 00:10:18.162
>> Excellent, well I think once companies
have recognized the benefit of this,

175
00:10:18.162 --> 00:10:21.748
they've recognized you get that buy
in after that you move forward and

176
00:10:21.748 --> 00:10:23.604
you're Lean Six Sigma all the way.

177
00:10:23.604 --> 00:10:27.168
And then things continue to work
the way they're supposed to.

178
00:10:27.168 --> 00:10:30.662
We continually improve as we make
our systems better and better.

179
00:10:30.662 --> 00:10:31.985
All right, well.

180
00:10:31.985 --> 00:10:33.623
We've had quite a long run.

181
00:10:33.623 --> 00:10:37.288
We went through a lot of different topics,
and a lot of different forms, and

182
00:10:37.288 --> 00:10:40.053
the DMAIC model, the PVCA and
all those other good ones.

183
00:10:40.053 --> 00:10:42.187
It's all a part of Lean Six Sigma.

184
00:10:42.187 --> 00:10:45.056
I think that we've pretty
much moved through it all.

185
00:10:45.056 --> 00:10:46.727
Are there any other concepts
that we need to hit on?

186
00:10:46.727 --> 00:10:48.526
>> I don't think so.

187
00:10:48.526 --> 00:10:51.551
>> [LAUGH]
>> I think we've really just done a great

188
00:10:51.551 --> 00:10:55.420
job on quickly giving the gist of
what Lean Six Sigma's all about.

189
00:10:55.420 --> 00:10:56.570
>> Excellent.
Well I

190
00:10:56.570 --> 00:10:57.860
know I've enjoyed the process myself.

191
00:10:57.860 --> 00:11:01.299
It's a lot to take in, and this is
really just the introduction, right?

192
00:11:01.299 --> 00:11:02.482
The yellow belt.

193
00:11:02.482 --> 00:11:02.993
>> Exactly.

194
00:11:02.993 --> 00:11:03.740
>> We've got more to go beyond that.

195
00:11:03.740 --> 00:11:06.190
If you move into green belt and
higher, but

196
00:11:06.190 --> 00:11:10.750
for now this is a pretty good spot for
us to wrap this series up.

197
00:11:10.750 --> 00:11:13.770
So I really hope you all enjoyed it out
there as much as we enjoyed filming it.

198
00:11:14.780 --> 00:11:16.470
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

199
00:11:16.470 --> 00:11:18.327
>> And I'm Dr. Stern.

200
00:11:18.327 --> 00:11:19.417
>> And we'll see you next time.

201
00:11:19.417 --> 00:11:26.929
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Once one has completed their training for the Yellow Belt certification, one must take the exam to achieve the certification. Viewers will also hear about the details involved with the exam and other processes in moving forward towards achieving the further Green Belt, Black Belt, and Master Black Belt certifications in Lean Six Sigma.  Learn more about Dr. Terra Stern and Lean Six Sigma by visiting her site www.SSDGlobal.net.
episodes.title: Next Step
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.130
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.913 --> 00:00:13.490
In this video we're gonna take a look at
the next steps after completing the lean

3
00:00:13.490 --> 00:00:16.810
six sigma yellow belt
of course on our site.

4
00:00:16.810 --> 00:00:19.340
Now for a lot of you guys, you've watched
the whole series from beginning to end.

5
00:00:19.340 --> 00:00:21.668
We've covered a bunch of great content.

6
00:00:21.668 --> 00:00:25.650
A lot of methodologies and models and
forms and tools and techniques.

7
00:00:25.650 --> 00:00:26.816
All sorts of craziness and

8
00:00:26.816 --> 00:00:29.390
now you're probably wondering
where do I go from here.

9
00:00:29.390 --> 00:00:31.792
Right?
What's my next step once I've watched

10
00:00:31.792 --> 00:00:35.451
the series and I've been turning
loose on the wild so, I brought Dr.

11
00:00:35.451 --> 00:00:39.575
Stern back into the studio so we can kind
of talk about that and see where to go.

12
00:00:39.575 --> 00:00:40.755
Dr. Stirling, what do you say?

13
00:00:40.755 --> 00:00:44.701
After somebody's watched the series,
what are our next moves from there.

14
00:00:44.701 --> 00:00:47.557
>> Okay.
Well, it depends on your goal and

15
00:00:47.557 --> 00:00:50.373
if your goal is to get certified.

16
00:00:50.373 --> 00:00:57.843
The fastest way to do that is to go to
my website, which is ssbglobal.net and

17
00:00:57.843 --> 00:01:02.863
there you'll see instructions
on how to sign up for

18
00:01:02.863 --> 00:01:06.505
the Lean Six Sigma yellow belt exam.

19
00:01:06.505 --> 00:01:11.817
Now one of the criteria to sit through
that exam is that you've had a certain

20
00:01:11.817 --> 00:01:17.906
amount of training in yellow belt, which
you have because you watched these series.

21
00:01:17.906 --> 00:01:22.040
It's probably gonna ask you a couple
questions about those types of things.

22
00:01:22.040 --> 00:01:24.338
The exam has 100 questions on it.

23
00:01:24.338 --> 00:01:25.429
It is timed.

24
00:01:25.429 --> 00:01:29.540
It's a nominal fee of $40 but
it also includes a study guide and

25
00:01:29.540 --> 00:01:32.246
a cheat sheet, [LAUGH] that's hard to say.

26
00:01:32.246 --> 00:01:36.610
>> [LAUGH]
>> The questions are multiple choice.

27
00:01:36.610 --> 00:01:37.750
It's not meant to trick you.

28
00:01:37.750 --> 00:01:38.790
Do you have to study?

29
00:01:38.790 --> 00:01:41.470
Absolutely, just like you
would with any exam but

30
00:01:41.470 --> 00:01:44.840
I think the study guide
that we give you and

31
00:01:44.840 --> 00:01:51.010
the cheat sheet that we give you, gives
you enough information to pass the test.

32
00:01:51.010 --> 00:01:53.705
>> Yeah, and that's really important
cuz you said it's an open book but for

33
00:01:53.705 --> 00:01:55.499
a lot of our viewers,
they just watch this show.

34
00:01:55.499 --> 00:01:56.463
>> Exactly.

35
00:01:56.463 --> 00:01:57.113
>> So, is it an open show?

36
00:01:57.113 --> 00:02:00.235
Well, it would take you a long time
to search for information that way.

37
00:02:00.235 --> 00:02:02.453
So, the study guide, you can download.

38
00:02:02.453 --> 00:02:04.508
When you sign up, you'll pay the $40.

39
00:02:04.508 --> 00:02:06.790
You immediately get that guide,
and it's available to you.

40
00:02:06.790 --> 00:02:10.110
So, you can jump right in and start
studying and then you take the exam and

41
00:02:10.110 --> 00:02:13.560
you have that study guide you can flip
through and the cheat sheet, right?

42
00:02:13.560 --> 00:02:14.604
>> Right.
>> Which is hard to say.

43
00:02:14.604 --> 00:02:16.011
[LAUGH]
>> Right, and

44
00:02:16.011 --> 00:02:20.397
then in the test itself there
are a lot of different questions so

45
00:02:20.397 --> 00:02:25.281
you never know which questions you're
going to get in your hundred but

46
00:02:25.281 --> 00:02:29.831
one of the things it's gonna ask
you is where do you get your formal

47
00:02:29.831 --> 00:02:35.424
Lean Six Sigma training, so you just wanna
pick the bubble that you got it here.

48
00:02:35.424 --> 00:02:37.096
So, that covers you there.

49
00:02:37.096 --> 00:02:41.479
If you pass the test with a 75% or
more, we contact you and

50
00:02:41.479 --> 00:02:46.770
get your information, if you want
a hard copy of your certificate.

51
00:02:46.770 --> 00:02:50.570
You can always of course get a soft
copy but if you want one of our nice,

52
00:02:50.570 --> 00:02:53.440
pretty copies with the seal,
we'll be contacting you for

53
00:02:53.440 --> 00:02:56.850
your address and letting you know
that that certificate is coming.

54
00:02:56.850 --> 00:02:59.000
That certificate comes
with a certificate number.

55
00:02:59.000 --> 00:03:01.620
So, you actually can
use it as a reference,

56
00:03:01.620 --> 00:03:03.800
if you wanna put it on your resume.

57
00:03:03.800 --> 00:03:07.730
I may have mentioned in some of the other
episodes that we do have some companies

58
00:03:07.730 --> 00:03:13.170
that I work with, that you have to be a
Yellow Belt to actually be considered for

59
00:03:13.170 --> 00:03:15.930
a position or for a promotion,
so that's kind of interesting.

60
00:03:15.930 --> 00:03:20.580
>> All right so, let's say I'm go getter,
I'm fully bought

61
00:03:20.580 --> 00:03:25.370
into the Lean Six Sigma world and I hit
my Yellow Belt Certification and now.

62
00:03:25.370 --> 00:03:26.809
I want to progress further.

63
00:03:26.809 --> 00:03:28.277
I want to move on to one
of the specialties and

64
00:03:28.277 --> 00:03:29.281
the more advance trainings.

65
00:03:29.281 --> 00:03:32.637
I know the green belt it the next step up.

66
00:03:32.637 --> 00:03:33.681
What's involved in that?

67
00:03:33.681 --> 00:03:35.544
What's the process
pertaining to green belt?

68
00:03:35.544 --> 00:03:36.056
>> Okay.

69
00:03:36.056 --> 00:03:40.350
Well, step number one is that
you want to have a yellow belt.

70
00:03:40.350 --> 00:03:42.940
I did mention that if you pass
a test with 75 percent or

71
00:03:42.940 --> 00:03:45.580
more you would have the yellow belt now.

72
00:03:45.580 --> 00:03:48.466
If for some reason you didn't pass that,

73
00:03:48.466 --> 00:03:53.500
you're able to take that test again
at no charge in one week increments.

74
00:03:53.500 --> 00:03:58.661
So, we want to give you a week to study.

75
00:03:58.661 --> 00:03:59.161
When you download the test a second
time it's gonna be a different set of

76
00:03:59.161 --> 00:04:00.035
questions.
Same topic but

77
00:04:00.035 --> 00:04:02.383
it's not gonna be the same test.
So,

78
00:04:02.383 --> 00:04:06.790
let's say you have your
yellow belt in hand

79
00:04:08.180 --> 00:04:13.010
then our company offers green belt, black
belt, and master black belt training.

80
00:04:13.010 --> 00:04:17.040
If you've got an awful lot of
experience in process improvement and

81
00:04:17.040 --> 00:04:19.620
just didn't realize it until you
watched this video and said wow,

82
00:04:19.620 --> 00:04:21.320
I've done this all of my life.

83
00:04:21.320 --> 00:04:25.895
You could be a candidate for our green
belt-black belt combo workshop and

84
00:04:25.895 --> 00:04:29.217
that usually requires you
submitting your resume but

85
00:04:29.217 --> 00:04:32.534
typically if you just want to sign up for
a green belt,

86
00:04:32.534 --> 00:04:36.702
which would be the typical next step,
we do offer classes in that.

87
00:04:36.702 --> 00:04:41.479
You just go to our website at SSBGlobal
and we have, sort of, all the endings.

88
00:04:41.479 --> 00:04:46.240
If you type in SSBGlobal into
your in your web browser,

89
00:04:46.240 --> 00:04:51.810
you're gonna end up at our
site eventually, right?

90
00:04:51.810 --> 00:04:57.930
The process for the green belt is that
our program is a three phase program and

91
00:04:57.930 --> 00:05:01.820
different vendors teach it a different
way, but the important thing if you decide

92
00:05:01.820 --> 00:05:07.050
to go to another vendor is we're all
working from the same play book.

93
00:05:07.050 --> 00:05:09.590
We're all using material
from ASQ about Six Sigma.

94
00:05:10.590 --> 00:05:13.950
Frome SME's,
Society of Mechanical Engineer's on Lean.

95
00:05:13.950 --> 00:05:17.550
We've blended that together because when
you take the two different methodology,

96
00:05:17.550 --> 00:05:20.070
Lean and Six Sigma.

97
00:05:20.070 --> 00:05:23.360
They're synergies but
there are some things that are left out.

98
00:05:23.360 --> 00:05:25.020
There's some things that are simplified.

99
00:05:25.020 --> 00:05:26.880
There's an emphasis in a different way.

100
00:05:26.880 --> 00:05:31.480
Lean six sigma really is a whole separate
body of knowledge from six sigma and lean.

101
00:05:31.480 --> 00:05:34.190
It has a lot of continuity.

102
00:05:34.190 --> 00:05:38.470
So, all vendors are working
essentially from that playbook.

103
00:05:38.470 --> 00:05:42.550
The way we structure the class
is that it's in three phases and

104
00:05:42.550 --> 00:05:48.920
phase one can be a live classroom or
online live opportunity and

105
00:05:48.920 --> 00:05:54.193
that's usually three days and
then the second

106
00:05:54.193 --> 00:05:59.070
phase you're given a series
of homework assignments and

107
00:05:59.070 --> 00:06:03.180
exercises to complete, and that goes back
to sort of like traditional education.

108
00:06:03.180 --> 00:06:08.390
So, you're reading a textbook but we've
summarized the textbook in a way that

109
00:06:08.390 --> 00:06:12.230
makes it simple to understand and there's
questions that you have to answer and

110
00:06:12.230 --> 00:06:16.070
turn in, and then our instructors look to
make sure that you're on the right track.

111
00:06:16.070 --> 00:06:19.370
Once you've completed those assignments
and generally there's five assignments.

112
00:06:19.370 --> 00:06:22.300
If everything's going well you
only have five assignments.

113
00:06:22.300 --> 00:06:26.276
If we kinda think you're veering off in
another direction you might end up with

114
00:06:26.276 --> 00:06:28.094
another online assignment or two.

115
00:06:28.094 --> 00:06:32.994
Once we feel comfortable with that
material and we're in constant

116
00:06:32.994 --> 00:06:38.254
contact with you online, then we set
you up for another open book test.

117
00:06:38.254 --> 00:06:40.042
Now this one is a little more complicated.

118
00:06:40.042 --> 00:06:41.713
It's a three hour test.

119
00:06:41.713 --> 00:06:46.635
It has a lot more questions but again it's
open book and as long as you pass that

120
00:06:46.635 --> 00:06:52.260
test with a 75% or more you go on to
the final phase, which is phase three.

121
00:06:52.260 --> 00:06:54.600
Now in phase three,
you're assigned a mentor.

122
00:06:54.600 --> 00:06:56.610
An actual mentor that works with you.

123
00:06:56.610 --> 00:07:00.280
We try as much as possible to find a
mentor that's in your industry, if that's

124
00:07:00.280 --> 00:07:05.480
the industry you want to stay in so
they can relate a little better with you.

125
00:07:05.480 --> 00:07:08.560
You fill out a project charter and

126
00:07:08.560 --> 00:07:11.100
when you fill out that project
charter your instructor says, yes,

127
00:07:11.100 --> 00:07:15.540
I think this is a great lean sig sigma
project or no and here's the reason why.

128
00:07:15.540 --> 00:07:19.890
Once your project charter's accepted then
to shop the project, you just submit

129
00:07:19.890 --> 00:07:25.000
a lean sig sigma report but what's kinda
nice about it is that you have a mentor

130
00:07:25.000 --> 00:07:29.280
right there and if you want to send them
the divine portion of your report and

131
00:07:29.280 --> 00:07:32.650
get some feedback before
you go on to measure.

132
00:07:32.650 --> 00:07:34.180
You can do it that way.

133
00:07:34.180 --> 00:07:36.210
If you have a lot of experience
with the demat model or

134
00:07:36.210 --> 00:07:40.090
you just sort of get it intuitively,
you could actually submit your

135
00:07:40.090 --> 00:07:43.360
entire project and
then when that project is submitted,

136
00:07:43.360 --> 00:07:48.510
your instructor goes through and
makes sure it's perfect and

137
00:07:48.510 --> 00:07:53.680
then they submit it to a committee and
the committee has four PhDs.

138
00:07:53.680 --> 00:07:57.980
And they can't be your primary
instructor or your secondary instructor,

139
00:07:57.980 --> 00:08:00.650
which is the one that
helped you in phase three.

140
00:08:00.650 --> 00:08:05.323
So, it's four independent eyes that
look at this Project and they say yay or

141
00:08:05.323 --> 00:08:08.536
nay but usually by the time
it gets to the committee,

142
00:08:08.536 --> 00:08:12.644
you're gonna get feedback like
that chart should go on page nine.

143
00:08:12.644 --> 00:08:16.731
I mean the instructors don't wanna
send stuff off to the committee that

144
00:08:16.731 --> 00:08:17.556
isn't well.

145
00:08:17.556 --> 00:08:20.436
So, once your project's
approved it's the same thing.

146
00:08:20.436 --> 00:08:25.413
You get contacted because on our database
we typically just have your email

147
00:08:25.413 --> 00:08:30.311
address and your phone number so you
get contacted to make sure that we have

148
00:08:30.311 --> 00:08:35.050
your name correct and you get a number
that's listed in our database.

149
00:08:35.050 --> 00:08:37.550
So, you can use this as a reference
if somebody is trying to verify that

150
00:08:37.550 --> 00:08:39.000
you have a project.

151
00:08:39.000 --> 00:08:42.520
Your mentor, a lot of times,
you can use as your personal

152
00:08:42.520 --> 00:08:46.410
reference because they have actually
worked with you on the project.

153
00:08:46.410 --> 00:08:50.680
So, the system from there,
you just keep wanting to go on.

154
00:08:50.680 --> 00:08:53.120
When you repeat that in black belt and
master black belt,

155
00:08:53.120 --> 00:08:56.100
should you decide to keep going further.

156
00:08:56.100 --> 00:09:01.250
We generally say you want to stay in that
green belt role for a year or two and do

157
00:09:01.250 --> 00:09:06.590
some projects before you move on to black
belt but if you move onto the blackbelt.

158
00:09:06.590 --> 00:09:07.800
Or master blackbelt,

159
00:09:07.800 --> 00:09:12.890
those follow a similar model except that
you're in class online or in person for

160
00:09:12.890 --> 00:09:19.120
five days but they have a phase
two where you have assignments.

161
00:09:19.120 --> 00:09:23.650
They're more aggressive assignments and
then in phase two in the blackbelt class,

162
00:09:23.650 --> 00:09:27.080
you're responsible for
two lean six sigma projects.

163
00:09:27.080 --> 00:09:31.390
If you've been in our program and
you've done a really good job

164
00:09:31.390 --> 00:09:35.510
on your greenbelt project, we will accept
that as one of your blackbelt projects.

165
00:09:35.510 --> 00:09:40.700
If that's something that you're thinking
you're wanting to do down the line,

166
00:09:40.700 --> 00:09:43.990
you just need to make sure that
your mentor knows that you

167
00:09:43.990 --> 00:09:47.920
want to do a blackbelt level project first
and so you kinda get that pre-approved.

168
00:09:47.920 --> 00:09:52.740
And in the master black belt program
there's a phase one five days,

169
00:09:52.740 --> 00:09:56.270
a phase two which a lot of assignments,
and phase three is a little bit different.

170
00:09:56.270 --> 00:10:00.932
In that particular program you're
not doing a lot of projects because

171
00:10:00.932 --> 00:10:04.329
you've already proven that
you can do projects and

172
00:10:04.329 --> 00:10:08.833
it's more about going on site and
helping our instructors teach and

173
00:10:08.833 --> 00:10:13.437
designing classes and we put you
into some coaching type scenarios.

174
00:10:13.437 --> 00:10:17.991
So, I don't know if I explained all that
and all that information is on the website

175
00:10:17.991 --> 00:10:20.507
with the outlines and
those types of things.

176
00:10:20.507 --> 00:10:25.077
I do want to take a quick moment to
explain that when you do a lean sigma

177
00:10:25.077 --> 00:10:27.654
green belt internal certification.

178
00:10:27.654 --> 00:10:31.762
So, a lot of many companies will
hire a master black belt and

179
00:10:31.762 --> 00:10:36.196
a lot of people who are in our black
belt program are there because

180
00:10:36.196 --> 00:10:40.606
their company decided they want
to build an internal program.

181
00:10:40.606 --> 00:10:48.820
When you are doing the internal program,
for the company it's a really great deal.

182
00:10:48.820 --> 00:10:52.390
For the employee it's better to
come to an outside company to do

183
00:10:52.390 --> 00:10:57.310
that because the assumption is if you take
an internal program you might have just

184
00:10:57.310 --> 00:11:00.540
concentrated on manufacturing or
retail or hospitality.

185
00:11:00.540 --> 00:11:06.150
So, it's always really better for the
student to get an outside certificate but

186
00:11:06.150 --> 00:11:10.280
it's a really pretty good deal for
a company to bring on a master black belt.

187
00:11:10.280 --> 00:11:13.986
When you take an internal program,
which is what I started to say,

188
00:11:13.986 --> 00:11:15.984
it works a little bit differently.

189
00:11:15.984 --> 00:11:20.898
Typically, internal programs call
the training waves and there will be three

190
00:11:20.898 --> 00:11:25.439
waves of training and in the first wave,
you're with the instructor for

191
00:11:25.439 --> 00:11:29.844
five days and then you go back into
the field and try to use those tools.

192
00:11:29.844 --> 00:11:32.899
Second wave, you're with
the instructor for another week.

193
00:11:32.899 --> 00:11:37.370
Third week, you're with the instructor and
the instructor or the black belt or

194
00:11:37.370 --> 00:11:39.981
master black belt assigns
you a project to do.

195
00:11:39.981 --> 00:11:42.154
So, but
you're still covering the same material.

196
00:11:42.154 --> 00:11:47.670
So, sometimes, and the reason why
I'm mentioning this is because

197
00:11:47.670 --> 00:11:52.840
ours is an accelerated program even though
we cover everything everyone else does.

198
00:11:52.840 --> 00:11:56.262
Sometimes you'll hear people that
will tell you, it took me a year or

199
00:11:56.262 --> 00:11:57.796
two years to get my green belt.

200
00:11:57.796 --> 00:12:02.037
Well, a lot of times the reason is because
these waves, the second wave will come up

201
00:12:02.037 --> 00:12:05.326
and all of a sudden your boss can't
let you go for a week, right?

202
